column1: How Much Will Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Fall If the iPhone 8 Flops?;3/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCalling a spade a spade
column3: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is the most recognizable names in the world. By extension
column4: AAPL stock remains one of the market's most sought-after picks.makeArticleAd();Source:iphonedigital via FlickrBoth platitudes are well deserved. The company has earned its way to the top
column5: making a piece of hardware - the iPhone - not only a technical marvel
column6: but a status symbol and lifestyle centerpiece like no other. The device keeps millions of consumers ranging from tweens to geriatrics with their noses buried in their smartphones in all four corners of the earth.Nevertheless …While Apple has been largely deserving of its spot on so many investors' pedestals
column7: that sort of collective homage is always dangerous. Nothing lasts forever
column8: and as unpopular as the premise may be
column9: it would be wise to at least entertain the possibility that the next-generation iPhone (referred to the iPhone 8 so far) could the unveiling that starts exposing Apple's cracks.iPhone 8 Flop? Never!Before you pull out your pitchfork
column10: start heating up the tar and gather your feathers
column11: dial it back just a bit. This isn't to say that even a mediocre Apple still isn't better than most any other stock on the planet.10 Safe Dividend Stocks to Own During the Next Market CrashStill
column12: there are three key reasons the iPhone 8 could end up not beingthe panaceait has been made out to be. Yes
column13: they're rather obvious
column14: but concerns all the same:1. People Really Are Growing Tired of the Constant ConnectivityIt was fun for a few years
column15: but some smartphone owners - an increasing number of them - are starting to realize their unhealthy addiction to their devices. A survey performed last year indicated that42% of Americansconstantly check their phones for new messages. It's a statistic being noticed by impartial observes like CTV technology analyst Carmi Levy.Levy commentedlast year:""The promise of technology is that it'll improve our lives
column16: but sometimes we become enslaved to the technology because there's so much going on. A certain part of our brain is always looking for something that is perhaps simpler … and delivers as promised with fewer frustrations.""Enough consumers are starting to move the notion out of their subconscious into their conscious.2. $1
column17: 000 for a Phone? Really?Yep
column18: somebody out there won't think twice about paying it. A lot of people won't think twice about paying it. For a wide swath of iPhone fans who will sooner or later realize that's more than one month's rent or mortgage payment
column19: though
column20: they're due a ""get real"" moment.3. Strong CompetitionFor the longest time
column21: Apple had little to no competition. That's changing though. Yes
column22: the exploding battery debacleSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) faced with its Galaxy 7 phones was damning
column23: and it's not like the Google Pixel fromAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column24: NASDAQ:GOOGL)was a smashing successthat threatened Apple either.Both companies are still overhauling their hardware and improving their designs though
column25: and consumers are taking notice
column26: for about a third to half the cost of an iPhone.Potential Impact on AAPL StockAs for the impact a lackluster iPhone 8 response might have on AAPL stock
column27: one can only guess. But
column28: one can still make an educated guess.For its most recently completed quarter
column29: Applesold 78.29 million iPhones
column30: generating $54.38 billion worth of revenue. That's not necessarily a full picture of the then-new iPhone 7's success
column31: however. The device was actually unveiled a few days prior to the beginning of the quarter
column32: and saw tremendous sales immediately after its launch. For the iPhone 7's inaugural quarter
column33: the company producediPhone revenue of $28.16 billion
column34: selling 45.51 million units. Between both quarters
column35: the bulk of the iPhones sold were the 7 model.It was record-breaking success
column36: by the way
column37: with the78.29 million iPhones sold last quarteredging out sales of the second edition of the iPhone 6 in the comparable quarter a year earlier. The average selling price for the most recent quarter comes out to $695 apiece.That price tag does present something of a quandary for any estimates regarding the impending success of the iPhone 8. It could sell 30% fewer phones
column38: but inasmuch as the cost of the 8 is more than 40% greater than the 7
column39: Apple could conceivably do just as well (and possibly post wider margins).This is where putting AAPL stock on a pedestal becomes a bit of a problem though.Bottom Line for AppleFor better or worse
column40: Apple shareholders have largely been trained to expect beats not just of revenue and earnings estimates
column41: but also beats of sales as measured by units. Any weakness on any front poses a risk to a usually frothy AAPL valuation.My prediction? I firmly believe the iPhone 8 will be an unexpected disappointment
column42: though that's distinctly different than a flop. Some - though not all - will balk at a four-figure sticker price
column43: forcing people to finally ask themselves ""What are we doing
column44: paying a thousand bucks to keep in touch onFacebookand to play mobile video games on a five inch screen?""Again
column45: don't misunderstand. I fully acknowledge there are some utilitarian features on the iPhone 8 that will be viewed as a must-have for some consumers.Wireless chargingis convenient
column46: and the built-in touch ID is going to be critical to some business users concerned about security.By and large though
column47: I have to believe the average consumer just wants a phone they can use to stay connected
column48: via the web and voice. An edge-to-edge screen or a lack of a home button isn't the game-changer it's being made it to be
column49: especially at $1
column50: 000 a pop … even for people who only own the iPhone as a status symbol.Kroger Co (KR) Stock Looks Very Attractive Right NowTo quantify my pessimism
column51: I'm guessing Apple sells 70 million units of the iPhone 8 in its first full quarter starting in October. That translates into more year-over-year revenue
column52: but is still a letdown for what's supposed to be ""the best iPhone ever."" Such a result could easily send AAPL sock careening
column53: though odds are good the market would figure it out before the official numbers were released by the company. AAPL stock could lose as much as 20% of its value on that kind of worry.Perhaps worse than the numbers themselves would be the sudden realization that Apple is indeed fallible. A bad quarter is forgivable. A flawed business model isn't as easily forgotten.As of this writing
column54: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace9 Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9 a Share10 Clobbered Stocks to Buy That Are About to Get Red-HotThe postHow Much Will Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Fall If the iPhone 8 Flops?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Google Hangouts: No More Text Messaging After May 22;3/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: GOOGL) Google Hangouts may remove text message after May 22.makeArticleAd();A new report claims that Google Hangouts will alert users that they will no longer be able to use the app for texting on March 27. It claims that users will be asked to select a new default messaging app after this. If they don't have one
column4: they will be taken to the Google Play Store to chosea new messaging app.The change won't actually stop everyone from using Google Hangouts as a messaging service. Google Voice users will reportedly still be able to use the app for text messaging even after May 22. However
column5: they will get a notification telling them that their carrier number can no longer be used with Hangouts
column6: reportsEngadget.Google Hangouts users that are worried about losing their old messages are fretting over nothing. When choosing a new default messaging app
column7: their old text messageswill be transferred overfrom Hangouts to that one. Google has plenty of messaging apps to chose from on the Play Store.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonThe reported decision to remove text messaging from Hangouts likely has to do with Alphabet Inc's plans for the app. The company has expressed its interest in making the app more focused on productivity. It hopes to set it up as a better tool for business users
column8: Ars Technicanotes.A Reddit post claims to have the full email concerning the changes coming to Google Hangouts. You can check it out for yourself byfollowing this link.More From InvestorPlace10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the Bills10 Mutual Funds You Can Buy and Hold ForeverThe postGoogle Hangouts: No More Text Messaging After May 22appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Google Aims at Workplace Diversity with Howard West Program;3/24/2017;"Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle has partnered with Howard University to offer black software engineers a chance to learn from a new program called ""Howard West"".The first 12-week batch consisting of 25 to 30 juniors and seniors in Howard's computer science program will commence this summer with numbers expected to increase in future semesters. Candidates have to apply and get accepted to the program
column2: following which they will receive stipend and school credits.Howard targets 740 students within the next five years. The broader plan is to extend the program to other historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) going forward.Extension of Google's Residence ProgramWith the Howard West program
column3: Google is extending its Google in Residence (GIR) program. Under GIR
column4: Google engineers teach on-job skills to students of Howard University and other HBCUs at their own campuses.The Howard West program will do the same at Google's Mountain View
column5: CA campus and its teachers include Google engineers and Howard University faculty.Alphabet Inc. Revenue (TTM)Alphabet Inc. Revenue (TTM)|Alphabet Inc. QuoteGoogle's Senior Executive is the MastermindBonita Stewart
column6: a Howard Graduate and Google's vice president of global partnerships has planned this project along with Howard University president Dr. Wayne Frederick.""Howard happens to be my alma mater
column7: so I am especially proud to share that our formal recruiting from the university has evolved into a residency for Black CS majors right here at the Googleplex
column8: Stewart commented while announcing the program.Diversification and Recruitment to Go TogetherThe program aims at giving more exposure and opportunities to students from the black community in the technology industry. That makes sense as tech giants like Google
column9: MicrosoftMSFT
column10: FacebookFBand TwitterTWTRhave struggled to hire and retain a racially diverse workforce.Google at present is far away from representing a diversified workforce.  Black employees represent only 2% of Google's total employees and 1% of Google's tech employees. Apart from getting candidates who have been mentored by its own engineers
column11: the program will also help it to attain workplace diversity.Over the last one year

column13: gaining 11.6% compared with the industry's gain of 8.9%. Proper recruitment and workplace diversification strategies are expected to back this momentum going forward.Currently

column1: Is India the Next Big Market for Apple's (AAPL) iPhones?;3/24/2017;"Indians will soon seeApple Inc.'sAAPLiPhone 6 and 6S models packaged with a tag line of 'Assembled in India'. Yes
column2: it's true.PerThe Wall Street Journal
column3: the company's Taiwanese supplier - Wistron - is likely to start making the aforesaid models in the next four to six weeks at its manufacturing facility in Bengaluru
column4: India. It should be noted that Wistron
column5: in late Dec 2016
column6: sought permission for expansion of its manufacturing facility from the Indian government.Though
column7: Apple's shares were down 0.4% yesterday
column8: it has gained 21.6% so far this year. Notably
column9: the stock's year-to-date return is almost in line with the Zacks categorizedComputer-Miniindustry's gain of 21.5%.Why is Apple Highly Focused on India?Since 2016
column10: Apple has been increasing its focus on India to claim a greater share of the vast smartphone market in the country
column11: of which it reportedly holds only 2% as of now. Apple has been facing a slowdown in iPhone demand in most regions
column12: either because of stiff competition or regulatory hurdles (China) or market saturation (the U.S). Thus
column13: it makes sense for the company to solidify/fortify its position in India
column14: which is projected to become the second largest smartphone market in the world.Notably
column15: in fiscal 2016
column16: Apple sales in India surged approximately 50% over the prior fiscal. Moreover
column17: during its last quarterly earnings conference call
column18: the company revealed that its smartphone sales in the country registered 51% year-over-year growth in the first three quarters of fiscal 2017.Apple
column19: of course
column20: is not the only tech player eyeing India for growth. Given the potential of this market
column21: Silicon Valley's interest is well understood. From Microsoft Corp.MSFTto AlphabetGOOGL
column22: to Facebook Inc.FB
column23: all remain laser focused on the Indian market.Furthermore
column24: a younger and skilled population
column25: along with increasing investment in broadband network by the government
column26: makes India an attractive growth opportunity for Apple over the long run. In fact
column27: the Indian government
column28: under Prime Minister Narendra Modi
column29: is eager to bring foreign capital and boost manufacturing facilities in the country.The recently outlined FDI policy by Indian government also bodes well for the company as it eliminates the requirement to locally source products for at least a three-year period. This will enable Apple to open its solely-owned retail stores in India. Thereafter
column30: the company will have to comply with the rule. In addition
column31: company has partnered with telecom company - Reliance - which is providing its Jio (a unique all-IP network) service for free with the new iPhones.Last year
column32: Tim Cook was on a charm offensive in India. Besides meeting Modi
column33: he also announced the opening of an iOS App Design and Development Accelerator in Bengaluru
column34: as well as a map development office in another Indian city - Hyderabad - in collaboration with regional firm RMSI. He was also seen hobnobbing with industrialists and movie stars during his maiden visit to the country.Will the Move Aid Apple's Cause?Per analysts
column35: the lion's share of Apple's revenues in the country comes from devices
column36: which are a couple of generations old. Newer models have relatively low demand given the hefty price tag. According to reports
column37: the Apple team in India is trying to increase revenues to $3 billion by fiscal 2017-18. Also
column38: by local assembling operations
column39: the company can start operating its own retail outlets and avail a 10% tax benefit. This
column40: in turn
column41: is likely to lower prices.However
column42: a Forbes analyst observes that even if Apple starts production locally
column43: the prices might not come down as much. This is because
column44: at present
column45: only assembling operations can be carried out in India as the country lacks a robust supply chain like China. Furthermore
column46: the analyst argues that though labor cost in the country is cheaper than China
column47: productivity is relatively better in China. Simple assembling may not drastically bring down prices. However
column48: if India can ""spark"" a creation of local supply chain like China
column49: then it will be a big positive.Moreover
column50: another analyst observes that Apple's lack of focus on regional customers' demand is a pressing concern. India is categorized by handsets that work on dual SIMs. Apparently
column51: Apple is not keen on making dual SIM handsets. This could be a very big impediment to growth in the country. The iPhone manufacturer is already late to the party. Its rival Samsung has long been in the market
column52: and with reportedly 23% share
column53: it is currently the leading player in the country.Bottom LineDespite Modi's historic move of demonetizing Rs 500 and Rs 1000 currency notes to combat corruption
column54: the company registered all-time record revenue figures in third-quarter fiscal 2017

column1: AT&T & Verizon Suspend Marketing Advertisements from YouTube;3/23/2017;"U.S. telecom behemothsAT&T Inc.TandVerizon Communications Inc.VZhave decided to suspend their marketing campaign on Google's YouTube site. The reason behind the decision is the appearance of their ads alongside offensive and highly controversial videos promoting adult contents
column2: terrorism and hate speeches. Notably
column3: Google is a division of Alphabet Inc.GOOGL.Yesterday
column4: the two companies announced that they are suspending all their advertising from Google's non-search platforms
column5: including YouTube as well as third-party websites that Google partners with. The withdrawal will stand until Google permanently solves the problem. So far
column6: more than 250 companies have pulled their advertisements from YouTube including Johnson & JohnsonJNJ
column7: the world's biggest health-care company.The decision of Verizon and AT&T is significant as telephone operators are among the biggest block of advertisers in corporate America. The two companies together spent $6.6 billion in advertisement in 2015. According to Kantar Media

column9: the two telecom giants have withdrawn their ads from Google's non-search platforms only. However

column11: research firm eMarketer estimated it to be around $5.6 billion and has projected this figure to reach $7 billion in 2017.At this stage
column12: it is worth mentioning that Alphabet Inc. has been in a tussle with AT&T and Verizon during the last couple of years over several regulatory issues related to broadband and data privacy. The company has significantly stepped up investments in fiber-optic broadband and wireless technologies to increase competition.Price Performance of Alphabet

column1: The Future of Virtual Reality: 5 Things to Know;3/22/2017;"Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) technologies   have gotten a lot of attention over the past few years.Sony's PlayStation VR headset is shining a spotlight onthe viability of VR gaming
column2: whileAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)  Google Cardboard and new   Daydream View headsets are pushing mobile VR into the mainstream.   The unexpected success of Pokemon Go last year showed that   smartphone users are ready and willing to adopt augmented   reality. AndMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT)  development of its HoloLens goggles aim to   prove that the virtual and augmented worlds will soon become a   part of our reality.Investors looking to benefit from these two intertwined   markets should keep these five things in mind:Image source: Google.makeArticleAd();1. The future of VR could be our next computing     platformMuch of the attention surrounding virtual reality right now   has to do mainly with how it will be used for gaming
column3: filmmaking
column4: or other entertainment content. ButFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) CEO Mark Zuckerberg believes that VR could surpass   all of these categories.He said in a Bloomberginterviewlast year that VR is ""a good candidate to be the next major   computing platform."" Zuckerberg thinks it'll take a while for us   to get there (more on that later)
column5: but he's optimistic that VR   could be a primary form of communication technology in the near   future:Photos are richer than text; video
column6: much richer than photos.     But that's not the end
column7: right? I mean
column8: it's like this     indefinite continuum of getting closer and closer to being able     to capture what a person's natural experience and thought is
column9: and just being able to immediately capture that and design it     however you want and share it with whomever you want.2. It will take a while for VR to gain     tractionVR is still in its very early stages
column10: and it's likely that it   will take many more years before it becomes mainstream --   Zuckerberg has put the timeframe at five to 10 years.Adding to the slow pace is the fact that some hyped   technologies
column11: like Magic Leap's AR headset
column12: have recently been   found to be behind schedule.The Informationreported(subscription required) at the end of the last year that Magic   Leap -- which has raised $1.4 billion in funding in about three   years -- pivoted away from some of its earlier fiber optic   technologies and now trails the image quality of Microsoft's   HoloLens.And even the HoloLens
column13: which currently costs $3
column14: 000 and is   mainly for developers
column15: has sold only thousands of units. Roger   Walkden
column16: Microsoft's HoloLens commercial lead
column17: recently toldThe Inquirerthat
column18: ""We're not trying to sell hundreds of thousands or millions   or anything
column19: it's expensive
column20: and it's not in huge numbers. So   we're happy with the level of sales that we've got -- I can't   tell you anything about the numbers
column21: but it's in thousands
column22: not   hundreds of thousands
column23: and that's fine. That's all we need.""While Microsoft may be pleased with those numbers
column24: it's still   a clear indicator that VR and AR have a long way go before they   become mainstream.And then there's the recent news that Facebook's Oculus is   shutting down 200 of its 500 demo sites within Best Buy   stores
column25: reportedly due to thelack of public interest. The future may be virtual
column26: but we're getting there slowly.3. It offers a new way of seeing our worldJason Pontin
column27: the editor of MIT'sTechnology Review
column28: recentlyinterviewedJessica Brillhart
column29: a filmmaker for virtual reality at   Google
column30: and talked with her about how VR is currently used and   what it might become in the near future. When asked if   people will eventually use VR to record home videos
column31: Brillhart   responded that we probably would but that it might not be a good   thing
column32: Think of everything you forget about a birthday party when     you're a kid. But now the rig would capture everything. You     could watch someone you loved respond the way she used to
column33: or     eat cake a certain way. It is going to be interesting to see     what happens when we aren't able to forget anything     anymore.The interview is a good reminder that VR is still in its early   stages and it's still unclear how this platform will be used
column34: and   whether or not we'll like exactly how it turns out.4. Virtual reality could eventually impact all of the     sensesRight now
column35: VR is limited to a user's visual and auditory   senses
column36: but in the future this will likely be enhanced.   The general manager of Dell's gaming PC manufacturer   Alienware
column37: Frank Azor
column38: said thisin an interviewwith TIME last year:Once you begin catering to the rest of the senses
column39: like what     we feel body-wise
column40: temperature-wise
column41: and smell
column42: the reality     factor of virtual reality [becomes] stronger and the virtual     piece begins to fade.Breaking the barrier between the virtual world and the   physical world with high-end touch sensors could be the next step   in virtual reality
column43: and it won't be here for a while
column44: but VR   hardware and software makers are already thinking about how this   technology can go from immersive to fully interactive.5. The market potential for both AR and VR could be     hugeThe virtual reality market was worth about $1.9 billion in   2016
column45: but that's expected to climb to $22.4 billion by 2020.   Those numbers include both software and hardware sales. And when   you factor in AR sales
column46: the market skyrockets even higher. The   combined AR and VR market will be worth $121 billion by 2021
column47: according to Digi-Capital.In that same year
column48: IDC estimates more than 99 million AR and   VR headsets will be shipped
column49: up from just 10 million last year
column50: which represents a 58% compound annual growth rate between 2016   and 2021..The good news for investors is that companies are just getting   started with AR and VR
column51: which meansthe opportunities to benefit haven't passed. There are still plenty of unknowns
column52: but as more companies rally   around these new technologies and make the necessary investments   to get them off of the ground
column53: we're likely to see the future of   AR and VR develop substantially over the next few years.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column54: it can pay to listen. After all
column55: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Is Alphabet Stock a Good Way to Invest in Self-Driving Cars?;3/22/2017;"Three things seem pretty clear at this point in history:Self-driving cars will begin coming to market before     long.They'll generate huge profits for some companies.Google has been a leader in developing self-driving     technology.But does it follow that Google's parent
column2: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column3: will reap the rewards of its   technological leadership? Or put another way
column4: are the potential   profits from self-driving cars a reason to add Alphabet's stock   to your portfolio?A lot of commentators seem to think so
column5: but I'm very   skeptical. Here's why.makeArticleAd();Driverless ""panda cars"" were the public face of the Google     Self-Driving Car Project for several years. Image source:     Alphabet.Alphabet has what looks like a leadership position...Google began tinkering with self-driving cars way back in   2009
column6: long before many investors began taking the technology   seriously. The original team behind what became knows as the   Google Self-Driving Car Project included several robotics   all-stars who seemed ready to invent the future. The whole thing   appeared to be decades beyond what the established automakers   were doing.For a while
column7: it was. Of course
column8: in the last few years
column9: some   automakers and auto-industry suppliers have invested heavily in   the technology and made significant gains. But even so
column10: Alphabet's self-driving unit
column11: which was spun out of Google and   renamed Waymo late last year
column12: retains some big advantages:By at least one measure -- ""disengagements
column13: the number of     times a human driver has to take control of a self-driving test     car -- Waymo made major progress last year andappears to be aheadof most known rivals.Maps. The first self-driving cars to come to market will     rely heavily on highly detailed maps as a backup to their     sensors. Google has been mapping the world in ever-increasing     detail for years; Waymo will have access to those maps
column14: while     its competitors will have to look elsewhere.Waymo has developed its own self-driving sensor hardware
column15: including -- crucially -- LIDAR units that cost much less than     current commercially available units.Those are significant advantages. But there's a big question   that might not be obvious to investors who don't have a deep   understanding of the auto industry:How will Waymo bring all of that to market?Waymo's current test fleet was built in partnership with     FCA
column16: but the companies have disclosed no plans to collaborate     on production vehicles. Image source: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles     NV....but bringing it to market may prove complicatedWaymo's CEO
column17: John Krafcik
column18: is a respected auto-industry   veteran who was hired to lead the project in September 2015.   Krafcik brought a welcome dose of realistic transparency to the   project when he made it clear that Alphabet has no intention of   manufacturing its own vehicles. Instead
column19: he said
column20: Waymo would   seek to bring its technology to market via partnerships with   established automakers.There's just one problem: The automakers aren't exactly   beating down Krafcik's door. In fact
column21: the auto executives I've   talked with feel that they have very good reasons to steer clear   of a deal with Waymo
column22: starting with control of the data generated   by self-driving cars.It's almost an understatement to say that automakers areveryaware of the smartphone precedent. The phone makers that chose to   adopt the Android operating system ended up making hardware on   very slim margins. Alphabet ended up with most of the profits
column23: because Android provided it with the (immensely valuable) users'   data.Auto executives don't want to end up in the same boat
column24: and   they know that they'll soon have alternatives that will allow   them to keep at least some control of the data. At least one   alternative
column25: a partnership betweenDelphi Automotive(NYSE: DLPH)
column26: Intel(NASDAQ: INTC)
column27: andMobileye(NYSE: MBLY)
column28: aims to have a self-driving system available to   any automaker that wants it by the end of 2019. That partnership   will allow automakers to retain much of the data
column29: and auto   executives see it as homegrown -- created largely by   established industry suppliers
column30: not by Silicon Valley   hotshots.Given that
column31: why go with Waymo?That said
column32: a couple of big automakers have kicked the tires on   Waymo's technology:Fiat Chrysler Automobiles(NYSE: FCAU) worked with Google engineers last year to createthe latest vehicles for Waymo's test fleet
column33: based on the well-regarded Chrysler Pacifica minivan --     but there's no sign that the two will move forward on anything     that could lead to a product for sale.Honda(NYSE: HMC) issued a somewhat odd announcement in December     saying that it was ""entering into formal discussions"" with     Waymo
column34: though nothing (so far) seems to have resulted from     those discussions. (I speculated at the time that Honda's     announcement might have been aboutprodding other potential partners to take     action. But at least as of right now
column35: it's not clear exactly what was     going on there.)Waymo may well find a profitable line of business in selling   its sensors to other companies. And it's likely that some   automaker
column36: somewhere
column37: will eventually give its self-driving   system a try.But unless other research and development efforts hit   roadblocks that Waymo is somehow able to skirt
column38: it seems unlikely   that it will be a dominant player in self-driving systems anytime   in the near future.The upshot: Don't buy Alphabet just for self-drivingThere are plenty of good reasons to consider adding Alphabet   to your portfolio. But if you're looking for a targeted   self-driving investment
column39: Alphabet probably isn't it: As of right   now
column40: it's not clear that Waymo will ever add much to the search   giant's bottom line.10 stocks we like better than AlphabetWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column41: it can pay to listen. After all
column42: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column43: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column44: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (A shares)     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Buy the Baidu Inc (ADR) (BIDU) Stock Dip;3/22/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsChinese tech companyBaidu Inc (ADR)(NASDAQ:BIDU) has been called ""the Google of China
column3: but BIDU stock's steady decline over the past six months suggests that the company is nowhere near comparable toAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL).makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIn mid-February
column5: BIDU looked to be on the upswing
column6: but the firm'sfourth-quarter earningsdealt a heavy blow to Baidu stock.With BIDU shares down nearly 10% from where they were a month ago
column7: however
column8: this dip could translate into a buying opportunity.Baidu EarningsIt's true that Baidu reported less-than-stellar earnings last month. The company's quarterly revenue came in a $2.6 billion
column9: which represents a decline of more than 2% from last year's figures.5 Big Financial Stocks That Just Got Leveled (And What to Do Next)Even more concerning was the fact that online marketing customers declined 18.6% in 2016. For investors that consider BIDU to be the Chinese Google
column10: that's a huge deal. Advertising dollars are everything to search engines like Baidu and Google.It's Not as Bad as It LooksThose figures are certainly scary
column11: but when you look at the reason behind them things start to look a little bit rosier. It's important to note that BIDU faced some major headwinds last year
column12: including a big change to China's advertising regulations. The cost to comply with the new rules was significant for Baidu
column13: whichgenerates around 96% of its revenue from advertising.Not only did the new regulations hit BIDU's revenue hard
column14: but they also hurt the firm's customers numbers. The new regulations include strict rules regarding how companies advertise and some of Baidu's current customers weren't able to meet those requirements
column15: which resulted in a loss.However
column16: there could be a silver lining in there for BIDU as the new requirements will help the firm identify who its quality customers are. If you look at per-customer spend
column17: you'll see that those who were able to meet the new guidelines actually spent about 14% more than they had in the fourth quarter of 2015.Huge Growth Potential for BIDU StockWhat's important to note here is that even if BIDU is struggling now
column18: there is a huge growth opportunity for internet companies in China. While you might think that a search engine doesn't have room to expand any further
column19: keep in mind that China is pretty far behind the U.S. when it comes to internet users.  Just over 50% of the nation's populationhas access to the internet.That's a big deal
column20: because it means that as the internet makes its way further afield
column21: advertisers are going to be willing to pay to reach even more people. Eventually
column22: online advertising will be the best way to reach the majority of Chinese residents
column23: and marketers will have to pay for that.Bottom Line on BIDU StockNot only does BIDU have a lot of growth potential in its core business
column24: but the firm has been investing heavily in hot new technology like artificial intelligence and self-driving vehicles. While advertising revenue still makes up the bulk of Baidu's bottom line
column25: we could see big-time benefits from the firm's focus on the future.The company's efforts to develop self-driving technology are particularly enticing because the cars' navigation systems will be equipped to deal with China's complicated traffic conditions. That means that once the vehicles are roadworthy
column26: tweaking their technology to make them usable on U.S. roads will be far easier than trying to do it the other way around.Baidu Inc (ADR) (BIDU) Stock Is Just Giving Away MoneyBIDU's fourth-quarter results were definitely scary on the surface
column27: but things aren't as bad as the market would have you believe. If you have ever considered buying BIDU stock
column28: now is the time to do it.As of this writing
column29: Laura Hoy did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace8 Places to Run and Hide in a Market Crash10 Safe Dividend Stocks to Own During the Next Market CrashThe postBuy the Baidu Inc (ADR) (BIDU) Stock Dipappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: FANG Stocks are Back in Focus;3/22/2017;"A while ago someone noticed that if you took the first letters of the names of the four big modern tech companies
column2: Facebook (FB)
column3: Amazon (AMZN)
column4: Netflix (NFLX) and Google (GOOG:GOOGL) they spelled out a wonderful acronym
column5: FANG. Of course
column6: since then Google has gone and spoiled it all by rebranding their holding company as alphabet
column7: but the acronym has stuck.At the risk of spoiling that alphabetic synergy I would add Apple (AAPL) to the list
column8: given that companies role as the largest of the tech stocks. In fact some people substitute Apple for Amazon and obviously if you do that you still get FANG rather than the less appealing FAANG. For argument’s sake
column9: let’s assume that all five stocks are still collectively known as the fang stocks
column10: and right now they look like a good place to be.The reason
column11: though
column12: is less about tech
column13: or indeed about business at all
column14: than it is about politics. The market seems to be driven at the moment by what comes out of the White House. Since the election there has been a lot of faith placed by traders and investors in certain policies outlined by the new administration and the Republicans who dominate Congress during the campaign; a “beautiful” replacement for Obamacare
column15: for example
column16: as well as tax reform and infrastructure spending.makeArticleAd();Yesterday’s drop in the stock market
column17: the biggest of the year so far
column18: was reportedly triggered by worries about the healthcare bill slated to replace the Affordable Care Act. It has met with opposition from within the Republican Party
column19: particularly from the Right
column20: and needs some serious negotiation in order to just pass the House.That in itself would be a bad thing if repeal went ahead without the replacement passed
column21: as most acknowledge that something has to fill the vacuum.More worrying for the market
column22: though
column23: is that if this bill fails
column24: it will indicate that the fiscal conservatives in Congress are sticking to their principles
column25: making stimulative infrastructure spending a virtual non-starter.Some of the biggest losers yesterday were in the industrial and material sectors that have gained the most since the election and which would be hurt most by delays in infrastructure spending. The reason the fang stocks look so attractive right now is because policy delays regarding healthcare and infrastructure spending will have little effect on them in the short term
column26: but things like tax reform when it does come
column27: especially the possibility of the repatriation of overseas profits
column28: will make an enormous difference. The consensus is that tax reform is an area that unites the party and thus could be even hastened by a split over the Obamacare replacement.The fly in the ointment could be that much of the potential growth for these firms lies in overseas expansion
column29: in particular to emerging economies. That would be a worry if the White House does push for more isolationist trade relationships
column30: but again the fact that the Freedom Caucus free market types in the GOP are flexing their muscles would suggest that any eventual move would have to be negotiated
column31: and therefore moderated from the campaign rhetoric.All in all
column32: then
column33: things look good for Facebook
column34: Amazon
column35: Apple
column36: Netflix and Google. That belief seems to have taken hold today as each of the tech big five has bucked the downward trend of the broader market and gained in early trading. Of course one swallow doth not a summer make
column37: but the logic behind these stocks’ contrarian behavior is hard to refute and they may prove to be a hedge against politics driven uncertainty over the next few weeks
column38: or even months."

column1: Does Facebook's Video Strategy Make It a Top Growth Stock?;3/22/2017;"Yesterday
column2: FacebookFBwas assigned a Buy rating by BTIG analyst Rich Greenfield
column3: who was quoted by media reports saying
column4: ""Not having a buy [rating] on Facebook has clearly been a mistake in 2017."" He further added that ""the secular trends toward mobile devices globally and the accelerating shift of ad dollars are simply too strong to ignore.""Facebook's Video StrategySince last year
column5: Facebook has been aggressively promoting live video content on its platform. Online video is emerging as a big opportunity to boost ad revenues. Ad revenues contribute over 95% to Facebook's total revenue. Earlier
column6: it was reported that the company is looking to grab a share of the reportedly $70 billion brand advertising that is allocated to linear TV by increasing video content on its platform.  At its last earnings call
column7: Facebook said that video has emerged as a ""megatrend"" on the same lines like mobile.Last year
column8: the company signed deals with media houses and Internet celebrities to churn out more content for its live platform and added a plethora of new features to Facebook live.  These include enabling broadcast for a Group or Event and at the same time allowing audience to respond to the live broadcast in real time through Live Reactions. Also
column9: recently
column10: it brought on board an ex-MTV executive
column11: Mina Lefevre
column12: to increase original live video content on the platform.In fact
column13: it has been on a signing spree to bring more live video content
column14: especially sports. Streaming
column15: particularly live sports
column16: is one of the most lucrative opportunities as it helps to boost engagement levels (especially millennials) and brings more advertisers. Facebook has struck a deal with MLB and has collaborated with Univision Communications Inc. to live stream 46 Liga MX games for an undisclosed amount.Mobile and live video efforts are paying off big time for the social media giant.  In the last reported quarter
column17: revenues of $8.8 billion increased 51% year over year. Advertising revenues were $8.629 billion
column18: surging 53% year over year.Mobile ad revenues in the quarter were $7.2 billion (up 61% year over year)
column19: contributing 84% to total ad revenues.Facebook
column20: Inc. PriceFacebook
column21: Inc. Price|Facebook

column1: The Google Ad Controversy:  Should it Matter to Investors?;3/22/2017;"Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle is currently in the news regarding the issue of ads emerging next to YouTube videos that display homophobic and anti-Semitic contents.The UK Government called upon Google last Thursday after ads for taxpayer-funded bodies like The Royal Air Force
column2: The Royal Navy and BBC appeared next to ""extremist"" YouTube videos.The Government has suspended all its advertising from Google until further confirmation about those ads no longer appearing against questionable contents. The stock has lost 2.4% since
column3: against the ZacksInternet-Servicesindustry's loss of 0.11%.Google has been summoned for the second time this week to provide the government an update of the efforts it has been making to ensure that ads appear in undisputed environments.Google's Initial Response Seemed a Bit WeakGoogle did give an explanation in a blog post the next day
column4: stating that the company has policies to debar ads from appearing on pages or videos with offensive or derogatory contents. But implementation is not always easy
column5: given the millions of sites in its network. Moreover
column6: 400 hours of video get uploaded to Youtube every minute
column7: which makes the implementation doubly difficult. The company
column8: however
column9: said that it had already initiated a review of the problem.Nevertheless
column10: the investor community did not seem satisfied with a ""half-hearted"" explanation. A rating downgrade came the very next working day
column11: with Pivotal Research analyst Brian Wieser downgrading Google parent Alphabet from ""Buy"" to ""Hold"".Adding to Google's troubles
column12: the issue that primarily appeared to be centered on the U.K

column9: such as power

column14: Georgia.Sticking With What WorksThere is little doubt that we are in a long term bull market. One of the best ways to play this market is by buying the stocks that are seeing positive developments and are hitting new highs. INAP has both of these even and the market breaks a long streak of days without a 1% drawdown.Earnings HistoryThe earnings history isn't exactly a stellar one. I see two beats and two misses in the last four outings. None of the last four reports saw the company outperform on the top line either. But something did catch my eye.The most recent report was a beat of $0.03 which translated into a positive earnings surprise of 20%. This solid beat caused the stock to jump more than 31% in the session following the release. That has a way of making the chart look great!EstimatesThe Zacks Consensus Estimate for CY2017 saw a huge boost following the most recent earnings report. The number moved from a loss of $0.57 in January to a loss of $0.52 in February and is now at a loss of just $0.34. column21: CEO of Twitter Inc.(NYSE:TWTR-Free Report)is facing another problem in convincing advertisers to return to Twitter

column23: 000 features to identify bot accounts on Twitter. It was estimated that between 9% and 15% of active Twitter accounts are bots.The estimate of 15% is almost twice of Twitter's own estimates. In Twitter's Q4 earnings

column1: Irrational Demands: Of Anchors
column2: Pearls
column3: and Procrastination;3/22/2017;"(0:20) - Dan Ariely: Predictably Irrational(4:10) - Do first impressions get imprinted on us?(6:30) - Arbitrary Coherence: Why do we accept anchors?(12:00) - Are price tags anchors?(14:30) - Dan Ariely: Payoff(16:40) - What gets scheduled
column4: gets done.Welcome back to Mind Over Money. I'm Kevin Cook
column5: your field guide and story teller for the fascinating arena of Behavioral Economics.Today we're going to focus on the work of Dan Ariely
column6: author ofPredictably Irrational. When he published the book in 2008
column7: Ariely was a professor of Behavioral Economics at MIT. Now
column8: he's Professor of Psychology and Behavioral Economics at Duke University and he also is the founder of The Center for Advanced Hindsight. Ariely's TEDtalks have been watched over 7.8 million times.We've talked before about the cognitive bias calledanchoring. Ariely has picked up where the forefathers of Behavioral Economics like Daniel Kahneman and Richard Thaler left off by doing new experiments to find out how prevalent this bias really is.In the podcast
column9: I read from Chapter 2 of Predictably Irrational
column10: titled ""The Fallacy of Supply and Demand: Why the Price of Pearls - and Everything Else - Is Up in the Air.""Ariely begins with a story about the ""pearl king"" Salvador Assael who achieved a remarkable marketing feat in the 1970s New York luxury jewelry scene by making so-called black pearls from Tahiti into a nearly precious gem.He tells this story to help explain the power ofprice anchorsin decision making
column11: especially when the initial price reference is completely arbitrary
column12: and thus
column13: irrational.Then he describes an experiment he conducted with colleagues at MIT in the first decade of the 21st century. The researchers used a class of 55 marketing MBA students to conduct a specialized auction where the participants were first asked to write down the last two digits of their social security numbers.The act of writing down those digits had a surprising overall impact on the results of the auction
column14: which included fine wines
column15: computer equipment
column16: and chocolate. Listen to the podcast and hear me read an excerpt from Dan's book that I hope inspires you to read it yourself.The GAF EconomyAriely's experiments with price anchors and buying decisions got me thinking about my favorite ""big brothers"" and hoarders of tons of data on consumer buying behavior:Alphabet(GOOGL)
column17: Amazon(AMZN)
column18: andFacebook(FB).I bet Ariely would love to have access to these databases for virtually unlimited testing. Note to self: see if Dan is looking for research partners in this ocean of data.Followers of my stock research and trading articles know that I often talk about The GAF Economy comprised of Google
column19: Amazon
column20: and Facebook. My focus is on the behemoths who have changed our entertainment
column21: education
column22: shopping and entrepreneurship with a digital deluge of information and marketing opportunities.Together
column23: Google and Facebook will break the $100 billion mark this year in advertising revenues according to market research firm eMarketer. Google broke the $50 billion mark a few years ago and Facebook topped $26 billion in 2016.Their combined 2017 haul will command over a 46% share of advertisers' total global digital ad spend. Just think about the volume of consumer purchases triggered by that $100 billion in ad spend.And if you have been listening to me about digital advertising growth in the past year
column24: you know that Facebook is not stealing market share from Google in that growth. Together
column25: they are expanding the pie as tons of small and medium-sized businesses realize the power of digitally-targeting audiences and geographies
column26: efficient ads testing
column27: and fine-tuning of their ad budgets.Welcome to the JungleAnd in the ""retail rainforest"" that is Amazon
column28: consumers continue to adopt its convenient platform for more purchases -- at the expense of traditional retailers. Amazon's total annual revenues grew 27% last year to $136 billion as it was responsible for possibly one-fourth of all online transactions in the US.Testifying to that reach
column29: according to web marketing services provider BloomReach
column30: 55% of consumers started their product searches on Amazon in 2016
column31: up from 44% in 2015.And here are some amazing stats from Amazon's Q4 report...Fulfillment by Amazon (FBA) delivered more than two billion units on behalf of sellers in 2016
column32: and the number of active sellers using FBA grew more than 70%. Using the FBA service
column33: Amazon sellers from more than 130 countries fulfilled orders to customers in 185 countries.In 2016
column34: there were over 100
column35: 000 sellers with sales of more than $100
column36: 000 selling on Amazon.To help put Amazon's share of retail sales in some perspective - I say ""some"" because the company doesn't break out their revenues clearly enough for us to know for sure -- let me share some paragraphs from an October USA Today article titledAmazon could be a lot bigger than we think...In the United States
column37: total annual retail sales are about $5   trillion
column38: with the Department of Commerce estimating 8% of that   is e-commerce. That puts total online sales at around $400   billion
column39: and Amazon's share at 15% (for domestic revenues   only).Amazon's retail revenue
column40: however
column41: doesn't reflect the full   value of the items sold on Amazon by other retailers. These are   companies that use Amazon as an online sales venue
column42: sometimes   their only one. Amazon says 49% of its units sold come from   third-party sellers.The company may actually be handling double that amount - 20%   to 30% of all U.S. retail goods sold online - thanks to the   volume of sales it transacts for third parties on its website and   app. Only a portion of those sales add to its revenue.""The punchline is that Amazon's twice as big as people give   them credit for
column43: because there's this iceberg under the surface
column44: but you only see the tip
column45: said Scot Wingo
column46: executive chairman of   Channel Advisor
column47: an e-commerce software company that works with   thousands of online sellers.When third-party sales are taken into account
column48: Amazon's share   of what U.S. shoppers spend online could be as high as $125   billion yearly
column49: and it could represent close to 30% of the online   goods Americans buy
column50: according to an analysis of Amazon's   financial statements.Gene Munster
column51: a senior analyst at Piper Jaffray
column52: estimates   Amazon touches 30% of total e-commerce in the United States
column53: and   its share is growing.""Amazon's just going to slowly grab more and more of your   wallet
column54: he said.Again
column55: Dan Ariely if you are listening
column56: we need to study the buying data and behavior of the GAF Economy. There must thousands of A/B split tests just sitting there waiting with evidence of how predictably irrational we are.A Surprisingly Simple Solution for   ProcrastinationFinally
column57: at the end of my podcast I introduce Ariely's latest book
column58: Payoff: The Hidden Logic That Shapes Our Motivations. I share a productivity secret from Dan that could literally change your life. It's a real golden nugget that will help you control
column59: if not crush
column60: procrastination. Or should I call it a black pearl?Make the time to read Ariely's book. If you liked Freakonomics for the way it gave you new perspectives about society and human behavior via statistics
column61: you'll lovePredictably Irrationalfor its ability to go inside our decision making.And be sure to listen to the podcast for that ""productivity pearl."" It'll have you finishing your own book this year.Disclosure: I own shares of Facebook for the Zacks TAZR Trader.Kevin Cook is a Senior Stock Strategist forZacks Investment   Research.Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? column1: AMD's (AMD) Success Is Not The Death Of Intel (INTC);3/22/2017;"My article on Tuesday
column2: which highlighted (some might say “boasted”) the recent achievements of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)
column3: was perceived by some readers as an attack on Intel (INTC). But that was the intent.While I’m admittedly an unabashed cheerleader of Intel
column4: I can still appreciate the rags-to-riches story that AMD CEO Lisa Su has successfully executed since her appointment in January 2012. AMD stock traded at $5.40 at the time. The stock recently made a 52-week high of $15.55. Save for the people at AMD headquarters
column5: no one anticipated this remarkable turnaround. But what’s good for AMD is also good for Intel since a excitement surrounding chip battles increases consumer interest.Notably
column6: this renewed battle comes even as the rate of PC revenue continues to decline. In other words
column7: both companies
column8: which struggled at the height of the mobile era
column9: have moved beyond being just PC shops. And while AMD continues to make impressive leaps
column10: Intel is still the leader. The extent to which AMD pushes Intel to innovate
column11: the better off Intel will be. And that’s exactly what Intel CEO Brian Krzanich has begun to demonstrate.makeArticleAd();Looking to avoid the another mobile-type miss
column12: Intel is pushing heavily to be future-ready. Fresh off its second mega-deal in less than two years
column13: Krzanich — in his fifth year at the helm — seems intent on putting Intel’s cash to use. The company’s$15.3 billion acquisitionof Israeli self-driving technology company Mobileye (MBLY) was the most recent example. This follows $16.7 billion deal for Altera back in 2015.These two deals suggest that Intel is not worried about what AMD is doing. It can be argued that it should. But Krzanich
column14: who has found ways to get Intel’s top line growing again
column15: has shown to have a good pulse on what the company needs. Not only does Intel
column16: thanks to Altera
column17: now have an inside track on the Internet of Things and data center market
column18: Mobileye now puts Intel in the driver's seat in the realm of autonomous cars
column19: allowing it to better compete with Tesla (TSLA) and Google (GOOGL).In both acquisitions
column20: however
column21: market pundits
column22: who were unable to immediately see the financial benefits
column23: criticize Intel for overpaying. But
column24: recall
column25: Google was laughed at for buying YouTube in 2006 for $1.65 billion. Today YouTube is worth anestimated $40 billiontoday. Likewise
column26: Facebook (FB) was criticized for taking out Instagram. But assuming Intel can realize the estimated $70 billion total addressable market of driverless cars by 2030
column27: Mobileye could prove to be a bargain.In short
column28: AMD’s improvements don’t spell the doom of Intel. The management of both companies are executing on their stated operating objectives. And both stocks should perform well in the next 12 to 18 months. As to which stock is right for you? That all depends on where your allegiance is."

Apple didn't specify on the timeframe for the Red iPhone and what percentage of the sales will be donated.Apple also announced a new video app

column11: emoji
column12: text

column1: 1 Great Tech Stock for Wary Retirees;3/21/2017;"Many retirees shy away from tech companies -- to their own   detriment. Maybe it's due to fear of a sector that
column2: as a whole
column3: is often considered to be higher risk than other
column4: less dynamic   industries. But there are a select few companies that
column5: thanks to   their dominant competitive advantages
column6: offer an excellent   low-risk way for investors to profit from emerging technologies.   Read on to learn about one of the best.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();All hail the kingFew businesses are as dominant within their respective   industries asAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) . The parent company of Google   gives investors an opportunity beyond a core Internet search   business that legendary investor Charlie Munger once described as   havingthe largest competitive moathe's ever seen.With a more than 90% share of the global search engine market
column7: Google is the undisputed king of search. Yet it refuses to grow   complacent; it's constantly expanding its reach with an   ever-growing array of services. It now possesses an incredible   collection of platforms that serve more than 1billionusers each
column8: including YouTube
column9: Android
column10: Chrome
column11: Gmail
column12: Maps
column13: Google Play
column14: and nowGoogle Cloud. Together
column15: they serve to expand and strengthen Google's powerful   ecosystem and widen its competitive moat.Moreover
column16: Google generates enormous amounts of cash
column17: to the   tune of nearly $26 billion in 2016
column18: which it has used to build a   fortress-like balance sheet with more than $86 billion in cash   and less than $4 billion in debt. This financial strength allows   it to invest aggressively in research and development
column19: and in the   acquisition of companies that are leading the way in important   new technologies. All of this
column20: combined with Google's renowned   culture of innovation
column21: helps it remain at the forefront of   technological change.Image source: Getty Images.Other betsIt's this innovation that necessitated its reorganization into   its current ""Alphabet"" structure. The design is brilliant
column22: as it sends a clear message   about what the company has become: a collection of businesses   with investments in a far-ranging array of exciting technologies   that are poised to pay increasing returns to shareholders in the   years ahead.Alphabet's holding company structure allows disparate   businesses -- such as self-driving technology leaderWaymo
column23: life sciences companyVerily
column24: and connected home device makerNest-- to be run and scaled independently. Management believes this   will give these ""other bets"" their best chance at receiving the   resources and attention they need to succeed over the long   term.Alphabet therefore gives investors many ways to win. The   company's core Google business is as dominant as they come
column25: which   helps to lower Alphabet's overall risk profile. And the company's   other bets have in many ways become analogous to an emerging   technology fund overseen by two of the greatest minds on the   planet: co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin. It's the perfect   balance of market dominance and optionality; cash flow and   reinvestment opportunity; current success and future growth   potential.ValuationAt first glance
column26: Alphabet's forward price-to-earnings ratio in   the low 20's may seem a bit expensive compared to the   S&P 500's forward P/E of about 18. But if you adjust for the   more than $82 billion in net cash it has on its balance sheet --   which equates to about $119 per share -- Alphabet's ex-cash P/E   drops to less than 19. On that basis
column27: Alphabet's stock is quite a   bargain
column28: especially considering its superior growth rates   compared to the market as a whole.Moreover
column29: investors who buy shares today will be buying   alongside Alphabet itself. The company has a $7 billion share   repurchase program currently under way -- a figure that's likely   tocontinue to growalong with Alphabet's ever rising cash flows. These share   buybacks should further help to support Alphabet's stock price
column30: and they signal management's increasing willingness to return   capital to shareholders.All told
column31: Alphabet offers retirees an excellent and relatively   low-risk way to profit from emerging technologies -- a high   potential field that's often underrepresented in retirement   portfolios.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why the Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Comeback Is Just Beginning;3/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) has gotten some of its moxie back. Granted
column3: the growth is nowhere near the pace of the glory years of the 1980s and 1990s. But then again
column4: the shareholder returns have been impressive. During the last 5 years

column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) lost about 11%.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBut it does seem like the opportunity may be mostly gone for Microsoft stock. Let's face it

column9: I think there remains more upside. The fact is that Microsoft stock is a great way to play the cloud megatrend
column10: which is likely to see growth for many years.Why MSFT Stock Is a Good BetThis technology has many benefits that are just too critical to ignore
column11: such as the ability for real-time analytics
column12: better integration with other systems and seamless updates. The business model is also fairly predictable
column13: since it is based on ongoing subscriptions.According toAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column14: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Cloud Chief Diane Greene
column15: only about5% of the world's data is in the cloud. She thinks that ultimately the market could hit a stunning $1 trillion.7 Small-Cap Tech Stocks on the Cutting EdgeBut there is another important driver: In today's world
column16: just about all companies need a strong digital presence to be successful. Simply put
column17: customers have come to expect that they should go to a site or app - and quickly get what they want.So to provide this service
column18: companies will need to rely on cloud services. And for now
column19: the two main players include MSFT andAmazon.com
column20: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN).But Microsoft stock may be in the best position. The company has a trusted global brand
column21: a massive global infrastructure
column22: a network of millions of developers as well as thousands of partners and a wide assortment of enterprise software products. Oh
column23: and there is a massive customer base that uses productivity apps like Office.Such advantages are extremely tough to replicate.Bottom Line on Microsoft StockBut what's also important for MSFT stock is that the company has essentially gone all-in with its cloud efforts
column24: such as integrating features among its products and engaging in aggressive M&A.For example
column25: the company has acquired MileIQ
column26: Xamarin and SwiftKey to bolster its mobile footprint. And more recently
column27: MSFT has been acquiring companies in the Artificial Intelligence space. Some examples include Genee (AI-powered scheduling) and Maluuba (natural language processing).Chesapeake Energy Corporation (CHK) Stock Is an Absolute Steal Right NowYet the $27 billion purchase for LinkedIn will perhaps be the most significant for Microsoft stock. With the deal
column28: MSFT gets the global leader in professional online networks - there are over467 million members- that should allow for powerful synergies with existing assets. Already
column29: the company has added LinkedIn services with the Dynamics CRM platform.So yes
column30: it should be no surprise that the quarterly reports from MSFT reflect lots of momentum. In the latestquarter
column31: the company's Azure service
column32: which is similar to Amazon Web Services
column33: saw revenues spike by 93%. In fact
column34: the annual run-rate for the total cloud segment is at over $14 billion.It's true that the cloud market is getting increasingly competitive
column35: as seen with the efforts of companies like IBM
column36: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) andHewlett Packard Enterprise Co(NYSE:HPE)
column37: but they are all really playing catchup and they do not have the breadth of services that MSFT has. In other words
column38: when it comes to playing the cloud
column39: Microsoft stock remains a great option for investors.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is the author of various books
column40: includingTaxes 2017: Saving A Bundle.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing

column1: New Details Emerge on Apple's Augmented Reality Ambitions;3/20/2017;"We already know thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is extremely interested in augmented reality (AR)   thanks to astring of commentsmade by CEO Tim Cook over the past year or so. Given Cook's   statements
column2: it should be obvious that the company is working onsomethingin AR; what's less clear is how Apple plans to create and deliver   AR experiences. Will it be a function of future iPhones? Perhaps   a new hardware product designed specifically for AR? Probably   both.Bloomberg's Mark Gurmannow has new details on the Mac maker's AR ambitions.Tim Cook hopes augmented reality will be Apple's next big     thing. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();With our powers combinedUnsurprisingly
column3: Apple has already assembled a team of   experienced hardware and software engineers
column4: while also tapping   ""talented outsiders
column5: according to the report. The team includes   engineers who have worked onFacebook's(NASDAQ: FB) Oculus Rift andMicrosoft's HoloLens. Some special effects artists from the movie industry   are supposedly even in the mix. The company has also made a   handful of AR-related acquisitions to accelerate its efforts
column6: such as the 2015 purchase of AR start-up Metaio or the 2016   acquisition of spatial perception start-up Flyby
column7: among   others.Gurman believes that Apple AR glasses will launch after Apple   attempts to include AR functions into future iPhones. The   challenge will be keeping the form factor thin and light while   being able to deliver compelling experiences. For this reason
column8: AR   glasses may be tethered to the iPhone
column9: which has more processing   power and can transmit data to AR glasses wirelessly. Keeping   costs down will also be important
column10: since the inevitable price   point needs to be justifiable to mainstream consumers.Mike Rockwell
column11: a former executive atDolby
column12: is reportedly in charge of the team. Rockwell reports to   hardware engineering chief Dan Riccio. The report also details   many other members of the team
column13: and a diverse range of   experiences and skill sets that will contribute to Apple's AR   vision.This all comes shortly after IDC recentlypredictedthat while virtual reality (VR) may be the early winner in the   AR/VR race
column14: AR very likely has greater revenue opportunities over   the long term.In other AR newsFacebook may be prioritizing VR with Oculus
column15: but a report   yesterday fromBusiness Insiderdetails some of the social network's other hardware projects   within its Building 8 division. Facebook has been ramping its   hardware efforts
column16: and has no less than four projects that it is   currently pursuing
column17: notably including one that involves cameras   and AR. The company is betting big that the next big computing   revolution will come in the form of VR and/or AR
column18: and being   relatively new on the tech behemoth scene
column19: it is determined to   help shape the technology.Once upon a time
column20: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) was the poster child for AR with   Google Glass. While Google Glass flopped on the consumer front
column21: NPRreports that Google Glass is still very much in use in industrial   settings. Manufacturing companies are exploring ways to improve   productivity with Google Glass and AR
column22: which allow workers to   access more information more easily while still being able to use   their hands. Workers previously used tablets
column23: but wearable AR   technology delivers many of the same benefits.In the coming years
column24: the AR front is going to get a whole lot   more exciting -- and crowded.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Twitter Bot Scandal Puts Further Pressure On CEO Jack Dorsey;3/20/2017;"Jack Dorsey
column2: CEO of Twitter Inc.TWTR
column3: is facing another problem in convincing advertisers to return to Twitter
column4: as new research showed that up to 15% of Twitter's 319 million users can be bots rather than human.The research was conducted by University of Southern California and Indiana University. Researchers used more than 1
column5: 000 features to identify bot accounts on Twitter. It was estimated that between 9% and 15% of active Twitter accounts are bots.The estimate of 15% is almost twice of Twitter's own estimates. In Twitter's Q4 earnings
column6: the company reported up to 8.5% of accounts could be bots.Twitter is hit particularly hard by this research because the company is already struggling to persuade advertisers to come back. Dorsey
column7: one of the site's co-founders
column8: came back in 2015 as chief executive and hopes to turn around the company's fortune; however
column9: little progress has been made.The company is still far away from making its first profit and stale user growth.The loss from operation of fourth quarter was  $143 million
column10: compared to $67 million during the same time last year. Twitter also reported just 4% growth to 319 million monthly active users year-over-year.The company's performance and the bot scandal puts further pressure on Dorsey to step down as Twitter's CEO.A Twitter spokesperson recognized that bot accounts often have negative connation but can be extremely beneficial
column11: like those that automatically alert people of natural disasters or from customer service points of view.While the researchers agreed on the benefits of the bot accounts
column12: they also pointed out
column13: ""there is a growing record of malicious applications of social bots. Some emulate human behavior to manufacture fake grassroots political support… and promote terrorist propaganda and recruitment.""This is a problem that not only Twitter is having but all social media platforms

column1: Google's Rating Cut Over YouTube Ad Placements;3/20/2017;"Alphabet Inc.GOOGL
column2: the parent company of Google
column3: received a downgrade today to ""Hold"" from ""Buy"" by Pivotal Research analyst Brian Wieser. The reason for the rating cut centered on the placement of YouTube's ads. Some ad buyers had voiced that their ads appeared next to videos carrying homophobic or terroristic videos on YouTube.This has become a large problem for Google in the UK

It is capable of interacting with smart home products
column8: such as the Philips Hue smart light bulbs and smart thermostats from Alphabet-owned Nest.Amazon has been continuously adding new features to its Echo devices. column1: Uber's President Quits: Are IPO Plans Toast?;3/20/2017;"Ride-hailing giant Uber Technologies confirmed on Sunday that   its president
column2: Jeff Jones
column3: has resigned.Jones
column4: hired just six months ago
column5: was the second-highest   ranking executive at Uber after CEO and founder Travis Kalanick.   His decision to leave Uber follows the departure of two other   Uber executives in recent weeks
column6: and a growing list of scandals   and challenges that calls into question when -- or whether --   Silicon Valley's most valuable private company will be able to go   public.The challenges facing Uber include an important lawsuit over     its self-driving technology. Image source: Uber     Technologies.makeArticleAd();Two explanations for Jones's departureWhy Jones left depends on who you ask.If you ask Uber
column7: or at least Kalanick
column8: Jones' decision to   depart followed an announcement that Uber has decided to seek a   strong chief operating officer to assist Kalanick in running the   compnay. In a note to Uber staff on Sunday
column9: Kalanick said that   Jones ""came to the tough decision that he doesn't see his future   at Uber"" after the announcement
column10: according to a Recodereport.But if you ask Jones
column11: it was a little more complicated. In a   statement provided to Recode
column12: Jones said
column13: ""It is now clear
column14: however
column15: that the beliefs and approach to leadership that have   guided my career are inconsistent with what I saw and experienced   at Uber
column16: and I can no longer continue as president of the   ride-sharing business.""Why Jones might have decided to get out nowFor starters
column17: Uber's decision to seek a COO was spurred by an   embarrassing video that showed Kalanick arguing with an Uber   driver over fare reductions that the driver claimed had hurt his   income. It also followed a former Uber employee's serious
column18: credible allegationof a pattern of sexual harassment at the company.Uber has hired two outside law firms to conduct investigations   related to the former employee's claims. One will investigate her   claims specifically
column19: the other is conducting a broader   investigation into Uber's workplace practices.In what may be related developments
column20: two other executives have   departed recently:Uber's senior vice president of engineering
column21: Amit Singhal
column22: resigned after a reporter from Recodeinformed the companythat Singhal had left a prior job at Google following a     ""credible"" allegation of sexual harassment.Uber's vice president of product and growth
column23: Ed Baker
column24: also     resigned following allegations that he had been seenkissing an Uber employeeat a company event.There's more.The New York Timesreportedearlier this month that Uber has been using a software tool   called ""Greyball"" to deceive authorities in markets where its   service had been pressured by law enforcement or banned.And in perhaps the most dangerous development for the future   of Uber's business
column25: Alphabet's Waymo self-driving subsidiary has sued Uber
column26: claiming that the   head of Uber's self-driving research program
column27: Anthony   Levandowski
column28: took proprietary technology secrets with him when he   left Google in early 2016 to found self-driving truck start-up   Otto
column29: which Uberacquired last summer. Waymo is seeking to halt Uber's self-driving operations. (Uber   has called Waymo's allegations ""baseless
column30: but hasn't yet   responded in detail.)Long story short: Uber's growth story could be in serious   trouble.The latest sign that Uber could be in serious troubleTaken together
column31: the recent reports paint a picture of a   company where sexual harassment is tolerated
column32: laws are seen as   inconveniences to be circumvented
column33: and a showcase technology   effort might be based on stolen secrets.That's all bad for obvious reasons
column34: and for one reason that   might be a little less obvious: Like all tech companies
column35: Uber is   in a constant battle to hire and retain top talent. These kinds   of stories hurt.Jones
column36: who had come to Uber fromTargetjust six months ago
column37: apparently decided that he had seen enough.   But his departure raises a big question: What will Uber's   valuation look like the next time it has to raise money -- or   when it attempts to go public?10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column9: the figure will increase to $383.3 billion by 2020.Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) is projected to be the highest growth service driven by improvement in PaaS and massive adoption of artificial intelligence (AI)

The new company will offer IaaS and Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) to Chinese enterprises and businesses. Reportedly
column16: IBM will have a share in revenues.Moreover
column17: as a part of the deal

column19: which will allow developers to add natural language interactions between applications and client.ConclusionDespite lagging in competition
column20: we believe that IBM is developing a niche for its hybrid cloud services along with ""Strategic Imperatives"" (cognitive computing
column21: Artificial Intelligence
column22: Machine Learning).IBM Watson on Cloud is a key growth driver in IoT
column23: healthcare and financial services end-markets. IBM Watson is anticipated to reach more than 1 billion people by the end of 2017. Moreover
