column1: What Is the Internet of Things?;3/18/2017;"Defining the Internet of Things (IoT) can be simplified down   to the connection of everyday things -- like homes
column2: industrial   equipment
column3: watches
column4: etc. -- to the internet
column5: for the purpose of   collecting data
column6: tracking usage
column7: and automating systems. While it   encompasses many technological devices
column8: it's important to   remember that the Internet of Things spans across all major   sectors. The amount of connected IoT objects will reach 50   billion by 2020 and will be worth $7.1 trillion by that same   year.Now that you know a little more about what the IoT is
column9: let's   take a look at how companies are using the IoT right now
column10: and a   few IoT examples you might not know about.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();You've probably already seen the IoT in actionIf you've ever seen anApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) Watch or an internet-connectedFitbitfitness tracker
column11: then you're familiar with the Internet of   Things. These devices fall into the broader wearable technology   market and they're what many people think of when they think of   the IoT.Or perhaps you've heard of a Nest programmable thermostat.Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)  owns Nest
column12: which makes   internet-connected thermostats that you can control via a   smartphone or tablet
column13: and learns your heating and cooling   preferences the more you use it.Both Alphabet andAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) are also pushing the Internet of Things into homes   with their smart home hubs
column14: like Google Home and the Amazon Echo.   Both devices use virtual assistants to answer questions
column15: order   things online
column16: or connect to door locks
column17: lights
column18: and home   security systems. Connected homes are a major part of the   consumer side of the IoT
column19: and will bring in $14 billion in   revenue this year in the U.S.Smartwatches
column20: internet-connected fitness trackers
column21: and smart   home connections are just a few examples of how companies are   investing in the IoT. While there are lots of companies betting   on the Internet of Things
column22: here's a quick list of some of the   biggest players.CompanyIoT FocusMarket CapAppleSmartwatches$729 billionAlphabetSmartwatches

column37: along with sensors

column39: and cloud services to   track the efficiency of seed planting. This type of agricultural   technology is transforming how food is grown and how farmers   manage their fields and equipment.Many other non-tech companies are also jumping into the IoT as   well. General Electric
column40: the 125-year-old conglomerate
column41: has   developed its own analytics software for industrial equipment. GE   uses its software to help its customers manage their equipment   more efficiently and anticipate when it needs to be fixed.Scottish and Southern Energyuses GE's Reliability Management software to track its   equipment and maintain uptime
column42: which saves the company an   estimated $3.6 million dollars every year.What the Internet of Things needs to growIn order for more devices
column43: equipment

Verizon is at the forefront of this change and   said last year that its upcoming 5G network will help address the   IoT's network needs. Verizon will roll out pilot tests of   its 5G network in 11 cities across the U.S. in the first half of   this year.While there's often a lot of hype around new technologies
column46: it's clear that companies are already taking the IoT seriously   and finding ways to use connected devices and software to offer   better products and services. And if this year is any indicator

column1: This Week in Solar;3/18/2017;"The solar industry had another busy week with a number of   announcements and earnings reports from some of the largest   companies in the business. It was so eventful
column2: in fact
column3: that I   can't cover everything in this week's roundup
column4: but I can hit the   items investors most need be aware of.As the solar industry evolves into a more mature market and   players define where they think they'll have a competitive   advantage
column5: it's time for investors to start looking at where   companies fit into the market and whether they'll have a   profitable future. With that context in mind
column6: here are the   notable news items from the solar industry this week.X-Series solar panels on a residential rooftop. Image     source: SunPower.makeArticleAd();SunPower signs a P-Series supply dealSunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) has been laying out its plans for the future
column7: and   a central piece of its strategy is based on combining the   P-Series solar panel (which uses commodity cells to create a   slightly higher efficiency ""commodity-plus"" panel) with the Oasis   power plant design. The company is essentially transitioning from   the utility-scale project-building business to supplying   pre-engineered solutions to developers
column8: like utilities. The   strategy makes sense
column9: but we had yet to see much indication that   it was taking hold in the market... until this week.SunPower signed a 125 MW supply agreement withNextEra Energy(NYSE: NEE) to provide its P-Series modules to the developer   between June and October of this year. There wasn't any   disclosure about whether the deal included the Oasis tracking   system or any design services
column10: but even if it's just a panel   supply agreement
column11: it would be a positive sign.If deals like this continue to come through in 2017 and   SunPower is able to supply panels and other services to   developers on short lead times
column12: it would be an immensely positive   development. One deal isn't a confirmation that the   P-Series/Oasis strategy is a success
column13: but it's a step in the   right direction for SunPower shareholders.Google takes Sunroof nationwideAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google subsidiary started the   Project Sunroof initiative in 2015 to try to give customers and   installers an easy view of the solar potential of homes around   the country. Initially
column14: the project covered just a few cities
column15: but the idea was to eventually roll it out nationwide. This week
column16: that happened.Project Sunroofnow allows people across the country to quickly view an outline   of their home's solar potential
column17: and get an idea of what a solar   system might cost them. Installers can be plugged into the search   to make sales easier
column18: and I would expect some will even use it as   a tool to target sales opportunities. This is one big example of   how solar is becoming a little easier for customers to understand   and see as accessible
column19: particularly outside of traditional solar   hubs such as California and Massachusetts.Trina Solar goes privateIn a deal that has been in the works for months
column20: Trina Solar   was finally taken private this week. The $11.60-per-share offer   made by a group led by the CEO looked to be on shakier ground   late last year as solar panel prices plunged and demand in the   solar market declined
column21: particularly in China.I questioned whether or not the deal would go through given   the questionable history of Chinese buyout offers and the decline   in the market overall. But Trina Solar is now private
column22: and the   fact that the deal went through may mean management sees a   brighter future than many investors currently do.Takeaways from earnings seasonEarnings season is about over for the solar industry
column23: and   afterJA Solar(NASDAQ: JASO) andVivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR)reported this week
column24: there were a few major takeaways from the end of 2016 and early   2017.Chinese solar panel manufacturers are down
column25: but not out.     Gross margins in the fourth quarter were in the low to mid     teens at most manufacturers
column26: and while profitability generally     dropped
column27: they were able to cut costs and remain near breakeven     levels.National residential solar companies are generally in     decline and having a tough time transitioning to a market where     loan and cash sales are the dominant financing option.Sunrunis the one company that has doubled down on leasing
column28: and it's     currently going well for the company. But withSolarCityand Vivint Solar seeing installations decline
column29: there's a lot of     uncertainty about what the residential solar industry will look     like in the future.Technology improvements are coming
column30: and those who stand pat     will eventually get run over. Whether it's First Solar     upgrading from Series 4 to Series 6 solar panels
column31: SunPower     discontinuing most of its mid-level E-Series production in     favor of its high-efficiency X-Series
column32: or the advance of     mono-PERC
column33: efficiency matters more than ever in the solar     industry.That's all for this week in solar. Check back to Fool.com next   week for more about the biggest events in the solar industry.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Investors Are Betting Against U.S. Concrete -- Here's Why They're Wrong;3/18/2017;"The construction industry is highly cyclical. When the general   economy is doing well
column2: or even booming
column3: the industry usually   isn't far behind. When growth slows or a recession strikes
column4: the   appetite for construction projects takes a big hit. Luckily for   investors
column5: we're currently in the midst of a broad economic   expansion.That has made construction companies
column6: and specifically those   of cement and concrete manufacturers
column7: some of the best-performing   stocks over the last three years.Vulcan MaterialsandMartin Marietta Materialshave nearly tripled the returns of the S&P 500 during that   period
column8: while the smallerU.S. Concrete(NASDAQ: USCR) has gained an incredible 181%.Although there are great fundamentals supporting the stock's   rise
column9: investors appear to be suspicious. Slightly over 28% of the   the company's shares are traded short
column10: according to numbers   compiled by Yahoo! Finance. There's no denying that shares have   outperformed most other stocks
column11: but I think investors are wrong   to bet against U.S. Concrete. Here's why.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Why short-sellers are wrongThe stock trades at an eye-popping 125 times trailing   earnings
column12: but there's an innocent
column13: if not downright weird
column14: explanation. It may sound odd
column15: but the better the stock performs
column16: the bigger the company's GAAP net loss becomes. That's because   U.S. Concrete must account for non-cash derivative gains and   losses from fair value changes in its issued warrants when the   stock price moves down or up
column17: respectively
column18: in any given   period.The good news is that recent quarterly GAAP net losses have no   impact on the company's cash position and have not had major   impacts on the share price. The great news is that operations   have maintained a strong level of performance for several years   in a row.U.S. Concrete notched $75 million in operating income and   $1.17 billion in revenue in 2016. Those metrics grew 235% and   95%
column19: respectively
column20: from the performance achieved three years ago.   Operating cash flow reached $112 million last year
column21: which was   well above the $24 million achieved in 2013.In other words
column22: the stock has certainly earned its 181% gain   in the last three years.USCRdata byYCharts.That said
column23: there's a strong case to be made that the company's   growth isn't over. Unlike other cement and concrete   manufacturers
column24: U.S. Concrete has strategically (and almost   exclusively) focused on major metropolitan areas in Texas
column25: New   York/New Jersey
column26: and northern California. Those markets were   responsible for 38%
column28: and 25%
column29: respectively
column30: of total revenue   in 2016. There are several advantages to that strategy that   short-sellers may be overlooking.First
column31: it allows the company to strategically acquire assets   to become a major and dominant player in each region and city.   Consider that in 2016 alone
column32: U.S. Concrete acquired four smaller   ready-mix concrete operators in the Bronx
column33: Queens
column34: and Brooklyn.   The acquisitions provided the company with 10 ready-mix concrete   plants and 189 mixer trucks. In addition to swiping away   competition
column35: the acquisitions allow the company to make more   competitive bids on larger projects. And in New York City
column36: there   are some pretty big projects.In fact
column37: the company supplied the concrete that built the new   World Trade Center Complex
column38: including Freedom Tower
column39: which was   the highest height concrete has ever been pumped in North   America. Expansions at LaGuardia Airport and the Modern Museum of   Art were also aided by the company
column40: as are other major ongoing   projects in the New York
column41: Dallas-Fort Worth
column42: and San Francisco   metropolitan areas.Second
column43: extending its leadership position in each major market   allows U.S. Concrete to have a greater influence on product   pricing. The fourth quarter of 2016 marked the 23rd straight   quarter that the company achieved year-over-year ready-mix   concrete price increases. That has an obviously beneficial impact   on revenue and margins
column44: and it has played a huge role in the   company's industry-leading margins in the ready-mix concrete   segment. Whereas the average material spread margin in the   industry was 45% last year
column45: U.S. Concrete achieved 49.2%.US Industrial Production: Cementdata byYCharts.Third
column46: operating in urban environments allows the company to   benefit from environmental considerations and initiatives
column47: such   as LEED building certifications. Humans manufacture more cement   than any other material. Unfortunately
column48: cement is also one of the   most carbon-intensive materials to produce
column49: accounting for 5% oftotal global CO2 emissionseach year. While certain materials can be substituted into cement   production processes
column50: they can significantly alter the   performance of mixed concrete. In other words
column51: it's not easy   being green.Luckily
column52: U.S. Concrete is a leading producer of low CO2   concrete. The company's EF Technology can reduce the greenhouse   gas emissions associated with cement production by between 42%   and 46%. Today
column53: over 30% of concrete used by the company benefits   from the technology. That allows it to place highly competitive   bids on major construction projects with LEED requirements -- an   increasingly important consideration. That's especially true in   environmentally conscious San Francisco
column54: where the company has   won projects including the Google Bayview Campus
column55: the Workday   Campus
column56: and even the Golden State Warriors Arena.What does it mean for investors?It takes a bit of digging around the company's primary   strategy and the driving forces for the industry at large
column57: but I   think short-sellers are wrong about this stock. The only way   short-sellers could be right about U.S. Concrete stock is if the   American economy heads for a slowdown
column58: which would have much   broader consequences. While that's not impossible -- in fact
column59: with recessions occurring every eight years or so
column60: we're ""due""   for one -- it's unlikely to sneak up on investors. The company   works off of a backlog of projects that are agreed to years   prior
column61: which provides fair warning to shareholders of potential   trouble on the horizon. Right now
column62: though
column63: there appears to   be consistent growth ahead for the foreseeable future.10 stocks we like better than US ConcreteWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Microsoft and Alphabet Are Catching Up to Amazon in the Cloud;3/17/2017;"Amazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) all-important Amazon Web Services (AWS) segment   has been the undisputed leader of cloud infrastructure
column2: by far
column3: for years. The most recent third-party estimate from Canalys pegs   AWS global market share at nearly 34% in the fourth quarter
column4: larger than the next three largest competitors --Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column5: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column6: andIBM-- combined (31%).Competition is heating up
column7: and rivals are starting to chip   away at AWS' dominance.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();AWS is hugely important to the Amazon thesisThat's the underlying theme of a research note from Pacific   Crest (viaTech Trader Daily). Analyst Brent Bracelin is reiterating an overweight rating but   slightly reducing his price target from $905 to $895
column8: while   expressing some concern that Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud are   starting to catch up and ""becom[e] more viable."" The software and   search giants both continue to invest heavily in their cloud   offerings
column9: both in terms of technical capability as well as   geographic expansion and reach.Since AWS is immensely more profitable that Amazon's core   e-commerce business
column10: its results carry a disproportionate weight   when it comes to the bottom line
column11: and strong AWS performance has   been a key driver of Amazon's rally over the past two years
column12: which has seen shares more than double.AMZNdata byYCharts.Microsoft Azure is making inroads at large enterprise   customers and government agencies
column13: which are increasingly   transitioning their needs away from their own data center   infrastructures and toward public cloud platforms. Google Cloud   has scored a high-profile win inSnap
column14: which has committed to spending $2 billion with the search   giant and is onlyusing AWS as a backup. Google also recently announced a handful of other big wins for   its cloud business.Bracelin still believes that AWS has a ""multiyear competitive   lead
column15: despite rivals starting to catch up in different ways. As   a result
column16: he is tempering his expectations for growth for the   next two years. Overall
column17: the analyst considers decelerating   growth a ""minor concern
column18: but it's definitely something that   should be on investors' radar.Rising cloud use lifts all infrastructure vendorsIt's worth pointing out that the cloud infrastructure market   is growing so fast -- up 49% last year and expected to jump   another 46% this year -- that there should be plenty to go   around. The cloud infrastructure market could generate a total of   $55.8 billion in total revenue this year. Of course
column19: the dominant   vendors will compete aggressively
column20: but we're not talking about   zero-sum competition.10 stocks we like better than AmazonWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 3 Companies Set to Make a Killing From Driverless Cars;3/17/2017;"Driverless car technology is still in its nascent stage but   will grow in leaps and bounds in the coming years. IHS Automotive   forecasts that autonomous vehicle sales will shoot up from   600
column2: 000 units in 2025 to almost 21 million by 2035
column3: clocking a   compound annual growth rate of 43%.The Boston Consulting Group
column4: meanwhile
column5: expects the driverless   car market to create a $42 billion revenue opportunity in 2025   itself
column6: indicating that there is a lot of money to be made in   this space. One of the ways to tap this huge opportunity is   through technology providers such asAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column7: Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column8: andNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA)
column9: as they will play mission-critical roles in   enabling autonomous cars.NVIDIA's GPUs are boosting self-driving technologyNVIDIA is best known for making gaming graphics cards
column10: but its   products are in high demand from automakers as well.Tesla
column11: for instance
column12: is using the chipmaker's artificial   intelligence-based DRIVE PX2 platform in the Model S and Model X   cars. What's more
column13: the automaker is also going to deploy NVIDIA's   supercomputer in its mass-market Model 3.makeArticleAd();The Tesla partnership is already delivering results
column14: as   NVIDIA's automotive revenue shot up over 37% year over year for   the fiscal fourth quarter. The company could sustain its   automotive momentum
column15: as it is working with German giant Audi to   bring a Level 4 autonomous car to the market by 2020. Level 4   means it can drive itself entirely on its own.The two companies showcased an Audi Q7 at CES earlier this   year
column16: claiming that the car learned to drive on its own in just   four days using NVIDIA's AI-based DRIVE PX2 supercomputer. More   importantly
column17: NVIDIA is looking to push the envelope: It's now   working on a more advanced supercomputing platform -- Xavier --   that consumes less power but packs more computing capacity.NVIDIA's graphics processing units accelerate the processing   of huge amounts of data in real time
column18: allowing the vehicle to   make quick decisions. As the company increasingly turns its   attention toward making its self-driving supercomputers better   through partnerships with big auto companies
column19: it won't be   surprising if its platform ends up powering fully autonomous cars   by 2020.NVIDIA
column20: therefore
column21: looks right on the edge of tapping the   driverless car opportunity
column22: as 80 companies are using the DRIVE   PX2 platform to develop their technology.Microsoft's big data opportunityDriverless cars
column23: or any connected car for that matter
column24: will   generate huge volumes of data from their sensors and cameras that   will need storage and processing. Microsoftwants to ingestall this data and then use its artificial intelligence (AI)   skills to analyze it to help cars drive better through its Azure   cloud-based Connected Vehicle Platform.Image source: Microsoft.The Redmond-based company has picked a sweet spot to tap the   driverless car opportunity
column25: as a connected vehicle is slated to   produce 20 gigabytes of data per day in 2017 if driven for just   two hours. In the case of autonomous cars
column26: the data generation   could be at least 10 gigabytes per second. Now
column27: all this data   can't be stored on the car itself due to limited storage   capacity
column28: creating an opportunity for Microsoft to push its cloud   product to automakers.TheRenault-Nissanalliance has already decided to use the software giant's   connected vehicle platform
column29: pledging to put 10 cars with   autonomous technology on the road by 2020. Additionally
column30: Indian   automakerTata Motorsis adopting the platform to bring connectivity   features and predictive maintenance at affordable prices to   mass-market vehicles in India.Microsoft is also finding demand for its connected car   platform beyond automakers. For instance
column31: reinsurance provider   Swiss Re will analyze driving behavior with the help of the   telematics data collected by the cloud
column32: and then create   customized insurance deals for customers.The inevitable data increase from driverless and connected   cars could power Microsoft's Azure cloud business to new highs in   the long run
column33: allowing it to sustain rapid revenue growth from   this segment.Image source: Waymo.Alphabet's Waymo moonshot could be a big businessAlphabet's Waymo division has thebest driverless cartechnology
column34: according to data from the California DMV. As it   turns out
column35: its driverless cars have the lowest incidence rates   and the highest miles logged compared to the others testing their   technology on California roads.Alphabet can use its lead in this space by becoming an   infrastructure and knowledge supplier to auto companies
column36: and this   is what it is probably planning to do. Earlier this year
column37: Waymo   announced that it is going to manufacture   driverless-technology-enabling sensors on its own so that it can   better integrate the software into hardware.In fact
column38: the Waymo division has slashed the price of the   crucial LIDAR sensor by 90% since 2009
column39: so it makes sense for it   to offer a packaged hardware-software bundle to potential   customers. The company has already gained a customer in the form   ofFiat Chrysler Automobilesfor its self-driving technology
column40: with Bloombergreportingthat both companies could eventually roll out a ride-sharing   service.On the other hand
column41: Hondaseems to be warming up to Waymo's self-driving capabilities to   accelerate its own driverless car development. The Japanese   automaker is now exploring the possibility of equipping its cars   with fully autonomous driving technology in cities instead of its   earlier ambition of just highway driving.Therefore
column42: Alphabet's years of leadership in driverless cars   make it one of the hottest prospects to benefit from this   emerging technology.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column1: The Gmail Phishing Scam Fooling Even the Internet-Savvy;3/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere's a new Gmail phishing scam that is crafty enough to fool even well-versed internet users.makeArticleAd();Source:YouTubeThe new Gmail phishing scam includes an image that looks almost exactly like theAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: GOOGL) company's own attachment image. However
column4: this is only a trick to gain a user's login credentials.When a person that is the target of the Gmail phishing scam clicks on the image in the email
column5: it will take them to a page that looks almost identical to Google's own login page. Once the person enters their email and password into the fake website
column6: their account can be taken over.This Gmail phishing scam has been around for a few months now
column7: but has started gaining additional attention following coverage fromLifehacker. Those with acute eyes may be able to notice the hack due to the URL being incorrect for Google's login screen.If users don't notice the URL change when being taken to the fake Google login screen
column8: then they may get caught by this Gmail phishing scam. Users of Chrome that keep it regularly updated will see a warning when visiting a site like this
column9: but other web browsers may not warn the user of the scam.The Gmail phishing scam was originally discovered byWordfenceback in January. It suggests that users with fears that their accounts may have been hit in the hack should check their login history to see where their accounts have been accessed from. The website also advises changing passwords every few months
column10: just to be safe.More From InvestorPlace7 Telecom Stocks That Are High-Yield Money Traps10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump Now7 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeThe postThe Gmail Phishing Scam Fooling Even the Internet-Savvyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Privacy Revamp Makes Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Even More Attractive;3/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsScore one for civil liberties. This week
column3: social networking giantFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) overhauled its privacy policies
column4: blocking police departments from using the siteas a means of keeping tabs on users who may also be associated with violent protesting.makeArticleAd();On the surface
column5: it may seem irrelevant to the current and future value of Facebook stock. Most members of the ad-driven platform know they're of no interest to law enforcement officials
column6: and the protestors that were making themselves known on the social media site likely didn't know they were being watched (and therefore didn't alter the way and frequency with which they used the website).In other words
column7: so what?Thing is
column8: it's more than conceivable there were enough users of the Facebook platform that had been steering clear due to privacy concerns - just on principle - to expect them to log on now that their privacy is being protected.Privacy Remains Contentious TopicIt's neither a new debate
column9: nor is it a minor one.Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)battled the FBI early last yearover the bureau's request that the company unlock an iPhone as part of a terrorism investigation.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column10: NASDAQ:GOOG) has long been deemed to be too intrusive
column11: keeping a detailed dossier on everyone who uses Google and its servicesthat facilitates more target marketing.EvenWal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT) is getting in on the snooping act
column12: using cameras to watch what shoppers pick up in stores
column13: and then put down without purchasing.So
column14: in the grand scheme of things
column15: it's not difficult to believe that Facebook was looking the other way when it knew law enforcement officials were using its platform as a new tool in the war on crime.7 Dividend Stocks With Yields That Grow Like WeedsThe question Facebook stock holders should be asking: At what point does accommodating every policy and agency request make the website too alarming for even the average user to visit?The American Civil Liberties Union asked the question
column16: and thenanswered it in a way that put Facebook in a questionable light. The company responded with a change in its policy.New Policies Curtail PinpointingAs of Monday
column17: police and other law enforcement agenciescan no longer tap Geofeedia's data
column18: which was built to pinpoint where Facebook users are - Facebook completely cut off Geofeedia's access to the site. It's not necessarily a permanent hurdle
column19: but it is one that will remain in place indefinitely on the location-based analytics platform.Facebook's deputy chief privacy officer Rob Sherman commented: ""Our goal is to make our policy explicit.""New PageThe clarified policy does not preclude FB from assisting law enforcement officials on a case-by-case basis. Indeed
column20: the company says it still intends to assist police when appropriate. Presumably
column21: this would mean instances where a search warrant has been issued
column22: which requires a reasonable suspicion that retrieving such information would help lead to a successful prosecution.Twitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) and Facebook unit Instagram also booted Geofeedia from using their websites to gather and sell user information following the ACLU's exposure of the organization's invasive tactics.Bottom Line for Facebook StockOn the surface it seems like a potential setback for Facebook
column23: and by extension for Facebook stock. One of the most compelling features of the social media platform to advertisers was the deep
column24: broad
column25: and well-defined data the company could collect about each and every user.If it's scaling that detail back - and presumably it's doing so to more developers than just Geofeedia - then the potential value to advertisers is crimped.Amgen
column26: Inc. (AMGN) Stock Crashed. Here's How to Trade.Don't overthink it
column27: though
column28: and don't assume there's a cut-and-dried if/then relationship between how invasive a website can be and how valuable detailed user data is to an advertiser. They say they want stratification
column29: but many advertisers are content to promote their product or service to any reasonably targeted consumer.On the other hand
column30: consumers are more apt to use caution when it comes to websites that may nefariously collect data on a consumer
column31: even without their consent or knowledge. People have a decent sixth sense when it comes to being unreasonably monitored.In other words
column32: a FB that's more interested in basic civil rights is a better investment than one that's not. The trade-off is more than palatable.As of this writing

column1: Google and Facebook Will Account for 74% of Digital Ad Growth in 2017;3/17/2017;"Marketers will continue to shift a larger percentage of their   ad budgets to digital in 2017. U.S. digital ad spending is   expected to reach $83 billion this year

column1: 5 Signs Snap Inc's High Growth Days are Over;3/17/2017;"Snap(NYSE: SNAP)
column2: the parent company of Snapchat
column3: made its public   debut on March 3
column4: and the results were underwhelming. Snap made   its public debut at $17
column5: surged to nearly $30 on the first day
column6: then tumbled back to just over $20 in less than two weeks.Why did investors seemingly snub Snap
column7: which some bulls have   hailed as the ""nextFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) ""? The answer is simple -- six red flags indicate   that the stock could slide much lower before it's considered a   bargain.Snap's Android app. Image source: Google Play.makeArticleAd();1. Slowing user growthThe decline ofTwitter's (NYSE:TWTR) stocktaught usthat social networks live and die by their active user growth.   Without active user growth
column8: advertisers start skipping the   platform in favor of faster growing ones. Snapchat's daily active   users (DAUs) rose just  3% sequentially to 158 million last   quarter
column9: compared to 7% growth in the third quarter and 17%   growth in the second quarter.That slowdown was likely caused by the launch of new   Snapchat-like features for Facebook's Instagram and Messenger   apps -- which include Instagram Stories
column10: vanishing Instagram   photos
column11: Instant Video for Messenger
column12: and a Messenger Day app   which deletes photos and videos after 24 hours. Instagram   Stories
column13: in particular
column14: grew its DAUs from 100 million to 150   million between last October and  this January.2. Its cash burn rateSnap's S-1 filing revealed that it finished fiscal 2016 with   just $150.1 million in cash and equivalents -- a 77% decline from   $640.8 million at the end of 2015. The company had a negative   operating cash flow of $188 million in the fourth quarter of   2016
column15: and it burned through $1.14 in cash for each dollar in    generated revenue.Snap will retain $2.3 billion of the $3.2 billion it    raised during its IPO. That amount will help Snap tread   water for a while
column16: but it might not last long if its cash burn   rate accelerates. Susquehanna analysts believe that Snap won't   achieve positive free cash flow until fiscal 2020. However
column17: that   estimate could be far too optimistic if rivals like Instagram   Stories continue throttling Snapchat's growth.3. Widening lossesSnap's revenue surged 590% to $404.5 million in 2016. But on   the bottom line
column18: its net losswidenedfrom $372.9 million to $514.6 million. The company's biggest   expenses include multi-billion dollar cloud contracts withAlphabet's Google andAmazon.If Snap can't narrow its losses with such massive revenue   growth
column19: things could getveryugly once its top line growth slows down. Snap has also warned in   its SEC filing that it ""may never achieve or maintain   profitability.""4. Unrealistic revenue growth targetsSnap claims that it can  generate $500 million to $1   billion in revenues in 2017. That's a very wide range
column20: but   analysts are modeling their forecasts on  the high-end
column21: with   an average estimate of $1.04 billion. However
column22: it's unclear how   Snap plans to hit that target.The three types of Snap ads. Image source: Snap.96% of Snap's revenue came from advertising in 2016. Snap's ad    products include full-screen video ads
column23: sponsored   geofilters
column24: and sponsored lenses. If Snap's user growth peaks
column25: it   could possibly boost its number of marketing partners to generate   higher ad revenues per customer. But more than doubling its 2016   revenues to $1 billion in 2017 seems like ahugestretch.Research firm eMarketer recently trimmed its 2017 ad    revenue forecast for Snapchat from $800 million to $770   million. That reduction was modest
column26: but it indicates that   analysts aren't certain that it can hit its ambitious growth   targets.5. It thinks it's a ""camera company""Co-founder and CEO Evan Spiegel has repeatedly declared that   Snap is different from other social networks because it's a   ""camera company."" Tthat statement sounded reasonable because it   produced special filters and lenses for smartphone cameras
column27: but   rivals like Instagram can easily make similar claims.Snap's Spectacles. Image source: Snap.Spiegel didn't say that Snap would sell physical cameras   anytime soon
column28: but the company launched its Spectacles   Snap-capturing glasses late last year. The devices attracted lots   of shoppers
column29: thanks to a clever marketing campaign featuring   vanishingvending machines.If Snap builds upon that idea
column30: it could start selling other   cheap image capture devices to build its brand and differentiate   itself from Instagram. However
column31: that move could cause it to burn   through its cash even faster and weigh down its bottom line with   a low-margin hardware business.Should you avoid Snap?Snap looks like a company that went public before it formed a   coherent roadmap toward positive cash flows and profitability.   Without the ability to reach those goals
column32: Snap remains an   incredibly overvalued stock at nearly 60 times sales.To put that into perspective
column33: Facebook had a P/S ratio of   about 10 at the close of its first trading day. Twitter ended its   first day with a P/S ratio of about 11. This means that Snap   could easily plummet to the single digits if investors realize   that this ephemeral emperor has no clothes.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: IBM Watson Health Inks Deal with MedyMatch for Healthcare AI;3/17/2017;"International Business Machines CorporationIBMowned Watson Health has recently inked a five-year agreement with MedyMatch

column3: IBM Watson Health will launch the MedyMatch brain bleeding detection application globally. Later
column4: the two companies will proceed toward integrating and achieving interoperability between IBM Watson Health's imaging offerings and MedyMatch's AI application.Reportedly
column5: IBM will incur several millions of dollars as recurring annual licensing fees to MedyMatch over the span of the agreement.Notably
column6: shares of IBM have underperformed the ZacksComputer - Integrated Systemsindustry over the last one year. While the industry gained a modest 24.3%
column7: the stock appreciated only 20.5%.The underperformance of the stock could be due to the time consuming transition to the cloud
column8: weakness in traditional businesses and lower IT spending worldwide. However

column1: Google Eyes Algorithm Enhancement, Flags "Offensive" Content;3/17/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle is reportedly taking steps to spot potentially upsetting or offensive content and reduce their appearance on the search results page. This will result in more accurate
column2: realistic and truthful information for users.Guidelines Updated With a New SectionGoogle uses around 10
column3: 000 contractors across the world as quality raters of its search results. The company has added the option of flagging ""Upsetting-Offensive"" content in its guidelines to these quality raters.They now can now flag content that promotes harmful activities such as discrimination or violence against any group of people
column4: animal cruelty
column5: child abuse
column6: racial slurs or human trafficking. Basically any hurtful or displeasing content may be flagged depending upon the motive of a search.The Broader Plan of Algorithm EnhancementData from quality raters will be used to train human coders (search algorithm writers) as well as update machine learning system on how to differentiate upsetting and offensive content from factual and appropriate ones.The broader aim is to make search algorithms capable of automatically flagging such content. This can happen if the algorithms better understand the motive of a particular search and display results accordingly.However
column7: that doesn't necessarily mean that that an offensive or upsetting content will not appear on the search results page. Rather
column8: the enhanced search algorithm will display results if it finds an explicit search being made for such content.We believe that Google's near-monopoly position in the search market is likely to drive Alphabet's stock price going ahead. Its shares have appreciated 15.2% in the last one year compared with the ZacksInternet-Servicesindustry'sgain of 11.6%.Our TakeWe believe that updates of this kind will improve Google's search quality and furnish quality results. The Google search engine is advanced

column1: Why This Market Researcher Lowered Its Revenue Expectations for Snap;3/16/2017;"Analysts haven't been kind toSnap(NYSE: SNAP) since it made its IPO. Not one analyst has given   Snap stock a buy rating
column2: and shares have fallen considerably from   its opening price at the beginning of the month.Most recently
column3: market researcher eMarketer lowered its   expectations for Snap's U.S. ad revenue from $800 million to $770   million. The reason behind the lower estimate is   ""higher-than-estimated revenue sharing with partners.""Snapchat offers revenue sharing as an incentive for content   publishers to use its Publisher Stories (formerly Discover)   format. Snap is also partnering with various media companies to   produce original shows
column4: which may provide even more favorable   revenue share for the content producer.makeArticleAd();Let's take a look at how revenue sharing affects Snap's   financials.Image source: Snap/Author.Revenue sharing doesn't impact Snap's top lineWhile eMarketer is lowering its expectations for Snapchat
column5: the   actual decline in net ad revenue won't show up in Snap's top   line. Snap reports gross revenue similarly to howAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) reports Google's revenue. Google   lumps in revenue from its network partners with its search and   YouTube revenue
column6: and then accounts for revenue sharing as part of   its traffic acquisition costs.The amount of revenue Snap shares with its publisher partners   is then reported as an item in the company's cost of revenue. So
column7: eMarketer may have well said it expects Snap's cost of revenue to   come in $30 million higher than originally anticipated.Snap's Publisher Stories. Image source: Snap.Last year
column8: Snap says revenue sharing payments increased $48.2   million from 2015
column9: but it doesn't provide a specific amount it   paid to partners. That does at least provide a floor
column10: and it's   nearly 12% of Snap's $404.5 million in total revenue last   year.For comparison
column11: Google paid out $10.9 billion in revenue   sharing to its network partners (not including YouTube) in 2016.   That's almost 14% of its total ad revenue for the year.Revenue sharing may increase even fasterWhile most analysts expect Snap to grow its top line to around   $1 billion this year
column12: its path to that mark may mean less of that   revenue makes it past the second line (cost of revenue) on its   income statement. Snap has inked several high-profile deals with   media companies over the last year.It already has deals in place with NBC
column13: ABC
column14: BBC
column15: Turner
column16: New   York Time
column17: Discovery
column18: Time
column19: A+E Networks
column20: and VICE to produce   original shows for Snapchat. Snap is still actively pursuing   these high-profile deals.It's important to note that Snap says its revenue-sharing   arrangements ""generally do not contain minimum financial   commitments to our publisher partners and are generally not tied   to specific events or promotions."" That seems to indicate Snap   doesn't pay anything up front for these productions
column21: but Snap may   help out with the costs as ""content creation costs"" also show up   in management's description of cost of revenue. Content creation   costs include personnel-related costs
column22: according to Snap's   S-1.With the growth of the Publisher Stories platform
column23: investors   should expect a stark increase in cost of goods sold due to   revenue-sharing and content-creation costs.Cost of revenue is already under scrutinySnap posted a negative gross margin last year as its cost of   revenue overshadowed its revenue. The biggest factor behind it is   Snap's hosting expenses
column24: for which it primarily relies on Google   Cloud. It's already committed to spending $3 billion in total on   cloud infrastructure over the next five years
column25: which will   continue to put pressure on Snap's gross margin as it tries to   scale.Add to that the fact that one of its revenue drivers is   growing content from publisher partners
column26: which contributes to   even more cost of revenue. While a few tens of millions of   dollars is relatively small compared to the hundreds of millions   Snap is spending with its cloud partners each year
column27: Snap's   margins are so thin that every dollar counts.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Better Buy: Intel Corporation vs. NVIDIA;3/16/2017;"Intel(NASDAQ: INTC) andNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) are titans of the same semiconductor industry
column2: born a generation apart. As in all human endeavors
column3: the only   constant in business is change
column4: and Intel and NVIDIA find   themselves today at different stages of their corporate life   cycles.Thanks to coming adoption of technologies such as self-driving   cars and artificial-intelligence (AI) software
column5: NVIDIA has seen   demand for its graphics chips move from a niche into the   mainstream. On the other hand
column6: Intel roared to global dominance   during the rise of PCs and mainframe servers
column7: but it has   struggled to tap into more recent growth markets such as mobile   computing
column8: deep learning
column9: and the like.So which is the better stock for you to buy today: Intel or   NVIDIA? Let's examine three different aspects for NVIDIA and   Intel to determine which companies' shares appear more attractive   today.makeArticleAd();Financial fortitudeThose same life-cycle differences reveal themselves in   assessing the financial strength of NVIDIA and Intel. Look at   these four important metrics of liquidity and solvency for both   companies.CompanyCash and InvestmentsDebtCash From OperationsCurrent RatioNVIDIA$6.8 billion$2.8 billion$1.7 billion4.7Intel$14.9 billion$25.2 billion$21.8 billion1.7Data sources: NVIDA and Intel investor relations; Yahoo!   Finance.NVIDIA easily beats Intel in terms of near-term liquidity --   as evidenced by its current ratio -- and in terms of net debt
column10: which is just a fancy accounting term for cash and equivalents   minus debt. That being said
column11: Intel's cash flow-generation   capabilities are staggering. Though $18.4 billion of its debt   will mature in 2022 or later
column12: Intel could easily erase the   majority of its leverage in a single year
column13: even after subtracting   the $9.6 billion it spent on capital expenditures in 2016.Intel is also an example of a company that uses debt
column14: or a   leveraged capital structure
column15: as a source of competitive   advantage. It's one of the few semiconductor companies that also   owns its chip fabrication plants; NVIDIA outsources its fab to a   consortium of partners includingTaiwan Semiconductor
column16: Samsung
column17: and more. Operating large fixed assets such as   semiconductor manufacturing plants requires plenty of capital
column18: which explains Intel's use of ample leverage. Either way
column19: both   companies are in fine financial shape
column20: given their respective   strategies
column21: so let's call this one a tie and move on.Winner: Tie.Image source: Getty Images.Durable competitive advantagesNVIDIA and Intel each enjoy meaningful competitive advantages   in their respective areas of the global semiconductor market.Sources estimate Intel controls 87% of the PC CPU market and   95% the server CPU market
column22: although the exact numbers aren't as   important as knowing that Intel dominates the global PC and data   center microprocessor markets
column23: and for a predictable reason:   Intel's longtime performance advantage over the competition --   namely
column24: Advanced Micro Devices(NASDAQ: AMD)  -- has allowed the company to charge higher   prices per unit for its chips.Intel plows an aggressive portion of its profits back into its   research and development
column25: which has
column26: in turn
column27: allowed it to   maintain the performance advantages of its chips. Barring   execution risks
column28: which have been a concern fromtime to time
column29: this long-standing trend has served as a virtuous cycle that   has allowed Intel to dominate its core markets and consistently   produce above-average profits for its shareholders.The dollar values involved help flesh this dynamic out a bit   more. In the past three years
column30: AMD's revenue has totaled $4.2   billion in 2016
column31: $3.9 billion in 2015
column32: and $5.5 billion in   2014. In contrast
column33: Intel's research-and-development budgetalonehas totaled $12.7 billion
column34: $12.1 billion
column35: and $11.5 billion over   the same period. This kind of structural advantage is   incredibly difficult to overcome.NVIDIA's competitive advantages are more technological than   structural at the moment. Because of its long-standing place as   the creator graphics computing
column36: on which it still focuses
column37: NVIDIA's chips have generally been the best of breed in each of   the graphics processing applications its products serve. The   company pressed that advantage with last year's debut of its   Pascal architecture
column38: around which it launched a number of new   chips.Better still
column39: NVIDIA has used its advantage to help   consolidate early leads in core growth markets such as AI   computing platforms and driverless cars. In recent years
column40: NVIDIA   has become the GPU supplier to the AI efforts atMicrosoft
column41: Facebook
column42: Amazon.com
column43: Alphabet
column44: andApple
column45: to name a few. Much has also been made of NVIDIA's potential in   self-driving cars
column46: where it supplies the graphics chips that   power the autonomous-vehicle efforts ofFord
column47: Tesla
column48: Volkswagen
column49: Honda
column50: and many more. Both of these industries figure to offer   substantial growth opportunities over the coming decade
column51: and   NVIDIA's place as the go-to supplier to support these emerging   technologies speaks to their compelling value proposition.Winner: NVIDIA.ValuationThe way the market is pricing Intel and NVIDIA shares should   come as little surprise
column52: given what we just learned about the   outlook for their businesses. Here's a snapshot of three of the   most commonly used valuation metrics for Intel and NVIDIA.CompanyP/EForward P/EEV/EBITDANVIDIA38.329.523.6Intel16.912.37.8Data source: Yahoo! Finance.Both companies also pay dividends: Intel shares currently   yield 2.9%; NVIDIA
column53: a mere 0.5%.As for which stock appears the more attractively valued
column54: I   think both companies appear reasonably valued
column55: given their   respective growth outlooks. The multiple trends fueling NVIDIA's   growth should support its earnings growth for arguably a decade   or more
column56: so its sky-high valuation shouldn't be a deterrent for   investors with a similarly long time horizon.As more of a mature company
column57: Intel will have its investment   outlook driven by its ability to grow its EPS and return excess   capital to shareholders. Its fantastic economics should allow it   to do so
column58: but it's hard to get excited about a company that   analysts see growing sales just 0.9% this year and 2% in   2018. So in terms of which company is more appropriately   valued
column59: I think both companies trade near prices that seem   fair.Winner: Tie.And the winner is... NVIDIA by a noseBoth companies present interesting value propositions to   investors today. Intel offers a mix of profitability and income   at a fairly discounted price
column60: which could prove compelling to   more conservative investors. However
column61: many of NVIDIA's growth   markets are in their early stages
column62: which makes it the more   attractive stock to own over the long term.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column31: Thailand

column1: An Uber IPO Will Be a Down Round;3/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmong venture capitalists a ""down round"" is defined as funding in a private company that carries a lower valuation than the previous investment.makeArticleAd();It means a company's investors are taking a loss. That's what is likely to happen whenUbergoes public.Right now
column3: Uber is said to be worth $69 billionafter taking losses of $2.2 billion during the first nine months of 2016. Its 2016 revenues were estimated at $5.5 billion
column4: and it is not unusual for fast-growing companies to sustain losses as they invest to keep the growth going.Valuing a company at 12.5 times revenue when it seems to be at the peak of its performance may seem to make sense for wealthy Silicon Valley investors
column5: but here in the real world
column6: we have a word for that kind of offer
column7: and the word is no.Trouble Ahead
column8: Trouble Behind for UberUber drivers are not employees. They are
column9: in theory
column10: business partners who pay Uber a commission to bring them work driving people around.They are unlicensed taxi driverswho don't pay for medallions and are thus subject to harassment by the government.10 Safe Dividend Stocks to Own During the Next Market CrashBut the Uber drivers I have met are incredibly professional
column11: and their cars are clean
column12: thanks in part to a""Vehicle Solutions""program that lets them rent
column13: lease or buy new or nearly new cars. This is how the company has grown.But relying on contractors carriesrisks. Uber is said to have a""toxic""work culture
column14: one rife with sexual abuse
column15: leading to aTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) campaign advocating thatcustomers delete the app.CEO Travis Kalanick described his corporate culture as""baller

column17: and political polarization now seems to be having an effect
column18: as rivalLyfthas reportedly grown7%in just the last two months

column22: the parent of Google andWaymo
column23: a self-driving car pioneer
column24: has filed a legal complaint charging thatUber stole Waymo's trade secretsby having an employee walk out with them
column25: founding a company called Otto
column26: then buying Otto for $700 million. If Alphabet wins the case
column27: it could take Uber completely out of that business.Uber is also challenging Google Maps
column28: pushing its own system on drivers
column29: one that will make their driving fit corporate needs. It also gives the company a direct online connection to drivers.Uber's fraught relations with competitors
column30: drivers and government is nowa global phenomenon. Competition from new entrants is also increasing
column31: even in Africa.The Bottom LineBuying Uber stock is based on a belief that the company will grow

column34: because Uber's ownership of the necessary intellectual property is under question.Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Is Flying High
column35: But Don't Go Contrarian Yet!The risk of venture capitalists holding companies through their period of maximum growth is always that they will hold on too long
column36: that they will be unable to exit the investment on their own timetable - that they will
column37: in the end

Treat Uber as the mature company it is.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud

column1: Google Home Is Catching Up to Amazon's Echo;3/16/2017;"Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) had a surprise hit on its hand with the Echo smart   speaker. After releasing it exclusively to Prime members in late   2014
column2: the device proved so popular that Amazon was able to   quickly open orders to everyone in the U.S. by the following   summer. On Christmas Eve of 2015
column3: the Echo was one of the top   five items ordered
column4: according to Amazon's annual holiday press   release. Last year
column5: Echo device sales climbed nine times compared   to 2015's holiday season.That's despite the November introduction of Google Home
column6: a   competing smart speaker from theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary. During Alphabet's   fourth-quarter earnings call
column7: RBC analyst Mark Mahaney suggested   Echo devices
column8: powered by the virtual assistant Alexa
column9: outsold   Google Home 10-to-1 in the quarter.But Mahaney is changing his tune after conducting a more   in-depth survey. ""Home's awareness and installed base could be   much closer to Alexa -- with a brand awareness in the U.S. 80%   that of Alexa and an installed base that may be close to a third   that of Alexa
column10: he recently wrote in a note.makeArticleAd();It looks like Google Home is quickly catching up to Amazon's   Echo.Image source: Google.Google plans to keep investing in Google HomeGoogle plans to keep making Google Home a better device by   improving its search capabilities and functionality. ""We are   going to invest a lot in it over 2017
column11: Google CEO Sundar Pichai   told investors on Alphabet's fourth-quarter earnings call. ""I   think there is a lot of work ahead to make all of this work well   for users. And this is the core area where we've invested in for   the very long term
column12: he added.Google intends to leverage its massive Android platform to   continue improving Google Assistant
column13: the artificial intelligence   (AI) behind Google Home. At least 200 million devices will have   access to the voice assistant
column14: which will provide Google with a   lot more opportunities to learn exactly what people are looking   for when they say
column15: ""OK

column18: 000-plus functionalities available with Alexa.   To that end

That still trails Amazon's sales by a   significant margin. The research group estimates Amazon sold 6.3   million Echo devices last year
column20: and that should go up   meaningfully in 2017. Mahaney estimates Amazon will sell 60   million Echo devices by 2020

column22: it's not clear device sales will follow a similar path. Google   Home lacks one of the key functionalities of Amazon's devices:   the ability to easily shop on Amazon.Seventeen percent of Echo owners use Alexa to place orders on   Amazon

column24: Mahaney expects the amount of shopping done via   Alexa on Amazon to grow as well. By 2020
column25: sales through the voice   assistant could reach $5 billion
column26: according to the analyst's   estimate.Google doesn't even have a business model for monetizing   Google Home beyond hardware sales. Search and display ads don't   work very well on a device with no display.Moreover
column27: Google doesn't offer a compelling differentiating   factor for consumers to pick its device over another smart   speaker. Comparatively
column28: Amazon Prime members
column29: of which there'sa rapidly growing number
column30: have lots of reasons to pick the Echo
column31: like easy access to   ordering things on Amazon or inexpensive use of Amazon Music   Unlimited.As such
column32: Amazon is poised to win the long-term competition   even if Google Home is catching up in the short term.10 stocks we like better than AlphabetWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Twitter's (TWTR) Prominent Accounts Hacked
column2: Shares Fall;3/16/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Reportedly
column3: Twitter IncTWTRwas in for a rude shock after some of its high profile accounts were hacked and used to post tweets in favor of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Shares went down nearly 2% to $15.03 yesterday.Per reports
column4: the accounts were not hacked from the main platform but from Twitter Counter
column5: an Amsterdam based third party statistics service for Twitter. Some of the prominent accounts hacked included pop sensation Justin Bieber's Japan account
column6: BBC North America
column7: Reuters Japan
column8: Forbes
column9: UNICEF
column10: Duke University
column11: Amnesty International and Starbucks Argentina. Tweets filled with swastika (Nazi symbol) and hashtags like ""NaziGermany"" and ""NaziHolland"" were sent from these compromised accounts.Currently
column12: it is uncertain as to who carried out this mass hacking.Turkey/Netherlands Face-offPer media reports
column13: Turkey and Netherlands are embroiled in a political spat ever since the latter barred Turkish ministers from attending a political rally in the country ahead of a referendum in Turkey. The rally was organized to gain support for Erdogan. Turkey is drawing up a new constitution that will significantly enhance the President's power and make the post of prime minister and vice president redundant. The referendum is scheduled to take place on Apr 16.Following the treatment meted out to its ministers
column14: Turkey has ""suspended high level ties"" with Netherlands as well as barred the Dutch ambassador from returning to Ankara. It has also labeled Dutch action as ""Nazi tactics"".Twitter
column15: Inc. PriceTwitter
column16: Inc. Price|Twitter
column17: Inc. QuoteTwitter's Trolling Trouble & MoreAnalysts observe that this incident is unlikely to cause much damage to Twitter but the increase in these types of occurrences (hacking
column18: fake news & hate speech) can prove detrimental.  Social media sites have come under tremendous scrutiny following the U.S presidential elections in 2016. FacebookFBand Twitter were accused of disseminating fake news resulting in surprising election results.Rising concerns have also come from Germany as the Social Democrat Party
column19: reportedly
column20: said it will fine social media companies 50 million euros ($53 million) for their inability to contain a hoax.  Since the beginning of the year
column21: German intelligence agencies have been on their toes as there are chances that fake news will alter election results. Reportedly
column22: Buzzfeed has found that there are several fake reports on Facebook about Angela Merkel
column23: who is campaigning for the fourth term as the chancellor.Twitter has been trying to contain the trolling menace that has plagued its platform for long now and possibly kept potential users as well as buyers at bay.Apart from taking down accounts of offenders
column24: Twitter also announced several measures to combat trolling. The company has improvised the ""mute"" button
column25: which will enable users to block tweets that include objectionable words
column26: phrases and conversations. Plus
column27: it has empowered users by giving them a ""more direct way of reporting"" hateful conduct. Twitter users can now report any hateful conduct that they come across on the platform. Per Twitter
column28: this ""helps reduce the burden on the person experiencing the abuse
column29: and helps to strengthen a culture of collective support on Twitter."" The company said that it is also ""retraining"" its staff to better tackle abusive behavior on the platform.Twitter cannot afford more troubles as it passes through one of the toughest phases in its corporate history. User growth is sluggish and advertising revenues are decelerating. Amid this entire fracas
column30: the exodus of high profile executives continues. In the past one year
column31: Twitter shares declined 10.18%
column32: as against 8.57% rise in the ZacksInternet Softwareindustry. Its CEO
column33: Jack Dorsey's focus on ""live"" and user friendly changes hasn't yet moved the needle for Twitter.To top it
column34: the widely expected takeover didn't materialize
column35: with interested parties like AlphabetGOOGL
column36: Salesforce and The Walt Disney CompanyDISpulling out last minute
column37: given the challenges that Twitter faces alongside trolling.At present

column1: Sound The Alarm
column2: ALRM is Headed Higher;3/15/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Get ready for some upward revisions to the earnings estimates ofAlarm.com( ALRM).  The stock is a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) right now but reported earnings after the close on Wednesday
column3: March 15.  The company posted revenues of $69.79M compared to the consensus of $63.95M.  EPS of $0.19 was $0.06 better than the Wall Street consensus estimate.In the release
column4: the company guided Wall Street higher.  FY2017 is now expected to produce revenue of between $322M to $325.5M and that is comfortably higher than the $300M consensus estimate.  The company expects to earn $0.73 to $0.75 for the year and that is also above the $0.65 consensus estimate.In late after hours trading
column5: I see the stock at $33.39 up $2.76 or about 9%.Estimates Likely Moving HigherWhen a company raises guidance over the consensus you can expect the analysts to adjust their models.  These models help them derive their earnings estimates which are used in the Zacks Rank.  Since there haven't been any earnings revisions over the last 60 days
column6: ALRM is a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).  In the coming days I anticipate the stock to see several upward revisions which should help boost the Zacks Rank for this stock to a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) or a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).AcquisitionsALRM made a few recent acquisitions and they were touched on during the conference call.  During the call
column7: management talked about how the ObjectVideo acquisition will allow customers to track cars and license plates or even customers in a store.The Icontrol Networks deal closed in the quarter and the company mentioned how the Piper unit powers a portion of the ADT platform.  The industry had been viewed as ""we versus ADT"" but that has changed with the advent of customer home protection services offered by cable companies.An analyst questioned if the company was looking to a product offering around cars
column8: and while the company would not commit on a specific answer
column9: it was clear that it could be something coming down the road.  Many times during the call management noted that they were maintaining a healthy level of spending for R&D.  Having an expandable platform is key because the security business has been changing very rapidly.Follow Brian Bolan on Twitter @BBolan1OutlookAs we think about the changes in home security
column10: it is clear that people are adding devices and services thanks to the relative ease of the internet.  Management noted on the call that people want these products and services to come from one source.As an example
column11: I have a Google Cam (formerly Dropcam) and while it is accessible via its own app I would like to see it be usable via my Amazon echo.  Yes the Google Nest is controllable via the voice recognizing tool
column12: but I would like more functionality.  I often search on Amazon for devices that are compatible with Alexa since I have power out that is controlled by another company.  It too has its own app and with only a few devices having multiple apps is already a pressure point for me.With the strong revenue guidance
column13: management believes that its products and services will be well received by customers.Analysts Notes ComingAs I look at where most recommendations are
column14: I see a few potential upgrades tomorrow.  Goldman Sachs started coverage of the stock with a Neutral rating on January 31 and a $31 price target. The analyst for the firm asked about the potential for organic growth from Icontrol which allowed management to talk about how they were going to hold their cost structure constant and could expect about $66M in EBITDA which translates to better than 20% margin.  It is possible that Goldman Sachs ups the stock to ""Buy"" tomorrow.Raymond James downgraded the stock back on August 16 as the moved their rating to Market Perform from Outperform.  Imperial Capital has the stock as ""In-line"" with a $30 price target.Roth Capital started coverage on October 3 with a buy and a $33.50 price target.  Don't be surprised to see that price target moved to $37.50 range.Maxim Group initiated with a buy rating and $37 price target on December 1.  They are clearly the most bullish on the stock and for good reason.  I would look for the Maxim price target to expand to $40 or more given the recently posted results.Trading Range?The stock has a 52 week high of $34.43
column15: but don't be too surprised to see a new level reached tomorrow.  Why do I say this?  Well back on October 31
column16: 2016 some unusual call buying was spotted in ALRM.  The call was a $35 strike with a March expiration.  At the time
column17: the stock was $29 and change so it was a pretty big reach.  I see those same calls closing at $0.17 with open interest of 856 - so not anything to get too excited about.What did catch my eye on the option chain was all the puts that moved the day of earnings.  The 27.5 strike that expires on Friday saw 729 contracts vs open interest of 898.  Check that open interest level tomorrow to see if those were all premium sellers as the put was paying $0.42.I like the chances of several price target increases coming tomorrow.  There is an outside chance we get an upgrade on the stock as well.  Throw in the idea that some mildly aggressive calls were bought several months ago I and I like the chances of this stock trading over $35 on March 16 or soon thereafter.  Either way
column18: look for this stock to become a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) or a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) in a day or two.Alarm.com Holdings

column1: What Will the Q1 Earnings Season Bring?;3/15/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Note: The following is an excerpt from this week'sEarnings Trendsreport. You can access the full report that contains detailed historical actuals and estimates for the current and following periods
column2: please click here>>>The Q1 earnings season will follow a strong showing in the preceding reporting cycle
column3: with growth reaching its highest level in two years and the overall quarterly earnings tally reaching a new quarterly record. The market will be looking for continuation of these favorable trends in the Q1 reporting cycle as well
column4: which has (officially) gotten underway already but wouldn't be in the spotlight for another four weeks.Total Q1 earnings are expected to be up +6.4% from the same period last year on +6.5% higher revenues. This would follow +7.1% earnings growth in 2016 Q4 on +4.4% top-line gains
column5: the highest growth pace in two years.Estimates for Q1 came down as the quarter unfolded
column6: with the current +6.4% growth down from +10.4% at the end of December. The chart below shows how Q1 earnings growth expectations have evolved over the last three months.Please note that while Q1 estimates have followed a well traversed path that we have been seeing consistently over the last few years
column7: the magnitude of negative revisions compares favorably to other periods. In other words
column8: Q1 estimates have come down
column9: but they haven't come down by as much.At the sector level
column10: ten of the 16 Zacks sectors are expected to earn more relative to the year-earlier period
column11: with earnings growth for the Technology sector expected to be up +10.2% from the same period last year. The sector is expecting strong earnings growth despite the relatively flattish expectation fromApple(AAPL). Strong growth atAlphabet(GOOGL)
column12: Facebook(FB) and easy comparisons atMicron(MU) are the big positive contributors to the sector. Earnings growth for the Finance
column13: Basic Materials and Industrials sectors are expected to be in mid-single digits while the Energy sector moves from a modest loss in the year-earlier period to improving positive earnings this quarter.The chart below shows current consensus growth expectations for the following quarters
column14: which reflect a continuation of the positive growth trend going forward.Please note that we have yet to see any 'Trump bump' in estimates along the lines of what we have been seeing in the market since November 8th. The sole exception to that comment would be the Finance sector whose earnings outlook has benefited from the post-election uptrend in interest rates.Note: Sheraz Mian manages the Zacks equity research department. column1: Family Link: 7 Things to Know About the New Google Accounts for Kids;3/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFamily Link is a new way for parents and their children to be connected onAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL) and its online capabilities.makeArticleAd();The service essentially allows your children to have a Google account in a safe way. Here are seven things to know about itFamily Link is an app that allows you to have a joint Google account with your kid.In order to access it
column4: you will need the app
column5: an Android phone running Android KitKat 4.4 or higher (for yourself)
column6: and a newer Android phone running Nougat (for your kid).The two phones will be in sync following this move and the parent will be able to keep tabs on what the kid is doing.Kids can use the app to play games and watch movies.Family Link makes it easy for parents ages 13 and under to approve or block apps
column7: set daily screen limits
column8: see how much time they're spending weekly or monthly
column9: and lock their devices when it's time to take a break or go to bed.Parents can monitor their kids settings remotely through their own device
column10: see the location of their child's device and more.You can also set a new unlock code if your kid forgets theirs in order to make sure they can be connected whenever they want
column11: unless you don't want them to.7 Cheap Dividend Stocks to Buy NowGOOG stock and GOOGL stock grew 0.2% and 0.3% respectively.More From InvestorPlace9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than Amazon10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the Bills7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You BackThe postFamily Link: 7 Things to Know About the New Google Accounts for Kidsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Twitter
column2: Inc. Is Missing Out on This Major Catalyst;3/15/2017;"Twitter(NYSE:TWTR) has undoubtedly missed the mark recently. Last year
column3: the social   network's sequential monthly active user growth stalled and even   temporarily turned negative. Meanwhile
column4: Twitter's revenue growth   rates have decelerated rapidly and its stock price has plummeted   nearly 70% in two years.Going further
column5: there isn't a clear end in sight to Twitter's   revenue challenges. A new report by research company eMarketer   (viaRecode) forecasts Twitter's U.S. mobile ad revenue will actually   decline in 2017 compared to 2016 asFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) andAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google gobble up marketers'   rising spending on mobile advertisements.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Twitter's missed opportunityIn 2017
column6: Twitter's U.S. mobile advertising revenue will   decline from $1.21 billion last year to $1.15 billion
column7: eMarketer   estimates. A quick glance at Twitter's financials in the   company's most recent quarter suggests this estimate is   realistic. Twitter's $382 million in U.S. advertising revenue in   Q4 was down 7% from the year-ago period. And given that 89% of   Twitter's global ad revenue during the quarter came from mobile
column8: it's safe to say that Twitter's mobile ad revenue in the U.S.   probably isn't faring too well.What's unfortunate about Twitter's struggling mobile ad   business in the U.S. is that it's happening at a time when   marketers are spending more on mobile ads. Total mobile ad spend   in the U.S. is expected to increase 25% in 2017 compared to 2016
column9: eMarketer estimates.Unlike Twitter
column10: advertising juggernauts Google and Facebook   are well-positioned to snap-up this incremental spending. The two   companies' combined share of U.S. mobile ad spend will increase   from 54% in 2016 to 57% in 2017
column11: eMarketer estimates. But   eMarketer estimates that Twitter's share of U.S. mobile   advertising revenue will decline from 2.6% in 2016 to 2% in   2017.Twitter management likely agrees that it won't be keeping up   with Google's or Facebook's growth rate in 2017. In the company's   fourth-quarter shareholder letter
column12: management said
column13: ""escalating   competition for digital ad spending"" could present challenges for   advertising revenue growth in 2017.Image source: Twitter.Can Twitter reinvigorate growth?Looking further into the future -- perhaps toward the end of   2017 and into 2018 -- Twitter's domestic advertising revenue   could start growing again. Management believes that the company's   recentreaccelerationin user growth will drive revenue growth. But it's going to take   time as management expects ""advertising revenue growth to   continue to lag that of audience growth in 2017
column14: the company   explained in its fourth-quarter shareholder letter.But if Twitter does return to mobile ad growth in the U.S.   toward the end of the year or in 2018
column15: don't expect growth rates   to be very high. Not only may overall growth in U.S.-based mobile   ad spend be much slower by then
column16: but Twitter's anemic 3%   year-over-year growth in U.S. monthly active users during the   company's most recent quarter -- notably below Facebook's 5.5%   year-over-year growth in U.S. monthly active users in the same   period -- suggests the user growth won't be much help for Twitter   in driving domestic ad revenue growth.10 stocks we like better than TwitterWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column17: it can pay to listen. After all
column18: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade
column19: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column20: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Twitter wasn't one of       them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even       better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
