column1: Genpact (G) Acquires Rage Frameworks to Boost AI Offerings;3/15/2017;"Genpact LimitedGrecently announced plans to acquire Rage Frameworks
column2: a Dedham-based artificial intelligence (AI) startup. The acquisition is expected to boost its AI technology platform targeting enterprises. However
column3: the terms of the deal were not disclosed.We note that the two companies have partnered many times in the past to cater to clients in the financial services and insurance sectors.With this acquisition
column4: Genpact will be able to provide AI offerings across industries such as consumer packaged goods
column5: industrial engineering
column6: life-sciences and high-tech.Genpact Limited Price and ConsensusGenpact Limited Price and Consensus|Genpact Limited QuoteWhy this Move?As per an IDC report
column7: worldwide spending on cognitive systems and AI is estimated to go past $47 billion by 2020 at a CAGR of 55.1%. Given the huge scope the segment has to offer
column8: it is not surprising to see a number of companies flocking to the scene.Apart from IBM'sIBMWatson

column1: PayPal's Stock Dips After Google Announces Money Transfer Feature;3/14/2017;"PayPal'sPYPLstock closed the day down 1.5% on Tuesday to $42.10 after Googleannounced in a blog postthat users would now be able to send and receive money in their Gmail app.Alphabet'sGOOGLGoogle said that users would be able to receive and request money as an email attachment through their Gmail App on Android. This service will have no fees
column2: and will work with other email services as well. Recipients can also arrange the money to go straight to their bank account. To use the new feature
column3: users will have to set up a Google Wallet account if they don't have one.Google's move to mobile could be a direct challenge to PayPal's Venmo
column4: the dominant person-to-person mobile payment app and social network.Will It Work?As personal finances become digitalized
column5: users not only want payments to be faster and safer
column6: but millennial users also look to share them. While the Gmail App allows users to send and receive money
column7: users won't be able to brag about their transactions like on Venmo.Venmo users can send money to a friend and write a memo. After the transaction is completed
column8: all of the user's friends on Venmo will be able to see the amount of money sent and the memo. And it turns out that people are interested in knowing whom their friends eat with and where they eat.""A lot of what we're seeing there is that people don't just come to transact. They 're coming there to see what their friends were doing
column9: PayPal's chief operating officer Bill Ready said at a Morgan Stanley technology conference in late February.One of the main reasons that PayPal is the top person-to-person vendor in the U.S. is that Venmo processed $5.6 billion in payment volume in the fourth quarter of 2016
column10: an increase of 126%
column11: the company said in its earnings report.Bottom LineIt is hard to say whether or not Google's new feature will disrupt PayPal's dominance in person-to-person transactions. With the introduction of One Touch
column12: a faster check out option online
column13: and Venmo expanding with their ""Pay with Venmo
column14: PayPal is certainly fortifying its power in the online transaction service.Zacks' 2017 IPO Watch ListBefore looking into the stocks mentioned above

column1: Apple Found Guilty of Price Fixing iPhones in Russia;3/14/2017;"AppleAAPLhas beenfound guilty for price fixingiPhones in Russia by Russian anti-trust regulator FAS (the Federal Antimonopoly Service). Apple has been price fixing in Russia since the release of the iPhone 5 and through the iPhone 6s; allegations against the iPhone 7 have not been proven.The FAS's investigation shows that when retailers in Russia attempted to sell Apple's iPhones at a lower price than what Apple wished
column2: a local subsidiary of Apple would email the retailers demanding them to hike their discounts. If the retailers failed to comply then Apple threatened to terminate their contracts to sell iPhones.No comments have been made from Apple yet; however
column3: FAS head Andrey Tsarikovsky stated Apple has ""actively cooperated"" to resolve the issue. Penalties have yet to be announced; in the meantime
column4: Apple has three months to challenge the ruling if they choose to do so.In translation from a statement by the FAS
column5: their public announcement wrote
column6: ""At the same time
column7: Apple Rus monitored retail prices for Apple iPhone smartphones installed by resellers in online stores and retail outlets
column8: and
column9: in case of setting ""unsuitable"" prices
column10: the Russian subsidiary Apple sent emails to resellers with a request to change them. Also
column11: compliance with recommended retail prices by resellers could be due to the provisions of contracts between Apple Rus and resellers.""Reporters say that the worst case scenario for Apple will be a fine calculated by 15% of Russian sales; however
column12: an official penalty will take several months to figure out.Apple is not the only leading smartphone producer to be found guilty of fraudulent activity in Russia. GoogleGOOGLwas fined $6.75 million by the FAS just last year for preinstalling their apps on Android smartphones and tablets.Zacks' 2017 IPO Watch ListBefore looking into the stocks mentioned above

column1: Twitter Is Selling Ads Like It's Television;3/14/2017;"One of the strongest trends in advertising is the shift of   budgets from television to digital as people spend less time   watching conventional TV. Consumers are spending much more time   on social media sites likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)

column5: anAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) company.But if advertisers are going to replace television ads with   digital ads

column12: promoted tweets

column1: Web Browsers Are Making A Comeback
column2: Just Not In The U.S.;3/14/2017;"In the U.S. where the monthly data plan and Wi-Fi are abundant
column3: the market for single-purpose apps like FacebookFBand SnapchatSNAPhas flourished. However
column4: across the world
column5: it is not apps that are racking up users but mobile web browsers.Browsers are popular again
column6: especially in developing countries
column7: where data plans are not accessible for everyone and prepaid data plans can't support data heavy single-purpose apps. Users are finding themselves turning to web browsers to stay connected.It is not a second choice either. While it may feel like apps are faster and easier to use
column8: browser developers have been working hard to compensate users. Not only have browser companies like UC Browser from AlibabaBABA
column9: Google Chrome from Alphabet Inc.GOOGLand Opera Mini by Opera Software
column10: have made their browsers data-efficient
column11: but these companies have also beenadding new featureslike voice recognition
column12: file sharing and integration with social media.In countries where it is easy to buy used or refurbished smartphones for as little as $25
column13: it is easy to see why users lean towards web browsers instead of single-purpose apps. You spend less and achieve more.The number of Internet users globally has reached around 3.5 billion and many of the people that became Internet users in the past few years are all part of the rise of the global middle class in emerging markets. And they provided the biggest user growth for browser makers. These companies also know how to keep their users occupied and monetizing them through mobile advertising.Internet giants like Google and Facebook are noticing these trends. Two thirds of Facebook's users are in emerging markets and Google's Chrome remains the dominant browser in many emerging markets. Facebook has Facebook Lite
column14: an app designed for low-bandwidth users and Google pays other search engines to direct search traffic to ad-supported Google services.It is logical that these new users in the emerging markets will likely follow in the footsteps of their richer peers and make the shift from web browsers to apps as they get wealthier and data becomes cheaper
column15: though this doesn't worry the browser developers. There will always be a new group of users joining emerging market.India is projected to increase its per-capita income by 125% by 2025 with its population of 1.3 billion people
column16: according to Morgan StanleyMS. Opera Software said Africa is growing the fastest in terms of new downloads and there are 600 million potential users in Southeast Asia
column17: which is a huge market for these browsers.Until cellular connection become more accessible and affordable
column18: web browsers will maintain its popularity.Zacks' 2017 IPO Watch ListBefore looking into the stocks mentioned above

Imagine being in the first wave of investors to jump on a company with almost unlimited growth potential? This Special Report gives you the current scoop on 5 that may go public at any time.makeArticleAd();One has driven from 0 to a $68 billion valuation in 8 years. column1: Can Intel Catch Tesla
column2: Google
column3: Apple In Autonomous Car Race?;3/14/2017;"Thanks to its$15.3 billion acquisitionof Israeli self-driving technology company Mobileye (MBLY)
column4: Intel (INTC) is no longer on the outside looking in when it comes to the autonomous car market
column5: which has become the new battleground for high-tech companies looking new revenue streams.While Intel’s semiconductor prowess and breadth in R&D should accelerate the pace of Mobileye’s technology innovation
column6: will the combined company have enough tread to catch the likes of Tesla (TSLA) and Google (GOOGL)?Intel seems to think so. The deal
column7: which sent MBLY stock soaring 28% in active trade Monday
column8: ""merges the intelligent eyes of the autonomous car with the intelligent brain that actually drives the car
column9: ” said Intel CEO Brian Krzanich in a statement. “The saying 'what's under the hood' will increasingly refer to computing
column10: not horsepower.”makeArticleAd();Investors weren’t immediately impressed
column11: sending Intel shares down 2.1% to close at a three-month low of $35.16. This isn’t Intel’s first run at self-driving cars
column12: however. The Santa Clara
column13: Calif.-based chip giant
column14: through its financing arm Intel Capital
column15: hasspent $250 millionin R&D looking for an edge. The Mobileye deal
column16: meanwhile
column17: has now made it known that autonomous driving capabilities was never a hobby for Intel. It’s become a critical market for the company.Still
column18: Tesla and Google won’t be run off the road. In December
column19: GooglelaunchedWaymo
column20: which stands for “a new way forward in mobility.” Waymo’s website features a two-seater prototype fitted with Google’s hardware and software that is built to move with the touch of a button
column21: with neither a steering wheel nor a brake pedal. Meanwhile
column22: in Tesla’s most popular sedan
column23: the Model S
column24: the company has already rolled out self-driving capabilities that receive incremental updates on autopilot features.These updates
column25: which include “exit ramp autonomy” on highways
column26: automatic lane-changing
column27: and auto-steering
column28: are also available to Model X
column29: its SUV family. And to say nothing about Apple’s (AAPL) own autonomous car ambitions
column30: which theWall Street Journalrecently confirmed. With more money stashed than the U.S. Treasury
column31: Apple’s autonomous car position depends only on how hard it wants to mash the accelerator.But here’s the thing: Mobileye was once a prominent partner to Tesla
column32: meaning it could have had first-hand knowledge of what Tesla has under its hood. And to the extent Intel can utilize that knowledge to accelerate its own technology
column33: Intel will narrow that gap relatively quickly.At the same time
column34: the fact that Intel wants to emerge as the go-to chip name when it comes to autonomous car processors
column35: powering functions such as displays and communication between two self-driving vehicles
column36: Intel doesn’t necessarily have to be the car
column37: it can just be the brainsinsidethe car — something it thrived on during the height of the PC era."

column1: Don’t Follow Warren Buffett Into Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock … Yet;3/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhen it comes to investing
column3: Warren Buffett says investors should go with index funds. But Buffett himself takes a different approach by buying individual stocks
column4: such asApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). The question is: Should you do as Buffett says and index
column5: or do as Buffettdoes
column6: and buy AAPL stock?makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBuffett's lack of technology exposure is well-known among Wall Street veterans. In fact
column7: many even ridiculed the Oracle of Omaha for missing out names like Apple
column8: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) andAmazon.com
column9: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN).Until Apple came along
column10: International Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) was Buffett's largest tech play. He used to say he skipped over tech stocks because he didn't understand them well enough.But it appears that Buffett's understanding of technology is growing.I n 2016
column11: Berkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.B) reported a 9.8 million-share position in AAPL stock as of March 31. That position almost doubled to 15.2 million shares as of Sept. 30
column12: then almost quadrupled to a whopping 57.3 million shares by year's end.So what has Buffett done with AAPL stock in 2017?7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You BackThe Oracle of Omahahas more than doubled his position. The stake now stands at some 133 million shares worth about $18.1 billion. Buffett buying some 75 million shares of AAPL stock in such a short span shows confidence in Apple.While Buffett is not known for his short-term predictions
column13: he is heralded for his long-term investments. So
column14: what does he like so much about Apple stock anyway? ""Apple strikes me as having quite a sticky product
column15: and an enormously useful product to people that use it
column16: Buffett told CNBC in late-February.Perhaps the most ironic part of Buffett's discussion on Apple centered on his own device - the famed investor doesn't even own an iPhone.Positives for AAPL StockApple stock has a lot of positives. For starters
column17: the company is flush with cash. With more than $40 per share of cash
column18: Apple could go on a transformative M&A spree - even with the repatriation tax that
column19: right now
column20: it would have to pay. Add in the potential for a tax repatriation holiday from the Trump administration
column21: and Apple's in even better shape.Additionally
column22: Apple is a cash cow that continues to bring in billions of dollars each quarter
column23: which should help continue to fund dividends and stock buybacks. Plus
column24: its cash hoard should continue to grow over time.Despite rallying more than 40% over the past eight months
column25: AAPL stock still trades with a below-market valuation. Sporting a price-to-earnings ratio of around 16
column26: it's hard to consider Apple overvalued.And the valuation argument is important. Too many investors try to justify a higher Apple stock price by applying a market-average multiple. That's an inaccurate measurement
column27: as Apple tends to trade between a P/E range of 10 to 17 (more on that in a moment). So rarely will it trade in-line with the averageS&P 500stock.With that said
column28: having a low valuation is part of what makes Apple stock attractive. Shares go through pretty extreme ups and downs. But long-term investors can feel confident in buying a stock that's not egregiously priced.Finally
column29: investors can look forward to Apple releasing themuch-anticipated iPhone 8later this fall. With a higher potential selling price and plenty of fancy features
column30: the new device is likely to drive record results.Add on its quickly growing
column31: high-margin Services business
column32: and AAPL stock becomes even more attractive for long-term investors.Should You Follow Buffett Into AAPL Stock?With all these positives
column33: Apple stock may seem like a slam-dunk.However
column34: I think investors would be best off waiting for a pullback. While we just highlighted its P/E ratio as a positive
column35: itisclose to the top of its five-year range. AAPL stock is cheap compared to the average stock
column36: but getting expensive compared to its historical average.Additionally
column37: Apple stock has gone on a massive rally. While it's admittedly consolidating nicely just under $140
column38: I find it hard to be a buyer at these levels.Why General Electric Company (GE) Stock Is Way Too DangerousWith the overall market still up big
column39: I can sleep more comfortably at night waiting for a pullback to buy Apple stock. If it doesn't materialize
column40: that is something waiting investors will have to live with. I would rather miss a few points of upside in order to avoid significant points on the downside.Historically
column41: Apple's stock is volatile
column42: whichmakes a pullback likelyat some point in the next few months.A 7% to 10% correction would be needed for me to get interested.Bret Kenwell is the manager and author ofFuture Blue Chips. As of this writing
column43: Bret Kenwell held no position in any securities mentioned.More From InvestorPlaceSnap Inc Snags Apple News' Media Head (SNAP)7 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are Actually SafeShould Apple Inc. Cut Its Dividend? (AAPL)The postDon't Follow Warren Buffett Into Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock … Yetappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: How a Major Drugmaker Plans to Cure Disease... Without Drugs;3/14/2017;"Pharmaceutical giantGlaxoSmithKline plc(NYSE: GSK) has the resources to pursue long-term bets in   medicine that could eventually change the course of disease   treatment and yield large payoffs. Three and half years ago the   company announced its plans for an audacious goal: to literally   eavesdrop on the body's electrical system and enter into the   body's own internal conversations in order to heal disease.Not as crazy as it soundsMedicine has long focused on chemical processes to alter   biological function
column2: but every organ has a nerve connection that   regulates its function. Organs are controlled by patterns of   electrical impulses transmitted through nerve fibers
column3: but when   organs dysfunction in chronic disease
column4: the electrical patterns   are different. That fact opens up the possibility that inserting   patterns in nerves to certain organs can correct conditions that   lead to disease. Using electrical impulses to influence organ   function is nothing new -- cardiac pacemakers have been in use   for decades -- but scientists are just beginning to realize the   possibilities of using nerve signals to restore organs to normal   function and actually treat disease.Image source: GlaxoSmithKline plc.makeArticleAd();A seminal paper was published in the scientific journal Nature   in 2000 which presented evidence that stimulation of the vagus   nerve could actually trigger an anti-inflammatory response in   rats. Electrical stimulation of the nerve inhibited the   production of tumor necrosis factor (TNF)
column5: which is also the   mechanism used by some blockbuster anti-inflammatory drugs such   asAbbVie's Humira. Since then
column6: researchers have come to believe that   influencing the the body's electrical system could lead to   treatments for conditions as diverse as asthma
column7: arthritis
column8: inflammatory bowel disease
column9: hypertension
column10: diabetes
column11: infertility
column12: and even cancer. A drug gets dispersed throughout the body
column13: affecting multiple pathways and organs in the process and   potentially causing undesired side effects
column14: but targeting the   signals of a specific nerve bundle with an implanted device has   the potential for producing highly localized and specific   effects.GlaxoSmithKline announced in 2013 an effort to pour resources   into the field of bioelectronics
column15: taking a leadership role in the   industry. The company announced a $1 million innovation prize
column16: the creation and funding of a network of researchers
column17: and the   launch of a $50 million venture capital fund
column18: Action Potential   Venture Capital
column19: to invest in pioneering bioelectronic   technologies.The investment is already producing visible progress. The   first investment by the venture capital fund was in SetPoint   Medical
column20: a privately held California company that is developing a   platform to treat inflammatory diseases by modulating nerve   signals with implanted devices and was co-founded by one of the   authors of the original 2000 paper in Nature. In July 2016 the   company reported the results of a first-in-human study of vagal   nerve stimulation by an implanted device for treatment of   arthritis. The study showed that the approach inhibited TNF   production and improved symptoms
column21: including in some patients who   had not responded to conventional drug treatments. In January   2017
column22: SetPoint reported positive results of another human study   using its device to treat Crohn's disease.Googling the body's internal networkImage source: GlaxoSmithKline plc.As encouraging as the results from SetPoint are
column23: that approach   is primitive compared with the ambitions of a $715 million joint   venture that Glaxo andAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) birthed last August called Galvani   Bioelectronics. The collaboration with Verily Life Sciences
column24: formerly known as Google Life Sciences
column25: aims to do no less than   to map the human nervous system
column26: crack the electrical codes   flowing through nerves controlling the body's organs
column27: and be able   to modify the signals to restore health using implantable   devices the size of a grain of rice.The effort has enormous potential... and enormous challenges.   Verily will contribute expertise in device miniaturization and   software. The tiny devices will need a read/write interface to   nerve fibers and a way to be powered without heating the body --   both significant technical problems yet to be solved. The   approach will also require the analysis and interpretation of   massive amounts of data taken from the signals sensed on   individual bundles of nerves controlling the targeted organs
column28: something that's right up Google's alley. Glaxo
column29: for its part
column30: has been working for several years on a ""nerve atlas"" with the   goal of identifying the specific nerve fibers whose signals will   need to be decoded and modulated.A long shot
column31: but we could get news by 2019Executives from GlaxoSmithKline and Verily are optimistic
column32: though. At the time of the announcement last August
column33: Glaxo   executive Moncef Slaoui expressed the belief that Galvani could   begin human trials within 18 months
column34: achieve proof of concept in   three years
column35: and begin commercialization in seven years. This   timeline puts the effort on the radar of long-term investors
column36: who   could be seeing news on developments in the next few years.The challenge is huge
column37: but then so is the potential   payoff. ""Bioelectronic medicines have the potential of doing   to the pharmaceutical industry what biopharmaceuticals did to   small molecules back in the 1980s
column38: says Imran Eba
column39: partner in Action Potential Venture Capital. If that happens
column40: GlaxoSmithKline could be in ideal position to benefit from the   next big disruption in medical technology.10 stocks we like better than GlaxoSmithKlineWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column41: it can pay to listen. After all
column42: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column43: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column44: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and GlaxoSmithKline wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Carries Some Risks;3/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI recently wrote anarticlesuggesting thatAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column3: NASDAQ:GOOG) was the perfect value play
column4: as it was a growth stock that was not unreasonably valued based on various criteria. Now I'll dive into what I think the risks of GOOGL stock are
column5: and how they may manifest.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockMy biggest concern with GOOGL stock has always been that it is effectively a one-trick pony. Alphabet is the largest digital advertising billboard in the world
column6: with about 88% of its revenues coming from advertising. Moreover
column7: GOOGL stock's growth has been driven by this spectacular seizure of internet territory from competitors.In fact
column8: during the financial crisis
column9: ad revenues still grew about 8% year-over-year in 2009 despite a worldwide ad revenuedeclineof 11% that year.GOOGL Stock and Digital AdvertisingNow
column10: digital advertising was still in its hyper-growth phase back then. Should another major crisis hit
column11: I'm not so sure that Alphabet won't see a decline. Yet what's so astonishing about GOOGL stock is just how much money it makes from advertising. It could get hit with a 20% decline in total revenues
column12: which would bring it roughly in line with fiscal year 2015 results
column13: and still generate net income of $15 billion or so
column14: and operating cash flow of $26 billion or so.This is hardly a catastrophe
column15: which shows that for now at least
column16: GOOGL has a lock on substantial growth in ad revenue. However
column17: that advertising is the result of people using Google's search engine. What if that changes? Right now
column18: Google has more than 80% search engine marketshare. It's so popular that we now use the product's name as a verb.7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You BackI think it will be very difficult to supplant Google as far as search engine usage goes. However
column19: there is other behavior which may result in less reliance on the search engine and
column20: therefore
column21: fewer eyeballs for ads. Mobile apps have obviously exploded in number and usage. The more adept and fully functional that apps become
column22: the less Google may be used.Social media is only going to grow
column23: and the more that these products offer in terms of either their own search engines
column24: or places for advertisers to divide their ad spend
column25: the worse it is for GOOGL.There's also some interesting competition in the form of product searches
column26: and of course
column27: that competition comes fromAmazon.com
column28: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). According to a 2016 PowerReviewssurvey
column29: 38% of users use Amazon as a place to search for products
column30: and Google comes in second at 35%. I think about my own usage when it comes to product searched
column31: and yes
column32: I always start with Amazon. Inventory
column33: price and reviews are the reasons why people start there. The larger that Amazon grows
column34: the stickier it will become as far as product searches
column35: and that could mean fewer eyeballs for GOOGL.Obviously
column36: Alphabet Inc. has plenty of money and can ramp up competition in mobile access
column37: butApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) andFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) obviously have a corner on that market so far.What Nvidia Needs to Avoid a Breakdown (NVDA)There is some regulatory risk
column38: as well. The EU slammed Alphabet Inc. for tweaking search results to direct people to its own shopping sites. The FCC is an unknown beast - it could end up regulating the internet in ways harmful to GOOGL stock.However
column39: when it comes to buying the stock
column40: I don't see immediate dangers to GOOGL that makes its valuation less attractive. At 18x next year's earnings
column41: and five-year annualized analyst projections of 19.3% growth
column42: it's already undervalued. When I give it a 10% premium for global brand name
column43: cash flow and cash on hand
column44: it becomes a true growth and value play. Still.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column45: and manager of the forthcomingLiberty Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column46: has no position in any stock mentioned. He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column47: and has written more than 1
column48: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.More From InvestorPlace9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than Amazon7 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are Actually SafeThe postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Carries Some Risksappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column14: Apple is aiming for $50 billion in services revenue by $50 billion. That's still only a fraction of the $215 billion worth of revenue Apple mustered in 2016
column15: but digital sales now make up the company's second-biggest segment; the iPhone is still the biggest.Before we pop the corks on the champagne bottles though
column16: there are three red flags everyone would be wise to process.1. The iPhone 8 (probably) costs too muchWhile the launch of the iPhone 7 in the fall of last year could be considered a success in that the company sold arecord-breaking 78.2 million units in the previous quarter
column17: given thehype surrounding the device
column18: the company should have blown away sales figures for its iPhone 6.Some (many) suspect the demand that should have materialized for the 7 was ultimately displaced to the iPhone 8
column19: which is supposed to be unveiled in September of this year. The word is that the admittedly impressive device is going togo for a cool $1000 each. At that price
column20: even the most loyal of Apple fans could balk.2. The popular smartphone is preemptively cannibalizing itselfAside from sticker shock
column21: would-be owners of the upcoming iPhone 8 may keep their wallet closed for the same reason many potential buyers of the iPhone 7 didn't pull the trigger - they're waiting for the phone after the next phone
column22: which is sure to be even more amazing.To that end
column23: what's currently being referred to as the iPhone 9 already promises (in rumors) to be an amazing piece of hardware
column24: complete with a folding screen. That may postpone purchases of the iPhone 8 later this year
column25: though 2018's iPhone 9 could see softer demand because whispers of the iPhone 10 rumors will be circulating by then.It's a vicious cycle
column26: with Apple arguably unable to ever really log a blowout iPhone launch.Fitbit Has BlackBerry Syndrome (FIT)3. The Google Pixel is really
column27: really impressiveFinally
column28: as solid as the recent Pixel phone fromAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column29: NASDAQ:GOOGL) subsidiary Google was
column30: it wasn't a game-changer. Analysts estimate the companyonly sold about 2.5 million of the device.Bear in mind
column31: however
column32: this is Google's first direct foray into the smartphone world
column33: and could be considered little more than a dry run.The Pixel 2 is slated to debut sometime this year
column34: and it's a good bet the company has made a point of learning a lot with its first outing.Bottom Line for AAPL StockInvariably
column35: some (or several) owners of Apple stock interpret these concerns as a call that the company is doomed
column36: and then proceed to ""colorfully disagree."" So
column37: let me clarify something that shouldn't need saying. That is
column38: even on AAPL stock's worst day it's still essentially unstoppable to other smartphone players. Don't read too much into the worries.On the flipside
column39: in that Apple stock is all too often found on investors' pedestals - lifted there by assumptions that the company is infallible - it's never a bad idea to recognize all plausible risks. These three risks could each end up stirring up surprising headwinds
column40: and nothing takes a toll on a stock like an unexpected disappointment.As of this writing
column41: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You Back7 Future Blue-Chip Stocks You Need to BuyThe post3 Reasons Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is Becoming Tougher to Ownappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: About to Buy Driverless Car Stocks? Read This First;3/13/2017;"There's no shortage of technology companies and automotive   makers that are are betting that autonomous vehicles will   transform both of their industries. But how do you figure   out which companies are poised to benefit the most?To answer that
column2: investors first need to know what the market   potential is for driverless cars
column3: what might slow it down
column4: and   how long it will take for the segment to mature
column5: and then   determine which driverless car investment angle they want to   take. Here are a few steps to help you get started:Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();How much the driverless car market will be     worthBy 2025
column6: the driverless car market is expected to be worth $42   billion
column7: according to Boston Consulting Group. The market size   jumps up to $77 billion by 2035
column8: which is the same year thatIHSestimates that there will be 76 million autonomous vehicles   already on the road.And it doesn't end there. Driverless cars are expected to   transform ride sharing services
column9: allow car owners to rent out   their own vehicles -- asTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has suggested -- and even help   traditional carmakers create their own ride hailing services
column10: likeFord(NYSE: F) has proposed.This might slow driverless car stocks downIt's not going to be all sunshine and lollipops for driverless   car stocks though. There are still many hurdles facing these   companies
column11: including federal regulations
column12: safety concerns
column13: and   consumer adoption issues.The two biggest automotive markets
column14: however -- the U.S. and   China -- have thus far been very open to driverless cars. Back in   September
column15: the federal government released guidelines for states   to help ensure that companies are able to innovate and not be   hampered by differing rules across state lines. But the problem   is that we're still in the very early stages of driverless   car technology (i.e. neither you nor I can buy fully autonomous   vehicles)
column16: so while the government is open to it now
column17: that could   change when more tech starts being used by the general   population.And even if the government doesn't end up stifling autonomous   vehicles
column18: there's currently a growing movement toban driverless cars in New Yorkbecause people are afraid they'll eliminate jobs for taxi   drivers
column19: bus drivers and others in the transportation sector. Add   to that the fact that there are parts of the population thatfeel very uneasyabout driverless cars and it's clear that the autonomous vehicle   market still has a long way to go.There are plenty of ways to investCompanies like Tesla are among the obvious choices for betting   on driverless cars. CEO Elon Musk has said he wants to have a   fully autonomous car capable of driving itself across the country   by 2018
column20: and every new Tesla built right now already has the   hardware capabilities for full autonomy (though not all of the   software is activated).Tech behemothAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is another clear choice. Google's   parent company recently spun out its driverless car segment into   its own company
column21: called Waymo
column22: and is working to bring fully autonomous minivans to the roads   this year for public testing
column23: along with a ride-sharing   service.And then there are chipmakers likeNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA)
column24: which is investing heavily in artificial   intelligence and its own supercomputers to power driverless cars.   The company'sDrive PX 2 supercomputeris already used by 80 automakers and automotive suppliers   (including Tesla) and is likely to expand its automotive revenues   substantially in the coming years.Of course
column25: you could go the traditional route too and bet on   automakers like Ford
column26: which is also focusing its attention on   self-driving technologies. The company recently invested $1   billion in a self-driving car start-up
column27: called Argo AI
column28: and says   that it will release its own fully autonomous vehicle (with no   steering wheel!) by 2021.Ford may be taking a slower approach than some other   self-driving tech makers
column29: but it has plans to have 90   self-driving test vehicles on the road this year and is working   with more than 40 start-ups on driverless car technology.And if you're looking for a driverless car stock outside of   the U.S.
column30: thenBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU)  isprobably your best bet. The company has been developing self-driving technology for   years and just launched a test program in some Chinese cities to   implement its tech. The company wants to release a fully   self-driving car by next year with the hopes of having a   ride-hailing service in the coming years. Aside from its   aggressive driverless car approach
column31: Baidu benefits from China's   openness to self-driving technologies and fewer regulations for   road tests than the U.S.Here's how long you might need to wait for this to play     outAlright
column32: so now we know how big this market will be
column33: some of   the potential hurdles
column34: and who the key players are. So how long   will investors have to wait for this opportunity to pan out? IHS   estimates that we'll reach worldwide driverless car ubiquity by   about 2050.That doesn't mean it'll take that long for driverless car   stocks to benefit of course
column35: but it does mean that we still have   a long way to go before the market will mature -- which makes now   the perfect time for investors to start considering driverless   car stocks.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Does DISH
column2: Sony
column3: or AT&T Have the Best Live-Streaming Cable Deal?;3/13/2017;"Cable without an actual cable may be the next big thing not   just for cord-cutters looking to save a buck
column4: but also for   consumers looking to leave their current providers without making   a major sacrifice.DISH Network(NASDAQ: DISH) was the first player in the space with the launch   of its live-streaming cable alternative a little over two years   ago.Sony(NYSE: SNE) began testing its own PlayStation Vue in select   markets not long after that and has since taken its cable-like   streaming product national. Most recently
column5: AT&T(NYSE: T) launched DirecTV Now
column6: giving consumers three distinct   choices (not counting the not-yet-launched options from YouTube   and Hulu which are still developing).For consumers it's a lot of choices
column7: but unlike traditional   cable where every company offers roughly the same package
column8: these   three players are somewhat different. That makes determining the   best one a bit of a moving target
column9: but with three players in the   space (and two more coming) it's clearly a buyer's market.makeArticleAd();DISH Sling has the cheapest offer. Image source: DISH.DISH has the lowest base priceFor consumers looking to cut the cord in order to save money   (or those who never had a cord
column10: but are looking for the cheapest   way to have some live-streaming channels) DISH'sSling   TVmay be the answer. The service offers 30 channels including ESPN
column11: CNN
column12: TNT
column13: and a number of other cable favorites for $20 a month   as part of its ""Orange"" package. For $25 a month consumers could   opt for ""Blue"" which drops ESPN but adds the FOX family of   channels including the broadcast network while offering 44 total   choices.On top of the base packages Sling Subscribers can choose from   a number of extra add-ons in areas like news
column14: sports
column15: and kids   programming which cost $5 or $10 each. Sling members can also add   HBO
column16: Cinemax
column17: Starz
column18: or one of a variety of global programming   options which conveniently all work within the same player making   for a very television-like experience.PlayStation Vue is cord-free cableSony's PlayStation Vue has four packages starting at $29.99 a   month. The entry-level offer
column19: ""Access Slim"" comes with 45   channels
column20: including in very-limited markets some broadcast   networks. Most of the stations offered are the same ones Sling TV   has
column21: with consumers paying slightly more money for them. The   ""Core Slim"" package offers 60 channels for $34.99 (perhaps the   best deal) while ""Elite Slim"" comes with 90 channels for $44.99
column22: and Ultra Slim at $64.99 which has the same 90 channels plus HBO   and Showtime.Like Sling
column23: PlayStation Vue also offers add-on packages of   Spanish-language and news programs. In addition users can buy a   number of premium channels on a stand-alone basis along with HBO   and Showtime. The bottom tiers for PS Vue are very similar to   DISH
column24: albeit pricier
column25: while the higher-end tiers are essentially   full-on cable packages (minus the broadcast networks in most   cases) at better-than-cable pricing.Here's what DirecTV is doingAT&T's entree into the space looks a lot like Sony's.   DirecTV Now offers very similar pricing with 60 channels costing   $35
column26: including ABC and FOX
column27: along with some top-tier cable   favorites. $50 a month gets users 80-plus channels
column28: while $60 a   month comes with over 100
column29: and $70 takes the package to over 120   stations including Starz.Subscribers can also add Starz separately to lower-tier deals
column30: or add HBO or Cinemax. AT&T does not offer add-on channel   packages covering specialty stations the way its rivals do. In   addition DirecTV Now launches with better pricing (the $35 price   for the $50 package) and it seems likely that AT&T will offer   future specials likely tied to bundling other services from the   company.Which one is the best?For consumers it's easy to test each service because all offer   free trials
column31: while also letting users come and go as they please   without contracts or penalties. Sling has the best service for   people looking to cut expenses while Sony and AT&T offer good   deals on services that come close to mirroring actual cable. Of   those two
column32: DirecTV Now gets a slight edge because it offers ABC   and FOX nationally while PlayStation Vue only offers access to   broadcast networks selectively.In addition to varying channel selections
column33: all three services   have different rules when it comes to multiple streams. Sling   Orange
column34: the cheapest service
column35: only offers a single stream
column36: while   the $25 Blue packages allows three. DirectTV Now offers two   streams to all subscribers while Sony's service allows customers   to stream on five registered devices at a time giving PS Vue the   advantage in this area
column37: but it's a minor edge over Blue.When it comes to interface all three leave something to be   desired. Sony's service has a DVR (with a lot of limitations)   while Sling has some on-demand programming
column38: as does DirecTV. The   biggest drawback of the streaming services is that none of them   offer an experience that feels like flipping around with   traditional cable. Still
column39: once you have selected a show
column40: the   viewing experience works and feels familiar.Sony and AT&T have decent products that save consumers   some money over the average comparable cable package. But for a   traditional family watching on multiple televisions
column41: the savings   may not be worth the holes in what's offered along with a viewing   experience that still lags traditional cable. Sling has those   same limitations
column42: but the three streams for $25 Blue package   represents the best combo of content and value
column43: giving it a small   victory in an emerging space.10 stocks we like better than DISH NetworkWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Should Apple Inc. Cut Its Dividend? (AAPL);3/13/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is the world's largest technology company
column3: and it once was one of the best growth stocks on the market. It has shifted gears
column4: though
column5: and now Apple stock is one of the more promising dividend growth plays on the market.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrAAPL paid its first dividend - at least since 1995 - on Aug. 16
column6: 2012. It paid investors 38.9 cents per share on a split-adjusted basis.The payout has been hiked four times since
column7: and currently sits at 57 cents per share. That's a compound annual growth rate of 10%
column8: with 2017's dividend increase expected to be similar. After all
column9: AAPL stock only has a payout ratio of 27% of its trailing earnings and a 1.6% yield.When you look at shareholder yield - dividends plus buybacks - Apple's record is even more impressive. The company spent $12.2 billion on dividends and a whopping $29.2 billion on share repurchases in 2016. That works out to a shareholder yield of 5.6%.AAPL is returning capital at a blistering pace.10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the BillsHowever
column10: while most shareholders are ecstatic with the dividend on Apple stock
column11: allow me to present an alternate argument:Apple should cut its payout … and maybe even eliminate it altogether.Apple
column12: Meet AlphabetLet's take a minute to compare Apple to one of its peers
column13: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL).Alphabet's dividend policy is pretty clear. It saidin its 2016 10-K filing
column14: ""We have never declared or paid any cash dividend on our common or capital stock. We intend to retain any future earnings and do not expect to pay any cash dividends in the foreseeable future.""Alphabet can easily afford a dividend
column15: too. It made $19.5 billion in 2016
column16: or $28.32 per share.The reasoning behind this is simple. Alphabet is aggressively investing in the kinds of projects that can really boost its top line. It has been working on a self-driving car since 2009. It invested more than$6 billion on Google Fiber. Alphabet also teamed up withFidelitytoinvest $1 billion inSpaceX.In total
column17: Alphabet spent $13.9 billion on research and development in 2016
column18: as well as $10.2 billion on capital expenditures.Apple is still investing in the future
column19: but not as aggressively as Alphabet. AAPL spent $10 billion on research and development and $13.5 billion on capital expenditures in 2016
column20: despite making a net profit of $45.7 billion.In other words
column21: Alphabet reinvested $24.1 billion back into its business in 2016 while earning $19.5 billion. Apple reinvested $23.5 billion while earning $45.7 billion. AAPL barely reinvested half of its earnings back into its business.AAPL Needs to Make Some AcquisitionsApple does have some exciting plans. One of the tech world's worst-kept secrets is Apple's plans to somehow be a part of thecar of the future. It has also been working in thevirtual reality space
column22: and many expect big improvements toApple TV. These investments are great. But I don't think they'll be enough to usher in a new era of growth.It's time for Apple to go shopping.Apple could easily take the $41 billion it gave back to shareholders in 2016 and use it to make a huge splash.Say Apple agreed to buyNetflix
column23: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) at a 50% premium to today's price - so
column24: roughly $91 billion. AAPL could pay off the deal in just a few years from its existing cash flow alone
column25: and would own a company that has doubled revenues in the last three years.Intel Corporation (INTC) Buys Mobileye NV (MBLY) to Win the Auto MarketApple's main growth driver today is service revenue. In its most recent quarter
column26: AAPL grew its top line 3% on a quarter-over-quarter basis.It grew services revenue by 18%. Acquiring Netflix would would not only supercharge that division
column27: it would give Apple access to Netflix's whole library of content.The Bottom Line on Apple StockThere's a reason why AAPL trades at the same multiple as the rest of the market. Investors assume - rightfully so - that it is a mature company with no immediate growth prospects. If Apple slashed its dividend and announced it was using that money for acquisitions
column28: investors would sit up and take notice.There's no guarantee such sentiment would send Apple stock soaring right away. In fact
column29: it'd be easy to see the market taking the short-term view that something is amiss
column30: and selling AAPL as a result.But if executed right
column31: such a strategy would make Apple shareholders richer in the long run.As of this writing
column32: Nelson Smith did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him onTwitter
column33: or his own personal blog
column34: Financial Uproar.More From InvestorPlaceHow to Trade Advanced Micro Devices
column35: Inc. (AMD) Stock After It Rebounds7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You Back9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonThe postShould Apple Inc. Cut Its Dividend? (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Can NVIDIA Regain Its Mojo?;3/13/2017;"It seems somewhat disingenuous referring to a stock that has   rallied roughly 530% over the last five years as having ""lost its   mojo.""However
column2: the fact remains that shares of graphics chip leaderNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) have indeed fallen roughly 18% from their 52-week   high in early February.makeArticleAd();NVDAdata byYCharts.So
column3: how should investors think about this newfound bearishness   in NVIDIA shares? Does the sell-off in its stock represent a   paradigm shift in investor sentiment toward the company
column4: or does   it create an attractive potential entry point? Let's explore this   topic in greater detail.NVIDIA stock: What goes up must come down?The only major news to break since NVIDIA's stock peaked --   which occurred on February 7th -- was the company's release   of its full-year and fourth-quarter results for its fiscal year   2017
column5: which took place on February 9th. As a quick point of   clarification
column6: NVIDIA runs its fiscal year one full year ahead of   the calendar year
column7: for some odd reason.At any rate
column8: NVIDIA actually released earnings that exceeded   analyst estimates in terms of sales and profits.If anything
column9: it seems safe to say that some investors have   been simply taking profits on their NVIDIA investments
column10: a   strategy that seems sensible for short-term investors concerned   about NVDIIA's admittedly rich valuation. Moreover
column11: while it   enjoys many well-defined positives
column12: there is one potential storm   forming on the horizon that could sap some of the wind from   NVIDIA's sails.Long-time graphics laggardAdvanced Micro Devices(NASDAQ: AMD) plans to launch its Vega chip series later this   year
column13: a move that some analysts believe could allow AMD to steal   significant market GPU market share from NVIDIA. Though we don't   know any of the specifics regarding AMD's Vega chips yet
column14: the   hope is that they will serve as a cheaper alternative to NVIDIA's   GTX chip series
column15: while not sacrificing much in the way of   performance. If that proves to be the case
column16: NVIDIA could be   forced to lower the prices of corresponding chipsets. Of course
column17: worrying about this is putting the cart before the horse to a   certain extent
column18: but it bears noting as something that could   inhibit NVIDIA's growth. And given NVIDIA'ssky-high valuation
column19: that could be enough to compel investors sitting on large paper   gains to sell.Image source: NVIDIA.NVIDIA long-term business outlook remains favorableIn as much as NVIDIA has indeed ""lost its mojo
column20: it's   important to remember that NVIDIA's multiyear investment thesis   appearsas strong as ever. As we saw in its earnings release
column21: the main drivers   underpinning NVIDIA's growth today are high-end gaming
column22: artificial intelligence (AI) software
column23: and self-driving cars.eSports still don't receive a lot of coverage from the   mainstream media
column24: but the craze's momentum is undeniable.   eSport's global audience was estimated to reach 256 million   viewers in 2016
column25: according to one industry researcher. Large   events regularly enjoy sponsorship from blue-chip brands likeCoca-Cola
column26: Nissan
column27: and more
column28: which has led to a dramatic increase in purse sizes   for some of the genre's most popular events. This
column29: in turn
column30: has   helped increase the awareness of the pastime to many casual fans
column31: particularly in Asia
column32: where the sport is most popular. The   same researcher believes total revenue related to eSports will   reach $1.1 billion by 2019
column33: up from $463 million in 2016. The   rush of money and interest into the sport should help continue to   create demand for NVIDIA's best-of-breed graphics processing   chips
column34: which rose 44% last year.Better still
column35: major trends like AI software and driverless   cars remain in their early stages. Last year
column36: NVIDIA saw an   unprecedented surge in demand for its GPUs to power an impressive   host of applications. NVIDIA's GPUs are the chip of choice to   power the various AI projects at tech giants such asMicrosoft
column37: Alphabet
column38: Facebook
column39: the National Cancer Institute
column40: the U.S. Department of Energy
column41: and many others. Turning to self-driving cars
column42: NVIDIA has also   partnered with an impressive array of major automakers
column43: though this technology figures to more meaningfully contribute to   its growth early next decade.Not to belabor the point
column44: but hopefully it's clear now that   NVIDIA has far from lost its mojo. True
column45: the company's stock   prices has fallen from its recent all-time highs
column46: but it easily   remains in positive territory over the last 12 months
column47: and for   good reason. NVIDIA is one of the best-positioned companies to   profit from several of the largest continuing trends in   technology.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Rev Up Free Profits from Ford Motor Company (F) Stock;3/13/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLast year
column3: I delivered results tradingFord Motor Company(NYSE:F)
column4: the easiest of which was a range trade thatyielded 50%. This year I am chasing a potential breakout that has been slowly developing.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockFundamentally
column5: Ford has good management pedigree. They weathered the effects of the 2008 financial crisis as well as could be expected. For the last few years we've had record vehicle sales.Therein lies my frustration with this breakout. Everything is going the auto manufacturing industry
column6: yet their stocks have yet to wow us. Ford stock has been in a descending trend for almost two years.Click to EnlargeEquity markets are at all-time highs. With auto sales also at or near record levels
column7: I expect better performance from F stock. For some reason it's mired under $13 and in a descending trend.General Motors Company(NYSE:GM)
column8: on the other hand
column9: has enjoyed an ascending 12 month trend.Even so
column10: I still like the Ford trade better.10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the BillsTechnically
column11: the recent price action in F stock has been building energy. We see lower highs and higher lows coming to a tight point. This energy needs to resolve itself soon. Unless there is bad news coming from Ford or a general equity correction
column12: the move should be to the upside.If that happens
column13: it could rally 8% to 10%. Today I want to set a pair trade to capture the upside breakout.F Stock Trade IdeaThe Bet:Buy the F May $13 call for 23 cents per contract. This will give me over two months to capture an upside move.To lower my out-of-pocket expenses
column14: I will finance the bet by selling risk against lower levels of Ford that I deem safe given the current environment.The Bank:Sell the F Sept $11 put and collect 35 cents. This is a bullish trade that commits me to buying F stock if price falls below it. I have an 85% theoretical chance of having F stock stay above my sold put. I only sell naked puts if I am willing to own it there.Taking both trades means that I am getting paid to bet on a Ford stock rally. Even if nothing happens
column15: I would be left with a net credit. As long as the price stays above $11 per share
column16: any premium I collect from selling back the May call is pure profit.Since I am not required to hold my trades open through expiration
column17: I can close any of them for partial gains or losses at any time.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column18: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlace7 Future Blue-Chip Stocks You Need to BuyAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Android Smartphones Found With Pre-Installed Malware10 Mutual Funds You Can Buy and Hold ForeverThe postRev Up Free Profits from Ford Motor Company (F) Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column2: Inc. (FSLR) Stock

column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFirst Solar
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:FSLR) is having a rough go of it. FSLR stock has plummeted as much as 17% since reaching its February high of $38.50
column6: and nowthe solar stock is being booted from theS&P 500.makeArticleAd();Source:U.S. Department of the Interior via FlickrYes
column7: the residential solar installer recently beat Wall Street's fourth-quarter estimates on both the top and bottom lines
column8: and raised its sales guidance for 2017.However
column9: thanks to apre-tax charge of $729 millionduring the quarter
column10: the company reversed last year's Q4 operating income of $131.82 million to a loss of $765.41 million. What's more

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Android Smartphones Found With Pre-Installed Malware;3/13/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMalware made the leap from PCs to smartphones along with users. It's always been known that devices runningAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Android operating system are much more susceptible to being infected thanApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones. However
column3: the situation may be even worse than we realized.makeArticleAd();Source: Check Point Software TechnologiesA mobile security research team posted on Friday that it scanned devices owned by two large companies and found Android malwarepre-installedon smartphones from 38 different manufacturers.That discovery should concern both corporate IT departments
column4: and consumers. And it once again validates Apple's ""controlling"" iPhone approach.Android Malware Illustrates the Downside of Google's ApproachFrom the launch of the first iPhone in 2007
column5: Apple retained full control of its iOS operating system and installed it only on its own hardware. Apps can only be downloaded from the App Store and these are checked and vetted by Apple engineers.7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You BackWith limited hardware configurations
column6: Apple is able to test iOS thoroughly for all iPhone users. The company is aggressive about pushing out new iOS versions (79% of all iPhones are running iOS 10)
column7: and in the event of a security issue
column8: it's able to quickly push out system updates to address it.With Android
column9: GOOGL took a very different approach from Apple. It went wide open
column10: licensing Android to dozens of different smartphone manufacturers. Users are free to tinker with the operating system and they can download apps from virtually anywhere - not just Google Play. This open approach helped Google to dominate the smartphone industry
column11: with nine out of 10 new smartphones running Android.But the approach makes smartphone security a nightmare.Android updates often require manufacturer and/or carrier cooperation. As a result
column12: only 2% of Android devices are running the latest version of Android
column13: while the majority are running software that's at least several years out of date.Freedom to install questionable apps plus an older version of the operating system has let Android malware run rampant. At one point it was estimated to account for97% of all mobile malware.Check Point's Pre-Installed Android Malware DiscoveryCheck Point Software Technologies Ltd.(NASDAQ:CHKP)
column14: an IT security company
column15: reported in aFriday blog postthat it had scanned the smartphones for two large companies (identified only as ""large telecommunications company"" and a ""multinational technology company"") and discovered Android malware had been pre-installed on smartphones from 38 different hardware manufacturers.Android malware identified ranged from adware to mobile ransomware capable of encrypting all data on the device until a fee is paid to unlock it. Some had been added to the smartphone ROM
column16: meaning reinstalling Android would not remove it. And none of this malware was downloaded by users. The smartphones arrived at the two companies pre-infected
column17: with installation happening ""somewhere along the supply chain.""Some of the most popularAndroid smartphones from 38 different manufacturers were infected
column18: includingSamsung Electronics Co Ltd's(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) best-selling Galaxy S7. Also caught in the sweep was the Nexus 5 - anLGsmartphone co-developed with Google.The Nexus 5 is several years old
column19: but the Android malware discovered on it had been there since the time of delivery.If a smartphone released in cooperation with Google itself is not immune from being infected before it even reaches the user
column20: then Android's smartphone security issue is even bigger than previously thought.Apple's Long-Term AdvantageThis isn't the first time Android malware has made headlines. Last November
column21: Check Point discovered a widespreadinfection of Android smartphones with HummingBad. This Chinese malware was found to have infected over 10 million Android smartphones worldwide.3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Mobileye NV (MBLY)
column22: Advanced Micro Devices
column23: Inc. (AMD) and Boeing Co (BA)And of course
column24: there was the infamousWikiLeaks CIA dumplast week that shone a light on smartphone security and the tools used by government agencies to bypass it. Several dozen Android vulnerabilities were revealed
column25: along with 14 iOS exploits.The difference is
column26: Apple had addressed most of the iPhone issues in iOS 10
column27: which has widespread adoption. Google may have patched Android
column28: but chances are most Android smartphones out there won't get the update and will remain vulnerable. This latest Android malware discovery shows that the weakness to GOOGL's approach extends all the way to the supply chain. Even the most trusted manufacturers are not immune to having their smartphones compromised before the consumer even gets their hands on them.Google's wide-open Android approach has let it build a commanding 90% smartphone marketshare. But with Android malware increasingly in the spotlight and no easy solution in sight
column29: the stage is set for Apple to press its advantage over GOOGL's approach.Apple built its iPhone empire around premium design
column30: ease of use and plentiful apps. But its advantage in smartphone security may turn out to be the factor that lets it eat into Google's Android lead in the long term.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceTrade of the Day: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL)An Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone Factory in America? Maybe Not.How to Trade Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Near All-Time HighsThe postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Android Smartphones Found With Pre-Installed Malwareappeared first onInvestorPlace."
