column1: Voice: The Next Computing Empire;3/11/2017;"This article is the first in a two-part series aimed at     exploring the rapidly developing state of voice computing from     the investor's perspective. In Part I
column2: I discuss why it's now     increasingly clear that the human voice will become society's     next major computing interface
column3: and why it will continue     proliferating through our homes and businesses. In Part II
column4: I'll dive deeper into the new and emerging business models. In     Part II
column5: I'll discuss the various players involved in the race     to commercialize the technology -- those best-positioned to     profit today
column6: those positioning themselves to thrive tomorrow
column7: and those dropping the ball entirely. I'll also dive deeper     into the fascinating business models voice computing will soon     enable
column8: and how those models will evolve as the technology     continues to improve.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();For nearly 40 years
column9: we've seen the computer evolve into an   indispensable accessory of Western society driven by three   powerful technologies that defined their eras and played a   monumental role for investors along the way.The personal computer gave many of us our first glimpse at the   digital world
column10: normalizing the idea that such machines have a   place in our homes and everyday lives. The internet tapped us   into that world
column11: offering us endless floods of information
column12: entertainment
column13: and commerce around which we willingly began   shaping our civilization. And then the smartphone encouraged us   to take that digital world everywhere we go
column14: leaving nothing but   a few taps on a touchscreen between us
column15: our computers
column16: and   constant immersion.Now
column17: a fourth technology -- voice computing--is removing that last barrier.Reimagining the roles computers playImagine driving down the highway
column18: coming home from work
column19: and     without taking your hands off the wheel or hitting any buttons
column20: asking your car to turn up the heat in your house
column21: preheat the     oven for dinner
column22: and play your favorite album
column23: all in the same     breath. Picture negotiating with a street vendor in Beijing
column24: having your phone translate the entire conversation between     Mandarin and English out loud
column25: so you can haggle in real time.     Or how about a stuffed animal that can tell your daughter     interactive stories every night before bed
column26: reshaping the     adventure at every twist and turn based on her responses and     reactions.These aren't hypothetical scenarios -- they're happening     right now.The human voice is well on its way to becoming the next     major medium we use to interact with computers
column27: and as we'll     explore in this two-part series
column28: voicecomputingis the burgeoning field of technology making it possible.     Already spanning multiple consumer and enterprise ventures     (think call center routing
column29: digital dictation
column30: or the virtual     assistants on smartphones)
column31: the industry's ultimate aim is     enabling people to carry on hands-free
column32: conversational-style     interactions with computers.It's an ambitious prospect capable of significantly     expanding the roles computers play in our everyday lives
column33: but     it's also one that appears inevitable when considering the     trajectory computers have taken
column34: without fail
column35: since their     introduction
column36: evolving in shape and form around contemporary     technology to solve unmet needs.Image Source: Getty ImagesAnd yet voice computing's evolution is different. Unlike any     form of computing to come before it
column37: the technology bypasses     the physical realm
column38: allowing users to query the internet
column39: manage their surroundings
column40: and connect to third-party services     without ever having to touch a physical device -- all in the     time it takes to form a sentence.If that sounds unnecessary
column41: then consider just how limitless     the applications could be. From the surgeon who needs to     rapidly adjust the conditions of her operating room     mid-procedure
column42: to the disabled veteran who simply hopes to     access the appliances in his home. The sheer number of everyday     applications for such a technology has prompted Grand View     Research to project the global market for voice recognition     technology will reach $128 billion annually by 2024
column43: an     estimate that may undershoot the overall economic opportunity     at play considering the potential verticals include healthcare
column44: defense
column45: entertainment
column46: consumer goods
column47: and more (I'll discuss     these in more detail in Part II).There is one thing we can be certain of
column48: however. Voice     computing is extremely likely to transform the way we interact     with technology in society
column49: but before that can happen
column50: a     large-scale societal shift toward adopting the interface must     occur
column51: a shift thatcannotoccur until several key hurdles are overcome.Understanding the challenges aheadTo analyze those obstacles
column52: let's turn to the most       promising application of voice-driven technology today:       virtual digital assistants.Data Sources: Socratic Technologies
column53: Vantiv
column54: Statista.         Chart by AuthorThanks to the success of the iPhone andApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) other devices
column55: Siri is currently the most       wildly used virtual assistant in the United States
column56: but until       recently
column57: it's also perfectly exemplified what's holding       voice computing back. To put it simply
column58: speaking with Siri       can often feel more like a novelty than a time-saver
column59: a       sentiment shared not just among Apple users
column60: but most       smartphone owners with access to similar voice computing       technology.It's a problem we can break down into three fundamental       hurdles.The first is that users must often resort to awkward       combinations of hyper-specific phrasing and hurried       robo-speak to have their speech accurately recognized. Andrew       Ng
column61: chief scientist atBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) and one the most respected names in the field
column62: perhaps put it best in 2015 when he noted
column63: ""Speech       recognition
column64: depending on the circumstances
column65: is say 95 per       cent accurate. So maybe it gets one word in 20 wrong. That's       really annoying if it gets one in 20 wrong and you probably       don't want to use it very often. That's probably where speech       recognition is today.""The second hurdle is that even when our speech iscorrectlyrecognized
column66: there still remains a strong chance it will bemisinterpretedwhile undergoing natural language understanding
column67: a process in       which the assistant attempts to comprehend what we want using       the sequence of words (and eventually
column68: the tone
column69: pace
column70: and       inflection) we give. And even if that speech is correctly       understood
column71: an assistant may still simply be unable to solve       for the request due to technical constraints. Examples of       both cases can be seen in the screenshot below
column72: along with a       sense of how frustrating the encounter can be.Image Source: Author's iPhoneEncounters like these make us feel as though we're wasting       our time trusting our phones to do what we could have done       ourselves with only a little more effort upfront. Over time
column73: they build up
column74: eventually discouraging us from even tryingto       use our assistants for anything complex
column75: instead relying on       them only for the most trivial of tasks
column76: like setting alarms       or creating reminders.Thankfully
column77: these first two hurdles are solvable with data
column78: third-party partnerships
column79: and time
column80: each of which the major   players in this space have been actively accruing for years.   Returning to our example
column81: since Siri was introduced to the world   in 2011
column82: virtual assistants have grown far more capable of   correctly interpreting requests thanks to advances in deep   learning
column83: a thriving field of AI being utilized byAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column84: Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column85: Baidu
column86: and others to improve speech recognition
column88: and other components of voice   computing at astounding rates. (Click herefor an outstanding story byThe New York Timeson Google's significant role in making this happen).Equally as important
column89: decisions by Apple and its competitors   to open their platforms up to third-party services have made   today's voice-based assistants feel far more capable than in   years past. These decisions allow Siri
column91: to call you   a ride using your Uber account
column92: or order a pizza through your   storedDomino'sinformation -- not unlike anactualsecretary would do.As the potential behind voice computing becomes increasingly   obvious in the coming months and years
column93: we should expect more and   more third parties to hop on board
column94: eventually expanding the   scope of what a partnership could entail (instead of ordering an   Uber
column95: imagine ordering a plane ticket). One look at the rate of   growth for third-party commands available on Amazon's voice-based   assistant
column97: can tell us a lot.Data Source: Voicebot. Chart by AuthorWith time
column98: these technical achievements and partnerships will   continue compounding
column99: eventually making for a highly practical   voice computing experience. Even marginal improvements in the   technology will convince users to begin using voice as an   interface more frequently. In the same talk regarding the current   state of the voice industry
column101: ""I think that as   speech recognition accuracy goes from say 95 per cent to 98
column103: all of us in the room will go from barely using it   today
column104: to using it all the time."" He added
column105: ""Most people   underestimate the difference between 95 and 99 per cent ... 99   per cent is a game changer.""Although we're not yet able to predict when the technology   will reach that point
column106: if the recent pace of progress is any   indication -- since Ng's speech
column107: Baidu has built a program   capable of dictating English three times faster
column109: than human beings -- it won't be much longer.In the meantime
column110: an arguably far more important hurdle stands   in the way. It's a problem shared by every other major computing   medium in use today
column111: only voice is actually solving for it.An instantaneous computing experienceNo matter the medium
column112: we've always interacted with computers   by issuing commands. In the 1950s
column113: we meticulously punched those   commands into cards before feeding them into hulking machines.   Now
column114: technology allows us to simply type
column118: speak them and expect a result.Yet despite these advancements
column119: today's mediums still subject   users to a unique set of delays
column120: a sort of friction that   inherently slows down the process betweenthinkinga command and actually being able tocommunicatethat command to your devices. A decade ago
column121: that friction most   likely entailed tracking down a PC with internet
column122: using the mouse   to open a browser
column123: using the keyboard to run a search
column124: and then   sorting for the result. But today
column126: it simply   means reaching into our pockets for our phone
column128: and tapping away.It's a process so effortless
column129: the average American now checks   their phone an estimated 46 times per day. It's even become   fashionable to argue there's no longerenoughfriction separating society from our devices; that we'retooplugged in to the digital world.So when you consider that voice computing's primary advantage   iseliminatingfriction
column130: it becomes tempting to dismiss the technology as a   solution to a trivial problem. What that argument critically   fails to consider
column132: is that friction is about more than   simple convenience
column133: and that any amount of friction
column135: fundamentally limits the dynamic between a user and   their computing medium in two ways.Let's take the smartphone for example.Image Source: PixabayThe seemingly trivial motions we make when reaching for our   phone still require us to be in immediate proximity of the   device. We have to walk over to kitchen counter if we left our   phone there; we have to remember it's on the counter even before   we can do that. Then
column137: we're   required to physically handle it
column138: a process that generally   requires we have one hand free and able.That may not sound like much
column139: but these limitations force our   computing experience to revolve around the location of our   device
column140: as opposed to it revolving around us.They can create roadblocks for those with disabilities affecting   their vision or hands (or really
column141: even those who just have sticky   hands
column144: those far away from their   device
column146: those with an immediate computing   need.There's a reason speech is our most instinctual form of   communication.If we have a question
column147: and if we know those around us can   answer that question
column148: we don't pull out our phone and run a   search
column149: we open our mouths and ask. We do that because it's   instantaneous. Now contrast that with having to locate your   phone
column150: having to type in your password
column151: having to navigate to an   app
column154: or speak your command. These behaviors   are not instinctual
column155: but we put up with them because the people around us usually   don't have the answers
column156: and because smartphones are our best   alternative.But they don't have to be.The rise of voiceIt's not obvious quite yet
column157: but today's physically bound   mediums have left a large hole to fill and voice computing is   starting to fill it.Over the past two years
column158: the technology has begun manifesting   itself in the form of always-on
column159: always-listening devices able to   virtually bypass the friction inherent in today's major computing   mediums. Currently
column160: these devices are best exemplified by   Amazon's line of Echo smart speakers
column161: which employ far-field   voice recognition technology allowing users to command Alexa from   across multiple rooms and through various background noises at   any time simply by calling for it out loud.Image Source: Amazon.com.Put another way
column163: Amazon's Echo is giving   consumers their first glimpse at a frictionless computing   experience. Following its initial setup
column165: no looking around for the device
column166: and no navigating   through screens to issue a command. When it works correctly (like   Siri
column167: Alexa is still very much in its infancy and subject to   misinterpreting commands) it really does allow users to convert   their thoughts to a command in the time it takes to form a   sentence
column168: capturing the essential promise of voice as a   medium.And if the early estimated adoption rate for the device is any   indication -- Amazon hasn't officially released sales   figures
column170: Consumer Intelligence Research   Partners (CIRP) estimates a staggering 8.2 million Echos have   already been sold in the U.S. (a number that pales in comparison   to Morgan Stanley's estimates of over 11 million)
column171: suggesting the   device has achieved well over 5% household penetration -- early   demand for a seamless computing experience is strong
column172: and will   likely grow stronger as capable competitors race to introduce   their own offerings (see Google's Home
column177: and third-party   support continue improving at rapid pace.Data Sources: VoiceLabs
column180: InfoScout. *2017     figures are VoiceLab projections. Chart by AuthorTo be clear
column181: these devices will never replace today's existing   computing mediums
column182: but will rather augment them. While   screens will remain the preferred medium for our more detailed   and visual computing needs
column183: voice will begin its ascent by taking   on an increasing share of our more ""conversational"" demands
column184: common requests we want addressed with the immediacy we expect   from dialogue (""Cancel my doctor's appointment."" ""Pause that   music!"" ""What's a good non-fiction book to read on the beach? ...   Great
column185: order that one."")As the technology grows capable of handling increasingly   nuanced and complex requests
column186: and as voice-enabled devices   proliferate and evolve
column187: we can expect more users to grow   comfortable engaging with the technology around the home
column189: and gradually more pervasive aspects of society.Andthat'swhere the real opportunities begin.The opportunity at handSome of the biggest tech empires in modern history have been   built around the personal computer
column192: each of which has provided the infrastructure for technology to   penetrate deeper and more reflexively into everyday life
column193: allowing creative companies to reach consumers in entirely new   ways.In just 10 years
column194: the iPhone helped Apple grow to become the   largest corporation in the world
column195: but it also popularized   smartphone technology in the U.S.
column196: helping to create the   infrastructure that in turn enabledFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column203: and countless others to create businesses that   reach deeper into our lives than any before.Image Source: Author's iPhoneAnd yet voice technology is going deeper.It's becoming an invisible
column205: weaving itself more seamlessly into the fabric of   our lives than any before it. It's called on using our most   instinctual
column207: and it's accessible   in the time it takes to form words. It's a technology that   provides tomorrow's innovators a far more intimate and pervasive   way to help us satisfy our digital wants.It's a startling but increasingly inevitable reality for both   investors and society.In Part II: The Playing Field
column208: I'll discuss various players   involved in the race to commercialize voice computing. To be the   first to know when Part II is released

column1: The 5 Biggest Challenges to the Driverless Car Revolution;3/11/2017;"The year 2017 is gearing up to be a momentous year for the   driverless car race. But despite major initiatives by   megacorporationsAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column2: Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column3: and others
column4: there are major road blocks ahead   for the driverless car revolution. A recentMcKinseyreport highlights five of them.1. PricingNo matter how incredible an innovation might be
column5: it's useless   if it's not affordable. Although Alphabet's Waymo has clocked   more than 2 million road miles in its autonomous vehicles
column6: McKinsey estimates that self-driving cars are ""unlikely to be   available before 2020."" Alphabet and others are inching closer to   commercializing their products. A partnership withFiat Chrysler Automobiles NV(NYSE: FCAU) will
column7: for the first time
column8: take Alphabet's autonomous   driving technology out of its peculiar ""panda car"" and into 100   Pacifica Hybrid minivans in early 2017. But those minivans aren't   for sale
column9: and
column10: if they were
column11: would probably cost magnitudes more   than an average minivan.2. Consumer UnderstandingmakeArticleAd();Video source: Waymo viaYouTubeEven if driverless cars become affordable
column12: no one will buy   them if they don't understand them. That means that self-driving   car companies need to educate consumers on the advantages of   autonomous vehicles. Informational videos like the one above   produced by Alphabet's Waymo are an important start
column13: and others   like Tesla Motors are producing their ownvideo vignettesto make self-driving cars salient. Tesla Motors and others have a   clear business incentive to make self-driving seem mainstream
column14: and the more that their message is spread
column15: the brighter the   future for their sales and sustainability.3. Safety/Security issuesConsumer understanding goes hand in hand with a major concern   about autonomous technology -- safety and security. At no point   was this clearer than in May 2016
column16: when Tesla Motors reported the   first driver fatality while its Autopilot technology was engaged.   The tragic crash occurred when neither the driver nor Tesla   Motors' technology recognized a truck's white-colored trailer   crossing its path on a highway. There will certainly be more   tragedies in the future of autonomous vehicles
column17: and it will   remain a continuing challenge and the highest priority for   self-driving car companies to minimize safety and security   issues. However
column18: it's also important to remember that these   high-profile cases can cause over-reactions
column19: and sticking to   statistics can help investors
column20: companies
column21: and consumers alike   identify the best autonomous option for investing
column22: manufacturing
column23: and purchasing.4 & 5: Regulation and TechnologyAs with all new innovations
column24: regulation and technology can   make or break a revolution. The McKinsey report is quick to note   that regulation is a hurdle
column25: rather than a never-ending issue. It   makes sense
column26: then
column27: that Ford
column28: Alphabet
column29: Lyft
column30: Uber
column31: and Volvo   Cars have all joined together to create the ""Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets."" Rather than rally for ""wild west"" free market competition
column32: these companies want to see a sensible framework of standardized   regulation upon which they can confidently build their new   business units.Technology isn't a hurdle
column33: but there is a minimum threshold   below which driverless cars will never be the norm. Companies   like Alphabet's Waymo and Tesla Motors are aiming for full   autonomy
column34: while others are taking the more step-wise approach of   offering semi-autonomous additions like Audi's ""Traffic Jam   Assist."" The McKinsey report estimates that
column35: once regulation and   technology issues have been resolved
column36: ""up to 15 percent of new   cars sold in 2030 could be fully autonomous.""Hit the brakes?Image Source: Getty Images.2017 will not be the year self-driving cars take over our   roads. Pricing
column37: consumer understanding
column38: safety/security
column39: regulation
column40: and technology issues will continue to impede this   industry's revolution. But Alphabet
column41: Tesla Motors
column42: and others are   making steady gains on addressing these issues
column43: and the ultimate   widespread adoption of autonomous technology is almost   inarguable. Forward-looking investors with long-term horizons   should acknowledge these issues
column44: select their self-driving stocks   accordingly

column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) shareholders. AMD stock

column11: Advanced Micro Devices has a lot more going for it besides the new CPU that investors aren't giving it credit for. Three specific items come to mind. Note than a handful of AMD's competitors are now becoming partners.3 Things AMD Still Has Going For ItWhile investors had high expectations for Ryzen
column12: the future for Advanced Micro Devices isn't dependent on it. In fact
column13: there are three other areas that may end up meaning even more for its top and bottom lines.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonIn no particular order …Penetrating the Cloud Market:While AMD has always had a presence in most key tech markets
column14: cloud computing was never a key one for the company. That's changing now though… a ball that got rolling just in the past few weeks. In November
column15: Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google division tapped AMD
column16: looking to add its graphical processor units to Google's machine learning architecture.It's a curious development
column17: as GPU chips weren't designed to do anything more than handle a computer's display screen. As it turns out
column18: though
column19: its GPUs are very capable of parallel computing
column20: which is a critical aspect of this new cloud-based function.In the meantime
column21: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) selected AMD processors to power its next-generation open course cloud platform.At stake is a piece of the cloud infrastructure market worth an estimated $300 billion per year.More Licensing Revenue:It's only an unconfirmed rumor thus far
column22: but a reasonably credible one. That is
column23: Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) is reportedly interested in using AMDs Radeon graphics technology to power Intel's integrated GPUs in future computers … displacingNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA). The agreement between Nvidia and Intel ends at the end of March.At the very least
column24: the prospect of such an IP licensing deal could mean a couple hundred million dollars in annual high-margin revenue. If Intel really wants to step up its game
column25: though
column26: it could help fund improvements in the way its CPUs handle graphics.New GPUs Will Enhance New CPU Revenue:While the reviews for the new Ryzen processor have been mixed
column27: AMD stock holders should bear in mind that they're only half the next generation of hardware for Advanced Micro Devices.The other half of the one-two punch combination for AMD this year is the new Vega GPU
column28: which should be unveiled around the middle of this year.As was noted back on Feb. 7:""Vega
column29: is a second-generation high bandwidth memory (or HBM2) design found on a stacked-memory architecture that performs significantly better than the more common GDDR5 (double data rate type-five) utilized by most graphics processing units today. An essentially-infinite amount of memory can be dedicated to handling the display - the maximum virtualization is capped at a ridiculous 512 terabytes. This platform is about twice as powerful as most current alternatives
column30: and will make Advanced Micro Devices competitive with the newest generation of GPU architecture from Nvidia
column31: called Pascal.""More important
column32: Vega was largely built with the Ryzen processor in mend
column33: with each getting the most performance out of one another.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock Is the Perfect Buy at This PriceIn the meantime
column34: it's not like the Ryzen CPU is a lost cause.As the company's CEO Lisa Su recently explained
column35: ""We hear people on wanting to see improved 1080p performance and we fully expect that Ryzen performance in 1080p will only get better as developers get more time with 'Zen.' We have over 300+ developers now working with 'Zen' and several of the developers for Ashes of Singularity and Total [War:] Warhammer are actively optimizing now.""Bottom Line for AMD StockAs encouraging as the future may be for the company whether or not Ryzen ends up performing well
column36: there's still no denying that AMD stock is overbought and ripe for some profit-taking; that 16% dip is nothing compared to 2016's huge rally.But don't confuse any future weakness from AMD as evidence of what's in store
column37: results-wise
column38: from the company. Advanced Micro Devices is very well positioned for a great 2017. The trick is just being patient enough to wait for a truly palatable entry price. That could still be well below the recent low.In other words
column39: you don't want to step into AMD stock for the long haul until it's almost uncomfortable to do so. We aren't there yet.As of this writing
column40: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Reasons Advanced Micro Devices

column1: Why Excluding Snap From the S&P 500 Is a Big Deal;3/9/2017;"Snap's(NYSE: SNAP) decision to issue non-voting shares through its   IPO may already have cost it billions of dollars in investor   support.A group of institutional investors have approached stock index   providers S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI to bar the shares   from becoming part of several major indexes. Their argument is   that one of the criteria for inclusion in the indexes is ""a   corporate governance structure consistent with U.S. practice.""   Snap's corporate structure is quite unusual
column2: with the founders   holding about 90% of the voting rights
column3: and average investors   holding no votes at all.Excluding Snap shares from the S&P 500 may not sound like   a big deal -- it doesn't affect the underlying fundamentals of   the company. But the growing popularity of index funds and ETFs   means Snap will miss out on billions of dollars of buyer support   that early investors may have been expecting down the road.makeArticleAd();Image source: Spectacles.com.$6 trillion and growingIndex funds and ETFs are expected to overtake actively managed   investments in the next seven years or so
column4: according to Moody's.   Currently
column5: investors have plowed $6 trillion in assets into the   passive investments. $2 trillion of those assets track the   S&P 500 index.Getting added to the S&P 500 is a big deal. WhenAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) was added to the S&P 500
column6: it   received an immediate 7% bump in its share price.Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) received a 4% boost upon the news that it would have   a place in the index.What's more
column7: the stocks continued to benefit for some time as   active funds that are benchmarked against the index were   compelled to buy more shares of the heavily weighted stocks.   Alphabet and Facebook are two of the largest companies in the   S&P 500. Snap
column8: with its market cap floating around $30   billion
column9: would be more moderately weighted than both
column10: but it   would still see similar benefits.Snap knew this was a possibilityIn Snap's S-1 filing with the SEC
column11: it wrote that it couldn't   predict whether its decision to make its Class A shares   non-voting ""will result in adverse publicity or other adverse   consequences."" Certainly
column12: it saw it as a possibility
column13: and it even   noted that no other company has made an IPO with non-voting   shares.While Snap's capital structure is different from those of most   U.S. companies
column14: it's worth noting that it's not the only company   with non-voting shares. In fact
column15: Alphabet has two publicly traded   share classes -- one voting and one non-voting -- and it's   included in the S&P 500. Likewise
column16: Facebook plans to issue   two non-voting (Class C) shares to current shareholders of any   class under its approved stock split plan.But the fact that investors cannot buy voting shares of Snap   on the open market makes its situation unique.How will it impact investors?While having buyer support in the form of institutional   investors is a nice insurance policy
column17: it's not the only thing   that matters. After all
column18: the primary driver of a stock's value is   the underlying company's performance. If Snap can continue   growing its user base and revenue at a rapid clip
column19: the share   price should inevitably climb to meet its fundamental   performance.There are a lot of question marks surrounding Snap
column20: especially   in light of the recent slowdown in user growth seemingly brought   on by the increased intensity of Facebook's competition. The   potential for several major indexes to exclude the stock make it   even riskier.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column21: it can pay to listen. After all
column22: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column23: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column24: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Snap Inc. wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Get Your "MPA" in Deep Learning;3/9/2017;"Big happenings in AI land recently as new supercomputers get built and Einstein meets Watson. Both events were announced on March 6
column2: 2017 and old Big Blue
column3: IBM
column4: finds itself at the center of all of this
column5: still as relevant as the day Deep Blue beat Garry Kasparov in 1996.The supercomputer comes from Fujitsu who is using 24NVIDIA (NVDA)DGX-1 AI systems to help build a supercomputer for RIKEN
column6: Japan's largest comprehensive research institution
column7: for deep learning research. Scheduled to go online in April 2017
column8: the RIKEN Center for Advanced Intelligence Project will use the new system as a platform to accelerate R&D into AI technology.The largest customer installation of DGX-1 systems to date
column9: the supercomputer will accelerate the application of AI to solve complex challenges in healthcare
column10: manufacturing and public safety.""DGX-1 is like a time-machine for AI researchers
column11: said Jen-Hsun Huang
column12: founder and CEO of NVIDIA. ""Enterprises
column13: research centers and universities worldwide are adopting DGX-1 to ride the wave of deep learning - the technology breakthrough at the center of the AI revolution.""According to the NVIDIA blog post on this news…""Conventional HPC (High-Performance Computing) architectures are proving too costly and inefficient for meeting the needs of AI researchers. So companies like Fujitsu and customers like RIKEN are looking for GPU-based solutions that reduce cost and power consumption while increasing performance. Each DGX-1 combines the power of eight NVIDIA Tesla P100 GPUs with an integrated software stack optimized for deep learning frameworks
column14: delivering the performance of 250 conventional x86 servers.""In the video that accompanies this article
column15: I share some simple graphics from NVIDIA that explain how GPU (graphics processing unit) semiconductors work.In the video
column16: I also explain the IBM-NVDA connection as the two have been working together for several years on building HPC architectures and in November announced collaboration on a new deep learning tool ""to help train computers to think and learn in more human-like ways at a faster pace.""Einstein Taps Watson's BrainThe second story revolving around IBM

column1: 1 Top Small-Cap Stock to Buy Now;3/9/2017;"Small-cap stocks can deliver explosive gains -- or sizable   losses. Choose well
column2: and these high-risk yet potentially   high-reward stocks can deliver multibagger returns and   turbocharge your portfolio's overall performance. But choose   poorly
column3: and a small-cap stock can produce painful losses
column4: up to   and including a complete loss of capital should the business be   forced into bankruptcy.That's why it's so important to invest in only the best of   these businesses -- those poised to benefit from undeniable   long-term trends and enjoy the largest growth opportunities. Read   on to learn about one such business that meets these challenging   criteria -- and that is one of the small-cap stocks best   positioned to reward investors in the years ahead.Image source: Mindbody.makeArticleAd();Mindbody(NASDAQ: MB) provides cloud-based software solutions to the   health and wellness industry: Think spas
column5: yoga studios
column6: and   fitness classes. It's a massive market that's gone largely   underserved -- and Mindbody is working to address that need.Mindbody's all-in-one solution helps its clients manage nearly   every aspect of their businesses. Need to post an online class   schedule and allow your clients to book appointments through   their smartphones? Mindbody has you covered. Want an easy way to   manage your employees' schedules? No problem. How about   processing payments? Mindbody can help you with that
column7: too.With plans starting at just $75 per month
column8: Mindbody's   offerings are affordable even for start-ups with the most limited   financial resources. And an increasing number of larger   businesses are utilizing Mindbody's more extensive -- and   higher-priced -- packages. In this way
column9: Mindbody is able to scale   its business along with the success of its customers.More than 60
column10: 000 businesses have turned to Mindbody's platform   for these solutions. That's up from less than 34
column11: 000 subscribers   in the first quarter of 2014. During this time
column12: Mindbody's   revenue has nearly doubled from $70 million in 2014 to $139   million last year.Still
column13: Mindbody isnot yet profitable
column14: which is likely why its stock is currently trading for around   $27; properly valuing early-stage growth companies can be   difficult. But at that price
column15: Mindbody's current $1.1 billion   market cap drastically understates its market potential. The   60
column16: 000 businesses Mindbody currently serves are just a tiny   fraction -- about 1.5% -- of the 4.2 million wellness businesses   that the company says exists around the world. And its $139   million in revenue is just a smidgeon of the $9.5billionthat Mindbody estimates as the current size of its addressable   market -- a market that itself is growing
column17: as more people come to   understand the benefits of fitness and overall healthier living.   That's a massive untapped opportunity that could offer Mindbody   years -- and potentially even decades -- of strong growth.Mindbody's powerful network effects should allow it to capture   the lion's share of this immense market. Each new user expands   the base of potential customers for Mindbody's business clients
column18: and each business that joins Mindbody's platform increases the   number of wellness offerings that users can choose among. It's a   virtuous cycle that should continue to grow stronger as Mindbody   expands its user and subscriber counts in the coming years.To further strengthen its ecosystem
column19: Mindbodyreached a dealwithUnder Armour(NYSE: UA) (NYSE: UAA) that lets the more than 180 million users   of Under Armour's MyFitnessPal app sign up for classes offered by   Mindbody's subscribers. Mindbody also has apartnership withAlphabet's Google(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) allowing people in several major   cities to book classes listed on Mindbody directly through Google   Search and Maps. These two titans choosing to partner with   Mindbody is a major vote of confidence for its platform
column20: and I   wouldn't be surprised if a company like Under Armour makes a bid   for Mindbody at some point in the future.All told
column21: Mindbody is a leader in a huge and expanding   industry with the ability to grow its market share exponentially   in the years ahead. And at current prices
column22: Mindbody offers   long-term investors a chance atmultibagger-type returnsin the coming decade. That makes this currently small-cap stock a   great buy today.10 stocks we like better than MindbodyWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column24: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeAlphabet(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report)

column9: AT&T(NYSE:T-Free Report) andDISH Networks(NASDAQ:DISH-Free Report).Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Wednesday's Analyst   Blog:Investors Still Discount Google Post-YouTube TV     AnnouncementAlphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) shares jumped up a point after the announcement of its live TV streaming service
column11: but the movement was more or less in line with the market. The shares lost most of the gains thereafter and remained below the S&P 500
column12: as they have been since the election.It's widely believed that Google won't have as strong a standing with this government as it had with the previous one
column13: but not for lack of trying. Company executives have been visiting the White House
column14: but Google's very public stand against many of President Trump's sentiments are expected to work against it.Google's results had been stellar in 2016. After the customary dip in the first quarter
column15: both revenue and earnings rose consistently through the year
column16: pulling share prices along... that is
column17: until the election.Revenue strength has come from both the search business as well as new areas including hardware
column18: Play and cloud. Management said on the last call that there was ""tremendous potential"" in these areas and enthused over ""continued development of non-advertising revenue streams for YouTube.""In that they were probably referring at least in part to YouTube TV
column19: an expansion of the Google service that is better known for letting you watch thousands of hours of video from a seemingly endless stock.DetailsThe company has joined with all four major broadcast networks (CBS
column20: ABC
column21: NBC and Fox)
column22: so a family of six can stream live content from 40+ channels at $35 a month. The company will maintain separate accounts for each member although only three can stream at a time.The price indicates that YouTube is probably still in negotiations to add more channels in the few months until it launches in important U.S. cities like New York
column23: Los Angeles
column24: Chicago and Philadelphia. The company plans to expand gradually to other U.S. cities. International expansion plans weren't mentioned.Also
column25: as far as channels are concerned
column26: there are some important exclusions: HBO
column27: CNN
column28: PBS
column29: the Cartoon Network
column30: TNT
column31: or Viacom channels such as Comedy Central
column32: MTV and VH1
column33: Nickelodeon
column34: Scripps' Food Network and Home and Garden TV.But Google does offer you all the goodness of YouTube (and that includes YouTube Red for original content
column35: if you are a subscriber). The YouTube TV app for Android/iOS also allows you to stream whatever you're viewing to Chromecast
column36: so you can make use of the larger TV screen (built-in Chromecast TVs will also do the job). At some future date (the demo failed during this announcement)
column37: Google hopes that you will be able to tell your devices via Google Home or Cast to turn on what you want to see.The best part? It gives you a real DVR experience by allowing you to store an unlimited number of your recordings for up to nine months
column38: quite unheard-of amongst its competitors like DirecTV Now
column39: PlayStation Vue and Sling TV. The Vue allows you to save shows from some channels for up to 28 days while Sling TV is still testing a service that will allow you to save up to 100 hours of recordings.Is It a Good Deal?That depends.If you're into traditional TV
column40: you would be spending $80-100 on it
column41: while making do with long-term contracts. YouTube TV is a good deal that way because it comes for just $35
column42: no strings attached while also allowing you mobility. Then again
column43: if you like all the content that's still exclusive to PayTV
column44: you may want to stick with your current subscription.If you're more of a netizen
column45: you're already familiar with the ""skinny bundle"" concept
column46: wherein the most-watched/popular channels are served at a lower price. Either way
column47: there's plenty of choice.So YouTube
column48: which still focuses on user experience more than profits and has the resources to go for the best content
column49: may be more capable of delivering the superior experience.What's In It for Google/YouTube?YouTube has for long been the go-to destination for online video consumption although Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)
column50: Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX-Free Report) and others also have their own thing. Now that it is getting into live TV streaming
column51: it's also pitted against traditional operators like AT&T (NYSE:T-Free Report) with its DirecTV Now
column52: DISH Networks (NASDAQ:DISH-Free Report) with its Sling TV and CBS with its All Access that are also turning to the Internet to protect their revenues. The market is very crowded
column53: so prices are under pressure.But if data from GfK is to be relied upon
column54: the portion of American homes subscribing to a Pay TV service has shrunk to 75% with a much smaller 6% using Apple TV-like devices to stream shows to a TV. Moreover
column55: the number of TVs per home is declining while the number of homes without a TV is on the rise (U.S Energy Information Administration survey). According to Morningstar
column56: Pay TV executives estimate that 10 million homes subscribe to broadband only and not TV.eMarketer estimates that YouTube's 180 million viewers generated $3 billion last year and Google recently announced that it surpassed a billion hours of daily viewership. TV ads reportedly generate $70 billion in revenues annually
column57: so there's a fair chance that as consumer preference continues shifting to online channels
column58: YouTube TV will allow Google to take its share of those dollars.About Zacks Equity ResearchZacks Equity Research provides the best of quantitative and qualitative analysis to help investors know what stocks to buy and which to sell for the long-term.Continuous coverage is provided for a universe of 1

column1: 10 Companies Set to Dominate the Next Decade;3/9/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Any investor would love to get their hands on a crystal ball   and take a quick peek at what's going to happen over the next   decade. The problem is
column2: those crystal balls are hard to come by
column3: so we all have to settle for looking at what companies are doing   right now -- and attempt to anticipate how that will help or hurt   them in the future.makeArticleAd();The good news is that therearecompanies positioning themselves for growth over the next decade
column4: and setting themselves up to dominate in their respective   markets. Take a look:Image source: Amazon.1. AmazonAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) has its hands in so many business it's hard to   keep up. For some companies
column5: that degree of diversification can   proof more trouble than it's worth
column6: but Amazon's has shown it can   sell everything from tablets to its Echo speaker
column7: while   simultaneously creating award-winning television shows and   managing a massive online consumer goods marketplace
column8: andstillhave business bandwidth to power some of the biggest websites   through its Amazon Web Services unit.The company's ability to diversify its businesses -- while   still tying many of them to its Prime service -- has given Amazon   a lead over its competitors that won't fade any time soon.Image source: Google.2. AlphabetWith a $581 billion market cap
column9: Google parentAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is a juggernaut of the technology   industry
column10: yet it still innovates like a much smaller
column11: scrappier   company. Alphabet may still earn most of its revenue -- 99% --   from Google
column12: but that hasn't stopped it from making big bets on   thedriverless car marketand even moonshots like curing cancer.Among the more than 20 companies under the Alphabet umbrella
column13: there are units trying to secure major positions in the future of   transportation
column14: artificial intelligence
column15: virtual reality
column16: and the   burgeoning Internet of Things. Add to that the company's mobile   dominance with its Android platform
column17: and its new devices like the   Pixel Phone and Google Home and its crystal clear that Alphabet   will still be one of the most dominant tech giants a decade from   now.Image source: Facebook.3. FacebookEvery day
column18: the world feels like it gets a little bit smaller   and slightly more connected
column19: andFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) deserves at least partial credit for that. With more   than 1.86 billion users on the company's main platform
column20: and more   growth coming in huge markets like India
column21: Facebook shows no sign   of slowing down in the social media space.The company plans to have 5 billion users by 2030. Take a   minute and remember that we have 7 billion people on the planet   right now. That's a hefty goal
column22: but if any company can do it it's   Facebook. Aside from its main Facebook platform
column23: the company is   investing billions in connecting people around the world through   its WhatsApp
column24: Instagram
column25: Messenger
column26: and is investing heavily in   building what CEO Mark Zuckerberg calls ""the next computing   platform"" -- virtual reality.Image source: Lockheed Martin.4. Lockheed MartinLockheed Martin(NYSE: LMT) has gotten some flak for the high price of its F-35   Lightning stealth fighter jet
column27: as President Trump has so kindly   pointed out onTwitter. But despite the criticisms
column28: the F-35 is poised to help Lockheed   Martin dominate the aerospace industry over the next decade.Consider that the F-35 is expected to be in service until 2070   and could bring in more than $1 trillion in revenue for the   company over that time span. Sure
column29: Lockheed may further trim the   cost of the planes -- as it did recently
column30: when it announced its   long-term efforts to reduce costs had cut the price on its next   batch of 90 planes by $700 million -- but with more than 50   years of revenues expect to come from this jet family
column31: there's   little reason to be skeptical of Lockheed's dominance.Image source: Netflix.5. NetflixNot so long ago
column32: the idea ofNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) being capable of creating original
column33: award-winning   programming would have seemed absurd. But over the past few   years
column34: the company has amassed a vast trove of original content   that has not only won over critics but also helped the company   win new customers. In fact
column35: 57% of the streaming service's U.S.   subscribers say they signed up for because of its original   content.Netflix now boasts about 93.8 million subscribers in 190   countries
column36: and it's still growing. The company faces rising   competition from Amazon's Prime video service
column37: but says it plans   on investing $6 billion in original content this year
column38: which   should help it fend off rivals. A decade from now
column39: Netflix will   have the advantage of that much more original content production   under its belt
column40: and more streaming experience than any of its   competitors.Image source: Disney.6. DisneyWalt Disney(NYSE: DIS) expanded its empire back in 2009 when it purchased   Marvel Studios for $4 billion
column41: and followed that up with another   $4 billion purchase -- of Lucasfilm -- in 2012. Those two   entertainment land-grabs alone will provide huge catalysts for   the company over the next decade
column42: as it reaps the benefits from   theStar Warsfranchise
column43: Marvel movies
column44: merchandise
column45: licensing ... you get the   picture.Add to all of that the company's long list of theme parks
column46: cruise ships
column47: resorts
column48: and its Pixar Studios
column49: and it's easy to   foresee Disney holding a powerful position the entertainment   business for years to come. The company will have to adapt to a   shifting pay-TV landscape
column50: and adjust to how those changes will   impact the company's all-important ESPN networks. But investors   would be wise to remember that the company already has many   decades worth of strategy-shifting experience.Image source: GE.7. General ElectricGeneral Electric(NYSE: GE) has weathered more changes than most companies over   its 100-plus year history

column1: Why Alphabet and Microsoft Should Start Disclosing Cloud Revenue;3/8/2017;"Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is currently hosting its Google   Cloud Next '17 developer conference
column2: which kicked off earlier   today in San Francisco and runs through March 10. Speaking at the   event
column3: Google CEO Sundar Pichai made it clear that he sees Google   Cloud as an incredibly important part of the search giant's   future
column4: and not just one of the company's many side bets. ""To me
column5: Google Cloud is a natural extension of our mission to make the   world's information accessible and usable
column6: Pichai said.The distinction is that while search helps regular users   access information
column7: cloud computing infrastructure and the   related value-added services like analytics help the enterprise   organize and access their information. The cloud infrastructure   market is booming
column8: growing 49% last year to $38.1 billion
column9: according to market researcher Canalys. It's expected to jump   another 46% this year to $55.8 billion. As the market grows
column10: so
column11: too
column12: does the impact on the financials of the major players:   Google Cloud
column13: Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure
column14: andAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) AWS.Google data center in Council Bluffs
column15: Iowa. Image source:     Google.makeArticleAd();As such
column16: the former two should start disclosing exactly how   much cloud revenue they're bringing in.Follow Amazon's leadI never thought I'd see the day when Amazon was leading the   way in investor transparency
column17: given the e-commerce giant's   long-standing refusal to share various operating metrics that are   pertinent to investors. Yet
column18: when it comes to AWS and cloud   revenue
column19: Amazon is doing just that; Amazon started sharing AWS   financials in 2015. AWS revenue was $12.2 billion last year
column20: translating into $3.1 billion in operating income.Microsoft only discloses growth rates for Azure (up 93% last   quarter)
column21: but lacking a base number
column22: that data point is less   meaningful. We do know that total revenue in Microsoft's   intelligent cloud segment
column23: which includes Azure among other   offerings
column24: was $6.9 billion last quarter
column25: resulting in $2.4   billion in operating income. Lacking an official figure
column26: JPMorgan   analysts estimate Azure revenue for all of 2016 was $2.7 billion
column27: which would make AWS nearly five times bigger.Google includes Google Cloud revenue within its Google other   revenues segment
column28: which generated a hair over $10 billion in   sales in 2016. That also includes revenue from Google Play as   well as the company's growing hardware portfolio. One   particularly prominent Google Cloud customer that just went   public likely spent between $400 million to $450 million last   year
column29: and is committed to $400 million per year for thenext five years
column30: so there's that.Sharing is caringYou could reasonably argue that AWS is far more important to   Amazon than its peers' respective cloud businesses
column31: though
column32: specifically since AWS is by far the market leaderandit's such a major contributor to profitability due to razor-thin   margins in the core e-commerce business. In contrast
column33: Google and   Microsoft enjoy much higher gross margin
column34: as they each specialize   in software and services.Still
column35: the cloud infrastructure market is only going to become   increasingly important in the years ahead
column36: and investors will   want to see the results from the three largest players to assess   each company's competitiveness. Google and Microsoft should start   sharing more

column1: YouTube TV's Biggest Advantage;3/8/2017;"YouTube recently announced its plans to offer a live   television streaming service to compete with the likes of DirecTV   Now
column2: PlayStation Vue
column3: Sling TV
column4: and more traditional pay-TV   operators. YouTube TV will include 40 live channels and will be   initially available in select markets.While YouTube TV is missing quite a few channels compared with   competing services
column5: it has the potential to attract a lot of   attention from media companies in the future thanks to one huge   advantage over the competitors: Google
column6: theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary and owner of YouTube
column7: is one of the best digital video advertisers in the world.Image source: YouTubemakeArticleAd();Disney already sees the value in digital streamingDisney(NYSE: DIS) CEO Bob Iger is actively trying to get his networks   into digital skinny bundles. Indeed
column8: Disney's networks
column9: including   ESPN
column10: are available in the lowest-priced tiers of all of the   aforementioned streaming services.Importantly
column11: Disney is not sacrificing any of its affiliate   fees to get its channels into those tiers. ""The per-channel fees
column12: which we are not getting too specific about
column13: are commensurate   with what the fees are on the existing services
column14: Iger said about   its deal with DirecTV Now.But there's an added benefit to going digital. ""Some of the   technology platforms will offer dynamic ad insertion. We think   that that has got some real potential for the company
column15: Iger told   investors on the company's third-quarter earnings call last   year.Dynamic ad insertion allows media companies to serve targeted   ads to viewers instead of using the one-size-fits-all system of   traditional live broadcasts. YouTube TV may give media companies   the opportunity to tap into Google's targeting data. On top of   that
column16: YouTube already has millions of advertisers on its   platform
column17: which it could tap for more premium YouTube TV ads.Media companies might give YouTube TV a bigger break on   affiliate fees if it can produce meaningfully higher ad revenue   per viewer than its competitors.YouTube will have a chance to prove itself
column18: tooMedia companies will handle the majority of their ad buying at   the launch of YouTube TV
column19: but YouTube will have access to about   two minutes of ads for every hour of viewing. That's the ad   inventory that every cable company receives. If YouTube can use   its decade of advertising experience and produce outsize results
column20: it could increase interest from media companies for its   services.That bit of advertising is about the only thing that will make   YouTube TV profitable
column21: as analysts estimate its affiliate fees   total about $29 before accounting for various regional sports   networks
column22: which could add $4 to $5.Suffice it to say YouTube TV has a lot running on that small   slice of advertising inventory.Taking on a $71 billion marketThe market Google is going after with YouTube TV isn't so much   the pay-TV market as it is the television advertising market.   Google tried to break into the market before by partnering with   media companies about a decade ago. Now
column23: it's using YouTube TV as   a platform to gain access to that inventory
column24: which generated   about $71 billion in the U.S. last year.Getting YouTube TV off the ground and showing media companies   what it's capable of with advertising is the first step. The more   successful it is with its own ad inventory
column25: the more likely it is   to win the business of more media companies. In turn
column26: more   customers will sign up as the value improves and YouTube is able   to bring on more networks.If YouTube TV is successful
column27: it will be because its superior   advertising makes it a win-win-win -- the media companies
column28: the   consumers
column29: and YouTube.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (C   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Will Snap Inc (SNAP) Succeed or Fall Out of Investors' Favor?;3/8/2017;"Snap Inc.SNAP
column2: the parent company of social network
column3: Snapchat
column4: was off to a brilliant start on its debut. The company's IPO was multiple times oversubscribed and shares soared 44% on the first day of trading. However
column5: shares fell nearly 10% yesterday amid reports that the company has come under fire from several institutional investorsSnap Lands into Trouble with Institutional   InvestorsInvestors aren't happy with the company's offering of 200 million Class A shares that carry no voting rights. Per a Business Insider report
column6: they have ""approached"" stock index providers such as S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI Inc to prevent Snap and other such companies that offer shares without voting rights from getting incorporated into these benchmark indexes. The meeting is scheduled sometime this week.Investors argue that the absence of voting rights completely bars a shareholder from speaking on issues like a company's growth plans or compensation shelled out to executives. Business Insider also adds that if such a company is listed on any of the indices
column7: ""then managers of stock index portfolios will have to buy its shares and other investors
column8: whose performance is tracked against such indexes
column9: would likely follow suit.""The absence of voting rights implies that the company does not intend to dilute its decision making power. Snap will have a three-tier share structure and founders Evan Spigel and Bobby Murphy will have maximum voting rights through the ownership of Class C shares
column10: which carry 10 votes per share. The Class B shares carry one vote per share. Such form of corporate governance might prove detrimental for investors
column11: especially when there is uncertainty about its future.What's Concerning Investors?Snap Inc has been shunned by many Wall Street analysts for various reasons. Citing instances of Twitter Inc.TWTR
column12: Groupon Inc and many others
column13: analysts believe that Snap ""will follow a pattern of hot
column14: then cooling
column15: tech IPOs.""Reportedly
column16: most analysts have initiated coverage on Snap with a ""sell"" rating. These analysts argue that Snap has already started seeing its average daily user growth rate slowdown.  Plus
column17: the company is yet to make profits. Though the company's revenues are on the rise
column18: losses are ballooning. Reportedly
column20: Snap's revenues of $404.5 million were nearly six times higher than 2015 revenues but net loss for the year increased 38% to $514.6 million.Moreover
column21: since Snapchat has just one source of revenues i.e.
column22: advertising
column23: which only began in Oct 2016
column24: it may be a concern for investors. Also
column25: it attracts a particular segment of the demography.Analysts argue that teens are inclined to sudden changes in preferences. Media reports have quoted Snap ""admitting"" that increasing competition from big players like Facebook IncFB
column26: which have better resources
column27: is a big threat as they can easily lure users to their platform.In fact
column28: Facebook outshines Snap in almost all aspects. The company enjoys a first mover advantage in the social media space with over 1.9 billion users from every segment of demography. It has a gargantuan base of over 1 billion DAUs compared with 158 million for Snap. Facebook presents a much larger canvas for advertisers than Snapchat. In fact
column29: Facebook's total addressable market (TAM) has been reported to be 80% bigger than that of Snap.Also
column30: Facebook through its Instagram application has started to emulate Snapchat features
column31: which is a big threat for Snapchat. Analysts observe that Facebook can easily take chances by unveiling features that are similar to other social media services. This is because if these ""inspired"" features do not work
column32: it can easily roll them back like it did previously with Poke
column33: Slingshot and Bolt.After all
column34: platforms like Facebook
column35: Instagram
column36: WhatsApp and Messenger do have their own inherent features that will prevent the loss of users. If these ""inspired"" features become popular like Facebook Live
column37: people will view it as an improvement over the inherent features. This will significantly cut down the risk of migration if Snapchat becomes popular going ahead.An analyst was quoted saying ""Good-enough features plus being the first app to offer them at scale in a market could succeed better than having the best features but showing up late."" Compared to Facebook's worldwide popularity
column38: Snap is mainly popular in the U.S and Canada. Apart from Facebook
column39: Alphabet'sGOOGLYouTube is another formidable opponent for ad dollarsAlso
column40: Snap's valuation is nosebleed. At nearly 60 times its revenues
column41: analysts remain wary as it is too high compared to existing and future growth prospects.Wait
column42: Not All Is Lost!!However
column43: there are some analysts who aren't so negative on the stock. They believe that product innovations might help Snap to sustain the momentum.Thebest partabout the company is that it does not follow the usual advertising model of charging per click
column44: rather it charges advertisers per day. The consistently expanding daily active user base has been attracting more and more consumers.Apart from this
column45: the company's Snapchat Discover feature has enhanced its picture and video library
column46: thereby attracting more and more advertisers. The feature also allows the company to partner with major events like the Oscars and Super Bowl. Discover currently accounts for a majority of the company's advertising revenues.At the Morgan Stanley conference held a couple of months back
column47: CEO Spiegel was quoted by media reports as saying that 50% of its new user base now comprises users over the age of 25. Plus
column48: Snapchat
column49: in order to diversify its revenue base
column50: has started selling Snapchat spectacles worth $130.ConclusionSnap is currently stealing all the limelight. It remains to be seen whether the company can keep the excitement alive by providing a more immersive experience. We can only hope that its success will not be ""ephemeral"" like its messaging features.Want to learn more about Snapchat stock? MSFT stock has risen roughly 150% in just four years - despite little movement in profits.""The lack of fundamental growth is even more perplexing when you consider Microsoft's position within the fierce environment. The company is either lagging

column24: Tableau Software Inc(NYSE:DATA) is challenging Excel - and 27% revenue growth in 2016 suggests DATA is taking share from MSFT. Behemoths likeOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) and many others are in the cloud space. Microsoft's Dynamics CRM product is a distant second tosalesforce.com
column25: inc. (NYSE:CRM).""A huge concern for those trading MSFT stock is the market capitalization. I'm not a fan of focusing on any one metric. Still
column26: with its equity valued at half a trillion dollars

column29: followed by performances of 28.4%
column30: 21.9% and 16.5%.Microsoft Stock Is a Proven WinnerAdmittedly

column34: its first quarter returns are a relatively pedestrian 8%.But at year's end
column35: the average return jumps up to 30.7%
column36: nearly four times higher. That also means that those who are concerned about this year's slow start for MSFT stock shouldn't be.The other attribute that is remarkable about Microsoft is its resiliency. Between 2000 and 2011
column37: MSFT stock suffered a negative Q1 performance ten times. But in four of those instances
column38: shares managed to claw back positive returns for the year. That provides a lot of security for those making strongly optimistic calls for Microsoft stock.While investors have reason to look at MSFT cautiously

column40: and the signs are encouraging. A prime example is Microsoft'shigh-profile acquisitionofLinkedIn. By integrating its intellectual capital with Microsoft's vast networks
column41: it can do serious damage in the social media sphere.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock: Stay Away at All Costs!Overall

column43: it's competing well in some of the most exciting and high-growth sectors. Both the company and the markets are loving the change in leadership and culture. Finally
column44: Microsoft continues to find ways to do well

column13: for free

column39: EMI

The popstar withdrew her entire catalog from the service because she ""didn't like the way it felt. I think there should be an inherent value placed on art. I didn't see that happening
column44: perception-wise
column45: when I put my music on Spotify

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8: New Name
column2: Late Release?;3/8/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) upcoming flagship smartphone continues to be the subject of intense speculation. With the countdown on to finalizing design and starting production of the new iPhone
column4: two details in particular have seen conflicting theories: the name and the display size.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleA new post from Japan'sMac Otakarasuggests AAPL will go with the iPhone Edition - instead of iPhone 8 or 10th anniversary iPhone - for its flagship model.The website also feels it has nailed the display size
column5: and agrees with a previous report that the new iPhone could arrive significantly later than usual.iPhone 8 = iPhone Edition?What to call the new iPhone is actually a big deal this year. The regular naming sequence will continue with the iPhone 7s and iPhone 7s Plus. Those are the phones for everyone. But what do you call the all-new flagship AAPL is expected to release -the $1
column6: 000+ smartphonethat celebrates a decade in the business (and hopefully helps to propel sales to stratospheric levels)?The iPhone X
column7: 10th Anniversary iPhone and iPhone 8 have been the front runners. But what would you call the 10th Anniversary iPhonenextyear? And iPhone 8 would mess up Apple's naming scheme for its mainstream models.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Can't Commit to HollywoodMac OtakarathinksAAPL will go with the iPhone Edition. The premium Apple Watch model is the Apple Watch Edition
column8: so the precedent has already been set and it would be consistent. This would also solve the continuity problem associated with naming a new iPhone specifically around the 10th anniversary
column9: without messing up the current iPhone naming scheme. iPhone Edition makes sense.About the New iPhone DisplayOutside of whether it would be curved or not
column10: or OLED or not
column11: there have been conflicting reports about the display's size. Most analysts have been calling for a 5.8-inch display with bezels practically eliminated. That would let AAPL fit a larger display into an iPhone that's smaller than the 5.5-inch iPhone 7 Plus.It's a similar approach to whatSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)appears to have taken with the Galaxy S8.However
column12: Mac Otakarahas always maintained - and still insists - that the new iPhone will have a 5-inch display. Which seems weird
column13: given the consumer preference for big screens.Mac Rumorsconnected the dotsand theorizes that the information given to the Japanese website is for theusablespace. The remaining display area would be where AAPL has a row of virtual buttons - a feature that has already been mentioned as replacing the Home button and mimicking the functionality of the new MacBook Pro Touch Bar.Take a 5.8-inch display
column14: reserve the bottom of that display for the virtual buttons
column15: and you end up with what is effectively a 5-inch display in terms of what the owner can make use of.The math is starting to add up.iPhone Edition Could Be DelayedFinally
column16: Mac Otakaraagrees with the growing number of analysts who are predicting the iPhone 8 - or iPhone Edition - is going to face a delayed release.A few days ago
column17: 9to5 Macreported the iPhone 7s series would go into production in July
column18: as expected. But there are rumors that the TouchID sensor that AAPL is integrating into the new iPhone Edition's display is proving challenging. The added manufacturing complexity may push mass production for the new flagship model to September. That would mean severe supply constraints
column19: including the possibility that theiPhone Edition would not begin shipping until a month after the iPhone 7s
column20: with only early pre-orders being delivered in 2017.If the production issues turn out to be true
column21: the results could be problematic … but not necessarily.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still ""The One""On the downside
column22: Apple would face the possibility that potential iPhone 7s buyers hold off until they can physically compare it against the iPhone Edition
column23: delaying that wave of upgrades. Potential iPhone Edition buyers could also shrug and order the iPhone 7s instead
column24: not wishing to wait a few months for their new smartphone. And without the 1-2 punch of the 7s and iPhone Edition together
column25: AAPL could miss out on the spectacularly record-smashing launch sales weekend it is gunning for to celebrate that 10th anniversary.On the upside
column26: the annual crest of sales that accompany every new iPhone release could be extended. The iPhone 7s would get the first rush
column27: followed by the iPhone Edition.It's possible.As always
column28: stay tuned. At this stage
column29: everything we ""know"" about the new iPhone is speculation. But with AAPL's supply chain starting to crank up for production
column30: the pieces are beginning to fall into place.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceHow to Buy Advanced Micro Devices

column19: allowing you to pocket the 35 cents per share ($35 total).The initial margin requirement for the naked put should be around $120
