column1: Will Snapchat Become the Next Twitter or Facebook?;3/7/2017;"After months of speculations
column2: Snap Inc.
column3: the parent company of social media mobile app Snapchat
column4: finally got listed on the New York Stock Exchange last week. With this
column5: arguments whether the company will become more like FacebookFBor turn to TwitterTWTRin the next few years
column6: have heated up.Notably
column7: shares of the two established social media companies - Facebook and Twitter - have taken divergent paths since their respective Initial Public Offerings (IPO). At yesterday's closing price
column8: Facebook is up 261.6% from its IPO price; while Twitter is trading 40.2% down from its IPO price.Undoubtedly
column9: neither the company nor the stakeholders will ever prefer it to become like Twitter
column10: which is witnessing declining user base
column11: revenues and earnings. On the contrary
column12: it will like to become more like Facebook or even better
column13: which has seen a tremendous rise in user base
column14: revenues as well as earnings.Although
column15: it will be quite early to forecast where the company will find itself after five years from now; the business model demonstrates both positive and negative aspects following thestock's recent decline post IPO.What Makes it More like FacebookSnap is known for its social media mobile app - Snapchat - which was founded in 2011
column16: and officially launched in 2012. The app allows users to take photos and record videos
column17: as well as facilitate editing options and share the same with friends. However
column18: photos or videos can be viewed for few seconds only and then they disappear
column19: and also cannot be saved.Since its launch
column20: the app has been steadily getting popular among teenagers
column21: thanks to its consistent focus on introducing new and unique features. Per the company
column22: the app had 158 million daily active users per day at the end of 2016
column23: which represented year-over-year growth of 48%. Of these
column24: majority are between 18 and 34 years old. The daily users visit the Snapchat app more than 20 times a day
column25: on an average
column26: and spend over 30 minutes.Although
column27: the daily active user count is way lesser than Facebook's over 1.20 billion
column28: it has already surpassed Twitter's over 130-million daily visitors. Also
column29: the rate at which it is growing
column30: it has the potential to reduce the gap with Facebook.Going ahead
column31: the best part of the company is that it has been able to monetize the app. The company does not follow the typical Internet advertising model of charging per click; rather it charges advertisers per day. The consistently growing daily active user base has been attracting more and more consumers.Apart from this
column32: the company's Snapchat Discover feature has expanded its picture and video library
column33: thereby attracting more and more advertisers. The feature also allows the company to partner with major events like the Oscars and Super Bowl. Discover currently accounts for a majority of the company's advertising revenue.It should be noted that the company registered almost a seven-fold year-over-year jump in its 2016 revenues
column34: which reached $404.9 million from $58.7 million recorded in 2015. Going ahead
column35: the company projects its annual revenues and daily active user base to reach approximately $2 billion and 221 million
column36: respectively
column37: in 2018.Snap's constant efforts in introducing new and unique app features
column38: along with its innovative adverting ideas
column39: will enable it in achieving its target.Despite this
column40: it will be far lesser than Facebook
column41: which generated $27.6 billion revenues in 2016
column42: and is still growing. However
column43: if Snap achieved its target for 2018
column44: it will certainly be closing its gap with Twitter which generated $2.5 billion in revenues and has been witnessing a slowdown in growth rate.Why It May Fall to TwitterLooking at the above discussion
column45: it seems that Snap does look like Facebook. However
column46: there are a number of challenges which may trouble it in becoming the next Facebook and put it in Twitter's shoes.The major threat comes from Facebook which introduced the new ""Stories"" feature at its Instagram app last year. This new feature allows users to post photos and video slideshows which disappear after a 24-hour period. Instagram stories directly mirror Snapchat's own stories feature. Reportedly
column47: after this launch
column48: Snapchat has recorded a slowdown in its users' growth rate in the second half of 2016.The second major concern is that even after five years of journey
column49: the company has failed to make itself profitable just like Twitter before its IPO. On the contrary
column50: Facebook had made over $1 billion of profit in the fiscal year just before its IPO in 2012.Furthermore
column51: since the early days of Snapchat
column52: this disappearing messaging app has been associated with sexting. Snapchat has also dealt with a few other embarrassing issues
column53: including two different racially insensitive filters. All this may put the company in unnecessary controversies and bring in unwanted investigation.ConclusionInvestors ideally vision Snap to grow like Facebook and not become Twitter. However
column54: we believe that Facebook's well established position in the social media industry
column55: ever-growing user base and the popular Instagram service are significant threat to Snapchat's growth prospects.In addition
column56: the company will have a tough task grabbing market share in the digital ad space
column57: which is mainly dominated by Facebook and AlphabetGOOGLaka Google.Want to learn more about Snapchat stock? column34: Google's initiatives have had mixed success. Investments in self-driving cars and virtual reality are years
column35: if not decades
column36: away from bearing fruit. So-called IoT (Internet of Things) products like Nest and Google Home are facing tough competition from Amazon's Alexa and a number of startups.But Alphabet stock is valued right in line with Facebook's. Backing out the company's nearly $100 per share in net cash
column37: GOOGL trades at 22x 2017 consensus and 19x 2018. Both figures are pretty much right in line with that of FB stock.That doesn't seem right. While Facebook has admitted to slowing growth in its core business
column38: Alphabet's core business
column39: Google
column40: is seeing outright pressure.More broadly
column41: the bet on Facebook stock versus Alphabet and Google is a bet on how consumers in the future will use the internet. And Facebook's continuing growth and global dominance appears to give it an advantage. That advantage - at the same valuation - would seem to argue for a long position in FB over GOOGL.Is Facebook a Buy Then?The fact that FB stock is cheaper than peers on its own doesn't suggest a buy. Some investors - and many analysts - believe SNAP is wildly overvalued. AMZN and NFLX have valuation questions of their own. Alphabet stock is at an all-time high as well. It's not impossible to be right that Facebook is cheaper than all those stocks - and yet still see Facebook stock decline
column42: if by less than those peers.And there are risks specific to Facebook stock. The most notable is whether the platform can keep its dominance. Facebook may not be the nextMyspace- but it's likely that at some point
column43: another social networking company will come along. Given the fickle tastes of younger consumers
column44: in particular
column45: the core question for FB stock is whether it will still bethedominant platform in 20 years
column46: or even 10.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Can't Commit to HollywoodFor now
column47: however
column48: that risk seems priced in
column49: and then some. We're nearing a point where the market is pricing Facebook like 'just another company' - but Facebook isn't just another company. It's a dominant global player
column50: with huge margins. It's already profitable in a way that Snap and evenTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) can only hope to be. And that dominance provides a huge moat around the business: if everyone already is on Facebook
column51: it's even more difficult to get them to leave.So the market doesn't seem to be pricing FB stock accordingly - even considering the risk involved. A sub-20x forward multiple is fitting for a low-growth
column52: established company. Facebook is established - but it still isn't anywhere near low-growth.As of this writing

column1: Why Baidu Inc. Probably Won't Spin Off iQiyi.com;3/7/2017;"In late February
column2: Baidu's(NASDAQ: BIDU) video  streaming subsidiary iQiyi raised   $1.53 billion in fresh funds to compete more effectively with   rival sites. Hillhouse Capital
column3: IDG Capital
column4: Sequoia Capital
column5: and   Baidu all purchased the newly issued convertible bonds
column6: and Baidu   disclosed that it had invested $300 million.iQiyi is the largest video streaming site in China
column7: but it   currently faces tough competition fromTencent(NASDAQOTH: TCEHY) Video andAlibaba's Youku Tudou. iQiyi has  been losing money since Baidu   purchased a majority stake in 2012
column8: which has repeatedly sparked   calls for Baidu to sell or spin-off the company to boost its   profitability.The iQiyi app for Android tablets. Image source: Google     Play.makeArticleAd();Last December
column9: theWall Street Journalreported that Baidu was planning to spin off iQiyi in an IPO   which could raise $1 billion. Baidu denied those rumors
column10: and CEO   Robin Li reiterated after the recent bond offering that the site   was ""a great asset and an important part of the Baidu ecosystem.""   Let's take a closer look at iQiyi
column11: and why Baidu prefers to raise   capital through convertible bonds rather than spin off the   company in an IPO.A brief look at iQiyi's historyBaidu and American private equity firm Providence Equity   Partners co-founded iQiyi in 2010. In 2012
column12: Baidu bought out   Providence's stake to become the dominant investor. It acquired   the  popular online video business of PPStream the following   year
column13: and launched its own film production division in 2014. That   same year
column14: smartphone giantXiaomiand Shunwei Capital acquired a 10%-15% stake in  iQiyi for   $300 million.In 2015
column15: it acquired the online rights to top entertainment   shows in China
column16: Taiwan
column17: and  South Korea -- including the   popular Korean variety showRunning Man. In 2016
column18: iQiyi launched in  Taiwan
column19: marking its first step   outside of mainland China.During last quarter's conference call
column20: Robin Li stated that   iQiyi ""performed very well
column21: with ""revenue and subscriber numbers   ramping up nicely."" According to iResearch's Dec. 2016 numbers
column22: iQiyi's mobile app remained the top video streaming app in China
column23: with 125 million daily active users and 480 million monthly   active users
column24: and streamed 335 billion minutes of   monthly content.iQiyi generates most of its revenue from ads
column25: but it launched   a paid service in 2015 that lets subscribers get earlier or   exclusive access to blockbuster shows. iQiyi claimed the service   reached 20 million subscribers last June
column26: up from 5 million at   the end of May 2015.But profitability is toughOn the conference call
column27: Robin Li stated that Baidu planned to   support iQiyi's ""further growth
column28: but noted that higher content   acquisition costs at the site caused its total content costs to   rise from 5.6% of revenues in 2015 to 11% in 2016. That statement   raises some concerns when we look at Baidu's operating margins   over the past five years.Source:YChartsRobin Li still hasn't provided a timeline for iQiyi's bottom   line to break even
column29: but CFO Jennifer Li noted that margins were   ""improving""
column30: and that they would continue doing so in the future.   She also stated that to keep costs under control
column31: Baidu will   invest more heavily in original content to ""further strengthen   and expand"" its subscription user base.YouTube faces the same challengesMaking a profit from streaming video is very tough. The   platform might generate revenue with ads and subscriptions
column32: but   those gains often can't offset the costs of hosting videos on   servers and content acquisition costs.EvenAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) YouTube
column33: the biggest streaming   video platform in the  world with over a billion users
column34: remains unprofitable due to those pressures. Last October
column35: YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki stated that the 12-year-old site was   ""still in investment mode
column36: and that there was ""no timetable"" for   achieving profitability. Like iQiyi
column37: YouTube offers a premium   subscription platform
column38: YouTube Red
column39: but the  service   reportedly only had 1.5 million subscribers at the end of last   summer.Baidu and Alphabet are willing to take losses on iQiyi and   YouTube for a simple reason: streaming videos tether more users   to their ecosystems. If those viewers use iQiyi they're more   likely to use other services -- like Baidu Maps
column40: Search
column41: and   Wallet -- instead of services from rivals like Tencent . Both   companies can also track watched videos
column42: which gives them more   data for targeted ads.The key takeawayiQiyi will probably keep losing money for years
column43: but investors   shouldn't fret over those losses. The platform brings more users   into Baidu's ecosystem
column44: which widens its moat against other   companies and ensures that it remains the top internet   advertising platform in China. Therefore
column45: investors shouldn't   expect Baidu to spin off iQiyi any more than they expect Alphabet   to spin off YouTube.10 stocks we like better than BaiduWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column47: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Alexa CAN Drive Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock … Someday;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) continues to roll along. AMZN stock trades just off all-time highs at the moment
column5: having gained over 2
column6: 000% over the past 10 years.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockWhile some investors point to the price-to-earnings ratio of Amazon stock as a potential danger sign
column7: I think that viewis short-sighted. The company's legacy business continues to change the face of U.S. retailing. Witness the sharp decline this week atTarget Corporation(NYSE:TGT)
column8: which seems directly attributed to Amazon's online success.Of course
column9: online retail isn't the only area where AMZN is having success - or where increased profits can drive Amazon stock higher. The company's Amazon Web Services (AWS) business has become a dominant player in cloud.And
column10: of late
column11: the company's Amazon Echo
column12: built on the Alexa Voice Service
column13: has added another layer to the bull case for AMZN stock.Though I remain bullish on AMZN
column14: I don't think Alexa really changes the value of Amazon stock - at least not yet. Amazon is too big and Amazon Echo usage is too spotty
column15: for Alexa and/or Echo to drive impressive sales or profit growth on their own.But both products highlight the success of Amazon's long-term strategy; Alexa
column16: in particular
column17: may become a bigger point of the AMZN story in the future.Why Alexa And Echo Aren't A Big Deal For AMZN Stock YetFor any other company
column18: Echo would be considered a monster hit. Amazon hasn't broken out sales figures
column19: but it did say in December that it had sold""millions""of Echo devices. An outside firm pegged the numberat over 5 million. With the average sales price for Amazon likely around $100 (including retail markup and sales of lower-priced Amazon Dots)
column20: that implies as muchas half a billion dollarsin sales for AMZN.10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump NowThat's a huge number - for anyone but Amazon.com
column21: Inc. AMZN generated more than $135 billion in revenue in 2016
column22: meaning Echo-related sales were likely a fraction of 1% of the overall total. Those sales almost certainly come at higher margins for Amazon than
column23: say
column24: shipping a book at the company's usually tiny markup. But from a profit standpoint
column25: Echo seems likely to offer at most a 1%-2% boost
column26: and thus little impact on the fair value of AMZN stock at the moment.Meanwhile
column27: the long-term prospects for Echo aren't completely clear. Usagetends to diminish over time(a trend certainly seen in my household). Echo isn't necessarily being used as a shopping device
column28: either. Rather
column29: the predominant uses are to set a timer
column30: play music
column31: and listen to news summaries.All told
column32: while I do think there's a strong bull case for AMZN stock
column33: that bull case isn't necessarily predicated on Echo. I wouldn't expect that by the end of the decade
column34: consumers across America are ordering Bounty paper towels via drone through Alexa.But that doesn't mean Alexa doesn't matter for Amazon stock.Why Alexa (In Particular) Could Be A Big Deal For AMZN StockOf course
column35: part of the genius of Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos is that Amazon's moves aren't based on the short-term. For all the complaints about AMZN stock's P/E ratio
column36: the company almost certainly could cut costs substantially
column37: and boost earnings
column38: any time it wants.But Amazon continues to play the long game. It continues to expand its addressable markets
column39: taking chances on major successes. (AWS remains the most obvious case of how that strategy has played out well.)From that standpoint
column40: Echo and Alexa are off to a strong early start.Ditch Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock and Look for Greener PasturesAdmittedly
column41: direct Echo revenues are a tiny fraction of overall sales
column42: and Echo-directed e-commerce revenue appears small. But Amazon still benefits from both products. For one
column43: Alexa gives the company a toehold in the important artificial intelligence (AI) space. It allows Amazon to take onApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Siri as well asAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL). Google Home sits in second place at the moment.For Alexa
column44: in particular
column45: the opportunities go beyond Echo. Alexa appears in Amazon Tap and the company's Fire Stick. Amazon wisely has opened the platform to third-party developers. They have created thousands of so-called ""skills
column46: which create a virtuous cycle. The more skills there are
column47: the more valuable Alexa is. The more valuable Alexa becomes
column48: the more skills are created. And the more consumers fall in love with the product.Where Alexa Goes From HereThat opens the door to the real potential value in Alexa.Alexa isn't about driving e-commerce sales through Echo. It's about creating the dominant AI framework in the world. Alexa can be used in automobiles
column49: to allow for safer multi-tasking. There are endless potential industrial applications. Because AMZN wisely has opened that system
column50: it's far more likely to see those applications than Siri or Google's AI.That'sthe value in Alexa: its possibilities seem almost endless at the moment. To be sure
column51: that doesn't mean Amazon necessarily will make billions of dollars off Alexa in two years
column52: or in twenty. That's not the point
column53: however. The point is that Amazon.com continues to innovate
column54: and continues to be an ever-increasing part of its consumers' daily lives. From there
column55: the argument goes
column56: the business end will take care of itself
column57: as will AMZN stock.Certainly
column58: it has worked so far.As of this writing

column1: This Long-Term Trend Makes Facebook an Awesome Buy;3/7/2017;"If you want your marketing message to reach a broad audience
column2: there used to be no better option than national television   commercials. But the growth of digital platforms likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) andAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google make it easy to reach   hundreds of millions of people. What's more
column3: you can target your   message so it only reaches the most qualified potential   buyers.That's why digital has been eating into television ad budgets   -- and why analysts expect that trend to continue for the   foreseeable future. eMarketer forecasts that digital advertising   spend in the U.S. will climb to $113 billion by 2020
column4: while TV ad   spend grows much more slowly
column5: reaching just $77 billion. Digital   spend just surpassed television last year.One of the biggest beneficiaries of the shift of ad budgets   from television to digital is Facebook.makeArticleAd();Image source: Facebook.A Super Bowl every dayFacebook COO Sheryl Sandberg once likened Facebook's reach to   the largest television event. ""We have a Super Bowl on mobile   every day
column6: she said.And it's true. Facebook has 1.23 billion daily active users --   1.14 billion on mobile and 180 million in the U.S. and Canada.   The Super Bowl earlier this year attracted 111.3 million viewers   in the U.S.Granted the Super Bowl lasts something like five hours (more   if Tom Brady sends it into overtime). The average Facebook user   spends ""just"" 50 minutes per day across Facebook
column7: Instagram
column8: and   Messenger
column9: the last of which doesn't yet show ads.However
column10: the average American watches less television today   than they did a few years ago. View time across all age groups   fell 11% in the six years ending last fall. The trend is more   pronounced among younger people. People between 18 and 24 spent   35% less time watching traditional television during the second   quarter last year compared to the second quarter of 2010
column11: according to Nielsen.While Facebook isn't the only reason people are watching less   TV
column12: it presents a very good option for advertisers looking to   replace that lost watch time.Facebook is taking a huge share of digital advertising   growthDigital advertising is growing rapidly
column13: but that doesn't mean   all of that ad spend will go to Facebook. Nonetheless
column14: Facebook   has done an excellent job winning those new ad dollars flowing   from television ad budgets to digital.In the third quarter last year
column15: Facebook took 45% of all   digital advertising growth. Google managed to take 54% of   advertising growth
column16: leaving just 1% of growth for everyone   else.Facebook is poised to continue capturing a lion's share of   digital ad spend growth in the future
column17: too. Display advertising   is the largest form of digital advertising today
column18: and eMarketer   expects that to remain the case in the future. Facebook holds a   wide lead in display advertising
column19: bringing in around $12 billion   in the U.S. last year compared to less than $5 billion for   Google.Facebook is also working to attract more video content to its   platform
column20: which fits nicely with the trend of shifting ad   budgets. Facebook is reportedly funding new content productions   for its platform in the hopes of seeding an entire ecosystem   similar to YouTube. YouTube has proven extremely lucrative for   Google
column21: and Facebook wants in on the billions of digital video   adverting revenue it generates every year.Not only are ad budgets shifting from television to digital
column22: Facebook is one of the few companies that's been able to attract   those ad dollars thanks to its audience size
column23: engagement
column24: and ad   targeting capabilities. As the trend continues through the end of   the decade
column25: that makes Facebook an awesome buy.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: YouTube TV Is Here: What Investors Need to Know;3/6/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Americans are changing the way they watch television. More and   more customers are showing interest in over-the-top streaming TV   services. Over 200
column2: 000 people joinedAT&T's(NYSE: T) DirecTVNow in about one month.DISH Network's(NASDAQ: DISH) Sling TV has over 1 million subscribers.Sony's(NYSE: SNE) PlayStation Vue is also very popular.makeArticleAd();Now YouTube -- a subsidiary of Google
column3: theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) company -- is throwing its hat in   the ring as well. The company recently revealed YouTube TV
column4: a   slightly differentiated television service that costs just $35   per month.Here's what investors need to know about YouTube TV.YouTube TV's channel lineup. Image source: YouTubeIt's missing a lot of traditional cable networksYouTube focused on signing deals with the big four broadcast   companies. As a result
column5: cable-only media companies such asViacomandTime Warnerare missing from the bundle. No CNN
column6: Comedy Central
column7: Cartoon Network
column8: TBS
column9: TNT
column10: or HBO. But it does mean cable   networks owned by the big four -- ESPN
column11: FX
column12: USA
column13: E!
column14: and so on --   are all there.That's kind of the opposite approach of Sling TV. Sling   launched without any broadcast networks
column15: inviting subscribers to   buy a television antenna to supplement the service.Importantly
column16: local networks are limited in availability.   That's why YouTube TV is launching only in markets where the   media companies own the local broadcast affiliate. Sony tried   something similar before expanding nationwide with a reduced   price for subscribers where live local channels are not   available.Overall
column17: the channel lineup is somewhat lacking compared with   competing services at around the same price point. Customers that   signed up early for DirecTV Now are receiving 100 channels for   $35 per month
column18: and new customers can still receive 60 channels   for that price. PlayStation Vue customers can get a similar   set of channels for $35 per month
column19: and Sling TV subscribers can   get around 50 channels for $40 per month.The limited geographical reach and channel lineup should   reduce the number of subscribers YouTube TV will attract.YouTube is a veteran at video streamingAlthough YouTube TV may lack some of the content available on   other platforms at similar price points and the geographic reach   of its competition
column20: it has one major advantage. It already owns   leading technology in video streaming.All three of the aforementioned competitors suffered major   technical difficulties following their launches. DirecTV Now   received a lot of bad press as its servers were overloaded making   parts or all of the service unusable. YouTube
column21: on the other hand
column22: already streaming 1 billion hours of video every day.Consumers may be willing to sacrifice some channels for more   reliable service. But YouTube still has to prove that it can   deliver where competitors failed.The bottom line for investorsYouTube TV is a somewhat underwhelming product at launch. With   a limited channel lineup and geographic reach
column23: it's unlikely to   make any significant impact on YouTube's operations in the near   term.In the long term
column24: however
column25: getting a viable product out there   now could lead to a much better product in the future. YouTube is   already offering a few differentiating features such as unlimited   cloud DVR
column26: AI powered search and personalization (likely backed   by YouTube viewer data)
column27: and the ability to split the account six   ways so different users get different recommendations. If YouTube   can get the content deals in place while maintaining competitive   pricing
column28: it could be a big winner in the future.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (C   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How Long Until I Get My Driverless Car?;3/6/2017;"Autonomous cars have been the buzz of the energy and tech   sectors for years now
column2: but how close are we as consumers to   actually having fully autonomous cars in our driveways?In this week's episode ofIndustry Focus: Industrials
column3: analyst Sean O'Reilly talks with Motley Fool senior auto   specialist John Rosevear about the state of autonomous driving   tech today
column4: and when consumers will start to see the fruits of   the industry's labors.Tune in to find out what the different levels of automation   are and why they matter; where companies likeTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column5: Ford(NYSE: F)
column6: andFiat Chryslerfit into the story; whereAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Waymo andApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) alleged car project seem to be heading; and   more.makeArticleAd();A full transcript follows the video.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column11: 2017This podcast was recorded on March 2
column12: 2017.Sean O'Reilly:Welcome toIndustry Focus
column13: the podcast that dives into a different sector of the stock   market every day. Today is Thursday
column14: March 2
column16: so   we're talking about energy
column17: materials
column18: and   industrials. I am your host
column19: Sean O'Reilly
column20: and joining   me today via phone is Motley Fool senior auto   specialist
column21: Mr. John Rosevear. Good morning
column22: John!John Rosevear:Good morning
column23: Sean! How are you
column24: today?O'Reilly:Extremely well. It's good to hear your voice. It's been   awhile
column25: a month or two
column26: since we last had a podcast
column27: and I   missed you
column28: buddy.Rosevear:Yeah
column29: it's been a few weeks.O'Reilly:I had to get you in here to answer an all-important question.Rosevear:What's the question?O'Reilly:You're the only guy I know who can answer this for   me. I hate driving
column30: I live in D.C.
column31: it's very tiring
column32: I   want to know when I'm going to get my self-driving car.Rosevear:Well
column33: it depends on what you mean by get
column34: and   really depends on what you mean by   self-driving
column35: [laughs] unfortunately.O'Reilly:I'm not touching the wheel in my driveway.Rosevear:Let's back up and define some terms here. This system of   classification for things that assist drivers has become   pretty universal. It was developed by the Society of Automotive   Engineers in the U.S. The U.S. government has adopted   it
column36: other governments have adopted it
column37: it's the way all   automakers talk now. They categorize it in six levels that   are helpfully numbered from zero to five. A level zero system
column38: there's no automation
column39: the driver does everything. This might   even include warning systems like lane departure warning. But
column40: the driver actually has to do everything. Level one is when   you get some basic level of driver   assistance
column41: assistance that parallel parks for   you
column42: that kind of stuff. That's a level one system.O'Reilly:Does that include anti-lock brakes? I'm surprised   that's on here.Rosevear:That's...O'Reilly:Eye of the beholder?Rosevear:The driver is still executing that. They count that as an   intervention system. It's when the car decides to break for you   that it starts to become assisted. These emergency   stopping systems that they have now where the radar is on   the front of the car
column43: the levels one through five require some   level of sensing what's going on around a car. So
column44: yeah
column45: these   parallel park systems where the car spins the wheel for you and   backs into the spot
column46: that kind of thing
column47: that's a level one.   Level two is where it starts to get interesting. This is the   system where you're on the highway and the traffic jam assist   systems
column48: maybe the earliest versions of Tesla's   autopilot
column49: where you can kind of take your hand off the   wheel under certain circumstances
column50: and the car will maintain and   adjust its speed relative to the cars around to you
column51: and it   will keep itself in its lane. It's doing a little   steering and a little accelerating and decelerating on its   own. But there still has to be a human driver
column52: the human   driver has to be ready to grab the wheel. In fact
column53: a lot of   these systems require you to actually touch the wheel every   minute or two
column54: or something like that. Level three is   when it kind of gets into self driving. This is a system that can   drive under certain conditions
column55: we might say highway   driving
column56: this is where Tesla's autopilot is starting to go
column57: this is where some of the systems
column58: GM's(NYSE: GM) Super Cruise that will come out on Cadillac   soon
column59: this is where it ends up
column60: level three.O'Reilly:Super Cruise? [laughs]Rosevear:That's what they call it. That's what they've been   calling it for a few years
column61: I'm not completely sure   that's what they're going to call it when it comes to   market. Anyway
column62: the gist here is
column63: it's self-driving until   suddenly it isn't
column64: the driver has to be ready to grab the   wheel. That makes it a little tricky. We'll talk about that   in a minute.O'Reilly:The Motley Fool's Dan Sparks did that article about a year   ago
column65: he lives out in Colorado and he has a Tesla
column66: how   far did he get
column67: 90 miles? I can't remember
column68: but
column69: I   don't think he touched the wheel on the freeway with that   thing.Rosevear:Tesla's official instructions with the original system where   you're supposed to touch the wheel regularly
column70: they considered it   an advanced level two system. I think now they're into level   three territory. The border here is a little bit fuzzy. The   border to level four is not fuzzy. Level four is
column71: the car is   driving itself
column72: period. It does not need you
column73: but it's   limited. Usually what it means is it's limited to an area   that's been mapped
column74: we say it's been geofenced.   These systems tend to depend on very highly detailed 3D   maps that show stuff that normal maps don't show
column75: like exactly where the curb is within a couple inches and so   forth
column76: so the car can navigate precisely
column77: especially on   a city street. So
column78: it's full self-driving
column79: you don't ever   have to touch a steering wheel
column80: but it only works where the   car has a map. Level five -- and we'll get back to this in a   minute -- is the full-blown thing. It'll drive itself   wherever you want under any conditions. If it's   snowing
column81: it'll go up a mountain
column82: whatever
column83: anything.So
column84: what we're talking about in the near future is level   four
column85: a car that will self-drive itself. This is coming soon. But   it's limited by its maps. The idea is
column86: gradually the maps   will expand over time and you'll be able to drive --O'Reilly:Are there cities that are being mapped right now? I'm   actually surprised to hear this.Rosevear:Yeah
column87: Pittsburgh is being mapped. This is where Uber is   doing their testing
column88: a lot of it. This is actually where   Ford's new company they created as a start-up with a veteran of   Uber and a veteran of Google's self-driving car project running   it. This is basically Ford's software team for self-driving
column89: and they're in Pittsburgh. There's been a lot of mapping   done
column92: because the   artificial intelligence lab at Carnegie Mellon is the   source of a lot of the research that went into this
column94: a   lot of the people are there. There's some mapping going on   in San Francisco. I know GM's   cruise automation subsidiary is doing testing of level   four assistance in San Francisco
column95: so they have mapping going   on. Then
column96: there are companies mapping all over the place. Tesla
column98: is automating some of this mapping with the sensors   on their existing cars. A company calledMobileye(NYSE: MBLY)  is going to start doing mapping with   sensors on their customers' cars
column99: these are sensors for level two   systems but they can help do the mapping for level four. This is   going to start very soon
column100: probably next year for Mobileye. There   are private companies trying to do this
column102: hoping to   be able to sell the maps to the automakers or whoever. And
column104: the big wild card in this is
column106: Waymo. Google's   been mapping for years and years. [laughs]O'Reilly:You've seen the cars? They look ridiculous
column107: they have the   pole and they have the ball of cameras on the top
column108: and they just   drive around all these cities. That's how I can see what   my dentist's office looks like from across the street.   They're mapping cities with that
column109: too?Rosevear:Yeah. I think everybody is. And it's not just mapping for   Google Maps
column110: it's mapping at a much more fine level of   detail
column114: so the car knows what to expect as it's driving. The   idea is
column115: a map is a fallback from its sensors. If it's dark   out
column117: if the lighter system is   being buggy for whatever reason
column118: you can kind of fall   back on the maps. Because these are safety systems
column119: there   has to be redundancy built in. That's the thinking.O'Reilly:So
column120: when is this stuff coming out?Rosevear:Good question. Tesla constantly does these upgrades
column121: and   they'll break into level four at some point. If I had to   guess
column122: I'd say 2019. But I don't know for sure. They may not   even know absolutely for sure when they'll be ready to ship   it. There's also an interesting question there that with their   owners of their current models

column1: 6 Things You Didn't Know About Baidu
column2: Inc.;3/6/2017;"Many tech investors are probably familiar with the basic facts   aboutBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) -- it's the biggest search engine in China
column3: it has   a growing ecosystem of cloud-based services likeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google
column4: and it benefited greatly   from Google's exit from the mainland Chinese market in 2010.Those are the bullet points in the growth story that boosted   Baidu stock by nearly 1
column5: 500% over the past decade. But today
column6: we'll take a look at six lesser-known facts about the ""Chinese   Google"" which many investors might have overlooked.Image source: Author's screenshot.makeArticleAd();1. CEO Robin Li cut his teeth in the U.S. tech     industryAfter earning a master's degree in Computer Science from the   University of Buffalo
column7: Baidu co-founder and CEO Robin Li worked   at Dow Jones & Co.'s IDD Information Services and search   company Infoseek in the  1990s.At IDD
column8: Li developed the software for the online version ofThe Wall Street Journaland invented his patented Rankdex site-scoring algorithm for    SEO rankings -- which currently powers Baidu's search   engine. At Infoseek
column9: Li created the image search function
column10: which   was subsequently used inDisney's Go.com network. After spending over five years at those two   companies
column11: Li returned to China and co-founded Baidu with   investor Eric Xu in early 2000.2. Baidu is developing driverless carsLike Google
column12: Baidu believes that autonomous electric cars   would be a natural extension of its data mining ecosystem. The   company started testing out driverless cars on public roads in   late 2015
column13: and formed a driverless tech research center in   Silicon Valley last April.Image source: Getty Images.Baidu is powering these vehicles with a combination ofNVIDIA's automotive chips
column14: HERE Maps
column15: and its own AI algorithms. It's   currently outsourcing production of these vehicles to Chinese   automakers
column16: and has declared that it will launch an autonomous   shuttle bus  by 2018.3. It's beefing up its AI effortsFor search engines like Baidu and Google
column17: AI plays a key role   in recognizing images
column18: analyzing search patterns
column19: and deciding   what types of targeted ads will appeal to users. That's why Baidu   hired a lot of top talent in AI -- its chief scientist Andrew Ng   previously helmed the Google Brain AI project
column20: and its new   augmented reality chief Qi Lu was previously an AI specialist atMicrosoft.Baidu hasn't been shy about challenging Google in the AI arms   race. In January
column21: it pitted its AI program against Google's   AlphaGo AI in  a series of facial and voice recognition   tests in a live TV broadcast.4. Baidu owns a small stake in Didi ChuxingBaidu previously invested in Uber's Chinese division
column22: but Uber   eventually retreated from the market due to tough competition --   especially from market leader Didi Chuxing. Uber sold its Chinese   business to Didi last August
column23: but retained a 17.7% stake in the   new subsidiary. Baidu and Uber China's other  shareholders   received a 2.3% stake.That stake is small
column24: but Baidu could boost it and more tightly   integrate Didi's services into its O2O (online-to-offline)   ecosystem. Didi could also play a key role in automating Baidu's   driverless cars.5. It owns a big part of CtripBaidu owns a 25% stake inCtrip(NASDAQ: CTRP)
column25: the largest online travel agency (OTA) in China.   For years
column26: Ctrip was engaged in a price war with its primary   competitorQunar(NASDAQ: QUNR)
column27: which crushed both companies' margins.Baidu owned a 45% stake in Qunar
column28: but it swapped that stake   for  a 25% stake in Ctrip in 2015 -- which effectively   merged the two companies and ended the price war. That move also   tethered Ctrip's services more tightly to Baidu's growing O2O   ecosystem.6. Baidu also sells smart bikesIn late 2014
column29: Baidu introduced DuBike
column30: a bike equipped with a   wide array of health and motion sensors which sync to a mobile   app. It also features on-board navigation signals
column31: which let   riders follow directions without glancing at their phones
column32: and   lets riders share their routes with friends. To top it off
column33: the   entire system is powered by a rider's kinetic energy -- so the   bike never needs to be recharged.Baidu's DuBike. Image source: Baidu.The key takeawayThe heart of Baidu's business is still search-based   advertising
column34: but that could gradually change as its efforts in   driverless cars
column35: AI
column36: its O2O ecosystem
column37: and even smart bikes pay   off. Therefore
column38: investors should keep an eye on these adjacent   efforts as the company trades blows with other tech titans --   likeTencentandAlibaba-- over the next few years.10 stocks we like better than BaiduWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column41: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column42: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Baidu wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column45: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors. Teresa Kersten is an employee     of LinkedIn and is a member of The Motley Fool's Board of     Directors. LinkedIn is owned by Microsoft.Leo Sunowns shares of Baidu
column46: Tencent
column47: and Walt Disney. The Motley Fool     owns shares of and recommends Alphabet (A shares)
column48: Alphabet (C     shares)
column49: Baidu
column50: Nvidia
column51: and Walt Disney. The Motley Fool     recommends Ctrip.com International. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: GoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Gutted? Time to Go Long!;3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsGoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO) is a camera company
column3: yet Wall Street experts expected so much more out the GPRO story. They even once labeled it as ""a YouTube killer."" I betAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL) management wasn't too worried then. That exuberance marked the top for GoPro stock.makeArticleAd();Source:ETC-USC via Flickr (Modified)Now
column5: GoPro stock gets a downgrade under $9 per share. I'm sure it's no coincidence that this coincides with the IPO ofSnap Inc(NYSE:SNAP)
column6: which had a successful offering last week. Money is probably flocking out of GPRO and into SNAP stock
column7: perhaps to recoup some losses there.I think the two have little in common. GoPro stock is a play on a line of action cameras known for being rugged and for active outdoorsy people. We see videos of extreme base jumping pros to teens clearing a two-foot hedge in their front yard. So far
column8: SNAP appears to capture more general scenarios.The hate for GoPro stock should abate eventually. It still has cool products with very few high-profile direct competitors. I don't have a lot of faith in management
column9: but just like in the case ofTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR)
column10: I think someone will eventually figure the stock out. But for this morning
column11: GPRO stock is down 7.8% on a downgrade from Goldman Sachs.Click to EnlargeBased on that logic

column1: IBM to Commercialize Quantum Computing Using Cloud Platform;3/6/2017;"International Business Machines CorporationIBMrecently announced plans to introduce quantum computing systems and services in the commercial space under the brand name ""IBM Q"". The company will leverage its IBM Cloud platform to deliver these systems and services.We note that this is an industry-first initiative undertaken by the technology giant and could revolutionize the way computing is being carried out in the present context.International Business Machines Corporation Price and   ConsensusInternational Business Machines Corporation Price   and Consensus|International Business Machines Corporation QuoteFilling in the Market GapCognitive systems such as IBM Watson run on classical computers and are capable of finding patterns and insights by deciphering huge amount of data. However

column4: financial services

column6: drug discovery and supply chain and logistics.What Does This Mean for IBM?As per a Market Research Media report

column1: This Odd Little Company Beat the Market in 2016. Is It worth a Look in 2017?;3/6/2017;"It's tough to know what to make ofRaven Industries(NASDAQ: RAVN) . This unique little company's stock jumped 62.7%   in 2016
column2: handily beating larger peers like3M(NYSE: MMM)
column3: as well as the S&P 500. But companies that defy   description can sometimes be hidden buys.If it's tough to describe Raven
column4: it's even tougher to figure   out where the company -- not to mention its stock -- is likely to   head in 2017. That's partly due to a huge issue with the company   that should worry investors who are interested in buying   top-quality stocks.Raven Industries invented the modern hot air balloon. Image     source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();What it doesRaven Industries was formed in 1956
column5: when a group of   businessmen leftGeneral Mills
column6: of all places
column7: to form an industrial balloon company. Over   the next few decades
column8: Raven invented the modern hot air balloon   and dabbled in other materials science industries like fiberglass   tanks
column9: parachutes
column10: cold-weather sportswear
column11: and utility truck   bodies. The company branched out into the businesses of flow   systems and agricultural control systems in the 80s and 90s.Today
column12: Raven still manufactures balloons
column13: covers
column14: liners
column15: and   films used in various applications from grain covers to   wastewater pit liners to industrial packaging. It also has robust   agricultural controls and radar technologies businesses. The   ""internet balloons"" developed byAlphabet's Google to bring broadband access to rural areas utilize   Raven's balloon technology.Even with its 2016 performance
column16: Raven is still a small   company
column17: with a less than $1 billion market cap. So
column18: let's look   at how such a small-yet-diversified company managed to crush the   market last year.The Trump factorAs you might expect with a small-cap company
column19: Raven's growth   was very lumpy throughout 2016
column20: in sharp contrast to the much   larger 3M and the S&P:RAVNdata byYCharts.But as you can see
column21: one of the biggest jumps of the year for   the company came
column22: unsurprisingly
column23: in the wake of Donald Trump's   upset win in the November election. Such a win was seen as a boon   forconstruction companiesbecause of a potential major infrastructure package
column24: fordefense contractorsbecause of potential increases in military spending
column25: and forenergy companiesbecause of the potential removal of environmental   regulations.Raven Industries operates in all of those fields
column26: manufacturing films for the construction industry
column27: surveillance   balloons and equipment for the military
column28: and films to contain   fracking waste. No wonder the market has high hopes for the   company going into 2017.Of course
column29: considering the amount of opposition on Capitol   Hill to some of President Trump's policies and proposals
column30: it   would be a risky bet to buy Raven's stock solely on speculation   about his agenda without more details about how it might be   implemented -- and whether Congress is buying in to his   proposals. But there's an even bigger risk for potential Raven   investors.The red flagRaven is in an unusual situation in that
column31: as of early   February
column32: it was in non-compliance with NASDAQ rules for failure   to submit quarterly reports to the SEC. Since then
column33: the company   has filed five quarterly SEC reports
column34: including amended Q3 2016   and full-year 2016 reports
column35: as well as an amended Q1 2017 report   and Q2 and Q3 reports.The company hadn't held an earnings conference call since   March 2016
column36: but it finally held one on February 16th. On   that call
column37: as you can imagine
column38: there was a heaping helping of   humble pie served up by CEO Dan Rhykus. ""I'd like to address our   reevaluation of our internal control framework and the controlled   deficiencies we identified
column39: he began
column40: before stating the   following:We are responding with the utmost urgency and diligence to     remedy the situation and to ensure that we maintain a more     proactive approach to adapting the changes in the future
column41: so     that our framework design appropriate adapts to whatever     changes our business may experience in the future or to changes     in the regulatory environment. As we work to remediate     these material weaknesses and enhance our control's framework
column42: we will keep you fully informed and updated.Essentially
column43: management discovered that ""The  Company's    controls  relating  to  the response    to  the  risks  of  material    misstatement  were  not  effectively    designed
column44: according to the company's amended 2016 10-K.   Specifically
column45: these control issues could -- and did -- lead the   company to misstate items including goodwill
column46: long-lived assets
column47: income taxes
column48: and inventories on its quarterly and annual   reports.While many of these misstatements were comparatively small --   selling
column49: general
column50: and administrative expenses
column51: for example
column52: were   revised upwards by just $20
column53: 000 for FY 2016 -- some were far more   significant. Long-lived asset impairment losses of $3.8 million
column54: for example
column55: weren't even included in the original 2016 10-K
column56: and   contributed to a $6.7 million drop in EBIT on the amended report.   That in turn helped to drop annual EPS from $0.23 (original) to   $0.13 (restated)
column57: a major change.What's of more concern than these identified issues
column58: however
column59: is the possibility that there are other problems that haven't yet   come to light.Investor takeawayThere's certainly a case to be made that -- with its reporting   now up-to-date and with remediation efforts under way -- Raven's   troubles are behind it
column60: and it's a safe investment moving   forward. Plus
column61: the company's reported third-quarter earningswere actually pretty impressive. Operating income was up 175% year over year
column62: for   example. So maybe I'm being overly cautious when I say that   I don't feel comfortable investing in Raven until it can provide   concrete assurances that it has its house in order (remember
column63: the   company hasn't yet been able to guarantee the issues are   solved).In the third-quarter earnings call
column64: Rhykus has promised to   keep investors updated
column65: so I'll be eagerly awaiting those   updates. In the meantime
column66: there are plenty of other companies   that aregenerating strong earningsthat don't seem to be having the internal problems that Raven is   having. If you're interested in materials science stocks
column67: you   could consider 3M
column68: despite its middling outlook. For now
column69: though
column70: cautious investors should probably look   elsewhere.10 stocks we like better than Raven IndustriesWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column71: it can pay to listen. After all
column72: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column73: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column74: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Raven Industries wasn't one   of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column75: 2017.Suzanne Frey
column76: an executive at Alphabet
column77: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.John Bromelsowns shares of Alphabet (A and C shares). The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Alphabet (A and C shares). The Motley     Fool recommends Raven Industries. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Apple Music Just Can’t Catch Spotify;3/4/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Apple Music is a success by all counts
column3: but one target still remains elusive.makeArticleAd();Despite impressive subscriber gains since its 2015 launch
column4: AAPL's streaming music service has been unable to catch primary rivalSpotify. And in the latest sign that the competition is far from over
column5: Spotify just announced it has hit the 50 million paid subscriber mark.Spotify Hits 50 Million Paid SubscribersApple Music and Spotify are considered to be the two big players in the streaming music war.Spotify launched in 2008
column6: giving it a long lead in which to build up steam over Apple Music
column7: which didn't go live until 2015. Despite that head start - and predictions that after its initial free three-month trial expired
column8: Apple's streaming music service would see a big drop off of subscribers - Apple Music quickly began to gain obliterate Spotify's numbers.Apple Music hit 10 million paid subscribers after just six months
column9: a milestone that took Spotify nearly six years to reach. Since then
column10: Apple Music has continued to add paid subscribers at a rapid pace: 11 million by last February
column11: 13 million in April
column12: 17 million in September and 20 million in December.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Posts Best Q4 Apple Watch Sales EverHowever
column13: despite the rapidly increasing popularity of Apple's streaming music service
column14: Spotify stubbornly refuses to go away. In fact
column15: rather than stalling or beginning to slip as many expected
column16: Spotify's numbers have also been growing strongly.Spotify had roughly 20 million paid subscribers at the time Apple Music launched. This week
column17: the company announced it hashit 50 million.In other words
column18: Spotify is not going anywhere any time soon.A Little More CompetitionWhile the big streaming music battle has been between Apple Music and Spotify
column19: many other competitors are duking it out for the dollars of music fans. And rather than scare off new entrants
column20: the success of Apple Music led to a big new competitor taking a shot at the business.Amazon.com
column21: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)launched Amazon Music Unlimited last fall
column22: matching Apple Music's basic subscription rates. But Amazon added a twist by discounting the service for Amazon Prime members and slashing it it less than half the regular $9.99 monthly fee for owners of its Amazon Echo smart speaker.Will Apple Music Ever Catch Spotify? (And Does It Need to?)The success of Apple Music isn't just about bragging rights.The streaming music service is part of Apple's Services division. That division is increasingly important to the bottom line. It provides recurring revenue
column23: which helps to protect against shocks when hardware sales hit rough patches. In AAPL's most recent quarter
column24: Services posted thestrongest year-over-year growth of any of Apple's divisions.2016 revenue numbers for Spotify aren't yet available
column25: but the music streaming service has consistently lost money
column26: including $176.9 million in 2014 and $188.7 million. Thesituation looked grim a year ago
column27: with Apple Music growing rapidly. However
column28: big increases in paid subscriber drove a revenue gain of80% to $2.12 billion. That marked a turning point in the outlook for Spotify's survival.With profitability a distinct possibility in 2017
column29: Spotify could be in acquisition territory.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) andFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) have both been floated aspotential buyers. An initial public offering could also be in its future.Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8 Lightning Port Drama ContinuesRegardless
column30: Apple Music seems unlikely to knock Spotify off the top of the streaming music charts
column31: at least not in the near future.That doesn't mean Apple Music isn't a success. It quickly vaulted from zero to a contender for top spot in mere months and has continued to grow. As shown by the number of streaming music services that continue to attract paid subscribers
column32: there is still plenty of room for multiple big players to make money.Apple Music will continue to drive revenue into AAPL's Services division
column33: even if that coveted No. 1 spot remains elusive.As of this writing
column34: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceFriday Apple Rumors: iPhone Delay

column1: Believe It or Not
column2: Apple Came in Dead Last in Customer Loyalty in This $24 Billion Market;3/3/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) knows what it's doing. The company is a market   leader in many fields
column3: and would often rather abandon a product   category rather than struggle on as a minor competitor to bigger   and better rivals.But even mighty Apple does the occasional swing-and-a-miss   routine. And some of Cupertino's whiffs come in vibrant   billion-dollar markets.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Apple ranks dead last in the $24 billion file-hosting   marketBrand Keysis a branding consultancy firm with more than three decades of   expertise-building history under its belt. The firm is best known   for its Customer Loyalty Engagement Index (CLEI) rankings
column4: where   a proprietary data-collection process builds customer-loyalty   ratings in more than 80 specific product categories.Apple
column5: of course
column6: dominates several of the latest Brand Keysratings. The iPhone shows up all comers in the smartphone category
column7: no   tablet can beat the iPad's consumer loyalty
column8: and MacBooks walks   away with the top rating among laptop brands. In something of an   upset
column9: Apple Musiceven takes home the online music segment.And then there's the file-storage category. There
column10: Apple   doesn't just miss the top spot
column11: but falls all the way to the   bottom of 13 ranked services.How bad is that result for Apple?To be clear
column12: Brand Keys claims that its measurements translate   directly into future sales prospects and revenues. According to   independent metrics fromMarkets and Markets
column13: cloud storage is a $24 billion market today -- and expected to   reach annual sales of $75 billion in just five years.In other words
column14: it looks like Apple is leaving a lot of cash   on the table. The iCloud file-storage service is not pulling its   weight
column15: or moving the needle for Apple. Instead
column16: consumers with a   need for off-site file-storage tools prefer free services like   Brand Keys' category winner
column17: Sabrecat -- or a plethora of   better-known options such as runner-up Dropbox
column18: or third-place   finisherGoogle(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Drive.Apple is not only missing a significant market opportunity
column19: but leaving a lot of that cash for Google parent Alphabet to grab   instead.Apple CEO Tim Cook. Image source: Apple.Why is Apple missing the boat?Apple's iCloud is
column20: in many ways
column21: very similar to Google Drive   and Dropbox. All three services allow users to store nearly any   type of file in a centrally managed cloud server
column22: accessible from   any networked computer. They all come with small storage limits   for a free account
column23: all offer a terabyte of storage for $9.99 per   month
column24: and come with various tools for managing your stored   files. But Apple does a few things differently.First and foremost
column25: the easiest way to access iCloud content   is via an iPhone
column26: iPad
column27: or MacBook. In fact
column28: signing up for an   iCloud account is part of the setup process for all of these   systems. Then
column29: the service is integrated into your Apple   experience as the destination for system backup files
column30: the   default storage location for files created in the iWork office   suite
column31: and an option for storing user files in newer versions of   the macOS system.All of this is designed to keep users tightly bound to Apple's   multi-device ecosystem. Once you're in
column32: it's not easy to get   untangled. Given Apple's massive market reach
column33: especially in the   tablet and smartphone segments
column34: this alone should make iCloud a   winner. Apple CEO Tim Cook introduced the package as ""a strategy   for the next decade"" in 2012.However
column35: Apple never quite delivered on that grand ambition.   iCloud is reportedly ostracized by other working groups within   the company
column36: starved of resources
column37: and mostly seen as a necessary   evil. Apple is a product company
column38: and iCloud is not a marketable   product on its own -- at least not in its current Apple-centric   form. So
column39: this odd piece of infrastructure machinery is left out   in the cold.And there goes Apple's ticket to a $24 billion industry that's   also on a rapid growth tear.Google sure is building its Drive product into everything from   Gmail to mobile photo storage to storage space for corporate   accounts. Dropbox is doing the same
column40: while on the lookout for   another buyout bid. And this market should only grow faster as   theInternet of Thingsgrows up
column41: requiring acres of cloud-based storage space. These   companies treat online file storage as an important business
column42: valuable on its own merits.Apple doesn't. Hence
column43: the company is holding back on promoting   iCloud
column44: developing it further
column45: or building it into other   products
column46: when appropriate. Cupertino misses out on a major   growth story
column47: with absolutely no loyalty from the customers who   do sign up.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column48: it can pay to listen. After all
column49: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Cisco (CSCO) Expands Its IoT Offerings Thanks to Jasper;3/3/2017;"Cisco Systems Inc.'sCSCOstock has been a consistent performer in the last 12 months. While the ZacksComputer - Networkingindustry gained 27.6%
column2: shares of this technology giant recorded marginally better returns of 27.7%. This trend can primarily be attributed to improving revenues from subscription services as well as robust demand in the telecom sector.Meanwhile
column3: the company is focusing on expanding its Internet of Things (IoT) division
column4: as per a recent announcement at the Mobile World Congress (MWC)
column5: held in Barcelona.Based on its acquisition of Jasper Technologies in Mar 2016 Cisco is aiming at becoming a major IoT platform provider going forward.Notably
column6: the platform has emerged as one of the biggest monetization assets for Cisco given the burgeoning demand for IoT.At MWC
column7: Cisco announced that itwill now provide support for narrowband IoT low-power wide-area network (LPWAN)
column8: which has applications in the industrial IoT space. Moreover
column9: the company inked a partnership with car-maker Honda and Bright Box
column10: a European connected-car platform which will enable Jasper to breath life into Bright Box's infotainment centers that come as a standard fitting in many of Honda's European car models. It was also announced at the event that Cisco will collaborate with Samsung and Jupl (a health data startup) to develop a wearable device targeted at the elderly for health monitoring purposes.What Does this Mean for Cisco?As of today
column11: on the verge of one year completion
column12: Cisco's IoT unit has witnessed a whopping surge of 157% in enterprise customer additions
column13: 135% increase in the number of devices that are being managed and a 42% advance in adoptions for Jasper's Control Center product.As per an IDC report
column14: the IoT market is estimated to reach a massive $1.7 trillion by 2020 with nearly 30 billion connected ""things."" Given the huge potential the sector has to offer
column15: the time is ripe to carve a niche and that's exactly what Cisco is doing right now.Not surprisingly then
column16: there is stiff competition in the space with the presence of major players such as Alphabet's GoogleGOOGL
column17: MicrosoftMSFT
column18: IBM
column19: Intel
column20: Siemens and AT&T.However
column21: with these announcements
column22: Cisco looks poised to take on the competition head on which augurs well for the company in the long run.Cisco Systems

column1: Google’s Groundbreaking Oscar Nod Could Pave the Way for VR;3/3/2017;"Virtual reality (VR) is a technology that is still in the   early stages of adoption. While headsets are available
column2: VR has   yet to gain wide acceptance due to the high cost of consoles and   equipment
column3: and the lack of sufficient content. Additionally
column4: the   technology is still largely unfamiliar to the majority of   consumers
column5: who may have heard of VR but have yet to experience   it. All that may be beginning to change.Pearl is the first VR movie to be nominated for an Oscar.     Image source: Google.makeArticleAd();For the first time
column6: a movie created specifically to be viewed   in VR was nominated for an Academy Award. Though the film didn't   win
column7: it may act as a touchstone for consumers.Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google Spotlight Stories
column8: a VR   storytelling venue
column9: has for the last several years produced   360-degree and VR films in the form of animated shorts. This   allowed filmmakers to reimagine storytelling and for technicians   from Google's Advanced Technology and Projects group (ATAP) to   hone the nascent technology.Its Oscar-nominated short
column10: Pearl
column11: is centered on the life and times of a musical father and   daughter traveling the country in pursuit of stardom. The   animated scenes all take place from the point-of-view of a   passenger in the front seat of their car. The ground-breaking   film was directed by Patrick Osbourne who received an Oscar in   2015 for his work onWalt Disney's(NYSE: DIS)Feast
column12: a short film about a man and his adopted dog
column13: which debuted in   2014. This highlights a recent push by filmmakers and the movie   industry to embrace the technology.Meanwhile
column14: legendary director Steven Spielberg is fronting a   new VR start-up
column15: Dreamscape Immersive
column16: which recently raised $11   million in funding from several Hollywood studios. Focusing on   location-based virtual reality
column17: the company plans to open a VR   multiplex in Los Angeles later this year.This comes on the heels of a similar location-based offering   that is the result of apartnershipbetween Google andIMAX Corporation(NYSE: IMAX) . The companies joined forces to create a cinema   grade VR camera using Google's Jump platform which seamlessly   integrates 360-degree video into a panoramic view. Last month
column18: IMAX opened its pilot VR center in Los Angeles and based on its   early success
column19: the company plans to open five additional test   locations by mid-year. This model incorporates original material
column20: as well as content that expands on big budget films
column21: such as   Disney'sStar Warsseries
column22: Lions Gate Entertainment Corp.'sJohn Wickmovies
column23: andHasbro'sTransformersfranchise.Samsung Gear VR. Image source: Samsung.In another sign that VR is gaining a wider audienceNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) released apps for its leading streaming service   that will work with several commercially available headsets   including theFacebook's Oculus Rift
column24: Samsung's Gear VR
column25: and Google Daydream View.  The app features   a virtual living room where viewers can connect with the familiar   Netflix interface to select programs for viewing. Website   ScreenRant.com detaileda listof movies that lend themselves to VR
column26: without being specific to   the technology. While Netflix is not providing any actual VR   content
column27: this is an acknowledgement that the public may be ready   for more in the way of interacting with VR technology.VR is still in its infancy and it will be some time before it   gains widespread adoption. Hollywood is leading the charge with   location-based options that will supplement the home VR market.   This provides evidence that the technology is gaining ground
column28: and   the tipping point may be closer than we imagine.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column17: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column18: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column19: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column20: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column21: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs   experienced notable outflows »"

column2: Inc. (AMZN) Isn’t Infallible After All;3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column5: which has ambitions of putting a warehouse in the sky and delivering products by drone
column6: among other projects
column7: seemingly can do no wrong
column8: positioning AMZN stocknear all-time highs. AMZN stock closed Thursday at $848.91
column9: up 13% year to date

column11: the recent outage of Amazon's web-based Simple Storage Service (S3)
column12: which disrupted websites
column13: apps and smart devices across the country
column14: shows the Seattle-based e-commerce giant isn't infallible
column15: after all. But
column16: don't hold your breath thinking this glitch will put a damper on AMZN stock.According to the company's statement
column17: the outage impacting the S3 cloud services was due to human error. An issue in the S3 billing process was being debugged by members of the Amazon Simple Storage Service team. In an attempt to rectify the issue
column18: which involved taking down a small number of servers
column19: one of the engineers entered an incorrect keystroke.""An authorized S3 team member using an established playbook executed a command which was intended to remove a small number of servers for one of the S3 subsystems that is used by the S3 billing process
column20: Amazon saidin a statement on its website. ""Unfortunately
column21: one of the inputs to the command was entered incorrectly and a larger set of servers was removed than intended.""The servers that were mistakenly taken down supported two other S3 subsystems
column22: which triggered a widespread outage impacting government services
column23: news sites
column24: the Securities and Exchange Commission
column25: Business Insider
column26: Quora and Slack and a host of other institutions considered significant to the internet infrastructure.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017It remains to be seen whether this issue will cause Amazon to lose any customers to competing cloud platforms such as those offered byMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) orAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL). column1: Does Alphabet's Self-Driving Car Lawsuit Spell Disaster for Uber?;3/2/2017;"Last week
column2: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)  spinoff Waymo sued Uber for   stealing some of its key autonomous car technology. It doesn't   take a lawyer to know that things don't look good for Uber
column3: but   does this spell disaster for the ride-sharing company's   self-driving dream? Here's what you need to know.The not-so-secret dirty detailsNow that this is in the rearview mirror
column4: it's clear we   should've seen it coming. According to Alphabet
column5: former Waymo   employee Anthony Levandowski illegally downloaded 14
column6: 000 ""highly   confidential and proprietary files""  in December 2015 that   detailed the secret software and hardware designs   for Waymo's LIDAR system. LIDAR systems are being developed   as the ""eyes"" of most companies' attempts at autonomous vehicles
column7: allowing them to ""see"" the world around them via millions of   low-power laser beams blasted out every second. In January   2016
column8: Levandowski started his own self-driving company in   and
column9: two weeks later
column10: resigned without notice from Waymo.   In August 2016
column11: he sold his company to Uber for $680 million.IMAGE SOURCE: ALPHABET (WAYMO)makeArticleAd();Levandowski and Uber might've managed to keep things under the   radar
column12: were it not for a LIDAR component vendor (apparently   inadvertently) copying Waymo on an email to Uber
column13: in which   attached documents bore a ""striking resemblance"" to Waymo's own   LIDAR designs.Alphabet knows a thing or two about computers
column14: and the details   of Levandowski's data dig only served to make the alleged act of   design theft look even more provable. So what does this mean for   Alphabet
column15: Uber
column16: and the future of self-driving car stocks?Blinded by the smite?Lawsuits are a norm
column17: not an anomaly
column18: among major corporations.   Alphabet itself is under constant legal attack: At the moment
column19: it's facing antitrust inquiries in the European Union
column20: Argentina
column21: India
column22: Brazil
column23: Russia
column24: and South Korea
column25: as well as patent   violation and intellectual property claims by the likes ofOracle. As a privately held company
column26: Uber doesn't announce its legal   matters in a single spot
column27: but a quick search turns up hundreds of   suits.On issues of intellectual property
column28: in particular
column29: lawsuits   can get particularly sticky. If proven guilty
column30: Uber will likely   cough up buckets of cash to Alphabet since
column31: in Alphabet's words
column32: Uber has avoided ""incurring the risk
column33: time
column34: and expense of   independently developing their own technology."" By Alphabet's   calculation
column35: that includes the $680 million valuation of OttoandUber's entire self-driving program
column36: since they believe it   would've otherwise stayed stalled.That counterfactual claim is hard to prove
column37: and it may also be   difficult to disentangle Uber's own recent advances in   self-driving technology. It's impossible for Uber staff to forget   what they now know
column38: and almost as impossible for them to even   determine whether what they know is Alphabet's or Uber's.A signal for self-driving car stocksImage source: Getty Images.More so than anything else
column39: this lawsuit serves as a warning   for self-driving car companies and their shareholders. Alphabet
column40: Uber
column41: and others are in a fierce competition to build the best   self-driving car out there
column42: and any attempt to cheat will be met   with the full force of the law.But investors shouldn't equate lawsuits with bankruptcy.   Rather
column43: they should take a ""buyer beware"" stance and ask whether   a given lawsuit is a warning sign of a deeper issue. An   intellectual property lawsuit could be an indicator of an overly   competitive company culture
column44: a short-term issue
column45: or even a lack   of creative talent. Which problem is at the root of the suit   could be a better indicator about the ultimate direction of the   corporate defendant's stock than the specific legal details. So   if you're an investor in autonomous car companies
column46: remember to   look out for lawsuits
column47: read into them the right things
column48: and make   informed choices as you hunt for the biggest potential winners in   this increasingly competitive race.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column49: it can pay to listen. After all
column50: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column51: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column52: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now… and Alphabet (A shares) wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
