column54: an executive at Alphabet
column55: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Justin Loiseauowns shares of Alphabet (A shares) and Alphabet (C shares). The     Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Alphabet (A shares)     and Alphabet (C shares). The Motley Fool owns shares of Oracle.     The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column26: but that is unlikely to last. The company needs something compelling enough to kick off a whole new cycle of iPhone upgrades.That's the Apple AR project. If Tim Cook can convince people that augmented reality is our spectacular future

column1: Snap Admits It Has No Moat;3/1/2017;"A moat is one of the most important things needed for a   company to succeed. The term
column2: coined by Warren Buffett
column3: is a   flowery way of describing a competitive advantage
column4: which will   protect the company's profits and market share (the castle) from   competing businesses.Snap(NYSE: SNAP)
column5: by its own admission
column6: doesn't have a moat.""In a world where anyone can distribute products instantly and   provide them for free
column7: the best way to compete is by innovating   to create the most engaging products. That's because it's   difficult to use distribution or cost as a competitive advantage   -- new software is available to users immediately
column8: and for free
column9: management wrote in the company's S-1 filing.makeArticleAd();In other words
column10: Snap believes the only way to compete in its   market is to out-innovate its competitors likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) and Google
column11: theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary. But what we've already   seen is that simply being innovative isn't enough if a larger   competitor can just copy the innovation.Image source: Snap.Snap's ""innovation"" budget is significantly smaller than   competitors'Snap spent $184 million on research and development (R&D)   last year. That's nothing compared to Alphabet
column12: Facebook
column13: or evenTwitter(NYSE:TWTR) . Keep in mind
column14: Twitter is reducing its R&D   expenditure.Company2016 R&D ExpenseR&D as a Percentage of RevenueSnap$0.18 billion45.4%Alphabet$13.95 billion15.5%Facebook$5.92 billion21.4%Twitter$0.71 billion28.2%Data source: SEC filings and company quarterly reports.To be sure
column15: as a percentage of revenue
column16: Snap reinvested much   more than any of its competitors. But it's unlikely Snap will   continue investing that high of a percentage of revenue into   R&D. It simply can't afford to if it wants to show investors   that it has any potential at all of becoming profitable at some   point.Snap's cost of revenue is its biggest expense
column17: and it alreadycommitted to spending $3 billion on cloud   infrastructure over the next five years.Snap doesn't have the resources to out-innovate its   competition
column18: even if it's significantly more focused than any of   them.Even if it does out-innovate...Snapchat is certainly an innovative app. It's changed the way   people communicate
column19: and it quickly grew very popular. Growth has   slowed in recent months
column20: however
column21: as its competitors --   specifically Facebook -- have attempted to copy some of its core   functionality.Facebook has been trying to copy Snapchat ever since it tried   to buy the company way back in 2013. While several attempts were   unsuccessful
column22: Facebook kept at it until it found a winner. Its   recent success withInstagram Storiesdemonstrates the risk Snapchat explains in its S-1. It must keep   innovating to stay ahead of competitors copying its product.But where Snap claims ""it's difficult to use distribution   [...] as a competitive advantage
column23: Facebook is showing exactly   the opposite. It's developed a huge competitive advantage because   it has a launching pad for new products like Instagram Stories or   Facebook Live. The company went from nearly 0 to 100 million   hours of video views per day in just over a year and a half.To say distribution isn't a competitive advantage ignores a   significant part of the value of Facebook's massive audience.   While not everything it launches succeeds
column24: the odds are stacked   in Facebook's favor. That's evident from the success of Instagram   Stories and other product features Facebook blatantly borrowed   from competitors like Twitter
column25: such as live video and trending   topics.Distribution isn't a competitive advantage for Snap (at least   relative to giants like Facebook and Google)
column26: but that doesn't   mean it's not a competitive advantage for Facebook or Google.   That fact makes Snap's admitted lack of a moat even more of a   risk for investors.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Snap Inc. wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column32: an executive at Alphabet
column33: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Adam Levyhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Alphabet (A shares)

column1: YouTube Tops 1 Billion Hours a Day: Can It Pass TV?;3/1/2017;"YouTube looks to take down television as the most watched format in the U.S.The Wall Street Journalreported users worldwide are watching more than one billion hours of videos a day on the online video platform.The one billion hours is partially the result of the artificial intelligence that is used to recommend videos and keep people tuned in. The number of hours watched has increased 10-fold since 2012
column2: when YouTube started building algorithms that look into user data to give each user a personalized lineup of videos.Currently
column3: TV still holds the title as the most watched platform in the U.S. with 1.25 billion hours people spent watching each day
column4: while TV also beat YouTube and other online streaming services in revenue generated from ads. YouTube may not be far off on the hours but it still has a long way to go on revenue.The content on the website is generated by users all around the world
column5: professional or not. These users are uploading 400 hours of video each minute
column6: or 65 years of video a day to YouTube.YouTube Profits?It is not clear how much money YouTube is generating for Alphabet Inc.GOOGLThe Wall Street Journalreported in 2015 that YouTube generated about $4 billion in 2014 and that division is ""roughly break-even.""The video-sharing website makes most of its revenue by running ads before videos; however
column7: it is not enough when taking the heavy cost of technology and rights to content into account. YouTube struggles to expand its core audience beyond teens and to gain users that visit YouTube.com daily instead of coming from other websites from links or embedded videos. The company relies on popular videos
column8: music videos and content created by the users to gain traffic. YouTube's content tends to attract only a few population groups; as a result
column9: not all companies are willing to pay for ads on YouTube
column10: even when YouTube has one billion hours watched.While YouTube focuses on the content that its users put out
column11: competitors like Amazon.com Inc.AMZNand Netflix Inc.NFLXfocus on licensing Hollywood-produced content and creating original programmingto attract a wide range of audiences.Next StepsHowever
column12: the new deal between Alphabet Inc.and Comcast Corp.CMCSAmight increase the traffic on YouTube. On Monday
column13: YouTube and Comcast announced that Comcast customers with the latest gear would be able to search and watch YouTube videos through their cable boxes.Google also helps YouTube tremendously in gaining new viewers with its enormous reach on the Internet. YouTube videos are embedded in search results and Google pre-installs the YouTube app on its Android software. The website is also starting to secure rights to sports videos and shows for children.On Tuesday
column14: YouTube announced YouTube TV
column15: their service to disrupt traditional cable providers. For $35 per month
column16: users will be able to stream major broadcast networks like CBS
column17: ABC
column18: NBC and FOX. Users will still get YouTube's original programming and sports networks like ESPN.""Millennial love great TV content
column19: but they don't want to watch it in the traditional setting
column20: said Susan Wojcicki
column21: YouTube CEO at YouTube TV's launch event.While YouTube is on pace to surpass TV in hours spent watching in the U.S.
column22: the company also focuses on their algorithms and software in identifying and catering the needs of their audiences. By expanding in this regard and working on their targeting
column23: YouTube can become America's favorite visual platform.Everything You Need to Know About Snapchat BEFORE It Goes PublicmakeArticleAd();You may be curious about the buzz surrounding Snap Inc.'s IPO on March 2. With the company expected to be valued around $22 billion
column24: it is expected to be the largest IPO since 2014. But should you snap up this tech stock on Day 1?In the 2017 IPO Watch List

Each could go public in the coming months.Imagine being in the first wave of investors to jump on a company with almost unlimited growth potential? column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsYesterday
column4: Amazon.com
column5: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) vice president of cloud architecture strategy
column6: Adrian Cockcroft
column7: gave apresentation at a tech conference. Of course
column8: he extolled the virtues of his company's cloud platform
column9: called AWS (Amazon Web Services). Meanwhile
column10: the service was experiencing a major outage.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockGranted
column11: the impact on Amazon stock was fairly minor. Yet
column12: investors should still be concerned. Let's face it
column13: AWS is critical for AMZN stock.Last year
column14: this business segment reported a56% spike in revenues to $12.2 billionand operating income came to $3.1 billion. There are over 1 million active customers. More importantly
column15: Amazon Web Services essentially subsidizes the core ecommerce business - which has razor-thin margins - but also allows for the heavy investments in efforts like video/music streaming
column16: Alexa and devices like the Kindle.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017As for the AWS outage
column17: it lasted roughlyfour hoursand resulted in the disruption of thousands of websites and cloud apps across the US. Some of the high-profile companies that were impacted includedApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column18: Twitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) andTwilio Inc(NYSE:TWLO).At the heart of this was the failure of the S3 system
column19: which provides for the efficient storage of content. The irony is that AMZN could not even access its own dashboard to deal with the problems - since it was also hosted on the AWS platform!The Real Impact?It is important to keep the outage in perspective. For the most part
column20: Amazon Web Services has a great track record
column21: with uptime that is over 99%. As a result
column22: whenever there is a major outage
column23: there is quite a bit of buzz.Besides
column24: AWS is a standout offering. Over the years
column25: AMZN has added great features - such as for data analytics
column26: AI (artificial intelligence) and improved security functions - and has also been diligent with lowering pricing. Yet
column27: this does not mean the outage is trivial. It's reasonable to assume that there are many companies that are evaluating the situation. After all
column28: should there be more usage of alternative systems?Well
column29: I think so. Note that other internet giants are leveraging their own systems to provide cloud services
column30: as seen withAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column31: NASDAQ:GOOG). Google is even the main vendor for the fast-growingSnap Inc(NYSE:SNAP)
column32: which has signed a$2 billion contract.Oh
column33: and many old-line tech operators have been investing heavily in their cloud systems. Just some includeInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM)
column34: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL)
column35: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co(NYSE:HPE) andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT). All these companies have key advantages like trusted brands
column36: global infrastructures and massive customer bases.Interestingly enough
column37: these companies also have something else: They provide hybrid solutions
column38: such as a blend of cloud services and on-premise technologies. This means a customer can place their mission-critical systems on private servers
column39: which would mean no disruption if there was an outage of AWS.Bottom Line for AMZN StockOK then
column40: with the outage of AWS
column41: there should still not necessarily panic. The market opportunity for the cloud is massive - with plenty of room for multiple players. What's more
column42: the financial costs for the outage will probably be immaterial. According to Global Equities' Trip Chowdhry
column43: he thinks that there could be a2% drop in revenues for the first quarter.Procter & Gamble Co (PG) Stock Remains a Good Bet for InvestorsIf there are a couple more outages
column44: however
column45: then the situation could get dicey. When it comes to cloud hosting
column46: there aren't too many second chances.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is the author of various books
column47: includingTaxes 2017: Saving A Bundle.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing

column28: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX)

This move has raised expectations that AAPL will revamp its Apple TV hardware. It also freed up the previous head of Apple TV to helplead Apple's efforts to sign content deals- something he had considerable experience in from his previous role as senior VP of content distribution atHulu.While YouTube TV offers a fixed content bundle

column1: AT&T Inc. (T) Stock’s Relationship with Facebook and Alphabet: Friends
column2: Enemies or Both?;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMajor telecom companies
column4: likeAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T)
column5: have a complicated relationship with tech companies likeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column6: NASDAQ:GOOGL).makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrTelecoms envy Facebook and Alphabet's profits and stock performance. Since January 2009
column7: Alphabet stock is up 460%
column8: while AT&T stock rose only 49%. And telecoms like AT&T particularly resent the fact that internet companies like Alphabet and Facebook gained these profits while piggybacking on the equipment the telecoms spent tens of billions of dollars installing. You wouldn't be able to access websites such as this one or Facebook without the help of a telecom
column9: such as AT&T.On the other hand
column10: when people access Facebook or search Google
column11: they are using data
column12: which means more business for telecoms.But tech companies hurt telecoms when they cannibalize their revenue with apps like Viber and Messenger and WhatsApp. Using WhatsApp is cheaper than sending a text message
column13: and has causedtext message volumeto decline.Storm Clouds on AT&T's HorizonBut that's not all. Alphabet and Facebook now are looking to compete with the core business of telecom providers such as AT&T. Alphabet'sProject Fi
column14: in collaboration withSprint Corp(NYSE:S) andT-Mobile US Inc(NASDAQ:TMUS)
column15: will free users from signing a contract with a single network. This allows users to switch between networks depending on which one has the best signal quality.8 of the Most Overrated Stocks on Wall Street Right NowAnd that's not all. Alphabet has more projects
column16: includingProject LoonandGoogle Fiber
column17: in the works. These also threaten telecoms like AT&T. And Facebook is doing likewise
column18: withFree Basics
column19: Express Wi-Fiand theAquiladrone project.Why are tech companies like Alphabet and Facebook doing this? Why don't they just stick to their core businesses
column20: search and social networks?Well
column21: Alphabet and Facebook derive most of their revenue from advertising. More people receiving access to the internet means more people viewing ads
column22: and more revenue for Alphabet and Facebook's core businesses. If people can't access the internet
column23: they can't bring the two companies revenue.Alphabet and Facebook want to see more people using the internet
column24: and if this means using drones or balloons to bring access to remote regions
column25: so be it. With greater availability of bandwidth
column26: traffic on their websites will go up.So are Facebook and Alphabet threats to T stock? Well
column27: yes
column28: in some ways. But in other ways they may help telecoms like AT&T by pioneering open-source hardware and software-defined networking. They have their own reasons for doing so
column29: and this could help AT&T by lowering the cost of equipment which AT&T uses.Facebook/Alphabet vs. T Stock: FriendsIn an article I wrote inNovember
column30: I discussed Facebook and Alphabet's efforts to develop open-source networking equipment. Currently
column31: companies likeCisco Systems
column32: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) make money by selling proprietary hardware and software to telecoms and internet providers like AT&T.Networking equipment has been described as a""black box
column33: where hardware and software are bundled together by the same vendor. Software from other companies might not run smoothly on one company's hardware. Companies like Cisco can earn high margins on these proprietary products. Routing equipment has not yet beencommoditizedlike other hardware
column34: such as servers.But the development ofsoftware-defined networkingandnetwork functions virtualizationcould change this. These trends involve using open-source software and hardware instead of more expensive proprietary versions. Telecoms like AT&T can then save money by switching to cheaper
column35: interchangeable""white box""switches and routers.Alphabet and Facebook are taking advantage of this
column36: and making their own networking equipment.Facebook developed its ownSDNswitch
column37: theWedge
column38: and open-sourced the Linux-based software to go along with that
column39: FBOSS. It made the design for the Wedgeavailable to the publicthrough the Open Compute Project. Customers can order this from contract manufacturers
column40: which sell it at a low margin
column41: cheaper than Cisco's products. Facebook also released an open-sourcetransponderthrough theTelecom Infrastructure Project
column42: which focuses on networking hardware for telecoms.Facebook hopes that releasing these to the public will speed up innovation
column43: which will in turn benefit Facebook
column44: a major hardware user.Similarly
column45: Alphabet built its own massivesoftware-defined network.How does this benefit AT&T? Well
column46: GOOG and FB are pioneering a technology which promises to lower costs for T stock. Through itsDomain 2.0program
column47: AT&T is taking advantage of software-defined networking and network function virtualization. Last year
column48: AT&T announced its intention tovirtualize 75% of its network by 2020. These technologies allow it to do more with less. They appear to bereducing capexat AT&T
column49: which would boost free cash flow and raise T stock. It also expects SDN and NFV to save it money onoperating costs.Facebook/Alphabet vs. AT&T: EnemiesBut GOOG and FB also may harm T stock by getting into the telecom business.GOOG'sProject Ficonnects users to the network with the best signal at the moment
column50: whether that's Wi-Fi or 4G LTE offered by T-Mobile and Sprint. Normally
column51: mobile phone subscribers must go with one service: AT&T
column52: Verizon Communications Inc(NYSE:VZ)
column53: or others. This could force telecom operators to improve their signal quality in order to compete.Alphabet also offers Google Fiber
column54: a high-speed fiber optics service available in some select cities in the United States. AT&T must feel threatened by this; last year AT&T andComcast Corporation(NASDAQ:CMCSA)sued Nashvilleafter the cityvoted to approveGoogle Fiber.Alphabet is also working on the previously mentioned Project Loon
column55: an effort to deploy telecom equipment in balloons 20km from the earth's surface. Since the equipment in a balloon is higher off the ground than an LTE tower
column56: it can provide a greater area with internet access.Facebook is doing likewise with the Aquila drone
column57: Facebook Express Wi-Fi and Facebook Free Basics. Free Basics brings internet access to200 million peoplein countries like Brazil and the Philippines.Impact on AT&TThe harmful effects of Facebook and Alphabet on AT&T stock may be a bit overstated.Facebook has expressed its intention towork togetherwith telecoms to roll out 5G technology.Nick Foxof Alphabet has stated that Alphabet's intention is not to compete with telecoms and put them out of business. Indeed
column58: Alphabet is cooperating withthree telecomsin Indonesia to test Project Loon.And Alphabet and Facebook may be doing telecoms like AT&T a favor by bearing some of the risk in these ventures. Telecoms are more conservative than Facebook and Alphabet and wouldn't want to bear these risks on their own. Telecoms like AT&T may benefit from the more efficient deployment of telecom equipment via balloons
column59: which cover a wider area than towers.Also
column60: many of these regions the two are targeting are regionswithout much internet access.Facebook and Alphabet wouldn't be threatening AT&T by bringing internet access to regions in Africa
column61: where T stock derives little if any revenue.Could Amazon.com
column62: Inc. (AMZN) Take a Hint From Best Buy Co Inc (BBY)?But some of these undertakings
column63: such as Google Fiber and Project Fi
column64: will probably be a headache for AT&T and holders of T stock.So it seems Facebook and Alphabet could best be described as AT&T's ""frenemies.""As of writing
column65: Lucas Hahn did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 MLPs to Buy With High (And Growing!) Yields7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightThe postAT&T Inc. (T) Stock's Relationship with Facebook and Alphabet: Friends
column66: Enemies or Both?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Potential Stock Market Winners of 2025;3/1/2017;"If you're a long-term investor
column2: you have to think on an   investment time scale that is more than a year or two away. The   greatest investments are the ones that can generate positive   returns for decades into the future. It sounds simple at first
column3: but when you start asking yourself questions like
column4: ""Where is this   company/stock in 2025?"" it becomes much more difficult .So
column5: we asked three of our contributors that very question.   Which companies do you see generating great returns for investors   all the way out to 2025? Here's a quick rundown as to why they   picked retail bankU.S. Bancorp(NYSE: USB)
column6: solar panel manufacturerFirst Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR)
column7: and water utilityAmerican Water Works(NYSE: AWK) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();A bank to buy and holdJordan Wathen(U.S. Bancorp):One of the best-managed banks in the country
column8: U.S. Bancorp   has been left out of the post-election bank stock boom. That's no   fault of its own
column9: though. After provisions for losses
column10: U.S.   Bancorp enjoys a roughly 50-50 split of interest income and fee   income
column11: making its earnings less sensitive to rate increases like   other banks that have seen their share prices surge.I think investors are undervaluing the downside protection   afforded by diversified sources of fee income
column12: and overvaluing   the potential for higher rates to fuel bank profits. In effect
column13: investors are placing too much importance on what makes banks   great over the short term rather than what makes them great over   the long haul.U.S. Bancorp's historical underwriting performance tells the   tale of its conservative culture. At the depths of the financial   crisis
column14: net charge-offs peaked at 2.17% of average loans in 2010.   Though it may seem unremarkable on an absolute basis
column15: consider   that ""retail loans"" made up 33% of its loan book at the time
column16: a   majority of which were clustered in credit cards and home equity   loans that ravaged banks across the country.U.S. Bancorp can play offense
column17: too. Its deposit franchise   gives it pricing power to hold down its cost of deposits
column18: which   recently averaged just 0.28%. On the asset side of the equation
column19: its commercial loan portfolio should generate incremental income   from rate increases.On a recent conference call
column20: a bank executive pointed out that   its commercial customers were using an average of 25% of their   credit lines. One would expect that faster economic growth could   bring higher balances
column21: higher benchmark interest rates
column22: and more   interest income. U.S. Bancorp has everything investors could want   in a bank to hold for years at a time.The sun is still rising on this investment opportunityTyler Crowe(First Solar):The solar industry is a difficult-to-understand
column23: and at times   frustrating
column24: industry to follow. That's because it's both a   high-growthanda cyclical industry at the same time. The problem is
column25: too many   investors simply look at it as the former and neglect to remember   the latter. While overall solar power consumption grows at   near-exponential rates every year
column26: panel manufacturers like First   Solar go through fierce supply-and-demand cycles as new capacity   and new technology come online.This past year is a great example of an industry downturn. The   industry is still growing
column27: but it hit a patch of slower growth   recently that brought down prices for new panels and   utility-scale projects. However
column28: the industry is expected to pick   back up again in earnest as renewable sources such as solar have   moved so far down the cost curve that they are now competitive   with fossil fuel power plants even without subsidies. As   technology improves
column29: costs will continue to decline
column30: and solar   will be able to take a larger market share and expand margins.   Keep in mind
column31: global electricity demand over the next 25 years   will require that we build 8 times the current generation   capacity in the U.S.This gives First Solar an immense growth runway over the next   decade
column32: and it is one of the best-positioned panel manufacturers   and utility-scale power developers out there to reap rewards from   this opportunity. The company has one of the most pristine   balance sheets in the business
column33: its low-cost
column34: thin-film solar   panel design is rapidly improving its efficiency metrics
column35: and it   is one of the only companies in the business whose returns on   invested capital have outpaced its cost of capital -- which is   essential for a company to grow and create wealth over time.The solar industry still very much looks like the wild west of   energy
column36: with new entrants rising and falling quickly
column37: but First   Solar is looking like the company that has the potential to turn   this fast-growing market into one that really generates long-term   returns for investors.As close to a sure-thing
column38: long-term winner as it getsBeth McKenna(American Water Works):I believe American Water Works -- the largest publicly traded   water and wastewater utility in the United States -- is as close   as it gets to a sure-thing 2025 winning stock. Moreover
column39: I   believe it has a good shot at significantly outperforming the   market over the next nearly nine years -- through the end of 2025   -- just as it has done in the nearly-nine years since going   public:Data byYCharts.Since its April 2008 IPO
column40: American Water's total return of   376% has crushed the S&P 500's return of 108% and pulverized   the returns of popular stocksIBMandGeneral Electric. Moreover
column41: it's also beat the 212% return of Google parentAlphabetover this period -- and in April 2008
column42: this tech stock was   less than four years off of its hot IPO. These stats should help   dispel the widespread belief that all utility stocks are stodgy   slow-growers. Moreover
column43: American Water's return leaves underwater   the solid 172% return of its closest peer
column44: Aqua America
column45: while also significantly beating the 158% return of   the largest electric utility on the S&P 500
column46: NextEra Energy.I'm confident American Water's winning streak will continue   over the long term. The company supplies the most essential   product in the world
column47: and it's the largest and most   geographically diverse player in its industry. These latter   attributes provide it with greater resources and opportunities   than its peers to more efficiently expand its regulated business   by acquisitions. The water industry in the U.S. is extremely   fragmented
column48: which means the potential acquisition pool (pun   intended) is a very large one.10 stocks we like better than American Water   WorksWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column49: it can pay to listen. After all
column50: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column51: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column52: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and American Water Works wasn't   one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column53: 2017.Suzanne Frey
column54: an executive at Alphabet
column55: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Beth McKennahas no position in any stocks mentioned.Jordan Wathenhas no position in any stocks mentioned.Tyler Croweowns shares of First Solar and General Electric. The Motley     Fool owns shares of and recommends Alphabet (A and C shares).     The Motley Fool owns shares of General Electric. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Alphabet Explores Streaming Video Space
column2: Launches YouTube TV;3/1/2017;"Rumors regarding the launch ofAlphabet Inc.'sGOOGLown streaming-video service have been doing the rounds for the past few months. The public announcement was finally made yesterday at an event held in Los Angeles.Though the news didn't move the needle much for the stock (closed at 844.93
column3: down 0.6%)
column4: over the last six months
column5: the stock has outperformed the ZacksInternet-Servicesindustry. It returned 6% compared to the industry's gain of 4%.The ServiceKnown as YouTube TV
column6: the subscription-service will offer over 40 channels alongside YouTube videos and YouTube Red original content for $35 a month.Alphabet reached agreements with CBS
column7: ABC
column8: NBC and Twenty-First Century Fox for the purpose of programming for this new service.In addition
column9: there are 35 affiliated cable channels including ESPN
column10: MSNBC
column11: Disney Channel
column12: National Geographic and Fox News.StrengthsThe biggest differentiator seems to be the cloud-based DVR component that allows unlimited storage in the cloud for up to nine months.Not to forget the low price point that includes up to six accounts
column13: each of which comprises a profile
column14: personalized recommendations and a personal library. A member's experience will not get disturbed by the preferences of others.Other facilities include live programming and fast-forwarding on pre-recorded shows to skip ads.LoopholesAlphabet didn't strike deals with cable networks like Discovery
column15: Turner
column16: Viacom
column17: A&E and AMC
column18: which means that subscribers are missing out on History
column19: Comedy Central
column20: HBO
column21: CNN
column22: TNT
column23: TBS
column24: AMC and so on.Though YouTube unveiled plans to expand the service as quickly as possible
column25: viewers from only those places will able to tune in where YouTube offers full live local broadcast feeds. There are no international expansion plans currently.Alphabet Inc. PEG Ratio (TTM)Alphabet Inc. PEG Ratio (TTM)|Alphabet Inc. QuoteThe Big PictureYouTube TV underscores Alphabet's continuous efforts to launch products and services for multiple industries.With the new move

column27: Dish Network'sDISHSling TV and Sony'sSNEPlayStation Vue.The company appears to have its strategy in place. The price of less than $40 a month will certainly place its competitors in a spot of bother.As the company generates significant cash from operations and also holds a huge cash balance
column28: management has the flexibility to pursue growth in any area that exhibits true potential. This flexibility
column29: along with its technological prowess allows it to pursue opportunities in different markets
column30: offsetting the late-mover disadvantage.Alphabet is leaving no stone unturned in the process of growing.Currently Alphabet carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). column1: The Snapchat IPO Will Be a Short-Term Winner
column2: Long-Term Loser;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThis Thursday
column4: theSnap Inc(NYSE:SNAP) IPO is expected to hit the markets. The current price range on the deal is $14 to $16
column5: which means that the company could raise over $3 billion. It seems like a good bet there will be a nice move on the upside
column6: but you will probably not get any shares at offering price.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockRather
column7: you'll have to take your chances in the aftermarket
column8: which can be dicey. So how should you approach SNAP? Ultimately
column9: it depends on your time frame.Let's take a look at some potential strategies:Snapchat IPO: The Long-Term TradeA lot of investors are wondering: Will this be similar to the opening ofFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) orTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR)?After all
column10: the performances are a stark contrast. FB has logged a gain of 254% since its debut while TWTR has lost a grueling 62%.8 of the Most Overrated Stocks on Wall Street Right NowUnfortunately
column11: for the Snapchat IPO
column12: I think there is a better chance that the returns will look more like the latter. Why? Snap Inc looks more like a niche operator. The 18-to-34 year-old category is certainly a valuable niche
column13: as many advertisers have a tough time reaching this demographic
column14: but the market opportunity may prove to be relatively small.According to Pivotal analyst Brian Wieser
column15: the revenues from youth-oriented cable channels like MTV
column16: VH1
column17: Comedy Central and Adult Swim come to roughly$3 billion per year.Besides
column18: if SNAP is unable to break out of its niche
column19: the company will certainly be challenged in keeping up the growth of its user base. Actually
column20: there has already been a deceleration. It went from 21 million net adds in Q2 of last year to only5 million by Q4.But there are some other issues that could be a problem for long-term holders of Snapchat stock:The net losses remain significant
column21: coming to $514.6 million in 2016. This compares to revenues of$404.5 million.The competition continues to get tougher. To this end
column22: FB's Instagram has been essentially matching many of SNAP's core features (and this may help explain the deceleration in the user growth). According to InvestorPlace contributorChris Lau: ""When FB launched Facebook Stories above the news feed
column23: it took away a reason for millennials to leave the site and use SNAP. Similarly
column24: Instagram Stories usage grew to 150 million daily active users in just five months.""There are signs that Spectacles
column25: which are glasses that allow you to take photos and videos
column26: may be losing much of their appeal. According to theWall Street Journal

column28: NASDAQ:GOOGL) for cloud services.Public shareholders will not have the right to vote. This will mean it will be nearly impossible for an activist investor to get any traction if there are problems with SNAP.There is no headquarters
column29: which could make it tough for allowing collaboration.Snapchat IPO: The Short-Term PlayWhile the risk factors mentioned above are downright scary
column30: they probably won't amount to much during the next few months. If anything
column31: the Snapchat IPO is likely to be a great vehicle for traders.One key reason for this is technical: The amount of shares on the market will be fairly small. This means it will not take much buying power to move Snapchat stock.Why Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Will Always Be Much Stronger Than SnapchatInterestingly enough

column36: and of course

column40: yet this is probably not a stock to hold on for too long.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is the author of various books

column1: The Pundits Are Wrong: Snap Is A Buy;2/28/2017;"ByToptal:Originally published onToptalbyValuation Expert Joe Matta.For those who haven't been following the news since Snap (SNAP) announced itsintentions to go public
column2: the press cycle has been on a rollercoaster ride. Initial valuation estimates in the$20-25bn rangewere quickly followed by a few bolder claims that the IPO may fetch the company a valuationas high as $40bn. With this in mind
column3: immediate post-announcement commentary was decisively bearish
column4: and largely centered around the company's disproportionatelyhigh pricecompared to revenues of only $405m in 2016.As time has gone by
column5: more thoughtful analyses have shifted attention over to Snap's growth prospects
column6: and here significant concerns have emerged over the company'sslowing user growth
column7: drawing comparisons to Twitter's (TWTR) lacklusterpost-IPO performance
column8: and thus placing serious questions on the purported valuation figures. As a result
column9: Snap has reportedlylowered its expectations
column10: and certain estimates expect pricing to come as low as $14-$16 per share
column11: implying a valuation of$16-19bn.makeArticleAd();Ahead of its expected pricing (anticipated onMarch 1st) we take a look at whether the rumored valuation makes sense
column12: and provide our own guidance on where investors should be pricing the stock.We find that while overall market concerns regarding DAU growth are justified
column13: the market is likely undervaluing the company's ARPU growth prospects and conclude that there is significant upside on the table for investors. For us
column14: Snap is a buy.Growth is the answerAs mentioned
column15: initial reports largely focused on comparing Snap's purported valuation to its revenues
column16: which when compared to its peers
column17: admittedly looks very expensive (table 1).But such an analysis misses the mark completely in two important ways. Firstly
column18: many of the companies in Snap's peer universe are not directly comparable (Google (GOOG) (GOOGL) is a search company and Amazon (AMZN) is an online retailer
column19: to name a few). Limiting the peer universe to Snap's most directly comparable peers
column20: Facebook (FB) and Twitter
column21: is a more appropriate juxtaposition (charts 1 and 2).But even when just limiting one's comparison to Facebook and Twitter
column22: the maturity profiles of the respective companies are very different and must be accounted for. A fairer analysis would look at the metrics pre-IPO for all three (charts 3 and 4). In doing so
column23: readers will notice that the relative valuation
column24: albeit still expensive
column25: looks less so than in the prior charts.There are still timing issues with such a comparison though. For reference
column26: Facebook was eight years old and Twitter was sevenat the time of their IPOs. Snap is only five
column27: and with 2-3 more years of growth under its belt
column28: Snap could be a very different company.Moreover
column29: Snap is a direct-to-mobile platform while Facebook and Twitter went public in a world in which desktop-delivery still played a dominant role. Considering the shift from desktop to mobile
column30: Snap is entering a market with a growing user base (mobile taking share from desktop) on a delivery platform that is capturing increasing user engagement (charts 5 and 6).In summary
column31: the different maturity profiles coupled with the different delivery platforms
column32: both now as well as at IPO
column33: make for a troublesome comparables-based approach when assessing Snap's valuation. Snap may look expensive when compared to its peers
column34: but comparing to its peers is not the right approach.With the above in mind
column35: a Snap-only analysis makes most sense. And such an analysis should almost solely be focused on one thing: growth. For any company at Snap's stage
column36: growth is paramount to valuation
column37: and to this end
column38: there are fundamentally two things that affect growth going forward:1) Growth in Daily Active Users (DAUs)
column39: and2) Growth in Average Revenue Per User (ARPU)We look at these in turn.DAU Growth: Doubts LoomMuch of the more insightful analysis which emerged a few weeks after the filing has in fact focused on DAU growth. And the hawks are out in flock. Unfortunately for Snap
column40: while initial user growth performance was impressive (chart 7)
column41: there has been a significant downtick in new users joining the platform in recent months. Despite outperforming both Facebook and Twitter in terms of user growth in the six quarters leading up to its IPO
column42: Snap saw quarterly growth rates drop from double digit figures to only 7% in Q3 16 and
column43: even more worryingly
column44: to a paltry 3.3% in Q4 16 (chart 8).Management's justification for the following can be found in their S1
column45: wherethey state:""The rate of net additional Daily Active Users was relatively   flat in the early part of the quarter ended December 31
column47: and accelerated in the month of December. Although we have   historically experienced lumpiness in the growth of our Daily   Active Users
column48: we believe that the flat growth in the early part   of the quarter was primarily related to accelerated growth in   user engagement earlier in the year
column49: diminished product   performance
column50: and increased competition.The rate of net additional Daily Active Users accelerated in   the first half of 2016 compared to the second half of 2015
column51: largely due to increased user engagement from product launches   and increased adoption rates among older demographics and   international markets. This created a higher baseline of Daily   Active Users heading into the third and fourth quarters
column52: so   incremental net additions within these quarters were more   difficult even with strong year-over-year growth. Additionally
column53: in mid-2016
column54: we launched several products and released multiple   updates
column55: which introduced a number of technical issues that   diminished the performance of our application. We believe these   performance issues resulted in a reduction in the growth of our   Daily Active Users
column56: particularly among Android users and regions   with a higher percentage of Android devices. Finally
column57: we also saw   increased competition both domestically and internationally in   2016
column58: as many of our competitors launched products with similar   functionality to ours.""The above explanation thus emphasizes two key potential causes for the slowdown in growth: technical issues with their Android product
column59: and/or increasing competition.The former
column60: while problematic
column61: would not be a significant cause for concern. One would think that a company funded to the tune of $2.6bn and withnearly 2
column62: 000 employees(many of them in engineering) would be able to solve this and revert the company's growth course back to what it was at the beginning of 2016.But the more worrying concern revolves around competition. Snap faces increasing pressure from competitors
column63: particularly Facebook and Instagram
column64: which
column65: if unresolved
column66: could continue to limit DAU growth going forward. In fact
column67: it is no wonder that Snapchat's growth numbers began suffering in Q3 16 as this was exactly when Instagramlaunched Stories
column68: a near-blatant copy of Snapchat's namesake.Unfortunately for Snap
column69: data regarding growth in DAU by geography only lends further weight to the competition concerns. In fact
column70: on a geographical basis
column71: much of the slowdown in Snap's DAUs appears to have been primarily in the ""Rest of World"" region (chart 9). Given Instagram's significantly larger user base abroad (80% of Instagram's c.300m DAUs are international)
column72: one could see how the incentives for installing Snapchat diminishes as Instagram (and other competitors) begin to offer the key features that Snapchat has to-date sold itself on.To summarize
column73: things don't look good for Snapchat from a DAU growth perspective. Not only was Q4 16 Snap's lowest growing quarter since the beginning of its publicly available data
column74: but it was even slower than that of Facebook
column75: a far more mature company (chart 10). Given these headwinds
column76: Snap will have to effectively convince investors that it can address its decelerating quarter-over-quarter DAU growth if it wishes to hit the valuation numbers that have been publicized.Looking Ahead: Facebook Growth or Twitter Struggles?With the above in mind
column77: our expectation is that Snap
column78: going forward
column79: will experience a user growth profile more akin to Twitter's than to Facebook's.While growth will be sustained by its continued popularity in the United States
column80: competition from Facebook
column81: Instagram andother international competitorswill continue to limit Snap's growth internationally.Our base case expectation is therefore for an average of 14.1% growth per year post-IPO
column82: almost right in between Facebook's and Twitter's annual average growth rates of 19.1% and 10.3%
column83: respectively (table 2). The primary source of the growth premium to Twitter derives from Snapchat's ability to innovate on product features better than Twitter (more on this below).ARPU Growth: Solid Start with Ample Upside RemainingWhilst the above DAU estimates are nothing for investors to get excited about
column84: and fall largely in line with most market commentary
column85: stopping one's analysis at DAU performance is shortsighted. In particular
column86: it misses the key other side of the coin: ARPU. And when it comes to ARPU growth
column87: we see a radically different story. Our view is that Snapchat will see strong ARPU growth going forward
column88: driven by the following factors:A more monetization-friendly productA more advantageous position with a key user demographicA generally more monetization-focused management mindsetAll of these will in turn be boosted by general underlying strength in the mobile advertising space. We look at these in turn.Snapchat is a very monetization-friendly productOne of the most attractive features of Snapchat from an ARPU standpoint is that the product itself appears to lend itself very well
column90: to monetization. The effectiveness of the platform is largely driven by Snap's ability to innovate on product features and stay ahead of the competition
column91: and this has allowed Snap to build impressively strong positions in image sharing and in video.Looking first at image sharing
column92: Snap has caught up rapidly with its competitors (chart 11) largely thanks to its ability to innovate with the format (initially with disappearing messages
column95: etc.). The implication of this is significant in that it has allowed Snap to lead the industry in terms of developing and delivering sponsored / branded content for this type of format. For instance
column97: Snap's ability to reach a large audience far exceeds Facebook despite its significantly smaller user base (chart 12).The growth in image sharing and the innovation surrounding its product features has positioned Snap favorably amongst advertisers
column98: allowing Snap to strike important partnerships with verysignificant brandsworldwide. One of the examples of such campaigns that Snap highlightsin its S1relates to how Wendy's blanketed its U.S. stores with Sponsored Geofilters that promoted the Jalapeño Fresco Chicken Sandwich. Snap's measurement tool reported that the Sponsored Geofilter drove over 42
column99: 000 incremental people to a Wendy's location within seven days of viewing the Sponsored Geofilter.Perhaps more important than image sharing
column100: Snap has developed a dominant position in video
column101: converting it into aserious threat to Facebook. According to theKCPB presentation
column102: as of Q1 16 Snap has surpassed Facebook in terms of daily video views despite its significantly smaller user base (chart 13).This success to date has been driven by Snap's unique approach to the video format. KCPB refers to Snaps approach as ""3V Advertising"": (1) Vertical - made for mobile viewing
column103: (2) Video - a great way to tell a story
column104: (3) Viewing - always full screen.The combination of these three has made video advertising that much more effective on Snapchat. In fact
column106: outside of Snapchat many video ads are ineffective with 81% of people muting the ads. However
column107: Snap points out in its S-1 that on average
column108: 60% of all Snap Ads are watched with the sound on.The above again points to Snap's effectiveness as a monetization platform as well as the management team's ability to keep innovating on product and stay ahead of the curve when it comes to marrying fun and engaging product features with monetization avenues. Arecent exampleof success with video would beGatorade's sponsored lens during the Super Bowl
column109: a campaign which led to 60 million plays in total
column110: 165 million views and an increase of 8 points in purchase intent.Snap has developed the ultimate trifecta - a robust advertising platform that combines communications (chatting)
column112: and video content. This has lead to numerous marketing campaigns achieving above average industry impact
column113: performance and ROI. This should support rapid growth of ARPU as more marketers recognize these benefits and decide to move advertising dollars over to Snap.Snap is very strong with a key user demographicAs the pool of mobile advertising investment dollars rises
column114: more advertisers are looking to target Millennials and younger demographics. In 2015
column115: Marketers dedicatedover a third (34%) of their annual marketing budgetsto targeting these groups. That figure was likely even greater with teens and ""tweens"" included.The above phenomenon is largely because Millennials are expected to drive consumer spending in the years to come. Millennials are80 million strong
column116: the largest demographic in the United States
column118: also the largest demographic in the workforce.This of course translates into huge spending power. Estimates indicate Millennials could be spending$1.4 trillion annually by 2020and could inherit as much as $30 billion in the coming years. Even teens and tweens are generating significant spending power
column119: spending as much as Baby Boomersin 2015.The issue advertisers face is that Millennials are moving away from traditional advertising channels to their phones (chart 14). Companies like Snap
column121: provide an optimal channel through which to target these groups.Fortunately for Snap
column122: they seem to have developed a very strong position in these age-groups. With 63% of Snap users in the 18-34 age category
column124: Snap has captured the attention of a highly coveted marketing demographic (chart 15 - note: chart is from a 2016 comScore report
column125: as such the data does not perfectly tie with Snap's latest demographics reported in its S-1).More importantly
column126: Snap has become a leading platform in terms of its engagement within 18-34 age demographic (chart 16). Facebook is clearly a dominant player with massive reach and significant engagement
column127: but Snapchat is the second leading platform in terms of average monthly minutes per visitor. As Snap continues to expand its reach and further penetrate this key age group
column128: Snap should move higher and further to the right on this chart as it continues to threaten Facebook's leadership.This all bodes very well for Snap. The company has continued to rapidly expand its reach within the 18-24 category while also broadening its penetration within older age groups. As of December 2015
column130: more than three-out-of-five 18-24 year olds now actively use Snapchat
column131: with older age groups also on the rise (chart 17).With a dominance in the Millennial
column133: the second leading platform in terms of monthly engagement and further expansion of its reach within each of those key demographics Snap should receive an outsized portion of advertising dollars going forward. This should support rapid ARPU expansion in the coming years.Snap management is more monetization focusedPutting the above two tactical points aside
column134: the most encouraging thing about Snap is that management has consistently shown a greater predisposition and knack for converting fun new product features into monetization avenues. In short: Snap management appears to be excellent at monetization.And the results bear this out. When comparing to Facebook and Twitter
column136: and has grown faster in terms of ARPU than both of its comparables
column137: despite being several years ""younger"" as a company (charts 18 and 19).Admittedly
column138: claiming that Snap is simply better at monetizing than its comps is a subjective and difficult-to-prove assertion. However
column140: then what makes this an even more interesting point is when you consider how much upside could still be left for Snap to capture. To this end
column141: a simple side-by-side comparison of ARPU numbers with Facebook and Twitter suggests that Snap's ARPU could rise as much as 7x what it is today (chart 20).For us
column142: Snap's impressive historical performance in ARPU driven by its clear ability to innovate in product and monetization
column143: combined with the tremendous upside still there for the taking
column144: points to strong and rapid catch-up in terms of ARPU in the years to come. It is therefore not surprising to us that after havingfailed to acquireSnapchat
column145: Facebook has now reverted toreplicating its features consistently.Overall Industry Growth will keep supporting Snap ARPU GrowthAside from the intrinsic strengths of Snap as a company
column146: it's also obvious that overall underlying industry strength will help sustain ARPU growth in the coming years (although the extent to which this will be remains a question).According to areport from IDC
column147: ad spending is expected to grow from $652 billion in 2016 to $767 billion in 2020 with mobile specific spending growing 3x from $66 billion in 2016 to $196 billion in 2020. Social media marketing in particular is expected to grow 20% per year to $50.2bn in 2019
column150: there is a $22bn market opportunity in mobile advertising as it is the only growing outlet in terms of percent of consumption time. This should continue to encourage marketers to shift away from more legacy outlets like TV and print and into mobile (chart 21). Given that Snap's entire advertising inventory is on mobile
column151: a growing pool of total mobile advertising dollars will certainly benefit Snap going forward.Rabbit from a hat: Ancillary product launches may add further upside to ARPUFor further revenue upside one can't overlook Snap's potential to develop ancillary products.Snap has already demonstrated a willingness to explore new product categories with the launch of Spectacles in September 2016
column152: its first ever hardware product. New product developments outside of software could potentially provide Snap with a very interesting monetization model that is different from their competitors (FB is exploring VR) and a unique way of owning more of the user's share of mind.Spectacles are wearable glasses with a built-in camera that links seamlessly to a smartphone to create unique Snaps from a ""human perspective."" The company views Spectacles as an extension of Snapchat and intends to use the glasses to create a unique circular format for video as opposed to the standard rectangular viewing perspective (once again reinventing the standard video delivery model).Spectacles do generate revenue for Snap
column153: but for 2016 the revenues were not material and
column155: not reported in the company's filing. Going forward
column156: Spectacles could represent a much larger portion of Snap's revenue.It's unclear what other types of new products Snap is planning to bring to market
column157: but Snap has demonstrated a strong ability to create innovative and sticky products that drive incremental user growth and revenue (chart 22). Expect each new product introduction to be strategic in driving user growth
column160: all things that should bring create even greater revenue opportunities for Snap.ARPU Growth Going Forward: A Monetization MachineLooking ahead and given all of the above
column161: our expectation is that despite slowing user growth
column162: Snap's platform should support very strong ARPU growth going forward. We see Snap's ARPU catching up with Facebook's in the next five years
column163: and it would not surprise us if it surpasses it further out. In other words
column165: Snap is likely to experience more of a Facebook-like
column167: ARPU growth profile.The biggest risk to this scenario playing out mainly relates to Facebook and other competitors' ability to replicate Snap's features both quickly and effectively. Should this be the case
column168: Snap's leadership in product innovation will likely fail to spill over into significant ARPU growth. However
column169: should competitors struggle to play the ""catch-up game"" well enough
column170: Snap will likely see ARPU growth rates in line with what we predict below. The latter has been interestingly described as the ""Gingerbread strategy"" inthis article.With that in mind we anticipate two possible ARPU growth trajectories. Our downside case projections are more in line with other commentaries and essentially consider the latter scenario of product innovation followed by effective catch-up by competitors. The base case is instead predicated on management's ability to keep innovating on product
column171: and competitors' relative ineffectiveness at copying such features.The numbers of both cases are displayed in table 3 below
column172: but the highlight is that in our base case projections
column173: we anticipate north of 50% CAGR over the next five years
column174: with ARPU catching up to Facebook's 2016 numbers by 2019/2020.Putting This All Together: What is Snap worth?With all of the above in mind
column175: we can now proceed to calculating our estimated valuation for Snap. We first look at what Snap's revenues will look like going forward
column176: based on our DAU and ARPU assumptions outlined above
column177: and then move into a valuation analysis using these revenue estimates.Financial ForecastsOur financial forecasts are summarized in Table 4
column178: but the headline numbers we want to highlight are the following:DAU growth in between Twitter and Facebook's post-IPO   performance
column179: reaching 246 million DAUs by 2019Strong ARPU catch-up and growth
column181: nearly equaling Facebook's current 2016 ARPU numbers
column182: in   the Base CaseMore limited ARPU growth in the Downside Case
column184: in line with Twitter's current ARPU numbersTotal Revenues of $1.6 billion and $3.8 billion achieved in   2017 and 2018
column186: in the Base CaseTotal Revenues of $1.3 billion and $2.7billion achieved in   2017 and 2018
column188: in the Downside CaseValuationWe value Snap on an EV / Revenue basis using a target multiple range of 6.0x to 10.0x derived from the midpoint of the range between Facebook and Twitter current trading multiples. On the one hand
column189: Snap's more limited DAU growth warrants a lower multiple than Facebook's
column190: but on the other hand its more favourable ARPU prospects warrant a premium to Twitter's multiple. We apply these multiple to forward 2018 revenue estimates to account for Snap being a younger company than both of its comps. Our valuation estimates are summarised in Table 5 below
column191: but the key takeaways are as follows:Despite limited DAU growth
column192: our base case ARPU assumptions   imply a valuation of c. $30bn based off a 8.0x multiple on 2018   forward revenue estimatesIn our bearish case
column193: we come out at $22bn on 2018 forward   revenue estimates
column194: in line but still slightly above more recent   price targets.Overall
column195: we see strong upside potential for Snap going   forward
column196: with the valuation potentially rising to nearly $50bn   assuming greater maturity of their comps justifies using Snap's   2019 forward revenue estimates for the valuation
column197: concluding that   this stock is a buy.Snap: Twitter growth
column199: one could say that the Snap IPO heralds a more general shift in social media platforms from building for user growth to building for user engagement and monetization. Since inception
column200: Snap has always felt more like a blend between a traditional social media app and a gaming app. The more playful nature of the platform has in turn translated positively into monetization and ARPU growth
column201: far more so than Snap's peers did at their equivalent stages of their lifecycle. Whether a purposeful management strategy or not
column202: Snap seems better built for monetization.This of course is occurring concurrently with an increasing shift in advertising spend from traditional media outlets to online/digital and particular mobile channels. In many ways
column203: it feels like advertisers are reaching the tipping point of shifting a majority of their dollars to social media and ""new media"" channels.As a result
column204: we view Snap's future financial prospects very favorably
column206: conclude that Snap is a buy. Snap's value is a function of being the first social media platform that has been built with advertisers in mind from the beginning.This opinion article is for informational purposes only
column207: and   does not constitute investment advice. The information in the   document should not be construed as any current or past   endorsement
column208: recommendation or sponsorship of any company or   security by the author or Toptal LLC.See alsoNexstar Media Group (NXST) Q4 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcripton seekingalpha.com"

column1: Why Was This Analyst So Wrong About Twitter Inc?;2/28/2017;"Sometimes going against the grain with a contrarian view pays   off for Wall Street analysts. Other times
column2: it blows up in their   faces and hurts investors who took their advice. The latter   recently happened to BTIG Research analyst Richard Greenfield
column3: who boldly upgradedTwitter(NYSE:TWTR) from  Neutral to Buy with a price target of $25 -- right   before the social network's dismal fourth quarter earningssank the stock.All analysts and investors eventually make bad calls
column4: but   Greenfield's upgrade raised eyebrows
column5: since it clearly went   against the popular view that Twitter was stuck in a terminal   decline. Let's take a look at why Greenfield believed that   Twitter could make a comeback
column6: and why those bullish ideas might   be misguided.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Why did BTIG believe in Twitter?Greenfield believed that several catalysts would help Twitter   recover. First
column7: he saw a ""meaningful uptick"" in downloads of the   iOS app
column8: which he attributed to the U.S. election and President   Trump's widely covered use of the platform. Second
column9: he noted that   a recent CivicScience survey showed an increase in the app's   daily active users (DAUs). Greenfield cited those two factors as   evidence of higher user engagement.As user growth and engagement rebound
column10: Greenfield believes   that advertisers and potential suitors could return. The analyst   doesn't ""expect immediate financial benefits"" in the first half   of the year
column11: but believes that Twitter's ""second half 2017   revenues could exceed investors' expectations with 2018 well   above consensus.""Why were those ideas misguided?Greenfield's claim that iOS downloads were rising is true.   According to App Annie
column12: Twitter's iOS rank in the U.S. surged   from  33th to 8th place between Feb. 29
column13: 2016 and Jan. 20
column14: 2017. Unfortunately
column15: that growth quickly reversed after Trump's   inauguration
column16: and the app slipped back to 26th place at the end   of February.Greenfield's claim that DAUs are rising was also confirmed in   Twitter's earnings report
column17: which revealed that its DAUs rose 11%   annually during the quarter -- an acceleration from 7% growth in   the third quarter
column18: 5% growth in the second quarter
column19: and 3% growth   in the first quarter. However
column20: Twitter left out one crucial   number -- the actual number of DAUs.That figure matters because Twitter's monthly active users   (MAUs) only rose 4% annually to 319 million during the quarter.   If Twitter's DAU growth is outpacing its MAU growth
column21: it means a   small group of power users are tweeting more frequently
column22: but the   platform still isn't reeling in casual users. Twitter also hasn't   made it easy for casual users to get started
column23: since it still   hasn't adequately addressedcommon complaintslike its 140-character limit
column24: non-threaded replies
column25: and the   proliferation of fake and spam accounts -- all of which make   user-to-user interactions difficult.Why advertisers and potential buyers aren't coming     backSome of the company's decisions over the last few years have   set it up for an uphill battle in winning back advertisers and   potential acquirers.First
column26: former CEO Dick Costolo pivoted Twitter toward a ""cost   per engagement"" model which let advertisers pay for only the   interactions (tweets
column27: likes
column28: retweets) that they wanted.At the time
column29: Costolo believed that move would help it reach   smaller businesses with limited advertising budgets. Instead
column30: the   move backfired and  allowed large customers to pay less   money for fewer clicks. Twitter still hasn't recovered from that   move -- that's probably why its core advertising revenues fell   0.5% annually last quarter.As for a buyout
column31: CEO Jack Dorsey and previous suitors seem to   have abandoned the idea. In January
column32: Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Googleagreed to buymost of Twitter's developer products for an undisclosed sum. That   sale indicates that Twitter could sell off non-core businesses to   generate fresh cash -- which might be attractive to companies   like Google
column33: which value Twitter's tech but don't want its   stalled out user base
column34: sluggish advertising business
column35: and   controversies regarding bullying
column36: trolling
column37: and illegal accounts.   Dorsey'srecent purchaseof $7 million in shares also indicates that the co-founder   believes in  Twitter's long-term future -- which might mean   that a buyout is off the table.Beating estimates in 2017 and 2018 might not     matterLastly
column38: Greenfield's suggestion that Twitter could beat   expectations in 2017 and 2018 isn't as bullish as it sounds.   Analysts expect Twitter's revenue to fall 6.4% this year and    rebound 7.5% next year -- indicating that Twitter's 2018   revenue will remain nearly flat from 2016 levels. Beating those   estimates won't put Twitter back on the track to higher   growth.Greenfield might believe that time will eventually prove his   thesis right. However
column39: Twitter's slumping sales growth
column40: the   sluggish evolution of its platform
column41: and a CEO that splits his   time between two companies all indicate that things could get   much worse before they get better.10 stocks we like better than TwitterWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column42: it can pay to listen. After all
column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column44: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column45: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Twitter wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column47: an executive at Alphabet
column48: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Leo Sunhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Alphabet (A shares)
column49: Alphabet (C     shares)
column50: and Twitter. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Better Buy: Facebook Inc vs. Netflix
column2: Inc.;2/28/2017;"These two are in rare company. How many other organizations   have ruled the age of the internet quite likeFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) orNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) ? We spend countless hours on each site keeping up   with friends and binge-watching our favorite shows.In fact
column3: with the addition ofAlphabetandAmazon
column4: I think we'd be hard-pressed to find more influential companies   in today's society. That fact has not been lost on   investors. Over the past four years
column5: both stocks have quintupled   in value.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();But which is a better buy today? That's a difficult question   to answer
column6: though we can get a better understanding for what   we're buying by looking at the question through three different   lenses.Sustainable competitive advantagesIf I had one word of advice for beginning investors
column7: it would   be this: Spend the bulk of your time investigating a company's   sustainable competitive advantages. Often referred to as a ""moat""   by investors
column8: sustainable competitive advantages are what keep   customers coming back for more every year and consistently keep   the competition at bay.Netflix benefits from
column9: as I see it
column10: three different types of   moats. The first is the brand. The Qwikster fiasco not   withstanding
column11: the company has won over legions of loyal customers   who appreciate the service and its original content. That   original content is key
column12: as it is gets people hooked into the   Netflix ecosystem.Management is able to target its original content because it   has more data on our viewing habits than any other organization   in the history of the world. That also gives the company the   upper hand when it comes to paying for content from third-party   providers. Imagine the negotiating table: Netflix knows just how   popular certain shows are to its viewers and how valuable it is.   The other side has no idea. That asymmetry provides pricing   power.Image source: Getty Images.Finally
column13: Netflix benefits from a sneaky type of moat I onlyrecentlycame to appreciate. Once customers sign on
column14: the cost of the   monthly plan is so low -- and the payments fully automated --   that a user would have to be highly motivated tocancelhis/her membership.Facebook
column15: on the other hand
column16: benefits from one of the most   powerful moats in the world: the network effect. With each   additional member who joins Facebook
column17: non-members are   incentivized to join as a way of keeping up with their friends   and family. It's a virtuous cycle that is in full effect. Even   though the company already has over 1billiondaily active users
column18: its roster continues to grow -- up 18% year   over year.Not only that but Facebook gets essentially all of its content   for free. That's often underappreciated by investors. Imagine   what a boon it would be if Netflix never had to pay for its   shows.At the end of the day
column19: both of these companies have powerful   moats. In years past
column20: I would have given the nod to Facebook. But   my realization of how easy it is for Netflix to keep subscribers   -- and how effective original content is at bringing in new users   -- is enough to call this a draw.Winner = TieFinancial fortitudeWhile conservative investors love seeing cash returned to them   via dividends and more aggressive investors love seeing cash   reinvested in a company's growth prospects
column21: there's something to   be said for cash.Every company will experience difficult financial times
column22: and   the companies that enter those phases with lots of cash will   prosper. They will have the flexibility to outspend rivals and   gain market share
column23: repurchase stock on the cheap
column24: and even make   strategic acquisitions. Debt-laden companies will be in the   opposite boat
column25: forced to satisfy the whims of their   creditors.CompanyCashDebtNet IncomeFree Cash FlowNetflix$1.7 billion$3.4 billion$0.2 billion($1.6 billion)Facebook$30 billion$0$10.2 billion$11.6 billionData source: Yahoo! Finance. Cash includes cash
column26: short
column27: and   long-term investments.Here
column28: we have a very clear winner. Netflix is spending lots of   cash on its international expansion and original programing.   That's a great strategy because
column29: as mentioned above
column30: once   customers are locked in
column31: they're a reliable source of recurring   revenue.But with that strategy comes financial fragility. Netflix is   free cash flow negative
column32: while Facebook is a cash machine with no   long-term debt whatsoever.Winner = FacebookValuationFinally
column33: we have valuation. While this isn't an exact science
column34: there are some straightforward metrics we can consult to give us   an idea of how expensive each stock is.CompanyP/EP/FCFPEG RatioNetflix340N/A1.6Facebook32341.1Data source: SEC filings
column35: E*Trade. P/E represents figures from   non-GAAP earnings.Here again
column36: we have a clear winner. Because of the   aforementioned spending
column37: Netflix isveryexpensive based on traditional metrics.Facebook
column38: on the other hand
column39: looks like a pretty good deal at   today's prices. While a P/E of 32 would never be described as   ""cheap
column40: the company increased earnings by 86% last year
column41: and is   expected to grow by 28% moving forward.Winner = FacebookThe winner is...So there you have it: While both companies have powerful   moats
column42: Facebook has a better balance sheet and appears to be a   better value at today's prices. You really can't go wrong by   investing in either
column43: but I'm a much stronger fan of Facebook at   today's levels. That helps explain why it accounts for 14% of my   real-life holdings
column44: while Netflix clocks in at just 2%.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
