column1: Facebook Inc's Chatbots Hit a 70% Failure Rate;2/28/2017;"Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) is reportedly scaling back its chatbot efforts on   Messenger after the programs failed to fulfill 70% of users'   requests.The Informationreports that those requests couldn't be handled without human   agents
column2: and bots built by outside developers ""had issues"" because   the ""technology to understand human requests wasn't developed   enough.""So instead of building a large ecosystem of chatbots
column3: Facebook   will train Messenger bots to handle ""a narrower set of cases
column4: so   users aren't disappointed by the limitations of automation.""   Let's see what this strategic shift means for Facebook's AI   efforts
column5: and whether or not chatbots will ever become meaningful   tools for the social network.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Understanding Facebook's AI strategyArtificial intelligence plays a vital role in helping Facebook   track users and deliver targeted ads. By using AI to scan a   user's status updates
column6: photos
column7: videos
column8: check-ins
column9: likes
column10: linked   apps
column11: and other data
column12: Facebook generates digital profiles of   users which help it deliver targeted ads to their News Feeds. In   2013
column13: Facebook launched the FAIR (Facebook Artificial   Intelligence Research) unit to continuously upgrade those AI   capabilities.That's where Messenger comes in. In 2014
column14: Facebook forced   users to download the stand-alone Messenger app to keep chatting.   That move -- whichclearly mirroredTencent's(NASDAQOTH: TCEHY) WeChat -- laid the foundations for Messenger   to become a ""platform"" which could eventually offer ride hailing
column15: mobile payments
column16: deliveries
column17: games and other services from a   single app.Facebook's Messenger app. Image source: Google Play.That move would give Facebook an ""OS within an OS"" to counter   the iOS App Store andAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google Play. Facebook's next   step would be toreplaceapps with Messenger chatbots
column18: which were introduced last April.   If that effort works
column19: it could turn the entire mobile app store   model upside down.The premature rise of the chatbotsIn theory
column20: a business chatbot could answer questions
column21: make   purchase suggestions
column22: process orders
column23: and send shipping updates   to customers. For customers
column24: having ""conversations"" with these   bots would feel more natural than scrolling and clicking through   a mobile app. Companies could  also cut costs by reducing   the number of human customer service representatives.Facebook tethers those bots to Messenger for Business
column25: which   provides a live customer service chat channel for a large number   of businesses. Businesses can choose to put a human or a chatbot   to handle queries on their end. This idea attracted a lot of   early adopters -- 30
column26: 000 Facebook bots were already active on   Messenger as of last September.But just as Google struggled with low-quality apps over the   years
column27: Facebook's ecosystem quickly became bogged down with   poorly produced chatbots. Badly made bots could annoy customers   and tarnish a company's image -- so the company decided it's a   better idea to send the bots back to the drawing board than   expand the overall ecosystem.Facebook should've seen this comingThe limitations of AI-powered bots were already clear when   Facebook launched its chatbot APIs last year. For example
column28: Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) launched its chatbot Tay onTwitteras an experimentlast March. Within 24 hours
column29: Tay started tweeting racist and   sexist comments
column30: forcing Microsoft to abruptly pull the plug and   issue an  apology. Tencent has also struggled to  purge   spam and scam bots on WeChat since it started letting millions of   accounts create their own bots.Facebook's AI tech also wasn't that impressive prior to the   arrival of its chatbots. Its News Feed struggled to discern fake   news headlines from real ones
column31: and its Messenger-based virtual   assistant M hasn't gained much  ground against Google Now or   Siri.Edison Investment analyst Richard Windsor -- who    recently called Facebook a ""laggard in AI"" compared to   Google -- stated that ""when Facebook tries to automate its   systems
column32: things always go wrong."" He also pointed out that while   Facebook has hired plenty of AI talent
column33: it simply hasn't been   working on AI ""for nearly long enough"" to challenge market   leaders like Google.So what's next for Facebook's AI efforts?Despite those missteps
column34: Facebook probably won't stop investing   in chatbots anytime soon. The company is expected to introduce   new AI plans at its F8 conference in April
column35: which will likely   include ways to boost the quality
column36: not quantity
column37: of its Messenger   bots. It could also introduce more ways to tether bots into other   Messenger features -- like payments and games -- to increase the   app's appeal as a stand-alone platform.10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Alphabet Suing Uber Over Self-Driving Car Technology;2/28/2017;"Uber badly needed self-driving car technology because it was in danger of getting pushed out of the market if many cheaper ride-hailing services using self-driving technology (no human driver) were to enter the market. So it assumed a not-so-honest way of getting it. That's what AlphabetGOOGLis claiming after discovering the theft of its technology by a former Googler.The Technology in QuestionGoogle has for long held that its technology
column2: which includes hardware and software components
column3: is superior to others. The company
column4: which originally used LiDAR based systems from Velodyne
column5: later developed a number of such systems for close-range
column6: mid-range and long-range ""vision"" of self-driving cars. These systems generate millions of laser images per second that offer a much clearer picture of the area surrounding the car and helps it take more accurate decisions.Additionally
column7: the company recently announced that it had devised a more economical system that would take its cost from $75
column9: to $7
column11: thus making it commercially viable.The AccusedAnthony Levandowskihas been accused of downloading 14
column12: 000 highly confidential files (9.7GB of data)
column13: including Waymo's LiDAR circuit board designs to an external disk drive using specialized software. He then downloaded a new OS to his company-supplied laptop that effectively deleted information
column14: in a rather elaborate attempt to erase his activity. Strangely
column15: Levandowski didn't use the laptop much after the new OS was installed.After quitting Google
column16: Levandowski set up a self-driving trucking company calledOtto
column17: wooing fifteen other Waymo engineers
column18: who brought additional supplier lists
column19: manufacturing details and other trade secrets.Otto quickly sold itself toUberfor $680 million.Uber's ResponseUber remains partners with Google for other technology despite their increased competition on the self-driving front. As an initial response
column20: a Uber representative said
column21: ""We take the allegations made against Otto and Uber employees seriously and we will review this matter carefully.""Later
column22: this changed to: ""We are incredibly proud of the progress that our team has made… We have reviewed Waymo's claims and determined them to be a baseless attempt to slow down a competitor and we look forward to vigorously defending against them in court. In the meantime
column23: we will continue our hard work to bring self-driving benefits to the world.""Other DetailsThe discovery of theft was intriguing: A Uber supplier had inadvertently copied a Google executive in a mail titled ""Otto files."" The mail was being sent to people at Uber that Google thinks were involved with Uber's self-driving technology.Google found that the replicated technology
column24: the diagrams of which were attached to the email
column25: bore a close resemblance to its proprietary technology and was based on Waymo trade secrets. ""Moreover
column26: the Replicated Board is specifically designed to be used in conjunction with many other Waymo trade secrets and in the context of overall LiDAR systems covered by Waymo patents
column27: the complaint reads.Upon inquiry with the Nevada Governor's Office of Economic Development and Department of Motor Vehicles
column28: it was found that Uber said its technology was internally developed.The Big PictureAs a Bloomberg report points out
column29: Levandowski didn't start out at Google. He has been working on autonomous vehicles for some time
column30: founding a startup called 510 systems in 2001 that he later sold to Google. The technology this startup brought is the foundation of Google's technology.At the end of the day
column31: engineers do like to move around because it's more profitable and allows them liberties that aren't available for sticking around at a big corporate house like Google. This is neither the first nor last time companies have whisked away people from competitors. All the major tech companies including Google itself
column32: MicrosoftMSFT
column33: FacebookFB
column34: TwitterTWTR
column35: AppleAAPL
column36: you name it
column37: have done likewise.Engineers are the life blood of companies like Google while on the other hand
column38: the big companies are the only ones that can make engineers rich. So while Google could win this battle
column39: the war will go on.A Full-Blown Technological Breakthrough in the   MakingZacks' Aggressive Growth Strategist Brian Bolan explores autonomous cars in our latest Special Report

column1: Alphabet’s Waymo Leads the Field in Driverless Cars;2/28/2017;"Image Source: WaymoAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) has been crushing its rivals in   self-driving cars
column2: according to the latest data from the   California Department of Motor Vehicles. Alphabet's driverless   car division -- Waymo -- reported the lowest disengagement rate   among all the companies testing self-driving cars on California   roads last year
column3: meaning there were fewer times when the   autonomous driving system had to be shut down.makeArticleAd();How things lookThe California DMV defines disengagement as either a failure   of autonomous technology or the requirement of human intervention   to switch off the autonomous mode. A lower disengagement rate   indicates that Waymo's driverless cars have become better at   driving themselves.In fact
column4: according to this data
column5: Waymo is not just better than   the rest; it is beating its rivals by a huge margin as its cars   had a meager disengagement rate of 0.20 per 1
column6: 000 autonomous   miles. This is down from the 0.80 disengagement rate in 2015.   This seems even more impressive in light of the fact that Waymo   vehicles covered longer distances than rivals and
column7: asTechcnrunchreports
column8: Waymo's autonomous vehicles and their engineers are set   to err on the side of caution when deciding to disengage.ManufacturerAutonomous miles driven in 2016DisengagementsDisengagement per 1
column9: 000 milesBMW63811.6Waymo635
column11: 099286.8Mercedes-Benz673183271.9Tesla550183332.7Data Source: California DMVA low disengagement rate and more miles driven indicate that   Alphabet's moonshot self-driving technology is the most   successful on California roads. More importantly
column12: the lower   disengagement rate has been accomplished mostly in suburban and   city driving conditions. Waymo
column13: therefore
column14: seems to be closer   than any other company to launching its self-driving project   commercially.This is not surprising as Alphabet (then Google) began working   on driverless cars in 2009 and has the first-mover advantage.   Since then
column15: its autonomous cars have driven over 2 million miles
column16: with most of the driving taking place on city streets.   Additionally
column17: Waymo clocked 1 billion miles on the simulator last   year.The amount of time and effort put in by Alphabet's Waymo into   the self-driving car project has placed it way ahead of the curve   in autonomous driving. This might eventually turn Waymo's   driverless rivals into potential clients if they are unable to   replicate the success of its driverless tech.Waymo's rivals could start using its     technologyWaymo calls itself a self-driving technology company
column18: not a   car company. It currently uses a Lexus vehicle and a prototype of   its own to test its driverless technology
column19: while it is also plans   to add 100 Chrysler Pacifica Hybrid minivans to the fleet.Image Source: WaymoIt is less likely that Alphabet will manufacture cars of its   own as it seems to have charted out a different go-to-market   strategy. In January
column20: Waymo announced that it will start   manufacturing sensors used in driverless cars in-house to   integrate its hardware and software development. This integration   should give Waymo a cost advantage and lead to stronger adoption   of its driverless technology.In fact
column21: Waymo has reduced the cost to build a Lidar sensor --   the most crucial part of a driverless car as it uses lasers to   generate maps of the car's surroundings -- by 90%. The price of a   Lidar sensor was $75
column23: but it costs just $7
column24: 500 now.   The integration of hardware and software under a single roof will   allow Waymo to deliver seamless self-driving performance to   potential customers as it is developing its sensors in   association with machine learning experts.As automakers can get turnkey self-driving solutions under a   single roof
column25: they will start turning to Waymo to power their   self-driving cars.Fiat Chrysler Automobiles(NYSE: FCAU) is the first such example.In May last year
column26: Fiat Chrysler and Alphabet's Waymo struck a   deal to develop 100 self-driving cars based on the Pacifica   Hybrid minivan. This was Waymo's first deal with an automaker to   supply its driverless technology. Last month
column27: it was reported   that both companies are going to double down on their efforts as   Alphabet could add another 100 Pacifica Hybrid minivans to the   Waymo fleet this year.ABloombergreport says Alphabet is in talks with Fiat Chrysler to start a   ride-sharing service with the minivans. If that's true
column28: it would   indicate that Waymo is finally taking steps to monetize its   driverless technology.Honda(NYSE: HMC)
column29: meanwhile
column30: could be Waymo's next partner.Both companies were in negotiations last December to put   Waymo's technology into Honda's vehicles. A partnership could   alter Honda's approach to developing its own driverless cars. The   Japanese automaker initially wanted to get its self-driving cars   onto highways by 2020
column31: but Waymo could help it go a few steps   further by adding city and suburban driving capabilities. A Honda   press release says:Honda previously announced its intention to put production     vehicles with automated driving capabilities on highways     sometime around 2020 related to its goal of a collision-free     society. In addition to these on-going efforts
column32: this technical     collaboration with Waymo could allow Honda R&D to explore a     different technological approach to bring fully self-driving     technology to market. These discussions are an initial step     that will allow Waymo and Honda R&D to further explore the     potential of a broad range of automated driving     technologies.The takeawayThe latest California data clearly indicate that Alphabet's   Waymo has a far better driverless technology than any of its   rivals. Waymo is using this to its advantage by partnering with   automakers and showing them the strengths of its self-driving   technology. This strategy of advertising its superiority in this   space is a smart one as it can help Waymo win over potential   clients
column33: making it a key player in the driverless car supply   chain.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A       shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column1: Get Paid to Trade International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI have not been a fan ofInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) for a long time. It is my opinion that management was slow to shift cash cows. They lost their way and have yet to recover. They have been trying to carve a niche in artificial intelligence
column3: but that story has been over a decade in the making. To use a poker term
column4: they are pot-committed to AI.makeArticleAd();Luckily
column5: artificial intelligence has seen a recent resurgence in popularity so the wait may actually pay off to IBM longs.Experts are in awe of what Watson can do. Unfortunately
column6: its profit stream is taking too long to develop. IBM is no longer the sure long-term bet it once was. To me
column7: it more resembles a startup with a cool product still finding its way.Click to EnlargeUsually
column8: I like to sell longer-dated risk in companies that I believe are long-term winners likeAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column9: NASDAQ:GOOGL) orApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). In this case
column10: I am putting my trust in the IBM price action more so than its fundamentals.The Bet:Sell the IBM Oct $130 put. This is a bullish trade for which I collect $1.40 per contract to open. This trade has a 90% theoretical chance of success. This sounds like a great idea now
column11: but it comes with risk. By selling the put naked
column12: I am committing to buying the stock at $130 per share if IBM falls below it. Anything below $128.60 per share would accrue losses for me.The 7 Best ETFs for Retirement InvestorsSelling naked puts is not suited for most investors
column13: so I can modify the trade to make it more attainable.The Alternate:Sell IBM $140/$135 credit put spread. This also is a bullish trade
column14: but one with a finite risk profile. I collect 40 cents per contract to open. The 22% price buffer is smaller than that of selling the $130 naked put but for the finite risk profile advantage.While 40 cents may sound too little
column15: it would represent an 8% yield on money risked and for the high chance of success it carries it should elate most investors.I chose longer-dated risk so I don't have to fret the short-term gyrations. I find that longer-dated options risk is easier to manage. Also
column16: I can close either of these trades at any time for partial gains or losses.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column17: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlace7 REITs That Should Be CondemnedExxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Should Keep an Eye on Tesla Inc (TSLA)7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThe postGet Paid to Trade International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 5 Reasons to Buy General Electric Company (GE) Stock;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsInvestors looking for a reasonably valued stock that is poised to benefit from the Trump presidency and the improvement of the global economy should buyGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE). From Trump's energy policy to his infrastructure plan to the better than expected economic performance of China
column3: the U.S.
column4: and Europe
column5: GE stock has a plethora of positive catalysts.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)At the same time General Electric shares haven't really risen all that much since the election - for a few reasons - and their valuation is still reasonable.Positive Catalysts for GE StockTrump's Energy Policy:Newly elected President Donald Trump is a major proponent of opening more land to oil drilling and fracking.FollowingGE's proposed $7.4 billion purchaseof oil and gas services companyBaker Hughes Incorporated(NYSE:BHI)
column6: which made GE the world's second largest oilfield services company
column7: the conglomerate is exceptionally well-positioned to benefit from Trump's energy policy.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightOf course
column8: the combined GE oil & services-BHI entity - when it finally closes - is expected to be spun off as its own separately traded company
column9: but anyone holding GE stock at the time should get a piece of that action
column10: and thus will benefit regardless.And as the Trump administration opens more areas to drilling and fracking
column11: energy companies will need more equipment
column12: products and services from GE.Trump's Infrastructure Initiative:General Electric's large lighting unit should get a major boost from the president's upcoming infrastructure initiative. The public-private partnerships expected to be implemented by the plan could be used to expand""public lighting.""Moreover
column13: other types of infrastructure - including new roads
column14: bridges and tunnels - need lights that GE can and does provide.Trump's Infrastructure Initiative (Part 2):Of course
column15: factories can be pretty large buildings
column16: and large buildings usually require a great deal of lighting.With its significant industrial lighting business
column17: General Electric also is poised to benefit from the president's well-publicized efforts to bring more factories to the U.S.Macroeconomic Trends:The European Union recently increased its 2017 economic growth forecastto 1.8%
column18: up from 1.6% previously
column19: as ""the EU's economic recovery is taking hold."" Meanwhile
column20: China's GDP rose a better than expected 6.8%last quarter
column21: and its economy appears to be stabilizing
column22: while the U.S. economy is rapidly improving.With major operations in all three areas
column23: General Electric should benefit from the improving economies in those areas. Many of GE's businesses
column24: including transportation
column25: aviation
column26: lighting and oil and gas
column27: are greatly impacted by economic growth trends.Advanced Micro Devices
column28: Inc. (AMD) Stock Is Ryzen Above the CompetitionValuation:Unlike many stocks that are poised to get a boost from Trump's policies
column29: GE stock is reasonably valued right now
column30: as it hasn't gotten much of a boost since the November election. GE trades at a reasonable 16 times forward earnings projections
column31: and it trades at just more than twice sales.Bottom Line on GE StockGeneral Electric sports a reasonable valuation and high leverage to the global economy and the Trump administration's policies.Couple those factors in with a 3.2% dividend yield at current prices

column1: The Next Big Thing for Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN): Productivity Software;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) has taken on some unexpected targets lately. None more ambitious - and unforeseen - than sticking its Alexa personal assistant in the Amazon Echo smart speaker.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonThat move has paid off with a big lead in the race to become the hub of the smart home
column5: despite AMZN's complete lack of smartphone presence.Per a report inThe Information
column6: Amazon is readying another bold move. If sources are correct
column7: AMZN is preparing to take onMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Microsoft Office andAlphabet Inc.'s(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google G Suite with its own cloud-based productivity suite.Report: Amazon.com Is Working on a Productivity SuiteThe Informationbroke the news that Amazon.com isworking on its own productivity suiteto take on Microsoft and Google. The website says AMZN's Amazon Web Services - AWS - unit has told some of its ""large corporate customers"" of its plans to offer a new suite of productivity apps that will compete against the two dominant players.7 REITs That Should Be CondemnedMicrosoft Office has always been considered a cash cow for the company. The productivity suite quickly became the industry standard
column8: the applications of choice for enterprise
column9: schools and home PC users. To make its software seem more affordable
column10: to break free of the boom bust cycle between major versions of Microsoft Office
column11: and to address the growing threat of Google's free Google Apps suite
column12: five years ago
column13: the company began pushing Office 365.This subscription version of Microsoft Office brought recurring monthly revenue and other advantages. Microsoft expanded into Office apps for mobile devices likeApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) iPad and began to sell online storage for Office 365 users
column14: with OneDrive.Google Apps/G SuiteGoogle wasn't sitting still
column15: though
column16: refining Google Apps intoG Suite
column17: a full-on competitor to Office 365
column18: with paid monthly subscription plans and online storage options. The company has also leveraged Google Apps and its lightweight Chrome OS into Chromebooks - ultra-low-cost laptops that have been giving Microsoft fits
column19: especially in the education market.That education market is where the potential for disruption is really playing out. With its free Google Apps and low-cost Chromebooks
column20: Google upended the education market. By the end of 2015
column21: more than half of all device in U.S. classrooms were Chromebooks. This has repercussions beyond the classroom
column22: as those students turn into young professionals who are more comfortable with Google's productivity software than with Microsoft Office.I've seen the effect first hand. My kids do everything at school using G Suite
column23: despite Microsoft offering free Office 365 subscriptions to students and computer labs full of Windows PCs. They ignore Microsoft Office and Apple's Pages/Numbers on our home computers
column24: and instead log onto G Suite for doing homework.If Google could quickly make waves in one of Microsoft's key strongholds
column25: why couldn't Amazon.com march in and disrupt both companies?Why Amazon Would Take On Microsoft OfficeThis is a key question. Taking on the Google and Apple in the smart home with the Amazon Echo made sense because the smart speaker was a Trojan horse. It offers a growing number of ""Skills"" that let it control other smart devices by voice command
column26: or interact with online services.That ropes consumers into buying it. But Alexa is a voice-activated path to effortlessly order products directly from Amazon.com
column27: and gives an incentive to buy other Amazon products and services like Amazon Music Unlimited and Amazon Fire TV.Where's the win for AMZN in offering productivity software
column28: other than to tweak Microsoft and Google?For the answer
column29: look to AWS. Amazon Web Servicesdominates the market for cloud infrastructureand the profit from this division is a big driver of Amazon's overall growth. Amazon already has the servers in place and it has several of the components needed for a productivity suite
column30: including its WorkDocs and WorkMail apps and the recently announcedAmazon Chimevideo conferencing software. Stitch these together with a few additional components and Amazon could have its Microsoft Office and Google G Suite competitor.Google charges $5 to $10 per month for G Suite
column31: while Microsoft Office 365 has several tiered options starting at $5.99 per month.AMZN could charge a competitive rate for its new offering
column32: adding more subscription-based revenue to its bottom line while taking advantage of its existing cloud muscle. The base monthly fee could be supplemented by charging for additional online storage for enterprise customers - something it has plenty of.Productivity software could also become another free perk of Prime membership. Prime members that start using Amazon's productivity software could put pressure on their employers to invest in a subscription
column33: in an effect like Google's approach that sees students graduate and look to their employers to provide G Suite access.The Dow Jones Industrial Average Keeps Rising
column34: But a Correction Is ComingAMZN isn't commenting andThe Information'ssources say all of this is still in the early stages
column35: but the move makes sense. Amazon has been aggressively expanding beyond its role as an online retailer
column36: AWS has the infrastructure needed to support the initiative
column37: the company has been creeping into enterprise software with apps like WorkMail
column38: and Google proved that the Microsoft Office behemoth isn't invulnerable. A productivity software suite from Amazon.com could well be the company's next big thing.As of this writing
column39: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 High-Impact Tech Earnings: Tesla

column1: Mobile World Congress: Apple Inc. (AAPL) vs. Everyone Else;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMobile World Congress is the industry's largest event for smartphone launches. Everyone who's anyone is there -unless your company name isApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).makeArticleAd();Source: BlackBerryMWC 2017 officially started today
column3: but the big announcements took place over the weekend.And in many ways
column4: they set the stage for the coming battle for best smartphone that will pit Apple's 10th anniversary iPhone 8 andSamsung Electronics Co Ltd's(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) comeback Galaxy S8 against everyone else.Here's what you need to know aboutMWC 2017.Cutting Edge New SmartphonesMobile World Congress is the venue where many manufacturers choose to launch their new smartphones. That means the trends are set for what to expect in the coming year. At MWC 2017
column5: there have been a few standouts that lead to some interesting conclusions.LG's new G6 smartphoneis one of the most talked about releases. The company abandoned the modular design it introduced in last year's G5. The new G6 incorporates design elements expected in the iPhone 8
column6: with a glass front and back held together with a stainless-steel band.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightWhile bezels are still there
column7: they're been minimized by moving the power button and fingerprint sensor to the back. The result is a 5.7-inch display in a compact body - and the display is wowing with its 564 ppi pixel density and support for HDR. The LG G6 also has a dual lens 13 megapixel camera
column8: but unlike the iPhone 7 Plus
column9: the extra lens is wide angle rather than telephone.Another interesting flagship release is theP10from China'sHuawei. This new premium smartphone includesLeica-branded cameras and a Portrait Mode to compete with iPhone 7 Plus feature. In addition
column10: the P10 uses Huawei's own processor
column11: the Kirin 960. This is bad news forQualcomm
column12: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM)
column13: which is seeing more smartphone makers follow the lead of Apple by ditching the Snapdragon to develop their own customized chips.When the iPhone 8 arrives in the fall
column14: its expected all-glass design isn't going to be as unique as Apple might have hoped. Cameras are going to be a big battleground
column15: too
column16: putting pressure on Apple to go further than it did with the dual-lens iPhone 7 Plus.No Galaxy S8 at MWC 2017Samsung traditionally unveils its new Galaxy S smartphones at Mobile World Congress. Not this year. Delayed by the Galaxy Note 7 battery investigation
column17: Samsung is expected tounveil the Galaxy S8at an event on March 29.The company did take the wraps offtwo new tablets
column18: though. The Galaxy Tab S3 and Galaxy Book. The latter is offered in two different sizes
column19: runs Windows 10
column20: comes with a snap-on keyboard case and stylus and is aimed atMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Surface Pro.Google Assistant Coming to Android Nougat and Marshmallow DevicesAlphabet Inc.(NASDAQ:GOOG
column21: NASDAQ:GOOGL) has had a big decision to make since introducing Google Assistant. The company broke with tradition to make its new AI-powered digital assistant exclusive to its own Google Pixel smartphones. But that restriction means the number of phones running Google Assistant are outnumbered by Siri-powered Apple devices andAmazon.com
column22: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa-powered smart speakers.Google chose MWC 2017 to announce it's decided to go back to the strategy of volume over exclusivity.Google Assistant will start rolling outto devices running Android Nougat and Marshmallow starting this week.BlackBerry and Nokia Makes a Splash at MWC 2017If you'd asked anyone a few months ago what companies would be generating buzz at MWC 2017
column23: it's doubtful thatBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) orNokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK) would be anywhere on that list. But they both pulled it off. Sort of.BlackBerry's last hurrah in smartphones is the newBlackBerry KeyOne. The last phone with the company's name on it that was designed in-house combines Android with a classic BlackBerry keyboard. There's grumbling about the $549 price
column24: but a general feeling that had BBRY releasedthisphone a few years ago
column25: it might still be relevant in the smartphone space.The other big surprise was the return of the Nokia brand. Finland'sHMD Globalbought the rights to use the Nokia name on phones
column26: and at MWC 2017 it announcedthree new Nokia Android smartphonesaimed at the Chinese market.The company is also bringing back the classic Nokia 3310 cell phone. Considered to be virtually indestructible
column27: the Nokia 3310 was first released in 2000 andsold over 126 million units. The new version is a little less sturdy
column28: but has new colors
column29: and updated display and runs just over $50.Nokia gets some licensing revenue out of this
column30: but was not involved in the development of the new phones bearing its brand.Everyone Against the iPhone 8The announcements from MWC 2017 largely set the stage for the coming battle for smartphone supremacy. Samsung still must take the wraps off the Galaxy S8
column31: but after that happens
column32: we'll largely know what Apple's iPhone 8 will be up against.Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Will Try to Dominate IndiaIt looks like Apple's 10th anniversary iPhone will face a strong field with large displays
column33: impressive cameras
column34: Google Assistant on board and new designs - at least some of which follow the direction Apple is expected to take.Who will have the best smartphone of 2017? With the big Mobile World Congress reveals over with
column35: the ball is now in Samsung and Apple's court.As of this writing
column36: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Heavy-Hitting Small-Caps That Will Wallop the Market7 REITs That Should Be CondemnedThe postMobile World Congress: Apple Inc. (AAPL) vs. Everyone Elseappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Will Try to Dominate India;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhile China's e-commerce market is still growing
column3: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA) and its affiliate Ant Financial are already looking south to India. Last year
column4: Morgan Stanley predicted that theIndian e-commerce marketwould grow the fastest globally
column5: to $119 billion by 2020. And Alibaba stock is poised to benefit.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockWhat's driving e-commerce and fintech in India? India passed the U.S. as the world's No. 2 smartphone market last year
column6: with 220 million users . T he number of smartphone users in India is expected to balloon to 810 million by 2021 and India's 3G and 4G networks could cover 300 million subscribers by March 2018.India's young and growing population is increasingly tech-savvy
column7: especially millennials.India's government also supports a cashless economy
column8: seeing this as a way to reduce corruption and tax evasion. The Indian government alsoremoved the largest banknotes
column9: 500 rupee and 1000 rupee notes
column10: from the economy. This led to an explosion in the use ofmobile wallets in India
column11: adding as many as  1 million users added per day .Last year
column12: the National Payments Corporation of India announced theUnified Payment Interface
column13: making it convenient for Indians to access their bank accounts on their phones and pay.And all these moving parts flow into the bull case for Alibaba stock.Taking Ant's Strategy to IndiaAlibaba and Ant (formerly Alipay) invested inOne97Communications
column14: the parent company of Indian e-commerce player Paytm. They are expected to increase their stake to 50% from 42%. Paytm last year spun off its payments business to comply with regulations. One97 holds a 49% stake in Paytm Payments Bank and Paytm founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma owns 51%.Paytm boasted177 million usersat the end of the year and CFO Madhur Deora has set a medium-term target of 500 million users . That growth would be a boost for Alibaba stock and Ant Financial which seeks2 billion users worldwideover the next decade.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightPaytm is clearly taking a page out of Alibaba and Ant Financial's playbook. Like BABA'sMyBank-  the bank ""for the little guy"" - Paytm's bank promises to be a vehicle for financial inclusion
column15: bringing services to India's unbanked.Like Ant
column16: Paytm also wants to offer loans andasset management servicesto those who can't access them now.Ant Fortune
column17: a wealth management app
column18: debuted in 2015. Its users can put money in Yuebao
column19: a money market fund
column20: and invest inZhao Cai Bao
column21: where they can loan money directly to businesses.Paytm's Threat to BanksBanks in both countries are threatened by this disruption. Ant's Yuebao offers depositors higher interest rates than banks andinstant withdrawals. Technology companies don't have to maintain as many employees at branches as banks do
column22: and can link borrowers and savers directly. Their asset-light model is simply more efficient than that of existing banks
column23: which have to use their own capital
column24: and are burdened by legacy systems and regulation.Banks earn a profit on the spread
column25: the difference between the rate at which they lend and the rates they offer depositors. Platforms that connect borrowers and lenders and cut out the middleman can exert pressure on this. And because Paytm and Ant Financial are branchless
column26: they have lower overhead costs
column27: and can offer lower fees than banks.Paytm will be both a friend and a potential enemy to banks. It will help them drum up business by cross-selling their services to its users. But Paytm will probably be the front-end in customer interactions and relegate the banks to the back end .Banks risk becoming ""dumb pipes."" As I mentioned inmy articlelast year
column28: the front-end generally gives banks a higher return on equity than the back. AMcKinsey & Companystudy found that banks earn a 22% return on equity from sales and origination
column29: but only 6% from the extension of credit.Protectionism RisksAll of this doesn't mean that the success of Alibaba
column30: Ant and Paytm is guaranteed. Some risks still stand in the way.First
column31: protectionist sentiment is rising in India asAmazon.com
column32: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) andUberclobber their Indian rivals. Indian startups such as Flipkart
column33: Snapdeal (in which BABA is an investor)
column34: and Ola have had their valuations repeatedly marked down over the past year. Now some are asking for protection against supposedly unfair foreign competition. Indian venture capitalist Vani Kola of Kalaari Capital called for such measures
column35: followed bysimilar sentimentfrom the founders of e-commerce player Flipkart and Ola
column36: viewed as India's home-grown Uber) .Since Paytm is an Indian company
column37: why would this be a concern? While Paytm is Indian
column38: its largest shareholders are Chinese
column39: Alibaba and Ant. Would India want such a company controlling something as critical as its payments infrastructure? Experts have raised concerns overPaytm user dataending up in servers outside of India.Pointing to Paytm's Chinese ties
column40: the chief minister of West Bengal
column41: Mamata Banerjee accused the prime minister ofcompromising national security. The Sino-Indian relationship is contentious; the two countries went to war as recently as 1962 over a border dispute.Valeant Pharmaceuticals Intl Inc (VRX) Q4 Earnings: What to ExpectFor Paytm to work
column42: users must see it as secure and reliable. Without trust
column43: Paytm cannot succeed. However
column44: in December the Paytm server was down for an hour
column45: leaving users unable to make payments.Paytm's customer service also is a weak spot
column46: with many rating it as bad. Also
column47: the recent user increase may be temporary. After March 13
column48: Paytm may lose as much as 30% of its offline customers once cash withdrawal limits end.Bottom Line on Alibaba StockEven if Paytm and BABA succeed
column49: however
column50: buying Alibaba stock is notwithout risks.Alibaba is a variable interest entity
column51: which means American shareholders own shares in a Cayman Islands-based entity. Chinese law forbids foreign ownership in Chinese internet companies like Alibaba
column52: so this structure is a way around it.But the Chinese government's position isn't clear
column53: and it could always change its mind
column54: at the expense of BABA stock holders.As of writing
column55: Lucas Hahn did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Tesla Inc (TSLA)

column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Alphabet
column2: Ford
column3: Toyota and General Motors;2/27/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column4: IL - February 27
column5: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeAlphabet Inc.(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report)
column6: Ford(NYSE:F-Free Report)
column7: Toyota(NYSE:TM-Free Report) andGeneral Motors(NYSE:GM-Free Report).Today
column8: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:GOOGL's Waymo Accuses Uber of Stealing Confidential     FilesAlphabet Inc.'s (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) Waymo has sued Uber and its subsidiary Otto
column9: alleging intellectual property theft and patent violation.In a lawsuit filed Thursday in San Francisco federal court
column10: Waymo accused that former manager at Google's self-driving car project
column11: Anthony Levandowski
column12: had downloaded over 14
column13: 000 highly confidential and proprietary files before leaving to work at his newly formed self-driving truck company Otto.Waymo claimed that Levandowski downloaded 9.7 GB of confidential files and trade secrets consisting of design files
column14: blue prints and test documentation from a Google-issued laptop to an external drive and formatted the laptop to delete forensic fingerprints.Waymo also alleged other Google employees who joined Otto to have stolen trade secrets. The company claims that without those stolen stuff
column15: Otto's technology
column16: which forms an important part of Uber's efforts to roll out autonomous vehicles for its ride sharing service
column17: wouldn't have evolved.Stemmed from an Accidental CC-ingA supplier had mistakenly included a Waymo employee on an e-mail chain that was supposed to be delivered to the Uber team. The attached ""OTTO FILES"" comprised a drawing of a self-driving car Light Detection And Ranging (LIDAR) circuit board quite similar to the one Waymo has been developing secretly.Waymo's lawsuit states that ""The sudden resignations from Waymo
column18: Otto's quick public launch with Mr. Lewandowski at the helm
column19: and Uber's near-immediate acquisition of Otto for more than half a billion dollars all caused Waymo grave concern regarding the possible misuse of its intellectual property.""Reigniting the ConflictThe two camps once lived in harmony. Alphabet executive David Drummond joined Uber's board in 2013 when Alphabet's venture capital arm GV
column20: then Google Ventures
column21: invested $258 million in the company and planned to include Uber rides in the Google Maps app.However
column22: things started to go wrong when Uber decided to develop its own mapping and driverless car technology. The company has opened a technology center in Pittsburgh and hired some robotics specialists from Carnegie Mellon University. It also collaborated with automakers such as Volvo and acquired Otto.Google on the other hand launched a pilot project that enables carpooling in San Francisco Bay Area. Available through Google-owned maps app
column23: Waze
column24: the service is presently under beta testing with a handful of Bay Area companies including Adobe and Google itself. Drummond stepped down from Uber's board last year.The lawsuit certainly complicates the ongoing clash between two of the early leaders in the autonomous vehicle space. Well established car companies like Ford (NYSE:F-Free Report)
column25: Toyota (NYSE:TM-Free Report) and General Motors (NYSE:GM-Free Report) on the other hand have just started to make their way into this market.Currently
column26: Alphabet shares carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.Google has outperformed the ZacksInternet - Servicesindustry over the last one year. While the stock returned 18%
column27: the industry gained 16.1%.Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above

column1: Incredible! Here's How Many Internet Gadgets the Average Home Has;2/26/2017;"The notion that the world around us
column2: particularly in   tech-friendly North America
column3: is becoming more connected by the   day isn't necessarily surprising. What may raise an eyebrow or   two is just how prevalent connected internet gadgets already   are.What makes the sheer volume of the average homeowner's online   devices jaw-dropping is that by most accounts the Internet of   Things (IoT) in general
column4: and ""smart"" homes in particular
column5: haven't   even gone mainstream yet as most pundits expected last year. But   that's about to change

column8: in other words using a smartphone to get   connected
column9: accounted for a mere 9% of fixed access traffic via a   Wi-Fi network. According to a recent study of North American   consumers
column10: that figure has jumped to nearly 30%.makeArticleAd();But mobile phones are just a small piece of the connected   smart home. Gaming consoles are another fast-growing means of   accessing the internet. Surprisingly
column11: few consumers actually use   consoles like theSony(NYSE: SNE) PlayStation to play games: a mere 2.5% according to   the study. However

column13: while still prevalent in North American   households
column14: now account for less than 25% of total internet   traffic. Toss in smart personal home assistants such asAmazon's(NASDAQ: AMZN) Alexa and similar solutions and the average home   in North American has over seven ""active devices in use each   day."" A mind-boggling 6% of homes use more than 15 connected   devices on a daily basis.If those figures seem a bit much

column16: and continue to climb for years to come.Alphabet Nest unit. Image source: Nest.Ready
column17: set

column20: this will be   the year of the smart home because providers ""will be smarter   about educating their consumers.""Consolidation of smart device manufacturers
column21: Alphabet's $3.2   billion deal for Nest three years ago is one notable example
column22: is   also expected to help in educating consumers as well as bring   costs down. column1: 3 Horrendously Bad Stock Market Predictions From Otherwise Smart People;2/26/2017;"""It's tough to make predictions
column2: especially about the   future.""-- Yogi BerraEvery year
column3: the stock market either advances
column4: declines
column5: or   stays flat. It's never clear beforehand which direction these   indexes
column6: or the stocks that comprise them
column7: will move; the reasons   for their price swings only make sense in retrospect.makeArticleAd();But that truth doesn't stop people from making aggressive   predictions attempting to identify the Next Big Thing or to call   a coming crash or boom. Here are a few classic examples of some   smart market watchers getting burned by their stock calls.1. McDonald's will trounce Google as an investmentWhitney   Tilsonhas used his value investing approach to produce awesome returns   for himself and his investors over the years. Yet his tendency to   bash ""expensive"" companies with high price-to-earnings ratios has   also burned the hedge fund giant -- big time.For example
column8: back in 2004
column9: Tilson made abold prediction. Writing for The Motley Fool at the time
column10: he said the   soon-to-be-publicAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) (a.k.a. Google) would almost   certainly flame out as a business. ""I'd wager that odds are at   least 90% that its profit margins and growth rate will be   materially lower five years from now
column11: he argued.Tilson got even more specific
column12: saying thatMcDonald's(NYSE: MCD) would make a much better bet given its far lower   valuation. ""I believe that it is virtually certain that Google's   stock will be highly disappointing to investors foolish enough to   participate in its overhyped offering -- you can hold me to   that
column13: he concluded.GOOGL Market Capdata byYCharts.So how did that prediction pan out? Since 2005
column14: Alphabet   shares are up roughly 16 times
column15: compared to less than a 400%   return for the fast food titan. The search engine giant produced   nearly $20 billion of net income last year
column16: versus McDonald's   $4.5 billion. Today
column17: Alphabet is worth almost six times   McDonald's in the eyes of the market.2. Smartphones will be a bustA deep understanding of technology isn't enough to protect you   from being surprised by major shifts in the industry. Andrew   Grove was one of the founders ofIntel
column18: which profoundly shaped the semiconductor industry. He wasTime Magazine's Man of The Year in 1997. Yet in 1992 he made a prediction that   looks amazingly shortsighted in retrospect.Image source: Getty Images.ANew York Timesarticledescribed Grove as standing diametrically opposed to the position   taken byApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)  that smartphones
column19: then imagined as ""personal   communicators
column20: might develop into a huge business. They'd be   ""the mother of all markets
column21: according to Apple's then-CEO
column22: John   Sculley.Grove disagreed. The idea of a communicating device that   people carried around with them is ""a pipe dream driven by   greed
column23: he said. Ironically
column24: the article lists a few predictions   about the technology that proved prescient. These personal   communicators might handle emails
column25: use GPS to map directions
column26: and   even allow someone to ""order pizza using a combination of custom   electronic forms and wireless fax.""Today
column27: the smartphone industry is massive
column28: with Apple   accounting for nearly 150 million iPhone sales in the past year.   These devices helped spur over $24 billion of complementary   service-based revenue
column29: which demonstrates that
column30: if anything
column31: investors weren't being greedy enough about the potential for   smartphones to find a huge market.3. The Dow is headed to 36
column32: 000James Glassman's 1999 book titledDow 36
column33: 000hasn't aged well. In fact
column34: Washington Post economics columnist   Neil Irwincalled it""perhaps the most spectacularly wrong investing book ever"" given   that it forecast a massive rally for stocks between 1999 and   2004.Glassman's timing couldn't have been worse. The Dow hit 14
column35: 000   the year his book published before plummeting to a 15-year low of   7
column36: 000 in 2009. A roaring rally has pushed the blue-chip index   back to new highs recently
column37: but today it's still 42% below the   mark he believed the Dow would achieve over a decade ago.^DJIdata byYCharts.To his credit
column38: Glassman has taken a hard look at how his   prediction could have been so far off the mark. He identified two   major factors thathe and his co-author missed: earnings growth and the attitude of investors as reflected in   the price-to-earnings multiples they are willing to pay for   stocks. Neither trend went in the direction they had   targeted.A better wayThese failed forecasts illustrate how overconfidence can prove   fatal to your portfolio while predictions about economic trends   are rarely more than a distraction from the business of   accumulating stock market returns.Bold predictions are compelling because they attract debate   and can pay big dividends if proven correct. But no one knows   which direction stocks or markets will move over the short term.   That's why investors are better off simply buying a diverse group   of solid stocks and holding on to the shares for years (or   decades) while allowing the power of compound returns to do all   of the hard work.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Tiny Company That Bought Google's Satellites Becomes a Rising Star;2/25/2017;"There's a battle going on in outer space
column2: for control of the   Earth imaging market.Yesterday morning
column3: we learned thatDigitalGlobe(NYSE: DGI) hassold itselfto Canadian space-tech specialistMacDonald
column4: Dettwiler and Associatesfor a purchase price of $2.4 billion -- and not a moment too   soon. DigitalGlobe
column5: if you recall
column6: is the American   satellite-imaging company that itselfbought one-time Motley Fool recommendation   GeoEyea few years ago.Just before announcingits ownsale
column7: DigitalGlobe reported a loss for its fiscal fourth quarter.   And if you ask me
column8: this suggests the time is ripe for   DigitalGlobe to cash out -- the more so because its primary area   of business is about to get even tougher to compete in.makeArticleAd();How hi-res is a high-resolution snapshot from space? Here's     one that Planet Labs' now-acquired Terra Bella satellites     recently snapped of the U.S. Air Force's Davis-Monthan airplane     ""boneyard"" of decommissioned military aircraft. Image source:     Terra Bella.Who is DigitalGlobe?DigitalGlobe is one of the biggest names in satellite-based
column9: highly detailed Earth imaging. The company operates a   constellation of five satellites capable of snapping photographs   from orbit at resolutions as minute as 30 centimeters per pixel.   DigitalGlobe calls its constellation ""the best in the world"" and   ""the largest constellation in the industry
column10: and that's at least   half right.Problem is
column11: it's also half wrong. DigitalGlobe may dominate   the market for highly detailed Earth imaging. But over at upstart   Planet Labs (also known simply as ""Planet"")
column12: one of the leaders   of the ""new space"" industry is rapidly overtaking DigitalGlobe in   breadth of coverage.(Re-)Introducing Planet LabsAs we discussed last month
column13: Planet had for some time been   discussing acquiringAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)satellite imaging business
column14: Terra Bella. The purchase price remains a mystery -- but the deal itself is   apparently now a ""go."" On Feb. 3
column15: Planet confirmed that it will   indeed acquire Terra Bella from Alphabet
column16: along with its fleet of   seven high-resolution (capable of sub-meter resolutions)   satellites.Then
column17: last week
column18: Planet announced the launch of 88 new ""Dove""   medium-resolution (three to five meters per pixel) satellites
column19: more than doubling the size of its medium-res constellation to   144 birds in orbit.Planet made history here in a couple of ways. First
column20: its   deployment was part of an Indian government PSLV (Polar Satellite   Launch Vehicle) launch that sent 16 other satellites
column21: in addition   to Planet's
column22: into space. At 104 satellites total
column23: the mission   that carried Planet's Doves was the largest-ever satellite   deployment made from a single rocket.More important
column24: Planet says that its 144 Doves in orbit
column25: plus   five RapidEye satellites acquired from BlackBridge in 2015
column26: give   it a constellation of 149 satellites in orbit today. Feel free to   mentally add seven more to that number once the Terra Bella   acquisition is finalized
column27: if you like. But already
column28: Planet's   mixed bag of 149 satellites gives it ""the largest private   satellite constellation in history.""This is significant not only because it gives Planet bragging   rights. By more than doubling its satellite constellation
column29: Planet   says it now has the ability to ""image all of Earth's landmass   every day."" Alone among satellite operators
column30: Planet can now take   a snapshot of every square foot of Earth's solid surface once per   day
column31: every day of the year.What it means to investorsWith every passing day
column32: Planet Labs is getting bigger
column33: treading more and more on DigitalGlobe's astro-turf
column34: and making   its rival's products nonunique. Indeed
column35: even if the photos taken   by Planet's Doves don't offer quite the same resolution as   DigitalGlobe offers
column36: Planet's ability to take somanysnapshots every day gives the company a more all-encompassing   view of what's happening around the globe.It's difficult to guess what advances will flow from access to   such data. Better weather forecasting
column37: certainly. A clearer view   of the progression of global warming
column38: its effects and its causes
column39: very likely. But we can also anticipate Planet generating better   data on traffic patterns on highways
column40: at ports
column41: and along   shipping routes; on the spread of residential development that   could guide brick-and-mortar retailers on where to place their   next big-box stores; and in countless other ways.The future is looking awfully bright for Planet Labs. And it's   getting brighter every day

column1: Buy the Kinder Morgan Inc (KMI) Stock Dip and Sit Tight;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsKinder Morgan Inc(NYSE:KMI) is one of the largest midstream energy players in the U.S. In the energy patch
column3: there are upstream firms (exploration and production)
column4: midstream firms (pipelines and storage terminals) and downstream firms (retail
column5: refining and distribution). Big energy companies likeExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM) are vertically integrated across all of these sectors.makeArticleAd();Source:Roy Luck via FlickrThe midstream players have been interesting for two core reasons: Many were master limited partnerships (MLPs) that treated shareholders as owners
column6: and distributed profits on a regular basis in the form of dividends. And those dividends were very juicy for a while.The second reason is
column7: midstream players are more like toll booth operators. Unlike their upstream or downstream brethren
column8: the price of whatever commodity is flowing through pipes matters little to midstream players. It's the volume that matters.3 Earnings Reports That Should Be on Your RadarWith all this in mind
column9: we can now explore where KMI fits into the picture right now.KMI Stock TurnaroundIn late 2014
column10: KMI announced it was going to buy up its MLPs and consolidate them into the general partner firm Kinder Morgan. This was a $76 billion internal acquisition and made KMI ""the largest midstream company and third largest energy firm in the U.S.""
column11: according to its CEO and Chairman Richard Kinder. It now operates 84
column12: 000 miles of pipelines in the US and Canada
column13: with 155 terminals.The goal was likely to consolidate the profits into KMI and not have to distribute so much of the profits to shareholders. That was all well and good
column14: but then the bottom fell out of the energy markets. As the merger was announced
column15: oil was nearly $100 a barrel and natural gas was around $4 per million BTU. Now
column16: oil and natural gas are slightly better than half those prices.Needless to say
column17: the past couple of years have been tough on KMI in particular and the U.S. energy patch in general. But there is a turnaround under way. Rig counts in the U.S. are up
column18: week after week. Mergers are popping in the midstream space and companies that have cash are looking to gain market share.U.S. inventories are growing and exports are booming. Shale production is getting back online. The economy is getting back on its feet. Things are looking up.And even if this increased production keeps prices low
column19: it doesn't matter to KMI. It will be making money on the increased flow
column20: not the prices. This is why the midstream sector is the best place to get back into the U.S. energy game
column21: since it's about increasing demand and is slightly agnostic about supply.This Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Trade Is a Sure ThingWhile KMI doesn't throw off a huge MLP-like dividend
column22: it does provide a 2.3% dividend that will at least pay you for your patience as the stock and the sector get back to full capacity.Richard Band'sProfitable Investingadvisory service helps retirement savers outperform the market without losing a minute of sleep along the way. column68: under this updated   legislation
column69: companies with under $1 billion in annual revenue   can file paperwork for an IPO confidentially with the SEC. That   allows the company to go back and forth with the regulatory   agency without alerting the public that they are planning on   IPO-ing

column255: zero.   A lot of tech companies have been doing this thing for a long   time where they give the public shares one vote

column259: between the   executives and directors of Google

Spiegel and Murphy   don't have that track record.Niu:Right. Zuckerberg has definitely earned some respect. column386: but as we've seen with many overhyped IPOs in   recent years
column387: it only takes a few months for the market to   sober up. Plus
column388: Snap's also doing a different thing with the   lock-up period. Employees will be able to sell sooner -- the   lock-up expires for employees sooner than is typical.   Normally
column389: it's about 180 days. They're going to allow   their employees to sell at 150 days
column390: along with all the   co-founders. So
column391: there could be some selling pressure as all   these investors and employees cash out. The employees and all the   insiders are going to make a ton of money
column392: but as far   as public investors go
column393: I don't know. It's also worth   mentioning that their stock-based compensation   expenses so far are quite small because they're still   private. I think last year it was something like $30-some   million
column394: which is a tiny proportion of their expenses.   But when companies go public
column395: the liquidity   event triggers a ridiculous increase in stock-based   compensation cost because now that stock is worth so much   more. And that's typical for all companies that go public   -- right after they go public
column396: they have a huge   increase in stock-based comp. That's something to be aware   that is coming. Plus
column397: they're probably going to start   unloading pretty quickly. I don't know
column400: how this thing can really   go even further
column401: after it's already at such a ridiculous   level. You know what I mean?Lewis:I am absolutely with you. Listeners
column402: you can be sure that as   details start to crystallize and we get a better sense of   what's happening with the Snap IPO
column403: we'll be sure to do an update   on this episode as market conditions clear up a little bit.   But
column405: I think that does it. Evan?Niu:Yeah
column407: that does it for this episode ofIndustry Focus. If you have any questions
column408: or if just want to reach out and   say
column410: you can shoot us an email atindustryfocus@fool.com
column411: or you can tweet us @MFIndustryFocus. We love getting   listener questions
column412: so please shoot them to us. If you're looking   for more of our stuff
column414: or check out   The Fool's family of shows atfool.com/podcasts. As always
column415: people on the program may own companies discussed on   the show
column416: and The Motley Fool may have formal recommendations for   or against stocks mentioned
column417: so don't buy or sell anything based   solely on what you hear. For Evan Niu
column419: thanks   for listening and Fool on!Suzanne Frey

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Sues Uber Over Allegedly Stolen Technology;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: GOOGL) Waymo is suing Uber for using technology that it claims was stolen from it by a former employee.makeArticleAd();Source:GoogleWaymo
column4: the self-driving car company that belongs to GOOGL
column5: claims that one of Uber's employees stole technology from it and used it for the company's own self-driving car efforts. The company says this employee is Anthony Levandowski.Anthony Levandowski is the founder of Otto. Otto is a self-driving car startup that was created in 2016. Uber bought this startup in 2016 and added Levandowski to its team. Levandowski was a previous employee of the GOOGL car company before founding Otto.According to Waymo
column6: Anthony Levandowski downloaded more than14
column7: 000 confidential and proprietary design filesfor its hardware systems six weeks before resigning from the GOOGL company. Among those files were the company's design data for its LiDAR system.Waymo says that it has decided to file a lawsuit against Uber after receiving an email from one of its suppliers. The supplier makes parts for the GOOGL company's LiDAR system. In the email was a picture of a circuit board for Uber's own LiDAR technology. Waymo says this circuit board looked incredibly like the one it created for its own LiDAR system.Waymo says that after conducting some research
column8: it has discovered that other former employees also downloaded confidential information from the company. These employees now work for Uber and Otto. The GOOGL company claims this was an organized act to steal its trade secrets and intellectual property.Waymo also claims that Anthony Levandowski expressed his desire to ""replicate"" the company's technology as a rival. It claims he told employees of this plan months before his retirement.More From InvestorPlace7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You Deserve7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All Worlds10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayThe postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Sues Uber Over Allegedly Stolen Technologyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column2: alleging intellectual property theft and patent violation.In a lawsuit filed Thursday in San Francisco federal court

column4: Anthony Levandowski
column5: had downloaded over 14
column6: 000 highly confidential and proprietary files before leaving to work at his newly formed self-driving truck company Otto.Waymo claimed that Levandowski downloaded 9.7 GB of confidential files and trade secrets consisting of design files
column7: blue prints and test documentation from a Google-issued laptop to an external drive and formatted the laptop to delete forensic fingerprints.Waymo also alleged other Google employees who joined Otto to have stolen trade secrets. The company claims that without those stolen stuff

QuoteStemmed from an Accidental CC-ingA supplier had mistakenly included a Waymo employee on an e-mail chain that was supposed to be delivered to the Uber team. The attached ""OTTO FILES"" comprised a drawing of a self-driving car Light Detection And Ranging (LIDAR) circuit board quite similar to the one Waymo has been developing secretly.Waymo's lawsuit states that ""The sudden resignations from Waymo

column12: and Uber's near-immediate acquisition of Otto for more than half a billion dollars all caused Waymo grave concern regarding the possible misuse of its intellectual property.""Reigniting the ConflictThe two camps once lived in harmony. Alphabet executive David Drummond joined Uber's board in 2013 when Alphabet's venture capital arm GV

The company has opened a technology center in Pittsburgh and hired some robotics specialists from Carnegie Mellon University. It also collaborated with automakers such as Volvo and acquired Otto.Google on the other hand launched a pilot project that enables carpooling in San Francisco Bay Area. Available through Google-owned maps app

Drummond stepped down from Uber's board last year.The lawsuit certainly complicates the ongoing clash between two of the early leaders in the autonomous vehicle space. column1: Facebook (FB) Launches Mid Roll Video Ads Beta Testing;2/24/2017;"Facebook IncFBsaid that it will now insert mid roll ads in its video content but as a  ""beta test"" for the time being.In a blog post
column2: Facebook said ""We want to help our partners monetize their premium video content
column3: both on Facebook and on their own websites and apps. The company further stated ""As the name implies
column4: Ad Breaks allows creators to take short breaks for ads during their live videos. When a broadcaster chooses to take an ad break
column5: people watching the video will see an in-stream ad of up to 15 seconds in length. The broadcaster will earn a share of the resulting ad revenue.""Facebook added that the feature will now be accessible to more Live creators. Only Pages and profiles with over 2k followers and 300 Plus views for recent live video can beta test mid roll ads. The first ad break can be taken only after the video has been live for a minimum of four minutes and for more ad breaks
column6: there has to be at least a gap of five minutes between each ad break. Ad breaks will last up to 20 seconds. Ad breaks beta testing will be available only in the U.S for the time being.Analysts observe that ever since Facebook has opted out of pre-roll ads
column7: most publishers haven't been able to earn money from their videos on the social networking platform. Plus
column8: it has kept sports publishers from running ""valuable content"" on the platform.  With mid roll ads
column9: Facebook is giving publishers an opportunity to make more money. Reports add that Facebook will share revenues with publishers in a 45:55 ratio
column10: similar to that of Alphabet'sGOOGLYouTube.Facebook is aggressively promoting ""Live"" in order to boost its top line further. Facebook is trying to bring more video content to attract more ad dollars. Ad revenues contribute over 95% to Facebook's total revenue. It intends to capture the opportunity presented by ever increasing video viewing on social media platforms. At its last earnings call
column11: Facebook said that video has emerged as a ""megatrend"" on the same lines as mobile.Facebook

column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Alphabet
column2: Intel
column3: NVIDIA
column4: Baidu and Microsoft;2/24/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - February 24
column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeAlphabet(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report)
column7: Intel(NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report)
column8: NVIDIA(NASDAQ:NVDA-Free Report)
column9: Baidu(NASDAQ:BIDU-Free Report) andMicrosoft(NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report).Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Thursday's Analyst   Blog:Google Finds 'Waze' to Build Self-Driving TechnologyWhen asked some time back about the use cases for self-driving cars
column11: Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) executives said that they were exploring alternatives. Things have changed somewhat since then and we have slightly greater clarity on whether Google will maintain its own fleet
column12: renting out for delivery of goods
column13: food and/or passenger transport
column14: or whether it will rent vehicles from their makers and sell those services itself.My bet was always on the latter
column15: first because Google is primarily a technology company and thrives on making the kind of software that can take over our lives. Getting into the low-margin business of vehicle maintenance and renting just isn't its area of expertise.Furthermore
column16: the kind of investment that is going into getting these animals on the road isn't justified unless there is a lucrative business out there with a relatively quick payback time.So the company's initial step toward commercialization by getting key people on board and announcing the name of the unit as Waymo was heartening. The goal of this unit is to develop self-driving technology for car makers.How Does All This Tie In with the Waze Carpool   Service?Waze was an Israeli crowd-sourced mapping service providing users with information such as traffic
column17: road conditions and other helpful pointers
column18: so they could quickly decide their route. At least that's what it was in 2013 when Google acquired it for $1.15 billion.Today
column19: Waze is also a carpooling service that gets people travelling in the same direction to travel together and share the cost of gas. So yes
column20: there are headaches to availing the service like having to book way in advance or not having anybody to pick one up on occasion. It also doesn't allow anyone to become a driver
column21: so they can't make a living from it.All this goes to show that Google's plans in the area probably aren't crystallized and the service is a temporary measure to access that all-important thing these days called data. Data that can add to the treasure trove Google's already collecting through the test driving of its self-driving cars.The difficulties don't seem to have deterred users
column22: however
column23: because Google just announced the expansion of the service to unannounced locations in the U.S. and Latin America. And while not all Waze users are signing up for carpooling
column24: it's significant that their numbers have reportedly swelled from 45 million in 2013 to 75 million today. So even if a small percentage of this growing number of people goes for it
column25: it can still be a compelling number.Taxi Service Is What Uber
column26: Lyft Do WellThere's no doubt about it
column27: these two companies have been growing in leaps and bounds as the convenience and quality of service have attracted more and more people. So the prospect of other
column28: perhaps cheaper (because a self-driving car doesn't need a driver) services coming online certainly isn't good news.Google was an initial investor in Uber
column29: but when the company started developing self-driving technology to save its neck
column30: Google representative David Drummond removed himself from its board. Uber still uses Google mapping services
column31: but has increased investments to develop maps of its own.ConclusionUber and its pals have popularized the concept of ride-hailing/car-sharing services but now that the concept has caught on
column32: there will be new entrants. This is a big opportunity for car makers because this is the space where new cars will be deployed in the future.On the technology side
column33: there is the need for machine learning and cloud support
column34: mapping technology
column35: and sensors
column36: which have to be installed on cars built to house the technology. And that's exactly why companies like Intel (NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report) are tying up with companies like Mobileye
column37: while NVIDIA (NASDAQ:NVDA-Free Report) pairs up with Baidu (NASDAQ:BIDU-Free Report) and Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report). Then of course there's Google. These companies are in turn testing the technology through collaboration agreements with automakers.But who will get there first? Industry watchers don't expect anything viable until 2020. Even if it's a couple of years out from there
column38: it does look like there will be more than one approach/technology driving the experience. And since the possibilities are tremendous
column39: there won't necessarily be a single winner.Google
