column1: Facebook Inc Stock (FB) Pulls Back After Another High: Now What?;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(FB) stock apparently hit a ceiling when it touched yetanother record high- the second record high in less than a month.makeArticleAd();FB shares soared to $136.79 on Wednesday before retreating on Thursday. The previous all-time high for Facebook stock was $135.49
column3: which was set on February 2.Facebook's Stock Move is Just Part of a Wider Tech TrendFB shares also managed a new record closing price on Wednesday at $136.12
column4: ahead of the previous record set on February 8
column5: which was $134.20.As Facebook stock retreated on Thursday
column6: so did most of the other big tech names that have also set record highs this year.Microsoft Corporation(MSFT)
column7: Amazon.com
column8: Inc.(AMZN)
column9: Netflix
column10: Inc.(NFLX)
column11: Alphabet Inc(GOOG) andApple Inc.(AAPL) were all in the red at the time of this writing.And all these big tech names are rising and falling pretty much in tandem with major indices
column12: including theS&P 500
column13: NASDAQ CompositeandDow Jones Industrial Average.Facebook Stock Could Drop Off SoonSo will Facebook stock be able to keep up themomentumfor the near future?Apple Inc. vs. Alphabet Inc: Value or Growth?Seeking Alphacontributor Damon Verial warns that it might not
column14: particularly because it almost always loses in March. He describes himself as ""strongly bullish"" on the name but adds that he only feels ""the urge to write about"" it when he thinks it is overvalued.He says he did call a pullback in Facebook stock in the past when it fell $10 to $123 per share over the four days following his call. Then it fell to $115 over the next two weeks.Of course the stock rallied
column15: as he says it ""always"" will
column16: but he notes that anyone who held through that pullback ""missed a significant buyback opportunity that would have more than accommodated a transition from capital gains tax on long-term holdings to income tax on short-term holdings for most sizable positions.""Verial noted that Facebook Inc (FB) stock has been in overbought territory since the end of January
column17: which means it probably won't take much to set off a downward spiral. He pointed to seasonal patterns in data on the stock showing where it almost always goes in each month.According to him
column18: Facebook stock almost always ends January in the green
column19: and its highest Sharpe ratio also is in January. Average gains during the month stand at 10%.But in February
column20: he said the stock's Sharpe ratio has fallen to zero
column21: making the month neutral. Then in March
column22: the Sharpe ratio turns negative
column23: ""hinting at a significant opportunity cost."" He adds that even long-term holders may find it beneficial to avoid the stock during the worst months
column24: which includes March
column25: May and August. These months aren't usuallyearningsmonths anyway
column26: and they're well after the holiday season at a time when spending on digital advertising starts to fall.He does feel that long is the only ""logical"" position to take on Facebook when looking at it from a long-term fundamental perspective.The postFacebook Stock Pulls Back After Touching Another Record Highappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column27: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" column12: should Apple be successful with its effort
column13: it opens the door to other litigation
column14: not to mention emboldens a similar case being brought against Qualcomm by the Federal Trade Commission.The short version of the story: Apple (and the FTC and the Korea Fair Trade Commission
column15: for that matter) are all arguing the same thing - Qualcomm's business model of licensing its technologies to phonemakers isnot only exorbitant
column16: but unlawfully stifles competition. That's a legal no-no in most any country. The Korea Fair Trade Commission isseeking $873 million for essentially the same.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy and Hold ForeverFor the record
column17: QCOM has lost this argument before. In 2015
column18: thecompany forked over $975 million to Chinafor breaking that country's antitrust laws. Indeed
column19: Qualcomm wasallegedly charging all-encompassing licensing feesto phonemakers that may or may not have needed access to all of the technology in that IP package… another dubious practice.Years of sharp dealing have finally caught up with Qualcomm.The GoodThe irony is
column20: while the company was over-milking its aging patent portfolio
column21: QCOM was also developing some new - and highly marketable - intellectual property.The idea of the Internet of Things (IoT) is an exciting one
column22: but the reality is
column23: the technology and bandwidth needed to meet the need just isn't ready
column24: yet. Or
column25: it wasn't anyway. This week
column26: Qualcommunveiled its 802.11ax technology
column27: which can carry four times the amount of data current Wi-Fi technology carries
column28: but without using any more bandwidth.Qualcomm Technologies VP Rahul Patel explained:It is taking Wi-Fi to a new level from a user-experience point of view. What it is trying to do is prepare the Wi-Fi network
column29: which in many cases is experiencing a lot of congestion
column30: largely because the network is becoming dense and is not able to deal with the amount of traffic.At the same time
column31: the company has created a whole new kind of RF ""front end
column32: or the radio connection between a mobile phone's modem and the transceiver. Not only is it a superior solution to current alternatives
column33: it's a simpler solution that works with a variety of connection protocols
column34: such as LTE and MIMO
column35: by the utilization of modem intelligence.They're not the kind of advances the average consumer cares about
column36: or even understands. With 5G connectivity about to become the norm
column37: however
column38: these little advances are actually big advances that phonemakers will desperately need.Bottom Line for QCOM StockIn simplest terms
column39: the future of QCOM stock lies somewhere between the two ends of this good/bad continuum. One way or another
column40: sooner or later
column41: Qualcomm's business model of leveraging an aging patent portfolio - and doing so in a questionable manner - is going to falter. If the company wants to continue being an IP player
column42: it's going to need some new IP.The question is
column43: will 802.11ax and new RF front-end platforms be enough? It matters
column44: simply becausethe company's licensing and royalty revenue is roughly twice its revenue from outright chip sales.3 Stocks That Could Soar on a Short SqueezeThe answer to this question is a qualified yes; the qualification is the speed with which lawsuits will result in a decision
column45: and the time that will be needed for IoT and 5G to reach critical mass. Odds are good the former will hurt before the latter helps
column46: meaning Qualcomm could be headed for a dry spell
column47: earnings-wise.Still
column48: for the true long-termer who can stomach the ""in the meantime"" volatility
column49: the market may start to appreciate the potential of the distant future now…after a few years of strong bearish pressure.QCOM stock may not be appropriate for grandma's retirement portfolio
column50: but there's little doubt the company's new technologies will be crucial to the next generation of connectivity.As of this writing

column1: Will Your Next New Car Help Build Maps for Self-Driving?;2/23/2017;"Mobileye N.V.(NYSE: MBLY)
column2: an Israeli company that specializes in advanced   driver-safety systems
column3: has begun rolling out a new offering that   will help the self-driving cars of the near future function in   more areas -- and your next new car might be enlisted to   help.The new offering
column4: called Road Experience Management
column5: or ""REM
column6: is a system that will create highly detailed maps that   self-driving cars can use to back up (or double-check) the inputs   from their sensors. It will use data collected by cameras on many   new cars
column7: starting with the 2018 model year.This is a big deal
column8: not just for Mobileye but also for its   customers -- which include nearly all of the world's automakers   -- and people who are hoping to have access to self-driving cars   in the near future.makeArticleAd();Mobileye's chief technology officer
column9: Amnon Shashua
column10: outlined     the company's approach to self-driving in a presentation last     month. Image source: Mobileye N.V.The problem: Self-driving cars need special mapsWhen the first fully self-driving cars arrive on the market in   a few years
column11: their capabilities will be limited. In most cases
column12: the cars will be ""geofenced
column13: restricted to driving in particular   areas. (In the widely used industry nomenclature
column14: these are   called ""Level 4"" systems. ""Level 5"" systems that are self-driving   with no restrictions are probably still many years away.)The cars will be geofenced because most of the self-driving   systems under development require specialized high-definition   maps to work safely. The maps help the car's ""brain"" figure out   exactly where it is relative to things like curbs and road   barriers
column15: providing a layer of redundancy beyond the car's   sensors. (That may sound
column16: well
column17: redundant. But it's critical to   ensuring that self-driving systems meet the required standards of   safety.)Obviously
column18: the companies that can access the best and most   extensive maps will have a competitive advantage. Cars equipped   with their systems will be able to drive themselves to more   places. That means that the race is on not only to create maps   covering the widest possible areas
column19: but to create ways to ensure   that the maps are always up to date.Mobileye has a direct stake in this race. It's gearing up to   bring aLevel 4 system to market by the end of 2019
column20: in partnership withDelphi Automotive(NYSE: DLPH) andIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) . That system will be marketed to automakers
column21: who   will probably be able to have it in showrooms (or in service with   ride-hailing companies) by about 2021.This self-driving test vehicle incorporates a prototype of     the system being developed by Delphi
column22: Mobileye
column23: and Intel.     Image source: Delphi Automotive PLC.The partners will almost certainly have competition from   companies likeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Waymo unit
column24: Ford Motor Company's(NYSE: F)Argo AI subsidiary-- and likely others.Mobileye's Road Experience Management initiative is intended   to make sure that its Level 4 offering is as complete
column25: and as   compelling
column26: as possible. And your next new car might help.How Mobileye will build -- and profit from -- the mapsThe idea behind REM is that Mobileye can use the cameras on   existing cars as a low-cost way to harvest the data needed to   make the maps
column27: as well as other information that will be useful   to self-driving cars. Many new cars have front-facing cameras   that are used for adaptive cruise control
column28: lane-departure   warnings
column29: and other advanced driver-assist systems (or ""ADAS"") --   and many of those camera-based systems were sold to the   automakers by Mobileye.In recent months
column30: Mobileye has been reaching out to its   automaker clients
column31: inviting them to join the REM effort by   allowing data from their vehicles to be collected. In exchange
column32: Mobileye is offering a share of the revenue it expects to   generate from selling that data to mapmaking companies.So far
column33: Volkswagen AGandBMW AGhave signed up to allow REM to gather data from their vehicles
column34: starting in the 2018 model year. Duringthis past week's earnings call
column35: Mobileye's CTO Amnon Shashua said that his company expects to   announce a third deal within a few weeks
column36: and to have the   majority of its automaker partners signed up by the end of 2017.   (These deals include extensive privacy safeguards; the data won't   be linked to specific car owners.)Shashua explained how revenue will be generated from the REM   effort:We believe revenue will be generated from two separate     products [of REM]. One is the map
column37: which is a critical input to     autonomous vehicle systems. The other is a broad set of     real-time dynamic information such as traffic density
column38: weather     conditions and open parking spots. We expect the primary     customers for each of these products to be mapmakers
column39: and we     recently announced engagements with both [high-definition     mapping company] HERE and the Japanese mapping company     Zenrin.The upshot: An important step as the self-driving race shapes   upAssuming that a majority of the world's major automakers do in   fact join the REM program
column40: Mobileye's effort stands to put its   venture with Delphi and Intel in a strong competitive position as   the market for self-driving systems takes shape.I've argued that the idea of a ""race"" to self-driving   technologyisn't a useful way for investors to think. Level 4 systems will be available to all automakers within four   or five years; there won't be much advantage to the company that   comes to market first. We won't be able to think in terms of   ""winners"" until the details of the different offerings become   clear.That process is starting. REM makes it likely that the   Delphi-Mobileye-Intel offering will have access to maps that   allow it to operate in many areas of the world
column41: right from the   start. For investors
column42: that makes the success of the partners'   system more likely
column43: and an investment in Mobileye -- the purest   play of the three -- a little more compelling.10 stocks we like better than MobileyeWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column44: it can pay to listen. After all
column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column46: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column47: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Mobileye wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column49: an executive at Alphabet
column50: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.John Rosevearowns shares of Ford. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Alphabet (A and C shares) and Ford. The Motley Fool     recommends BMW and Intel. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Google Finds 'Waze' to Build Self-Driving Technology;2/23/2017;"When asked some time back about the use cases for self-driving cars
column2: AlphabetGOOGLexecutives said that they were exploring alternatives. Things have changed somewhat since then and we have slightly greater clarity on whether Google will maintain its own fleet
column3: renting out for delivery of goods
column4: food and/or passenger transport
column5: or whether it will rent vehicles from their makers and sell those services itself.My bet was always on the latter
column6: first because Google is primarily a technology company and thrives on making the kind of software that can take over our lives. Getting into the low-margin business of vehicle maintenance and renting just isn't its area of expertise.Furthermore
column7: the kind of investment that is going into getting these animals on the road isn't justified unless there is a lucrative business out there with a relatively quick payback time.So the company's initial step toward commercialization by getting key people on board and announcing the name of the unit as Waymo was heartening. The goal of this unit is to develop self-driving technology for car makers.How Does All This Tie In with the Waze Carpool Service?Waze was an Israeli crowd-sourced mapping service providing users with information such as traffic
column8: road conditions and other helpful pointers
column9: so they could quickly decide their route. At least that's what it was in 2013 when Google acquired it for $1.15 billion.Today
column10: Waze is also a carpooling service that gets people travelling in the same direction to travel together and share the cost of gas. So yes
column11: there are headaches to availing the service like having to book way in advance or not having anybody to pick one up on occasion. It also doesn't allow anyone to become a driver
column12: so they can't make a living from it.All this goes to show that Google's plans in the area probably aren't crystallized and the service is a temporary measure to access that all-important thing these days called data. Data that can add to the treasure trove Google's already collecting through the test driving of its self-driving cars.The difficulties don't seem to have deterred users
column13: however

column15: it's significant that their numbers have reportedly swelled from 45 million in 2013 to 75 million today. So even if a small percentage of this growing number of people goes for it
column16: it can still be a compelling number.Taxi Service Is What Uber
column17: Lyft Do WellThere's no doubt about it
column18: these two companies have been growing in leaps and bounds as the convenience and quality of service have attracted more and more people. So the prospect of other
column19: perhaps cheaper (because a self-driving car doesn't need a driver) services coming online certainly isn't good news.Google was an initial investor in Uber
column20: but when the company started developing self-driving technology to save its neck
column21: Google representative David Drummond removed himself from its board. Uber still uses Google mapping services
column22: but has increased investments to develop maps of its own.ConclusionUber and its pals have popularized the concept of ride-hailing/car-sharing services but now that the concept has caught on
column23: there will be new entrants. This is a big opportunity for car makers because this is the space where new cars will be deployed in the future.On the technology side
column24: there is the need for machine learning and cloud support
column25: mapping technology
column26: and sensors
column27: which have to be installed on cars built to house the technology. And that's exactly why companies like IntelINTCare tying up with companies like Mobileye
column28: while NVIDIANVDApairs up with BaiduBIDUand MicrosoftMSFT. Then of course there's Google. These companies are in turn testing the technology through collaboration agreements with automakers.But who will get there first? Industry watchers don't expect anything viable until 2020. Even if it's a couple of years out from there
column29: it does look like there will be more than one approach/technology driving the experience. And since the possibilities are tremendous
column30: there won't necessarily be a single winner.Google

column1: Is Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) In a Dividend Aristocrat Bubble?;2/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn May 23
column4: one of the greatest financial bubbles in the history of the world kicked off when the Compagnie Perpetuelle des Indes was granted a monopoly by the French monarchy over all the trading rights of all French colonies worldwide.makeArticleAd();The company's stock price quickly soared
column5: from 300 livres per share to more than 1
column6: 000 just a few months later. It was quite a jump. But the enthusiasm continued for more than 18-months.In fact there was such a frenzy to buy shares that it wasn't uncommon for the stock price to double in a single day. By November
column7: share price had surpassed 10
column8: 000.Based on modern-day calculations
column9: a share price of 10
column10: 000 livres would have valued the company at more than the entire GDP of France at the time.That would be likeAlphabet Inc(GOOGL) orAmazon.com
column11: Inc.(AMZN) having a $20 TRILLION stock market capitalization today. Insane.As with all bubbles throughout history
column12: that one burst as well… quickly and violently. Call it 'reversion to the mean'. Stein's Law. Or just plain old common sense.It's pretty simple- there are certain anomalies that are too absurd to last. And nature always finds a way to correct them.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveWhile it's nowhere near as extreme as the Compagnie Perpetuelle des Indes
column13: the market today is also in a completely unsustainable position.I'll show you what I mean-Take a look atExxon Mobil Corporation(XOM); it's one of the largest companies in the world and a favorite among investors due to its 3.7% dividend yield.Quarter after quarter
column14: Exxon Mobile has been paying dividends to its shareholders without fail for decades
column15: even at the peak of the financial crisis.Not only that
column16: but the company has generally increased its dividend each year as well. To stock investors
column17: that kind of consistency is a gold mine. But there's a small problem.For the last several years
column18: Exxon has been borrowing money in order to maintain its dividend payments. Last month
column19: for example
column20: the company reported $26.4 billion in cashflow from its business operations during 2016.But in order to maintain the business
column21: the company had to spend $16.7 billion on what's known in finance as ""capital expenditures"" or ""capex"". Capex is critical to a big business like Exxon Mobil; every year they have to replace old machinery
column22: purchase more land
column23: etc.If they don't do these things
column24: the business will suffer and revenues will decline. So after subtracting the capex
column25: Exxon Mobil had $9.7 billion remaining in ""free cash flow"".Not bad.Except that
column26: according to the company
column27: they paid $12.5 billion in dividends.Hang on a sec. How is it possible that the company could pay $12.5 billion in dividends when they only had $9.7 billion in free cash flow remaining after the capex spending?Easy. They went into debt. Exxon borrowed billions of dollars in order to pay its shareholders a healthy dividend. And they've been doing this for years. Exxon Mobil is FAR from alone.Verizon Communications Inc.(VZ) is another shining example: in 2016
column28: the company earned $22.7 billion from its business operations
column29: but had $17.1 billion worth of capex. That left $5.6 billion remaining. Yet Verizon paid $9.3 billion in dividends.Once again
column30: the company took on billions of dollars in additional debt.This has been a major trend across the biggest companies in the market.There's nothing wrong with debt; sometimes it can be a smart move that creates value for the company.Our manufacturing business in Australia recently took on some debt to buy some new equipment
column31: for example. It's been a great decision; we're able to generate more revenue with less cost
column32: so the overall growth in our profit is multiples greater than the interest payment.But borrowing billions of dollars just to pay out what amounts to sham dividends is a complete waste of money… and irresponsible.It also means that these record high stock prices are artificial
column33: based on debt-fueled dividends and share buybacks instead of healthy free cash flow.This is totally unsustainable.In addition
column34: with an average P/E ratio of 26.5
column35: stock valuations are at their highest level since the financial crisis; it's yet another layer of risk in this market.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayFew people ever got rich buying what was popular and expensive. But that doesn't stop anyone from trying.Sometimes the hardest thing to do is wait patiently on the sidelines.But successful people don't follow the crowd. They get out in front of the crowd
column36: even if it means being early.The postDividend Aristocrat Bubble?appeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column37: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" column17: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks

column1: 2 Reasons Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Is Even More Enticing;2/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA) shares continue to move closer to all-time highs thanks to impressive continued growth in China and new international markets. BABA stock is certainly not done running and has a promising future with the company's Cloud division and international expansion.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAlibaba Australia is the latest in a series of moves to diversify away from China and the company's core business line.BABA opened a headquarters for its Australia/New Zealand operations in Melbourne. The headquarters will help the company expand its already strong relationship with Australia and continue to expand its Cloud offerings outside of China. Alibaba plans on building this headquarters to create operating infrastructure
column3: online payments and cloud computing.Why Alibaba Australia Is Good News for BABABusinesses in Australia and New Zealand have beenusingAlibaba and its Tmall store to get its products into Asia. More than 1
column4: 300 Australian brands and 400 brands from New Zealand have products on Tmall. For many of these brands
column5: Tmall was their entry point for China. Australia ranks as the fourth-highest selling country on Tmall
column6: showing the strength of the relationship between it and China.Along with the introduction of a headquarters in Australia
column7: the company hascollaboratedwith Australia Post. This deal will strengthen trade between Australia and Southeast Asia
column8: and ultimately strengthen BABA stock as well. The deal centers around Lazada Group
column9: an Alibaba majority owned subsidiary
column10: that will help bring Australia Post to regions like Malaysia
column11: Singapore and Indonesia. Lazada provides merchants direct access to more than 560 million consumers in six countries.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowBrands like Chemist Warehouse
column12: Swisse
column13: and Balckmores areamongthe top brands selling on Tmall from Australia. Popular categories that have helped Australia see strong Chinese sales are health and nutrition
column14: milk power
column15: snacks
column16: coffee and instant beverages.BABA is heavily investing in Australia
column17: with attention being paid to cloud computing and also the selling of goods between Asia and Australia. Alibaba is also actively exploring the real estate market of Australia
column18: which could represent the e-commerce giant's early intentions to take on another area of revenue.The company is considering selling apartments and also facilitating payments for deposits or settlements of apartments through its Alipay payment service. This is just another example of BABA stock spreading itself into new areas through its already existing strengths.The Cloud Computing segment for Alibaba still makes up a fraction of its revenue. However
column19: this unit is fast growing and the company believes it can outpace current worldwide leaderAmazon.com
column20: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). In the last fullfiscal year
column21: the Cloud Computing segment made up $648 million in revenue. Compare that to the company's Core Commerce division and its $14.7 billion revenue and it doesn't look like much.The investments made by Alibaba in its Cloud division continue to represent the number one reason to buy BABA stock. Alibaba hasplacednew facilities in four regions to help boost its Cloud division. New Cloud facilities are in the United Arab Emirates
column22: Australia
column23: Japan and Germany.In four years
column24: the company believes it can overtake AMZN as the No.1 cloud provider in the world. Alibaba currently ranks first in China and in the top five worldwide.BABA stock recieved some major positive news for the Cloud division
column25: when itsigneda 12-year deal to provide cloud services to the Olympic Games. This deal also covers an e-commerce platform to sell Olympic branded goods. Alibaba is now able to use its dominance in both commerce and cloud to attract new customers and countries for expansion. BABA will also optimize an Olympics Channel for the Chinese audience.Bottom Line on BABA StockThe financial performance of the company's Cloud division continues to amaze and might explain some of the recent gains. In the recent quarter
column26: overall revenue was up 54%. The company's main Core Commerce division gained 45% from the prior year. Cloud revenue grew a brilliant 115%.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still a Top Tech StockAnother key driver for growth is international commerce
column27: which grew 288% from the prior year. Take what you learned from the company's focus and investment on Australia and both of those great growth figures are headed even higher in 2017.BABA stock investors seem to be missing how important this deal in Australia is and the company's recent cloud infrastructure expansion in new international markets are. China's e-commerce continues to grow and Alibaba is a clear winner. The company is not standing still and staying content with just that growth. China is attacking a high-growth cloud market and will come out victorious.BABA stock has performed well over the last year
column28: rising 54%. Alibaba shares are up 17% in the short 2017 year
column29: yet BABA stock is still up only 10% from its highly valued IPO.With the company's expansion beyond China and just being an online retailer
column30: Alibaba is a big buy for investors. I was bullish nearly a year ago sharing BABA stock as away to investin the growth of the Chinese movie business. That remains true today and with the focus on cloud computing
column31: investors have even more reason to buy this Chinese giant.As of this writing
column32: Chris Katje did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Consumer Stocks That Will Knock Your Socks Off7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears StrikeThe post2 Reasons Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Is Even More Enticingappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still a Top Tech Stock;2/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI'm a firm believer inAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL). In the markets
column4: there is an elite group of companies that define their respective industries. For example
column5: Amazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) owns e-commerce
column7: whileFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) has forever changed social media. And for now
column8: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is the king of smart devices. But in my humble opinion
column9: GOOGL stock tops them all.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockDon't get me wrong as this is not a slight against any of the above companies. Just let me forward a very basic observation - all these other names essentially require the internet to function. If not directly
column10: then certainly
column11: access to the internet represents their core marketing message.But what happens when you own the internet? That's a theoretical question to everyone except GOOGL.As I mentioned in a prior contribution
column12: thedominanceof the GOOGL search engine is unparalleled. The margin between Alphabet Inc and the next biggest competitor
column13: Bing
column14: is a whopping 300%. It just gets worse as you go down the rankings. By the time you hit fifth place
column15: it's just not even worth considering. In any other industry
column16: such a statement would be the death knell for the competition.Essentially
column17: GOOGL stock is an investment in life itself. Many people thought that thename changeto Alphabet - a play on the financial term ""alpha"" and the gambling term ""bet"" - was cheeky and a bit ridiculous. But it also signified that Alphabet Inc could do whatever it wants because no one can stop it. GOOGL stock was essentially either an asset or a threat
column18: depending on your perspective.Volatility Is a Risk to GOOGL StockUnfortunately
column19: where it matters most for investors
column20: GOOGL stock hasn't always shown its best stuff. True
column21: it's early into 2017
column22: and so far
column23: it's up over 4% year-to-date. Keep that up every month and you're guaranteed a stellar annual return. But Alphabet Inc has also beeninconsistent
column24: as InvestorPlace contributor Chris Tyler points out. For example
column25: GOOGL was looking at closing January at over 6%. Instead
column26: it only secured 1.4%.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowOn a strictly nominal basis
column27: that's not much of a swing. But on percentage basis
column28: it's a much different story. It has been well over a decade since Alphabet stock introduced itself to the markets. The crazy dynamics involved in a fresh tech company should be over by now. Today
column29: GOOGL and its subsidiaries are comparable toGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE) if GE was a little more hip.But with great size comes great envy. Alphabet Inc now faces a fundamental problem.Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) wants to reengage acourt rulingthat went in favor of GOOGL. At issue is the company's generous use of Oracle's Java software in order to design the Android operating system. GOOGL contends that using Java - which is open-source - is fair game. Oracle contends that it violates the ""fair use "" component of copyright law.For those that acquired GOOGL stock
column30: it's an ugly situation that might be a legitimate risk. Here's the thing - whether it's legitimate or not doesn't matter. If the markets think it's a problem
column31: it's a problem. That makes the sighting of what appears to be a bearish head-and-shoulders pattern (between early December until now) a curious development.Don't Panic on Alphabet IncGenerally
column32: it's not the best idea to buy an investment with baggage. Certainly
column33: it's not a good idea when the baggage is from a giant company like Oracle. Ditto that for its 6'3″ CEO that doesn't come off as someone you want to mess with. In other words
column34: GOOGL stock has some challenges.3 Struggling Stocks That Could Make Epic RunsI also don't think it's a coincidence that the head-and-shoulders pattern is emerging right now. If I'm looking at Alphabet Inc purely as a swing trade
column35: I wouldn't go full bore at this juncture. I expect shares to at least test its 50-day moving average
column36: which stands just under $800. It would not shock me
column37: however
column38: to see GOOGL stock slide towards its 200-day moving average
column39: which is around $763.Again
column40: that's looking at Alphabet Inc from a short-term perspective. For those that have a wider time horizon
column41: the king of the internet is as strong technically as it is fundamentally. Aside from some bumps in the road
column42: GOOGL stock is enjoying clear blue skies. Most importantly
column43: those bumps have never affected Alphabet Inc in a permanent way.The bottom line here is that I would be content holding GOOGL stock. Further
column44: any dips are justifiable buying opportunities
column45: not mere contrarianism for its own sake. Alphabet Inc isgoing to $1
column46: 000- just try to ignore the turbulence as best you can.As of this writing
column47: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Consumer Stocks That Will Knock Your Socks Off7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears StrikeThe postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Is Still a Top Tech Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Will Driverless Cars End Traditional Car Ownership?;2/23/2017;"I bought a used car recently
column2: and a few days after I brought   it home
column3: a friend asked me
column4: ""Do you think this is the last car   you'll ever buy?""We talk a lot about self-driving cars
column5: so I knew exactly where   he was going with his question. He was hinting at the   fact that both autonomous car technologies and ride-sharing   services are advancing so quickly that by the time I'd be in   the market for another vehicle
column6: I might not actually need to buy   one.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();By 2035
column7: the IHS estimates there will be 76 million cars on   the road worldwide with some level of autonomy.Even now
column8: semi-autonomous cars that can keep themselves in   their lanes
column9: automatically brake in emergency situations
column10: and   slow down to match the speed of the car in front of themcan be purchasedfor as little as $20
column11: 000.And as genuinely driverless cars get cheaper and become   ubiquitous
column12: you and I may opt out of monthly car payments and   opt-in to a monthly mileage subscription service instead.Automakers are investing in this futureTo understand how it's possible that we could soon live in a   world where most people don't own cars
column13: we need to look no   further than what the automakers themselves are doing.Elon Musk's recently updated version ofTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA)  master plan includes details on a new   service: When the company's vehicles become fully autonomous (by   2018 or 2019
column14: according to Musk)
column15: Tesla owners will be able to   allow their vehicles to drive themselves around and be rented out   by other people.As Musk wrote:You will also be able to add your car to the Tesla shared     fleet just by tapping a button on the Tesla phone app and have     it generate income for you while you're at work or on vacation
column16: significantly offsetting and at times potentially exceeding the     monthly loan or lease cost.Image source: Tesla.Musk also said that Tesla would deploy its own fleet of   driverless vehicles for rent in areas where there was more demand   for Tesla vehicles than privately owned cars could meet
column17: so that    ""you can always hail a ride from us no matter where you   are."" Remember
column18: this isn't the catchphrase of a taxi company
column19: nor   even a ride-hailing service -- but rather the direction where   Musk sees his automaker headed.And just in case think this mentality is unique to the   innovative Tesla
column20: consider whatGeneral Motors(NYSE: GM)  is doing. The giant automaker launched a   ride-sharing service last year called Maven
column21: which allows some GM   owners to rent out their vehicles when they're not in use. The   cars don't drive themselves yet
column22: but the company sees it as a   first step toward a future where people are less inclined to own   cars.In a press release at the time
column23: GM said that more than 25   million of its customers around the world will use some form of   shared mobility by 2020
column24: and describe Maven as ""a key element of   our strategy to changing ownership models in the automotive   industry."" Maven has spread to 17 cities across North America in   just 11 months
column25: has 22
column26: 000 members
column27: and has been used for 57   million miles of driving.Not to be outdone
column28: Ford(NYSE: F) has launched i ts own ride-sharing service
column29: and is   developing autonomous cars just like GM. Ford has made it clear   that it intends to launch a ""high-volume"" driverless car paired   with ride-hailing and ride-sharing services by 2021. The   company is already testing 30 self-driving Fusion Hybrids in   several states
column30: and plans to triple the number of test vehicles   this year.Other automakers are moving in this direction as well.Fiat Chrysler(NYSE: FCAU) is working withAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google to test a fleet of 100   self-driving minivans that will be the basis for aride-hailing serviceset to launch later this year. It's still unclear what the   service will look like
column31: or if Fiat Chrysler will play a critical   role in it
column32: but what is clear is that the automaker believes in   the viability of Waymo's cars-as-a-service goal.Will this really end car ownership?It's hard to answer this question conclusively
column33: of course.   After all
column34: most people haven't even seen a fully autonomous   vehicle on the road
column35: let alone ridden in one.But John Zimmer
column36: the co-founder and president of   ride-hailing company Lyft
column37: believes thatby 2025 ""private car ownership will all-but end in major U.S.   cities."" Lyft expects the majority of its vehicles to be   self-driving by 2021
column38: and rival Uber is testing similar   strategies as well.Others have set similar timelines for the demise of car   ownership. Georg Bauer
column39: who has held executive positions at   Daimler

column1: Mobileye NV Q4 Earnings Are Good Enough for Now
column2: But …;2/22/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI've long thoughtMobileye NV(NYSE:MBLY) is too expensive. Mobileye has an interesting opportunity in driver assistance
column4: and eventually
column5: autonomous driving. But it also has intense competition from companies ranging fromNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) toAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) to Tier 1 suppliers likeDelphi Automotive PLC(NYSE:DLPH) andAutoliv Inc.(NYSE:ALV). But I haven't shorted MBLY stock - yet - and I hardly thought Mobileye's fourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday presented an opportunity.makeArticleAd();Source:U.S. Embassy Tel Aviv via FlickrAfter all
column6: MBLY is a story stock
column7: and the story looked strong heading into Mobileye earnings. A series of deals and partnerships announced in the past few weeks led MBLY stock up 35% from late December lows. Optimism around autonomous driving and increasing automotive technology continues to rise; there's a reasonTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) stock is near all-time highs. Betting against that in the short-term seemed foolish.That story appears to hold for a little while longer
column8: as Mobileye earnings out Wednesday morning came in ahead of consensus estimates and the company's own guidance. In response
column9: MBLY stock reversed from modest gains to modest losses back to 2%-plus gains again in premarket trading. That seems to imply that investors already are looking forward.But it's there the Mobileye story might have some holes.Mobileye Earnings Look SolidMobileye earnings for Q4 beat both Street consensus and its own guidance on the top and bottom line. Revenue of $104.6 million
column10: in particular
column11: looks impressive. MBLY had guided for roughly $96 million coming out of Q3 in moving expectations to the high end of a full-year $344 million-$350 million range. Heading into the earnings report
column12: analysts largely backed those projections.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowThe beat
column13: then
column14: implies growth roughly 11 points higher than thought
column15: with revenue growing almost 46% year-over-year.The driver (no pun intended) appears to be aftermarket sales. Those sales - largely dash-mounted systems on existing cars
column16: rather than installed systems in new cars - increased 156% year-over-year. MBLY management had raised full-year projections for that division after Q2 to 20% of total sales. In fact
column17: Q4 Mobileye earnings show the aftermarket drove 23% of full-year revenue
column18: with sales increasing 113% for full-year 2016.Earnings per share beat consensus and implied guidance by 2 cents
column19: which implies that profit margins were roughly as expected. The reason likely is that aftermarket sales offer lower gross margins
column20: and thus aren't quite as profitable. MBLY has improved gross margins in the business
column21: but mix seems like the most significant reason why the company didn't better leverage sales growth.Long-Term Questions Remain for MBLY StockThe fact that the revenue beat came from aftermarket growth isn't quite the outcome that Mobileye stock bulls would have preferred for Q4.The exciting business here is in OEM
column22: from both the standpoint of market opportunity and profit margins. While 113% growth for aftermarket sales is nothing to sneeze at
column23: it's still off a rather small base. And $82 million in aftermarket sales for 2016
column24: on its own
column25: isn't near enough to support a stock with an enterprise value over $10 billion.That seems to mean investors are looking forward. 2017 guidance on the conference call is for EPS of $1.01-$1.05 and revenue of $490 million-$505 million. Earnings appear just shy of analyst estimates of $1.04
column26: while revenue of $490 million-$505 million suggests an outperformance to Street expectations of $491 million.That combination
column27: however
column28: means margins will be a bit lower than forecast by analysts. That
column29: in turn
column30: likely comes from a higher-than-expected proportion of aftermarket revenue - again
column31: not what the bulls necessarily wanted to hear.And that may be enough for some of the long-term concerns to enter the narrative in MBLY stock in post-earnings trading.Looking ForwardMorgan Stanley downgraded Mobileye stock at the beginning of the month based on margin concerns - a move that took MBLY stock down 3%. And the ability of Mobileye to maintain margins is a big concern of mine
column32: longer-term.I'm still skeptical that any semiconductor company can hold pricing (and thus margins) longer-term. One of the few exceptions
column33: of course
column34: is Nvidia itself. But Mobileye stock
column35: now trading at ~45x 2017 EPS
column36: still is priced higher than NVDA
column37: and part of Nvidia's huge gains over the past year have come from optimism over prospects for its Drive PX 2 platform.How to Trade Facebook Inc for 470% ReturnsThat platform is what Tesla turned to after its relationship ended with Mobileye (and somewhat acrimoniously). That decision alone illustrates the long-term challenges. Competition will be intense
column38: and pricing will be too. It's important to remember that MBLY is a semiconductor company (though it has software capabilities
column39: admittedly) and an automotive supplier. Neither industry traditionally gets very high earnings multiple
column40: because both businesses are extremely tough.For Mobileye to be an outlier on both fronts
column41: its execution needs to be perfect
column42: and its growth flawless. Mobileye earnings for Q4 show a step in the right direction from that standpoint.But with the earnings beat driven largely by aftermarket sales
column43: that step probably isn't big enough for MBLY stock to take another step higher.As of this writing

column1: Could Apple Inc. (AAPL) Be The First Ever $1 Trillion Company?;2/22/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI stumbled across a prediction last week that would impress even Mad Money's Jim Cramer.makeArticleAd();According to a recent report from Oxfam
column3: an international charitable organization
column4: Bill Gates has a shot at becoming the world's first trillionaire. Oxfam speculates that if the returns on the tech mogul's $75 billion fortune in the next 25 years are similar to those in the last 25 years
column5: Gates has a shot at jumping the $1 trillion mark.That got me thinking
column6: if one man has a shot at becoming a trillionaire
column7: certainly one of theS&P 500′s biggest companies has a shot at becoming the world's first $1 trillion company?Turns out
column8: a few do.I see five S&P 500 companies with a shot at breaking the $1 trillion mark in the next five years.-Facebook Inc(FB) is the smallest company on the list with a market cap of $386 billion. Facebook's share price would need to hit $345
column9: up 159%.-Amazon.com
column10: Inc.(AMZN) has a market cap of $400 billion. Shares would need to hit $1
column12: up 125%.-Microsoft Corporation(MSFT) has a market cap of $498 billion. Shares would need to hit $130
column13: up 100%.-Alphabet Inc(GOOG) is currently worth $570 billion. Shares would need to hit $1
column15: up 70%.I believe every one of these companies will eventually be worth $1 trillion. However
column16: one other company will beat them all to it.Thanks to a variety of factors
column17: Apple Inc.(AAPL) is set to become the first $1 trillion company in the world in the next five years.The company has been on a roll. After beating fourth-quarter earnings by 4%
column18: shares just hit a new all-time high above $135.That gives Apple a market cap of $710 billion
column19: making it the largest company in the S&P 500. It has also placed Apple within striking distance of the $1 trillion mark. Shares of Apple would only need to climb 50% to $200 to give it a market cap of $1 trillion.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThat is well within reach.If its current valuation stayed the same
column20: Apple would need to grow earnings by 8% annually in the next five years to hit that target. As it stands
column21: Apple is expected to grow earnings by 8% this year and another 13% in 2018. Those two years alone get Apple almost half way to 50% earnings growth.But even if Apple's earnings grow slower than expected
column22: it has an ace up its sleeve.Apple Has $246 Billion In Cash On Its Balance SheetApple's cash position is larger than the GDP of most countries. In recent fourth-quarter results
column23: Apple's reported a cash position of $246 billion. Some of that cash is already accounted for in Apple's $700 billion valuation. But not all of it.Using as little as half of its cash balance to repurchase shares adds another $125 billion to Apple's market cap.Apple's Is One Of The Most Undervalued Stocks In The S&P 500Apple is one of the most undervalued stocks in the S&P 500. Its forward P/E ratio of 15 is a discount to the S&P 500s 20. That lower valuation exists despite the fact that Apple is projected to grow earnings faster than the S&P 500 in the next five years.Technically speaking that means Apple should be trading with a higher P/E ratio than the S&P 500. If Apple traded with the same P/E ratio as the S&P 500
column24: shares would shares would climb 25%
column25: giving Apple a market cap of $887 billion.Warren Buffett Just Made A Huge Investment In AppleApple's pursuit of the $1 trillion threshold has attracted the attention of the world's greatest investor. In recent regulatory filings
column26: Berkshire revealed it had quadrupled its ownership in Apple to 57 million shares. Buffett's stake was worth approximately $6.6 billion at the end of 2016.With shares of Apple already up 17% on the year
column27: Buffett has pocketed a quick $1.1 billion gain in less than six weeks.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveRisks To Consider:Apple has struggled to launch new hits in the last few years. Although sales growth in its most important product the iPhone is still strong
column28: Apple isn't the innovative company it was under Steve Jobs.Action To Take:Apple is on pace to become the world's first $1 trillion company. Even though shares are trading at an all-time high
column29: I see plenty of growth and gains ahead. Buy shares anywhere below the all-time high and hold until Apple becomes the first $1 trillion company in the world.Editor's Note:Tech companieshave a history of turning stockholders
column30: secretaries and even janitors into ""overnight"" millionaires.In 2017
column31: innovations in virtual reality will do the same for owners of these 2 stocks…StreetAuthority's mission is to help individual investors earn above-average profits by providing a source of independent

(AAPL) Be The First Ever $1 Trillion Company?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Mark Your Calendars: This Is When You Can Buy the Snap IPO;2/22/2017;"The most highly anticipated IPO of the year finally has a date   set to begin trading.Snap(NYSE: SNAP) will price its shares on March 1after the market closes
column2: which means investors should be able to buy shares on March   2.Snap expects to price its shares between $14 and $16
column3: and it   will sell 200 million shares with 30 million in reserve to raise   as much as $3.7 billion. The share price range represents a   market cap between $19.5 billion and $22.2 billion. That's short   of the $25 billion sources originally reported late last year
column4: and very close to the valuation at which Snap raised funds during   its series F round about nine months ago.How does Snap's IPO pricing compare to competing digital   advertisers
column5: and should investors grab shares on March 2?makeArticleAd();Image source: SnapA look at valuationAt its IPO
column6: Snap will be worth about $21 billion. That's a bit   more thanTwitter(NYSE:TWTR)
column7: but considerably less than ad giantsFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) andAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) .CompanyValuationPrice-to-Sales RatioSnap$21 billion*51.9Twitter$11.7 billion4.6Facebook$386.5 billion14.1Google (C shares)$580.9 billion6.4Data source: Snap S-1/A and Yahoo! Finance *Based on the   midpoint of Snap's expected pricing range.Despite its relatively small valuation
column8: investors will still   be paying a huge premium for Snap based on its sales. Last year
column9: the company brought in just $405 million in revenue. By   comparison
column10: Twitter brought in more than six times as much ($2.5   billion). Snap and its underwriters think a dollar of its sales   is worth more than 10 times as much as Twitter's.Granted
column11: Twitter is expected to see sales declinethis year
column12: while analysts believe Snap could grow revenue around   150%. Still
column13: Snap will trade at a huge premium to the still   rapidly growing Facebook and Alphabet
column14: which are expected to grow   sales 37% and 18%
column15: respectively.But the IPO pricing is still attractiveSnap's IPO pricing is still somewhat attractive however
column16: if but for one reason. It's nearly the same valuation as its last   round of funding. Snap's trailing 12 months of revenue for that   round was just $93.5 million. Snap will IPO at about one-quarter   the multiple of its last funding round.In that light
column17: Snap's price looks much more reasonable. If   some of the smartest venture capitalists were willing to invest   when Snap's latest advertising products were still at their   earliest potential
column18: it may well be worth it for investors now   that Snap has proven those products work. And if they can get it   at the same price
column19: so much the better.You probably won't get Snap shares at $16Unfortunately
column20: it's highly unlikely you'll be able to buy   shares of Snap at its IPO price on March 2. Since its planning to   price shares around the same price as its last round of funding
column21: Snap is potentially setting the stock up for a pop in the stock   price before it opens on the New York Stock Exchange.That's good for Snap. Even though Snap will only receive funds   at the price it sets on March 1
column22: a first-day pop in the stock   price makes it look much more attractive. (Remember what happened   toFacebook stockafter its botched IPO?)Snap itself is only selling 145 million to 175 million shares   of the company's 1.2 billion shares outstanding
column23: so it's not   leaving too much money on the table
column24: either
column25: by keeping its IPO   price low. The other 55 million shares will come from early   investors and company officials.If you're lucky enough to have a broker that's offering you a   chance to get in on the Snap IPO price
column26: it may be worth   considering buying a stake in the company. Even at $16 per share
column27: however

column1: Warren Buffett Might Make These 3 Driverless Car Investing Mistakes;2/22/2017;"Warren Buffett is well-known for having
column2: among the core tenets   of his investment strategy
column3: a preference for companies with   serious ""competitive moats"" -- attributes that give them the   ability to sustainably keep ahead of their competition. But based   on his rues
column4: Buffett would never invest in an emerging industry   like self-driving cars
column5: and his competitive moat ideas don't   necessarily hold water in this world. If you're a fan of the   Oracle of Omaha
column6: beware of following his investment philosophy   into these three mistakes.1. Focusing too much on sizeImage source: Alphabet (Waymo)makeArticleAd();Economies of scale are an important indicator for almost any   company. As the logic goes
column7: the bigger a company is
column8: the greater   its ability to cut per-unit costs.Ford's(NYSE: F) ability to keep its car costs lower thanTesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column9: for example
column10: isn't just based on the fact that   it produces more economically designed vehicles. It's also due to   the fact that Ford produced 1.5 million cars in the third quarter   of 2016
column11: compared to the 24
column12: 800 cars Tesla Motors delivered   during the same period.But scalability in the driverless car industry doesn't   necessarily have anything to do with car sales. The automaker   with the best technology may ultimately come out ahead.   Technology is scalable at almost no cost. When Tesla Motors   wirelessly uploads its latest software to its already-sold   vehicles around the world
column13: the company pays nearly nothing in   per-unit costs. The race to build the best driverless car at this   stage has much more to do with technology than with numbers of   vehicles sold
column14: and the quantity of cars a company has sold thus   far isn't a indicator for which company is best placed to scale   in the future.2. Exaggerating the value of network effectsWhat network?Network effects are often touted as one of the strongest   competitive moats around.Facebook
column15: an actual social network
column16: perfectly defines the allure of the   network effect. If everyone is using a specific product or   platform
column17: it can be extremely difficult for another company to   make inroads.At first glance
column18: driverless cars seem to be an excellent   opportunity to build network effects. If one company's cars all   ""talk"" to each other as they navigate the roads
column19: they'll get to   their destinations faster and more safely than competitors' --   right? Wrong. Driverless car technology must necessarily take   into account public safety
column20: and unique
column21: exclusionary networks fly   in the face of a universal platform for safe self-driving cars.   Automakers engaged in this space already know this; it's why   Ford
column22: Tesla
column23: and others are equipping their driverless cars with   the best real-world object detection technology available.When Ford announced earlier last week that it would invest $1   billion over five years in Argo AI
column24: it wasn't because   the startup has thousands of self-driving cars on the road   -- it was because the company's robotics expertise ""gives Ford a   distinct competitive advantage at the intersection of the   automotive and technology industries
column25: explained Ford Chief   Technology Officer Raj Nair in a press release. Likewise
column26: Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) spinoff Waymo isn't relying on   Google's treasure troves of data to guide its vehicles as they   drive around. Instead
column27: Waymo cars are equipped with sensors and   software designed to detect obstacles up to ""two football fields   away in all directions."" Ford
column28: Alphabet
column29: Tesla Motors
column30: and others   aren't interested in network effects in this arena. They're   interested in their cars having the most acute local-area   awareness they can contain.3. Expecting government regulation to limit competitionRegular regulationRegulation can provide some of the widest competitive moats   around. If only one company is able to meet all the regulatory   requirements of being in a business
column31: it's essentially illegal for   others to try to compete with it. The driverless car industry   recognizes this
column32: and is making moves to ensure a level playing   field for all involved.Alphabet
column33: Ford
column34: Lyft
column35: Uber
column36: and Volvo Cars joined together   last April to create the ""Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets
column37: "" a lobbying group whose stated mission is to ""work with   lawmakers
column38: regulators
column39: and the public to realize the safety and   societal benefits of self-driving vehicles."" These companies are   interested in standardizing national policy with simple and   low-cost barriers to entry for all interested automakers. So for   Buffett fans looking to back the company with the strongest   regulation-related advantages
column40: know that some of the biggest   names in the business are working proactively to push   policies that ensure no company can ever build a regulatory   moat.Picking the right self-driving car stockWarren Buffett is an incredible investor
column41: but he doesn't have   answers for every industry. There are many open questions around   self-driving cars
column42: and some companies are morepoised to profitthan others. Rather than sticking to one-size-fits-all investment   mantras
column43: equip yourself with the factsyou need to know
column44: make informed investments
column45: and set your   portfolio to auto-pilot for years to come.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column47: the newsletter     they have run for over a decade

column1: Will Twitter's (TWTR) Fortunes Improve on the Trump Effect?;2/22/2017;"Since its debut
column2: Twitter Inc. (TWTR)has been a social phenomenon but somehow hasn't been able to leverage that success to boost user growth.Twitter has vastly underperformed the ZacksInternet Softwareindustry so far in 2017. We note that shares have declined 10.22% as against the industry's gain of 20.37% during the period.Twitter's Dry RunThough the company has been working hard to bring about a turnaround
column3: its efforts are yet to yield the desired results. Focus on Live video content
column4: a flurry of live streaming deals
column5: user friendly changes
column6: measures to curb the trolling menace
column7: divestment of non-core operations
column8: and layoffs
column9: the company has done it all. But all these are yet to move the needle for Twitter.Moreover
column10: CEO Jack Dorsey has often been widely criticized for playing the dual responsibilities of heading both Twitter and Square
column11: especially when both the companies are at crucial junctures. Dorsey was quoted by media reports saying ""My intention is to serve both companies in every way I know how and make sure that we are really focused on what's most important for each.""Last year
column12: rumors about Twitter's probable sale did the rounds. Big names like AlphabetGOOGLand The Walt Disney Company were speculated to have shown interest in buying the micro blogging site. But t most bidders pulled out of the race. The news managed to drive share prices
column13: albeit for a while
column14: as the easing of the acquisition news led to a drop in the same.Twitter's Trump CardNotably
column15: President Donald Trump used Twitter heavily for his presidential campaign in 2016. Given Trump's excessive usage
column16: Twitter became all the more popular. Now that Trump is in office
column17: he continues to use the same to broadcast his agendas.Trump's tweets have the power to influence markets and make headlines. Twitter reached an all-time intraday high of $25.25 on Oct 5
column18: 2016 when the election campaigns were in full swing. Trump has been breaking stereotypes and making important announcements on Twitter instead of press conferences including his choice of Vice-President
column19: Mike Pence

column1: Can Amazon's Chime Challenge Microsoft's Skype and Cisco's Spark?;2/21/2017;"Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) recently introduced Chime
column2: an  enterprise   collaboration service for online meetings
column3: video conferencing
column4: voice calls
column5: chat
column6: and content sharing. Chime's apps work on iOS
column7: Android
column8: Windows
column9: and Mac
column10: and the content is synchronized across   all platforms via Amazon Web Services (AWS).Chime comes in three versions -- Chime Basis
column11: for 1:1 voice   and video calls and chat; Chime Plus
column12: which adds screen sharing   and the integration of company directories; and Chime Pro
column13: which   adds tools for scheduling
column14: hosting
column15: recording
column16: and personalizing   meetings for up to 100 people.Image source: Amazon.makeArticleAd();These features indicate that Amazon is taking aim at   collaborative tools likeMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) Skype andCisco's(NASDAQ: CSCO) Spark. But are those rivals already too deeply   entrenched in the enterprise market for Amazon to disrupt? Let's   take a closer look at Amazon's game plan to find out.Entering the crowded SaaS marketAmazon's AWS
column17: which has an annual run rate of $14 billion
column18: is   the  biggest cloud infrastructure platform in the world.   It's several times larger than its closest competitor
column19: Microsoft's Azure. But while AWS dominates the cloud platform   (infrastructure/platform as a service) market -- which hosts   storage space
column20: processing power
column21: and other tools for companies   and developers -- it doesn't have a major presence in the SaaS   (software as a service) market yet.The SaaS market is the crowded
column22: consumer-facing side of the   cloud
column23: which includes services like Microsoft's Office 365
column24: Dynamics CRM
column25: and Skype. The lion's share of Microsoft's   commercialized cloud revenue run  rate of $14 billion is   generated by those SaaS products instead of Azure. Microsoft has   also been expanding Skype's capabilities as an enterprise   collaboration tool with  Microsoft Teams
column26: which enhances   Skype's cloud-based communication features and tightly integrates   the service into Office 365.Microsoft Teams. Image source: Microsoft.Meanwhile
column27: networking giant Cisco aggressively bundles   software and security products with its routers
column28: switches
column29: and   unified computing systems. Those bundles include collaboration   tools like Spark
column30: the cloud-based platform for  messages
column31: meetings
column32: and calls it launched in late 2015. Last quarter
column33: Cisco's collaboration revenues rose 4% annually to $1.06 billion   -- making it its third largest business after its  core   businesses of router and switches.But Microsoft and Cisco aren't the only players in the crowded   field of cloud-based collaborative tools.Alphabet's Google has been promoting Hangouts to enterprise customers   over  the past year
column34: Boxhas added collaborative tools on top of its cloud storage   platform
column35: andLogMeInacquiredCitrix's GoToMeeting video conferencing platform for the same purposes.   However
column36: all these challengers notably lack Microsoft and Cisco's   clout in the enterprise market.That's why Amazon believes it can succeedBut like Microsoft and Cisco
column37: Amazon also has leverage -- the   growing importance of AWS to enterprise customers. Amazon likely   believes that by offering Chime as an extension of AWS   (especially with its 30-day free trial) to its enterprise   customer base
column38: it can gain a foothold in the crowded ""unified   communication"" platform market.Amazon previously launched enterprise SaaS products like    WorkSpaces
column39: WorkDocs
column40: and WorkMail
column41: but it hasn't ever   released official growth figures for those products. However
column42: most industry watchers believe that those products are still   dwarfed by comparable solutions from Microsoft and Cisco. This   strongly indicates that AWS' dominance of the PaaS/IaaS markets   doesn't guarantee that Chime will become a Skype or Spark killer   anytime soon. Chime Pro also  costs more than Skype for   Business -- so it doesn't look like Amazon plans to undercut its   way into the market.The key takeawayChime sounds like a logical way for AWS to straddle the   PaaS/IaaS and SaaS markets
column43: but it's easier said than done. The   market for cloud-based unified communication platforms is   incredibly crowded
column44: and it's doubtful that a new service -- even   one bundled with AWS -- can claim a meaningful slice of the   market. However
column45: Amazon investors should still keep an eye out   for future SaaS products to see if the company can eventually   challenge heavyweights like Microsoft and Cisco.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: These Are the 10-Most Admired Companies in the World;2/21/2017;"When the public votes for something the results can skew based   on perception

column5: 000   names were submitted

column1: 3 Virtual Reality Stock Investing Tips That Will Pay Off Long Term;2/21/2017;"Virtual reality (VR) is forecast to become a $162 billion   market by 2020
column2: and the opportunities for investors to benefit   are growing. Nearly every major technology company is pursuing   VR
column3: or at least looking into it
column4: and some are spending billions   in order to make it the next popular computing platform.So how can individual investors benefit from all of this?   Start with these three tips:Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Don't focus on hardwareYou're probably hearing a lot about VR headsets these days.   Oculus released its long-awaited Rift headset last year;Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) purchased the company more than two years ago for $2   billion.Sony's(NYSE: SNE) PlayStation VR headset launched back in October
column5: giving PS4 users the ability to play and view VR content on their   consoles. AndAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) recently launched its new mobile   VR headset
column6: called the Daydream View. The company also just hired   a key VR headset designer away from HTC
column7: which makes the popular   HTC Vive headset.But don't focus on any of that.VR headsets and other hardware are clearly an important part   of this market
column8: but the real gains will come from software and   services. Tom Mainelli
column9: vice president of devices and AR/VR at   IDC
column10: said last year that ""... what people can do with   that hardware will depend upon the applications and services that   power it.""According to IDC
column11: hardware sales will account for more than half of VR and   augmented reality (AR) revenues through 2020
column12: but that it's   software and services that have the real long-term potential.""AR/VR software revenues will also get off to a quick start
column13: growing more than 200% year over year in 2016
column14: but will quickly   be overtaken by services revenues in the middle years of the   forecast
column15: as logistics and manufacturing demand enterprise-class   support
column16: Mainelli said.The bigger
column17: the betterIn the technology sector
column18: it's often the players that start   out the biggest that win in the end
column19: and virtual reality will   likely be the same.That's why it's important to look at what Facebook
column20: Alphabet
column21: and Sony are doing in the space. Facebook's long-term goal isn't   to just sell high-end VR headsets
column22: but rather to create the next   widely adopted computing platform.CEO Mark Zuckerberg said in aninterviewwithBusiness Insider last year that Facebook is ""mostly interested in the software""   aspect of VR
column23: though he noted that the early stages of VR   development will require a focus on both hardware and   software.His long-term goal for AR and VR is to create an entirely new   computing platform. ""So I do think a new computing platform   always emerges every 10 or 15 years. VR is currently the most   promising candidate
column24: he said.While Facebook is looking ahead to the next computing   platform
column25: Alphabet is busy focusing on how it can gain from the   mobile VR market. The company recently debuted its Daydream   platform for Android users to find VR videos and apps.The importance of this VR hub can't be overstated. Smaller   companies may be making VR content
column26: but Alphabet's Google has   built one of the only places where all of this content can live
column27: and be easily found. As mobile VR takes off
column28: Daydream will   likely be the place where users go to get their content. Think of   it like a Google Play store for VR.And while Facebook and Alphabet are busy building out   platforms
column29: don't forget Sony's potential to make itself a   powerhouse in the VR gaming market. The company already   working with more than 230 developers and publishers to create   160 PlayStation VR software titles.Sony's Game and Network Services is the company'ssecond-most profitablebusiness
column30: and the company has said the VR ""offers great   future potential"" for the segment.Stay the courseHonestly
column31: the payoff for VR investors will likely take some   time to materialize. That's because while the market is growing   fast
column32: VR represents only a small portion of revenues -- if any --   for many of the companies involved in the space right now.Facebook said its investments in VR weren't material to the   company's 2016 financials
column33: and Zuckerberg has stated several   times that VR probably won't truly take off for another five to   10 years.But that shouldn't be a deterrent for investors. Virtual   reality has the potential to transform how people access   information
column34: view content
column35: and interact with each other. If it   does become the next big computing platform
column36: then taking a   long-term approach to the will be the wise course.Investors should heed this advice Zuckerberg gave last year:   ""We are betting that virtual reality is going to be an important   technology. I am pretty confident about this. And now is the time   to invest.""10 stocks we like better than FacebookWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
