column1: Ignore the Management Shakeup Drama -- Viacom Is a Fantastic Buy Today;2/20/2017;"Long a pillar of the entertainment industry
column2: Viacom(NASDAQ: VIAB) has fallen on hard times as of late. First
column3: its   Paramount film division has suffered a string of box-office   flops
column4: with its share of the box office falling to just 8% in   2016. Then there's its portfolio of television networks
column5: once the   envy of the entertainment industry
column6: but have suffered amid   increasing competition not only from peers likeWalt Disney
column7: but from the internet itself. Viewers used to have to tune   into Viacom'sMTVto view the latest music video
column8: or to itsComedy Centralnetwork for a laugh -- now consumers need only head over toAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOGL)YouTubefor the latest hit song and a laugh.However
column9: for reasons that are detailed below
column10: shares in the   entertainment conglomerate offer a compelling value to   prospective investors. Read on to learn more.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Recent eventsThere's no other way to put it -- the last year or so has   tumultuous within the C-suite of Viacom's management. The drama
column11: which has been more than covered by the media
column12: culminated with   theresignation of multibillionaire Viacom   Chairmanand former CEO Sumner Redstone. Now
column13: with the appointment of new   CEO Robert Bakish
column14: the situation appears to be on the mend
column15: which   is great news
column16: because all has not been well
column17: not only in the   C-suite
column18: but on the income statement as well:Metric20162015ChangeRevenue$3.32 billion$3.15 billion5%Operating income$706 million$839 million(16%)Diluted EPS$1.00$1.13(12%)Data source:Viacom February 9
column19: 2017 Quarterly Earnings   Results.While revenues were obviously headed in the right direction
column20: profits were not -- which partially explains the company's low   earnings multiple. However
column21: this has not always been the case. In   fact
column22: lackluster growth could very well be considered an anomaly   in the company's operating history.A look backHistorically
column23: Viacom has a history of profit growth and solid   returns on capital. In fact
column24: its record over the years has been   quite good.VIAB Normalized Diluted EPS (TTM)data byYCharts.Alas
column25: perhaps caused by or contributing to the myriad problems   at the top that the public has been more than privy to over the   past year
column26: the company's momentum has been all but   derailed. Fortunately
column27: there lies a strong case to be made   that the company's inherent advantages remain intact
column28: and   brighter days lie ahead.Content is king!Viacom was built into what it is today by 93-year-old Sumner   Redstone
column29: who built his empire on the belief that it was content
column30: not distribution
column31: that would fuel the entertainment industry in   the decades ahead. When he made this shift
column32: in the 1970s when he   was working for his father's National Amusements theater chain
column33: this was a novel innovation. Today
column34: the world has caught onto   this insight and is giving the company a run for its money.   However
column35: this should not detract from the company's prime   properties
column36: networks like MTV (and its derivative channels)
column37: as   well as Nickelodeon
column38: Comedy Central
column39: Spike
column40: BET
column41: and CMT. On top   of all this
column42: the company is also the owner of Paramount   Studios.Despite increasing competition from all quarters
column43: Viacom's   networks are holding their own. For the quarter ended December   31
column45: Media Networks' revenues rose 1% to $2.6 billion -- and   this ignores an averse 2% impact due to foreign exchange losses.   Softness in total advertising revenues (-2% to $1.29 billion) was   balanced out by an increase in affiliate (essentially   international) revenues
column46: which climbed 2% to $1.14 billion. These   results are nothing to write home about
column47: but they aren't   terrible
column48: either. All the more
column49: when looking at the situation   holistically and holding shares up to the light of its enviable   brands and good-not-great recent financial results
column50: shares become   increasingly attractive when one reflects on their current   valuation.VIAB PE Ratio (TTM)data byYCharts.Should Viacom be able to right the ship
column51: investors will more   than likely be handsomely rewarded given the stock's historically   low valuation. Here
column52: the situation appears to be positive as   well. Management is no longer distracted by the drama surrounding   the departure of Sumner Redstone and will be able to focus on   international expansion of its brands. Also
column53: Paramount Studios   has recently been given a ""booster shot"" of sorts via a$1 billion dollar
column54: 3-year dealby Chinese film studios Shanghai Film Group and Huahua Media. The   cash infusion
column55: coupled with the potential for allowing Paramount   to make strong inroads into the fast-growing Chinese film market   all bode well. These facts are perhaps why analysts polled byS&P Global Market Intelligencethink Viacom's EPS will likely grow from $3.85 per share in FY   2017 to a respectable $5.26 per share (an annualized 8%   annualized increase).A few words of cautionThe world continues to change
column56: and while few could have   imagined Viacom's reach 30 years ago
column57: the same could have been   said of potential threats to its core entertainment   brands. The fact is
column58: the company faces threats from all   quarters
column59: from individuals in their homes posting comedic videos   on YouTube to Time Warner'sHBO. Consumers only have so many hours in the day
column60: and fantastic   content is now everywhere they turn. Viacom likely has what it   takes to continue to compete and garner viewers' eyeballs and   attention -- but the ever-present risk that the company will   slowly be overtaken is there.Foolish final thoughtsIt appears that now is a rare time to buy into a fantastic   media enterprise at a time when its shares are trading hands at a   historically low valuation. True
column61: its competitive position isn't   what it used to be
column62: and yes
column63: the company has been mired in an   ugly battle for control that was only recently resolved. But   these negatives should not detract from the company's   one-of-a-kind media properties
column64: nor its attractive valuation that   brings with it a 1.8% dividend yield to boot. Overall
column65: Viacom's   shares are worthy of strong consideration by Foolish investors   with an eye to the future.Offer from The Motley Fool: The 10 best stocks to buy     nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more     than a decade beating the market. In fact

column1: 5 Finalists for Google Lunar XPrize Race to the Moon;2/19/2017;"Only 46 weeks remain for one of five lucky companies to claim   a $20 million prize -- and the first one to arrive on the Moon   gets it.For the past 18 months
column2: I've kept you up to date on the   loomingGoogle Lunar XPRIZE competition
column3: a $40 million effort (recently increased from $30 million) --   sponsored byAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) and organized by Peter   Diamandis' nonprofit XPRIZE organization -- to encourage   private development of the Moon. But it's only now
column4: this year
column5: that the clock really starts ticking. At some time within the   next 10 and a half months
column6: one company must succeed in achieving   XPRIZE's three key stated requirements -- or forfeit its chance   to win the $20 million purse for placing first.Sometime in 2017
column7: someone will land on the Moon. Bet on it.     Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();First thing's firstIn case youhaven'tbeen paying attention to the Google Lunar XPRIZE competition
column8: let's bring you up to date. So far
column9: $5.25 million in prizes have   been doled out to teams demonstrating ""milestone"" capabilities in   the skills of conducting lunar landings
column10: moving about on the   lunar surface
column11: and lunar imaging.Still up for grabs is the grand prize -- $20 million for being   the first team to successfully land on the Moon
column12: travel at least   500 meters from the landing site
column13: and transmit two   high-definition ""Mooncasts"" back to Earth. The second team to   complete all three missions will receive $5 million
column14: and then   there are up to $17 million in additional prizes for   accomplishing various add-on missions (e.g.
column15: conducting a   Mooncast from the Apollo 11
column20: or 17 landing sites
column21: keeping a rover alive and functioning for at least two days
column22: or   finding water on the Moon).But to win any share at all of this loot
column23: someone has to land   on the Moon -- and someone has to be first.Round up some unusual suspectsWho will the winner be? I've already introduced you to two of   the leading contenders:Israeli start-up SpaceIL
column24: which has contracted with     Spaceflight Industries for room aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket     to carry its spacecraft and lander to the Moon.And America's ownMoon Express
column25: the first company to receive U.S. government approval to land     on the Moon (with a little help from Rocket Lab's Electron     rocket
column26: which will be carrying it up there).Both these rivals have set launch dates vaguely in the ""late   2017"" range
column27: ensuring this race will go down to the wire. As for   the other participants
column28: last month
column29: XPRIZE announced the   remaining three finalists ready to take a shot at the Moon. These   include:Synergy Moon
column30: an international alliance among the Human     Synergy Project
column31: California-based Interplanetary Ventures
column32: British satcom company RPC Telecommunications
column33: and American     aerospace manufacturer Interorbital Systems. Interorbital will     provide the rocket for this team -- a NEPTUNE 8 launch vehicle     launching from sea
column34: off the California coast
column35: sometime later     this year.Team Indus
column36: flying aboard an ISRO space agency     PSLV rocket from India before attempting to land an ""ECA""     moon rover.And finally
column37: Japanese competitor Hakuto
column38: an eclectic team     backed by everyone from Japanese space agency JAXA to Suzuki to     a rock band called ""Sakanaction.""Curiously
column39: both Indus and Hakuto will ride the same PSLV   rocket to the Moon
column40: and land their rovers on the same lander.   This could make it difficult deciding which one lands ""first"" and   gets the big $20 million prize. But seeing as they have to land   on the Moon successfully before they encounter this dilemma
column41: figuring out who arrived first will be a nice problem to have   once they get there. Indus and Hakuto plan to launch their XPRIZE   mission on Dec. 28
column42: 2017.What it means to investors$20 million
column43: $30 million
column44: $40 million -- however much prize   money Google ultimately antes up for the winners
column45: it's unlikely   thatanyof these teams will make much of a profit from running the first   privately funded Moon landing. But that's not the point.First and foremost
column46: the point will be earning bragging rights   for accomplishing something no nongovernmental agency -- not even   SpaceX -- has ever done before: landing a spacecraft on the Moon.   And as we saw when privately held Scaled Composites won the   Ansari XPRIZE back in 2004 -- and was later bought out byNorthrop Grumman(NYSE: NOC)
column47: which had previously owned only a minority stake --   just placing first in an XPRIZE competition could make a company   more attractive to would-be acquirers.Of greater import to investors
column48: though
column49: is what comesaftersomeone successfully lands a spacecraft on the Moon. Proving the   mission is feasible will almost certainly invite imitation by   larger companies
column50: and with any luck
column51: publicly traded companies   that we can invest in ourselves. It will open up not just a new   market
column52: but literally a whole new world of opportunities for   those who follow the trail blazed by this year's space pioneers.   All we need now is for someone to take that first step.And by Dec. 31
column54: we should know who that will be.10 stocks we like better than Northrop GrummanWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Are General Motors and Lyft About to Crush All Self-Driving Rivals?;2/19/2017;"General Motors(NYSE: GM) is planning to build and deploy thousands of   self-driving electric cars in test fleets with Lyft next year
column2: according to a newReutersreport.If that's for real
column3: it will be by far the largest fleet of   autonomous test vehicles in operation. It's a very big deal that   has huge implications for GM
column4: Lyft
column5: and their   rivals.What the report saidAccording to the Reuters article
column6: GM will build thousands of   Chevy Bolts equipped with prototype versions of the self-driving   system GM has developed with its subsidiary
column7: Cruise Automation.   Most of these self-driving Bolts will go into ride-hailing   service with Lyft in several states starting sometime in   2018.makeArticleAd();GM has no plans right now to sell the self-driving Bolts to   the general public.CEO Mary Barra announced in December that GM would begin     producing self-driving Chevrolet Bolt test vehicles in early     2017. Image source: General Motors.What it would mean for GMGM has been working on self-driving technology for years. That   work seemed to take a big leap forward with the acquisition of   San Francisco-based start-up Cruise Automation early last year.   It appears that Cruise has since become the center of GM's   research efforts. Cruise's self-driving Chevy Bolt test cars have   become regular sights on San Francisco streets
column8: and recent videos   taken from inside self-driving Bolt test cars suggest thatthe GM/Cruise technology is at a fairly advanced   level. GM announced in December that it would soon begin   producing self-driving Bolt test vehicles
column9: but the hint was that   -- at least in the near term -- they'd be produced in   small quantities for GM's own testing.A mass deployment would demonstrate two things: First
column10: that   GM's technology really is at a high level
column11: and second
column12: that GM   and its supplier partners are ready and able to mass-produce   self-driving cars.Both of those things are significant. Taken together
column13: it would   be a strong argument that GM is leading the way to mass-produced   Level 4 self-driving vehicles. Companies likeAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) have attracted a lot of investor attention for   (among other things) their self-driving efforts
column14: but --   as of right now
column15: at least -- GM seems poised to leapfrog just   about everybody.What it would mean for LyftLyft
column16: like its larger rival Uber Technologies
column17: knows that   replacing its human drivers with self-driving vehicles is crucial   to its future. Autonomous ride-hailing vehicles will allow Lyft   to lower its prices while generating (hopefully) strong   profits.Uber has been working on its own self-driving technology for a   couple of years
column18: and has a fewprototype self-driving test cars in servicenow. Lyft isn't known to have done any work on a self-driving   system of its own
column19: but it doesn't need to: GMowns a 9% stakein Lyft
column20: and GM seems to have it handled.If Lyft beats Uber to a self-driving fleet at scale
column21: Uber will   have a big challenge on its hands.GM president Dan Ammann (center) with Lyft co-founders Logan     Green (left) and John Zimmer. GM owns 9% of the ride-hailing     company
column22: and Ammann is a member of its board of directors.     Image source: General Motors.Could this be for real?The Reuters report
column23: by veteran auto-business journalist Paul   Lienert
column24: cites two unnamed ""sources familiar with the automaker's   plans."" Generally
column25: investors (and everyone else) should take   reports based on information from unnamed sources with a grain or   two of salt. But a few things suggest to me that this is probably   for real.First
column26: Lienert is a veteran with good sources
column27: and Reuters   holds its reporting to high standards. Second
column28: the report fits   with the known facts: GM and Lyft have both said that atest of autonomous GM vehicles in Lyft service is   forthcoming. Third
column29: GM's Orion
column30: Michigan
column31: factory
column32: where the Bolt is built
column33: has plenty of capacity to do a special production run in the   thousands.Finally
column34: and most tellingly
column35: neither Lyft nor GM denied the   report. In fact
column36: GM's statement in response was almost a smiling   hint:We do not provide specific details on potential future     products or technology rollout plans. We have said that our AV     technology will appear in an on-demand ride sharing network     applicationsooner than you might think. [Emphasis added.]Translation: This is likely to happen
column37: and it might begin   sooner than 2018.How important is this for GM investors?If it happens
column38: it will be a big deal. While the idea of a   ""race"" to self-driving technologyisn't really useful to investors
column39: a big test like this next year (or sooner) will show that GM   isn't about to be disrupted by Silicon Valley when it comes to   self-driving. It will also give lots of people an   opportunity to experience self-driving technology firsthand
column40: which will almost certainly speed its adoption by increasing   consumer demand.If nothing else
column41: it seems very likely to attract investors'   attention and give GM shares a boost.10 stocks we like better than General MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Does Thinking About Your IRA Give You Heartburn? Let Us Help;2/17/2017;"An IRA is a fantastic retirement saving tool
column2: but many   Americans don't take advantage of it
column3: and when they do
column4: they fail   to make the most of it. If you're among them
column5: don't worry. Here   are some rules to help you build a bigger nest egg with an   IRA.What are IRAs?As a refresher
column6: you can get big tax benefits by saving money   for retirement in a traditional IRA or a Roth IRA.In 2017
column7: you can set aside up to $5
column8: 500 of your earnings in   either a traditional IRA or a Roth IRA or a combination of the   two. If you're 50 years old or older
column9: then you can save up to   $6
column10: 500 of your earnings in an IRA.makeAd('4'
column12: 'mktsnews'
column13: 'vanguard'
column15: '');IMAGE SOURCE: GETTY IMAGES.Traditional IRAs can be funded with pre-tax money
column16: which means   that money you put in now isn't taxed at your current tax rate.   Instead
column17: that money
column18: and any future gains
column19: are taxed when its   withdrawn. Because of this feature
column20: traditional IRAs can make   sense if you think your income tax rate in retirement will belowerthan it is today.Alternatively
column21: Roth IRAs are funded with after-tax money
column22: which means you're paying taxes on your contributions now so that   you can withdraw them -- and future gains -- tax-free in   retirement. Because of up-front taxation
column23: a Roth IRA can make   sense if you expect your income tax rate in retirement to behigherthan it is today.Some important IRA withdrawal rulesIn the case of a traditional IRA
column24: if you don't wait until   you're at least 59.5 years old
column25: the IRS will charge you income   taxes on any money that you withdraw
column26: plus a 10% penalty
column27: unless   you qualify for an early withdrawal exemption (more on that in a   minute).In the case of a Roth IRA
column28: you can withdraw your contributions   tax-free at any age without a penalty
column29: as long as the Roth IRA   has been established for at least five years. However
column30: any gains   that you withdraw prior to reaching age 59.5 can be subject to   income tax and penalties.Both traditional IRAs and Roth IRAs do allow penalty free
column31: early withdrawals in specific instances. A full list of these   exemptions can be foundhere
column32: but the big ones to know about include purchasing a first home   (up to $10
column34: or payingcollege tuitionfor you
column35: or an immediate relative
column36: such as a spouse or child. The   rules for taking advantage of these exemptions can be quite   complex
column37: so make sure you consult a tax professional before   taking any early withdrawals. After all
column38: the last thing you want   is a surprise at tax time!Overall
column39: a Roth IRA might be a better option if you think   you'll need to withdraw contributions five or more years from   now
column40: and you won't be 59.5 years old or qualify for an early   withdrawal exemption at that time.Navigating the IRA income capsIn order to qualify for a tax deduction on a traditional IRA   contribution
column41: your modified adjusted gross income has to be below   set limits if you
column42: or your spouse
column43: are covered by a retirement   plan at work. Similarly
column44: in order to contribute to a Roth IRA
column45: your modified adjusted gross income needs to be below set limits   too.Recently
column46: fellow Motley Fool Matthew Frankel did a great job   at explaining adjusted income limits for IRA'shere
column47: but in short
column48: if you're single and you are covered by a   retirement plan at work
column49: you can take the full deduction on a   traditional IRA contribution if your adjusted income is below   $62
column50: 000 in 2017. You can qualify for a partial deduction if your   adjusted income is between $62
column52: 000.If you're single
column53: you can make a contribution to a Roth IRA as   long as your adjusted income is less than $118
column54: 000. You can make   a partial contribution if your adjusted income is between   $118
column56: 000.If you're married filing jointly and covered by a retirement   plan at work
column57: then you can take a tax deduction on your   traditional IRA contribution
column58: as long as your adjusted income is   below $99
column59: 000. A partial deduction is possible if your adjusted   income is between $99
column61: 000.If you're not covered by a plan at work but your spouse is
column62: then you can make a tax deductible contribution to traditional   IRA if your adjusted income is below $186

column1: VMware
column2: Inc. (VMW) Keeps the Momentum Going;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsVMware
column4: Inc.(NYSE:VMW) may not be one of the first companies that comes to mind when you're thinking about cloud services stocks. But
column5: it should be.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrBelieve it or not
column6: VMW is one of the top enterprise cloud services and virtualization companies out there. And
column7: its growth up to now
column8: while impressive
column9: is just the beginning. In the past 12 months
column10: VMW stock has almost doubled.That sounds compelling
column11: but the underlying story is what makes VMW's rise something you should understand
column12: especially if you're looking for exposure in this massively disruptive market.Simply put
column13: cloud computing means that your computer doesn't need to have individual software packages for each specific job you want it to do. In the old days
column14: you ran a word processing program
column15: a spreadsheet program
column16: a design program
column17: etc. And
column18: every machine had to have its individual software suite.The rise of networked computers meant that all of this software could be stored on a network ""library"" and each user could access what they needed.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteThe next iteration of these networks were housed in the ""cloud
column19: which simply implies a virtual space built into servers. One of the primary advantages is the ability to access your information from the cloud
column20: regardless of where you are or what computer you're using.Cloud computing has been around for a long time
column21: and companies such asAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column22: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column23: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) andAmazon.com
column24: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) have been using the cloud for many years.Now
column25: companies of all sizes are migrating to the cloud
column26: and within the cloud universe there both public clouds (where many people have access) and private clouds (where only select people have access). VMW provides the ability to develop each of these systems
column27: and also facilitates unique access between public and private clouds.Why Don't We Hear Much About VMware?VMWare is actually owned byDell Technologies Inc(NYSE:DVMT) subsidiary
column28: EMC Corporation(NYSE:EMC). Last April
column29: Dell bought EMC to become the largest privately-held tech company in the world. So
column30: VMWare is a cloud-based
column31: publicly-traded branch of this major tech player now.Part of the reason you don't hear about VMWare as much as its competitors is because the company's relationship to its owners is a bit convoluted
column32: and analysts aren't very confident in figuring out how to value VMW stock. Their loss is your gain.3 Stocks to Buy for Under $10 With 25%-Plus UpsideQ4 and full-year numbers were posted in late January
column33: and they show how strong VMW stock remains. Earnings beat analyst expectations and revenue continued to grow at a solid clip. A new strategic partnership with AMZN's cloud-computing juggernaut
column34: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
column35: adds some serious firepower to the VMW arsenal. It also helps the company remain competitive in a very dynamic field.When you have a tech parent like EMC and a tech partner like AWS
column36: you are doing very well. These brands are major players in the enterprise sector and will open even more doors for VMW in the future. VMWare stock is on a significant growth trajectory that should last years
column37: not months.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth

column1: Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock: The Pause That Refreshes;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) is all about visual computing.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe company started as a high-end graphics card maker for users who were interested in having the best display quality you could get. That ranged from online gamers to research scientists.Given that chip and card makers aren't exactly in short supply
column3: few investors gave this niche player much time. The thought was
column4: NVDA may have a great graphics card
column5: but it's a ""nice to have
column6: not a ""need to have"" kind of product.What's more
column7: most chipmakers had perfectly serviceable graphics cards. Why contract out to yet another vendor when you already had a chipmaker that could provide you with a decent graphics card?Those Days Are Gone NowQuality graphics are no longer just a nice add on; they're crucial now that processing speeds have soared and new technologies have been able to thrive. In this visual computing space
column8: Big Data
column9: virtual reality (VR) and the Internet of Things (IoT) are three major disruptive forces that lean heavily on quality rendering and fast processing.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteSimply put
column10: Big Data packages large data sets and then analyzes them to find any discernible patterns or trends. For example
column11: a store can figure out what day and time is best for 30-something women to buy a shirt. Visualizing these data sets is very helpful in analyzing this process.VR and its cousin
column12: augmented reality (AR)
column13: are not only the hottest technologies in gaming
column14: but are already revolutionizing other fields where interaction is highly prized. For example
column15: medical schools are using AR tech to virtually operate on an augmented cadaver
column16: rather than physically operating on one. The possibilities are just being tapped at this point.IoT is another technology in its infancy. As artificial intelligence and bandwidth merge
column17: opportunities are appearing everywhere
column18: for instance in ""smart"" cars
column19: homes
column20: offices
column21: you name it. One of the best examples nowadays isAmazon.com
column22: Inc's(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa orAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Home device
column23: where you can do everything from order a pizza to set your thermostat just by talking to the thing. It recognizes your commands and then
column24: through its connectivity
column25: turns your request into reality.NVDA is already working with many major car companies to create the next-generation car dashboard
column26: as well as other interactive possibilities. It is helping scientists manipulate molecules and atoms to build better drugs. And
column27: it's building the chips that are featured in the newest gaming system fromNintendo Co.
column28: Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NTDOY).These are just a few reasons that NVDA is up 282% in the past 12 months.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeservePart of this big move was because the entire semiconductor industry was weak because demand had slackened. But
column29: this is a cyclical industry and it's ""game on"" once again. Plus
column30: NVDA has shown that it's more than just a graphics card maker at this point. It is on the leading edge of the next generation of visual computing.NVDA numbers for Q4 were recently released
column31: and the stock came down from its 52-week highs on the news.But
column32: this is simply the pause that refreshes. The numbers were still impressive and there is significant untapped growth for NVDA stock. Management's guidance may have been slightly conservative
column33: but it's likely that stellar growth will remain in Nvidia's future for many years to come.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth

column1: Apple to Begin Assembling iPhone SE in India from April;2/17/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Reportedly
column2: Apple Inc.AAPLin collaboration with its manufacturer
column3: Wistron Inc. will begin to assemble iPhone SE in India starting this April. The plant will be located in the state of Karnataka in south India.Though there is no official word on the matter from Apple or Wistron
column4: it has been reported that initially the Cupertino giant wants to assemble 0.3-0.4 million units of iPhone SE. Apple hasn't even waited for the numerous tax concessions that it sought from the India government including the 15-year customs duty holiday.Analysts observe that it was prudent on part of Apple to begin assembling its most economic iPhone offering
column5: SE
column6: which was launched to cater to cost sensitive markets like India. Plus
column7: it also will support future iOS upgrades unlike iPhone 5S
column8: which will soon be discontinued in most of the markets including India.Apple Inc. PriceApple Inc. Price|Apple Inc. QuoteWhy is Apple Keen on India?Since the last year
column9: Apple has been increasing its focus on India to claim a greater share of the vast smartphone market
column10: of which it reportedly holds only 2% as of now. Apple faces slowing iPhone demand in most of the regions
column11: either because of competition or regulatory hurdles (China) or market saturation (the U.S). Therefore
column12: it makes sense for the company to solidify its position in India
column13: which is projected to become the second largest smartphone market in the world. In fiscal 2016
column14: Apple sales in India grew approximately 50% over the prior fiscal.Furthermore
column15: a younger (and skilled) population and increasing investment in broadband network by the government also make India an attractive growth opportunity for Apple over the long run. In fact
column16: the government under PM Narendra Modi is eager to bring foreign capital and boost manufacturing facilities in India.The recently outlined FDI policy also bodes well for the company as it eliminates the requirement to locally source products for at least a three-year period. This will enable Apple to open its solely-owned retails stores in India. Thereafter
column17: the company will have to comply with the rule. The company has also partnered with telecom company Reliance
column18: which is providing its Jio (a unique all-IP network) service for free with the new iPhones.Last year
column19: Tim Cook was on a charm offensive in India. Besides meeting Modi
column20: he also announced the opening of an iOS App Design and Development Accelerator in Bengaluru and a map development office in another southern Indian city
column21: Hyderabad in collaboration with regional firm RMSI.ChallengesThe market is highly cost sensitive. Reportedly
column22: majority of the smartphones sold are priced around INR 10K (roughly $145). iPhone 7 on the other hand costs almost five times more. Even iPhone SE is priced at INR 30K. The lion's share of Apple's revenues in the country comes from devices
column23: which are a couple of generations old. Newer models have relatively low demand given the hefty price tag.  A few days back
column24: it was reported that the Apple team in India is trying to increase revenues to $3 billion by 2017-18 and by local assembling operations
column25: the company can start to operate its own retail outlets and avail a 10% tax benefit. This should lower prices.Plus
column26: Apple's rival Samsung along with a few Chinese smartphone makers dominates this market. Samsung has long been in the market and with reportedly 23% share
column27: it is a leading player in the country. Apple is quite late to the party.Also
column28: Apple's lack of focus on regional customers' demand is a concern. India is categorized by handsets that work on dual SIMs. Apparently
column29: Apple is not keen on making dual SIM handsets. This could be a very big impediment to growth in the country.Also
column30: analysts observe that Apple is ""relocating"" manufacturing to India from China
column31: given rising labor costs. However another analyst argues that though labor is cheap compared with China
column32: productivity is relatively better in China. Simple assembling may not drastically bring down prices. However
column33: the creation of a local supply chain as in China will be a big positive.Despite the pros and cons
column34: Apple is expected to continue its India drive. It will be taking up a lot more initiatives this year. However
column35: whether those initiatives yield desirable results remains a watch and see story.Apple
column36: of course
column37: is not the only tech player eyeing India for growth. Given the potential of this market
column38: Silicon Valley's interest is well understood. From Microsoft Corp.MSFTto AlphabetGOOGLto Facebook Inc.FBall remain laser focused on the market.Zacks Rank & Price MovementAt present
column39: Apple has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.Over the past one year
column40: shares of Apple have registered growth of 37.81% compared with the ZacksComputer Miniindustry's gain of 37.59%.Just Released - Driverless Cars: Your Roadmap to Mega-Profits TodayIn this latest Special Report

column1: Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Heading to $160 on Video Capabilities;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMaking excuses to not likeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) and avoiding FB stock is just plain dumb. Ahead of the company's fourth-quarter earnings report
column3: I gave FB stock a Strong Buy rating with a 12-monthprice target of $150. With the earnings report now in behind us
column4: I'm inclined to raise that target to $160.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIndeed
column5: FB stock is no bargain when shares are near all-time highs
column6: but the company's revenue growth engines are certain to significantly impact the bottom line. Although management didn't scale back on plans to increase capital spending
column7: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg
column8: who said the social media giant was aiming for shorter-form content
column9: has made clear that FB intends to dominate video
column10: which is where the bulk of its capex will go.And
column11: that spending has already begun.Why Amazon.com

column14: former head of scripted development atViacom
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:VIA). This hire can only be for one reason: to increase Facebook's transition toward developing original content. Contrary to popular opinion
column16: Zuckerberg is not pushing Facebook to become a television network
column17: nor does he envision the company competing withNetflix
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX). His drive to become a ""video-first"" company has everything to do with selling more ads.From my vantage point
column19: the reason Facebook must spend money is because it has begun to experience a problem thatTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) craves: It has run out of ad space on its news feeds. But
column20: Facebook doesn't want to sacrifice the user experience without first knowing what sorts of videos users will want to see - and how to make them less intrusive.To that end
column21: Lefevre
column22: whose track record at Viacom-owned MTV Networks includes producing teen-focused content
column23: is a solid hire. To the extent Facebook's shorter-form content can put it into the realm ofAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) advertising juggernaut YouTube

column25: given Zuckerberg's Midas-like qualities
column26: it would be a mistake to avoid FB stock solely on the fears of high capex. It would make more sense to focus on the return Facebook can realize from its investments.Bottom Line for FB StockFacebook - as it promised in the third quarter - has signaled that it will be in a period of transition. Investors
column27: however
column28: are now taking their time to see how the increased spending balances out with management's warning of slow ad growth. While this might put FB stock in limbo
column29: now is also the time to look at the big picture. And my crystal ball says to own FB stock
column30: don't trade it
column31: and wait for $160.As of this writing

column11: and communication capabilities
column12: is a two-way street that benefits the darker side of human nature

column14: Facebook's Graph Search tool
column15: introduced in 2013
column16: can help you search the site efficiently. It can also help youstalk someone.Facebook Live
column17: which lets users stream live video on the site from their camera phones

column19: as it happens. It can also let youshow the child being killed.CEO Mark Zuckerberg promised to do something about this in November

column23: subject to responsibility for what it posts

column25: Dan Rose

column31: for instance

column33: and other networks

column38: which holds its own elections this September
column39: is also threatening to imposea 500
column40: 000-euro finefor each fake news story it runs.How Bad Can It Get?To see how bad things can get with fake news and the abuse of Facebook Live

column1: Would You Ditch Your Home Phone for Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN)?;2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRoughly half of American homes no longer have an old-school telephone
column4: relying instead on cell phones and smartphones. IfAmazon.com
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) have their way
column6: home phones could become even more of a rarity.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonA report inTheWall Street Journalsuggests the companies are working on adding voice-calling capabilities to the Amazon Echo and Google Home smart speakers.The Plan to Make Amazon Echo Your New TelephoneTheWall Street Journalis reporting that Google and Amazon are looking at an all-new use for their smart speakers:replacing the home telephone.The idea makes sense. Telephones increasingly seem like outdated technology. Between smartphones and PC-based calling services likeMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Skype
column7: the days of the dedicated home phone seem numbered. In 2015
column8: a survey by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (which
column9: apparently
column10: cares about these things) found thatnearly half of American homes had given up their dedicated landline.But
column11: that still leaves a lot of telephones in operation.Apparently
column12: it's occurred to both Amazon and Google that smart speakers such as the Amazon Echo and Google Home may be the right device in the right place at the right time. Smart speakers get the name because they leverage an AI-powered personal digital assistant.Why Amazon.com
column13: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1
column14: 000 in 2017Amazon's Echo is home to Alexa
column15: withover 5
column16: 000 skills. These devices have the smarts to take on telephone functionality. They could incorporate Skype
column17: for example. And
column18: Google has a slew of its own telephony applications it could leverage
column19: including Google Voice and Duo.The Amazon Echo and Google Home are equipped with excellent microphones
column20: they have speakers
column21: they are always connected (to the internet) and they respond instantly to voice commands
column22: even from across a room.So
column23: as long as privacy isn't an issue (since using one would be like using a speakerphone)
column24: a smart speaker could replace a telephoneandsave consumers money by eliminating the monthly cost of a landline. While this would be a potentially useful trick for existing smart speaker owners
column25: it's the kind of practical capability that could drive sales among those consumers who wouldn't otherwise consider a high-tech device like the Amazon Echo.The Challenges of Turning a Smart Speaker Into a TelephoneWhile the technology and built-in smarts may be there
column26: in reality turning that Amazon Echo on your kitchen counter into your home phone may not be quite that simple.TheWall Street Journalarticle lays out some of the challenges. For example
column27: there are potential privacy issues
column28: not only in speaking out loud to the Echo (it lacks an AUX input
column29: so you couldn't physically connect a handset)
column30: but the fact that now your telephone would always be listening to you and recording key data like phone numbers and call durations.Amazon and Google would also have to implement a feature to prevent voice commands from being triggered during a phone conversation.It's also been pointed out that switching from a cell phone or landline to an internet-based telephone service has implications for emergency services. For example
column31: theFCC lists a series of limitations to 911 servicewhen home owners rely on internet-based (or VoIP) services.Calls may not be routed directly to an emergency center
column32: locational information may not be available to emergency responders and
column33: in a power outage
column34: internet telephones go offline without battery backups.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteDespite the challenges
column35: The Wall Street Journalsays its sources are convinced Amazon and Google will move forward
column36: calling the move to telephone capability ""the logical next step for the artificial intelligence-powered speakers."" And
column37: that move could happen later this year.The question is
column38: knowing that there are some privacy concerns and potential safety issues in doing so
column39: would you ditch your landline and use an Amazon Echo as your home's new telephone?As of this writing
column40: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears StrikeBank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Is Going to $30 This Year7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingThe postWould You Ditch Your Home Phone for Amazon.com

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Careens Closer to Major AR Announcement;2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) CEO Tim Cook has been talking an awful lot lately about augmented reality - or AR. The latest episode was last week
column3: when hecompared the technology to the iPhonein terms of its potential to be big.makeArticleAd();Source: NanticAfter months of repeatedly playing up AR in public
column4: it's beginning to feel as if Cook is setting the expectations of the press and public about the technology.That begs the question: Is Apple Inc. planning a major augmented reality announcement?AR vs. VR: What's the Difference?Augmented reality is related to virtual reality - or VR - but the two are also very different.Virtual reality uses technology to completely immerse people in a virtual world. This requires powerful computing hardware and special headgear. VR has spent several years as the next big thing
column5: culminating withFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) buying VR pioneer Oculus for $2 billion in 2014.Virtual reality hasn't quite caught on in a big way - the expensive and awkward equipment is a big hurdle to overcome - but gamers have begun embracing it.7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingSo far
column6: Apple has shown no interest in virtual reality and Tim Cook has actually made a point in several interviews of downplaying VR. In the latest
column7: when Cook spoke toThe Independent
column8: he laments the fact that virtual reality""closes the world out.""""Most people don't want to lock themselves out from the world for a long period of time and today you can't do that because you get sick from it.""The antisocial aspects of virtual reality
column9: the equipment requirements and side effects such as motion sickness have been common themes in Cook's argument against virtual reality.However
column10: he is very excited by augmented reality and its ability to go mainstream. Instead of locking a person into a virtual world
column11: AR overlays the existing world with additional information. One of the most popular examples of AR in action is the gamePokemon Go
column12: released last summer. That game was themost downloaded app of 2016on Apple Inc.'s App Store.Is Apple Inc. Planning a Major AR Announcement?Tim Cook's views on augmented reality seem to have been getting more positive in the past few months
column13: reaching the point where he's actively hyping the technology.In October
column14: he said:""I do think that a significant portion of the population of developed countries
column15: and eventually all countries
column16: will have AR experiences every day
column17: almost like eating three meals a day. It will become that much a part of you.""And last week
column18: he toldThe Independent:""I regard it as a big idea like the smartphone. The smartphone is for everyone
column19: we don't have to think the iPhone is about a certain demographic
column20: or country or vertical market: it's for everyone. I think AR is that big
column21: it's huge.""What's holding AR back is the technology.Hardware doesn't need to be as powerful as the silicon needed to drive virtual reality gear. And rather than a fully enclosed headpiece or goggles - that themselves are so complex they can cost $600 on top of the PC needed to drive them - augmented reality can be delivered through specialized eyeglasses or on a smartphone's display. The problem is current efforts haven't been quite good enough.Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column22: NASDAQ:GOOGL) failed Google Glass is the best-known example of the AR overlay glasses model
column23: whilePokemon Goshows the relatively primitive AR experience that current smartphones can deliver.What if Tim Cook has been playing up augmented reality (and dissing VR) because Apple Inc. is preparing to make a major push into AR? It could be the company that takes augmented reality mainstream by nailing the hardware
column24: while everyone else is distracted by trying to get consumers to buy into VR.There has been speculation that Apple is working with German optics firmCarl Zeiss AGonApple-branded AR glasses. The iPhone 8 could also incorporate next generation hardware - from cameras to CPU and GPU - that are optimized to make AR a killer feature.Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Could Win Big With 'Windows Cloud'We'll have to wait until the company is ready to show its hand to know exactly what is up. But based on Tim Cook's continued promotion of the technology
column25: it seems likely that Apple Inc. is priming us for AR-related announcement.And if Cook is even close to being right about augmented reality having the potential to be as big as the iPhone
column26: the upside for Apple stock could be huge.As of this writing
column27: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears Strike3 Tire Stocks That Are Burning Rubber in ChinaThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Careens Closer to Major AR Announcementappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column9: and it has been paying dividends in a rising stream since 2003. Payouts started at 20 cents per share and now bring in $2.50 each quarter. An income investor who got in on the 1999 IPO
column10: paying $14 per share
column11: is now collecting $10 per share in dividends each year.Some of the capital gains are a trick of the light. BlackRock did not participate in the ""dot-bomb
column12: the collapse of Internet stocks that began in early 2000 afterTime Warner Inc(NYSE:TWX) gave AOL 60% of its equity in a merger. BlackRock doubled in value that year.If you start calculating after the dot-bomb wreckage cleared
column13: BlackRock is up ""only"" 1
column15: against a nearly 5
column16: 400% gain for Amazon during that time.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) has also outpaced it since going public in 2004.The point is that with few exceptions
column17: like the 2008 stock market collapse
column18: the value of BLK stock has consistently increased. And
column19: even during that crisis - where its market cap was cut in half and other companies collapsed completely - BlackRock did not cut that dividend.America's Best Banker?CEO and co-founder Larry Fink is not often mentioned in the same breath as bankers like Jamie Dimon ofJPMorgan Chase & Co.(NYSE:JPM) or Lloyd Blankfein ofGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS); he just does better for his investors.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveBlackRock wasfounded in 1988with operating capital from Pete Peterson of the Blackstone Group
column20: from which it separated in 1995 after a dispute withStephen Schwarzmann
column21: orchestrated withPNC Financial Services Group Inc(NYSE:PNC)
column22: whose investment arm came into BlackRock in 1998. BLK went public a year later at $14 per share.Since then
column23: Fink has gone from strength to strength. BlackRock was hired to clean up the mess of the 2008 meltdown. BlackRock Solutions unwound the toxic mortgage assets. Plus
column24: the same year it was hired for that job (2009)
column25: BlackRock acquired Barclays Global Investors and its iShares franchise.BlackRock's tech assets include Aladdin
column26: an investment system from BlackRock Solutions
column27: andiRetire
column28: a retirement investment framework offered by other financial advisors.Hedge in the Age of TrumpAs BlackRock has grown
column29: it has developed a knack for taking deals others wouldn't even consider - and making them work.Right now
column30: for instance
column31: BlackRock is spending $500 million renovating the Willis (nee Sears) Tower in Chicago. In 2015
column32: BLK bought the 108-story landmark
column33: the world's tallest building when completed in 1973
column34: for $1.3 billion.For BlackRock
column35: that's a small deal
column36: actually. It's currently buying First Reserve Energy Infrastructure Funds
column37: a $3.7 billion owner of income-producing energy projects like mid-stream pipelines
column38: grabbing for Trump's infrastructure moneywith both hands.Fink is skeptical of the Trump rally
column39: and of the President's plans for the dollar. Fink still loves the Mexican peso and is worried about the future of the global economy in the age of Trump. But
column40: BlackRock keeps politics and business separate
column41: its response to the travel ban mainly a letter to employees.BlackRock's ETF business hasmore than $1 trillion in assets.It considers Russia a buy
column42: but is skeptical of Brexit
column43: even while former UK Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne joins BLK as an adviser.Trade Apple

column1: Trade Apple
column2: Inc. or Own It? I Have the Answer!;2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWe've all heard the argument that it's wrong to tradeApple
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). Many prominent experts rage over those who dare to trade around the price action of AAPL stock. It is confusing to investors to figure out who is wrong. Sure
column5: I could spend a few hours parsing data and calculating returns while making assumptions of entry and exit spots. Or
column6: I can accept the fact that they are both right to a degree.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockOn the one hand
column7: it is undeniable that owning Apple stock for decades has been a winning proposition. But so was trading around the chop. It comes down to what works for each us individually. Most investors enter positions but get stopped out when things go wrong. So I will refrain from judging which group is smarter.I found neutral ground using AAPL options. I commit to Apple long-term
column8: especially when it falls out of favor
column9: and leave myself room for error. I do so with no money out of pocket
column10: thereby rendering my risk to a fraction of owning the stock.Last month
column11: I created $5 per contract out of thin air trading AAPL stock when ithad appeared to be too late. Even more recently
column12: I repeated for another $1.2 yield in mere days.This strategy is easy to do on equities that are solid and what some would consider sure things like AAPL orAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column13: NASDAQ:GOOGL). I am less easy about doing this with sayNetflix
column14: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX). With stocks that are perceived to be risky
column15: such as Netflix
column16: I would need to be pickier with my entry and exit points.Today
column17: I want to repeat performance regardless of which whale bought Apple or who sold it.How to Trade AAPL Stock HereThe Trade - Long AAPL:Sell the AAPL 2018 $105 put for $2.70 to open. The 22% price buffer from current levels translate into a 90% theoretical chance of success. I only sell naked puts if I am willing and able to own AAPL stock at the strike sold. Some investors prefer spreading the risk into a credit put spread instead
column18: and that works too.7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingClick to EnlargeI have been a longtime harsh critic of Tim Cook
column19: so I don't count myself as an AAPL bull
column20: but I do know how to do math. Apple's valuation makes sense at $100 or even $200 per share given current conditions. So I do trust selling risk against that fact rather than chase hope that Tim Cook is able to grow the company.For now
column21: he has a boulder that is hard to stop
column22: and I can count on buyers to support the price.I realize that markets are at all-time highs and precariously perched. So I could buy sacrifice puts in AAPL stock to guard against a market crash. For example
column23: I could spend 20 cents buying the AAPL Jun $100 put to limit my loss if we fall off a cliff in the next four months.I am not required to hold my trades through expiration. I can close it for partial gains or losses at any time.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column24: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlaceNvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock Isn't Done CorrectingGo Short Netflix

column1: Get a Free Refill on Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM);2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLast fall whenExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM) fell hard
column3: I wrote onhow to catch a falling machete. The trade was profitable and I have since booked it. On this dip
column4: I want to reload the same setup for the opportunity for more profits.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockI am not one who likes to reinvent the wheel
column5: so I will retrace my steps almost exactly from the last time I traded XOM stock.Since my last trade
column6: oil prices overcame the $50 crude oil resistance price and established it as support. But they still haven't lived up to the entire upside measured move that should have taken out $58 per barrel. So crude oil prices are now stuck in a range.One major development since last fall is that OPEC is now committed to defending energy prices
column7: so I don't anticipate oil falling too far. Consequently
column8: I view any weakness in XOM stock as temporary and that buyers will step in to defend XOM stock.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteClick to EnlargeFundamentally
column9: XOM andChevron Corporation(NYSE:CVX) are giants with little worry over their viability. However
column10: technically XOM is at a must-bounce level. Else
column11: and if it loses current levels
column12: it could invite more technical sellers and retest $79 per share.This is not a forecast
column13: but I do have to acknowledge it as a possibility.XOM Stock Trade IdeaThe Trade - Long XOM:Sell Jan 2018 $65 put. For this I collect $1.5 per contract to open. I only sell naked puts if I am willing and able to own the stock at the strike sold. I need XOM stock to stay above my strike sold. I have a 90% theoretical chance of success with this 21% buffer from current price. My breakeven price is $63.50 per share.I chose $65 per share because it gives me room for error and it puts my risk below recent lows.Selling naked puts is not appropriate for all investors. Luckily
column14: I can modify the trade to better suit more conservative risk tastes.The Alternate Trade - Less Aggressively Long XOM:Sell the Jan 2018 $70/$67.50 credit put spread. This is a bullish trade for which I collected 40 cents per contract to open. I have a 95% theoretical chance of success to yield 17%. I have to note that the tradeoff for having a limited loss
column15: this trade has a slightly smaller price buffer from current levels.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Holders Shouldn't Worry About OracleI am not selling opposing credit spreads to hedge the trade. Instead I will closely manage the risk. I don't like to sell credit call spreads after a sharp drop in price like XOM has recently had.I can close it at any time for partial gains or losses. I may need to manage this risk through future earnings reports. The short-term price reactions earnings report are often a coin flip.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Holders Shouldn’t Worry About Oracle;2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAll too much like James Cameron's 2009 sci-fi flickAvatar
column3: just when you think the feud betweenAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL) andOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) is over
column5: you find out it's not.* Last week
column6: the iconic database company told the iconic search engine company it was appealing a ruling made against Oracle - in favor of Alphabet - in May of last year.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockFor better or worse
column7: GOOGL stock owners either didn't hear
column8: or didn't care. If it's the latter
column9: it's not terribly surprising. The company formerly known as Google is sued on a regular basis
column10: often by parties with weak cases just looking for a payday.GOOGL shareholders may want to take a closer look this time around though. While successful appeal cases are tough
column11: Oracle's argument holds slightly more water than the typical long-shot caselike the one Vringo levied (and ultimately lost) back in 2014. Moreover
column12: the case itself could have significant repercussions for other outfits in the heat of similar arguments about open source software.GOOGL: Here We Go AgainWarning: You may need to read through the intricacies of this case twice to fully understand what's going on
column13: and even then
column14: there's no guarantee it will make complete sense. Here's the crux of the argument though … Oracle says Alphabet used a little too much of its Java software - which is free
column15: open-source software - in its Android operating system.The suit largely hinges on what constitutes ""fair use"" of open-source and freely-available software.7 Stocks to Buy for the Future of TVWhile Oracle offers Java for any consumer to download and any developer to utilize pieces of
column16: the company contends it was never intended for wide swaths of the code to be cut and pasted and utilized as part of a commercial
column17: revenue-bearing system.The complaint specifically read:""The undisputed evidence showed that Google verbatim copied the heart of Oracle's creative work for an entirely commercial purpose without any change to Oracle's expressive content or message
column18: took far more than necessary to program in the Java language
column19: and
column20: in so doing
column21: harmed the market for Java.""The strength of Oracle's copyrights on its application programming interfaces
column22: or APIs
column23: was particularlyemphasizedby the company in the prior jury trial.Alphabet's counterargument is simpler -CEO Larry Page said
column24: ""We didn't pay for the free and open things.""If all of this rings a bell with GOOGL stock owners
column25: there's a reason. This argument has been waged in a courtroom a few times
column26: going back as far as 2010. The current stage for this battle of the titans is an appeal of last year's loss suffered by Oracle. That case's loss likely saved Alphabet Inc from being forced to pay the $9 billion in damages Oracle was seeking.Bottom Line for GOOGL Stock
column27: and OthersOwners of GOOGL stock don't have a great deal to worry about here. The courts sided with the company in the most recent case
column28: and appeals - a reversal of a prior judgment - are very difficult win.The case
column29: though
column30: will have far-reaching consequences beyond the Alphabet/Oracle tiff. In essence
column31: this contest could largely help affirm just how ""open"" open source code really is even if its user ends up commercializing it as Alphabet did with Java via Android. Perhaps in a bigger sense though
column32: this trial will once again serve as an indictment on decency (or lack thereof) and common sense (or
column33: again
column34: lack thereof).Why Amazon.com
column35: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1
column36: 000 in 2017While not a legal matter raised during any of the lawsuits' arguments
column37: all juror's minds were apt to be asking themselves why Oracle would offer Java in part or in whole for free - even for commercial uses - if it didn't want it to be used this extensively.Another relevant but unasked question is why Java's original developer
column38: Sun Microsystems
column39: supported Android's use of the platform before Oracle acquired Sun
column40: but Oracle switched gears on the stance after buying Sun Microsystems. And
column41: perhaps if Oracle had been more clear about how its rampant use of it in the Android OS had ""harmed the market for Java"" when it's not really otherwise monetized
column42: a judge and jury could have been a little more sympathetic.As it stands though
column43: the Oracle argument looks to be founded more on regret and frustration and less on merits. The courts so far seem to be picking up on that.Broadly speaking
column44: it all bodes well for other entities that have somehow commercialized open source software and APIs.* Avatar
column45: while a stunningly successful film
column46: was a three hour epic
column47: and could have easily ended at two points in the film before the third (and actual) ending.As of this writing
column48: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy Today10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThe postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Holders Shouldn't Worry About Oracleappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Should I Buy General Motors Company (GM) Stock? 3 Pros
column2: 3 Cons;2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM) has certainly made a tremendous comeback since 2008
column4: after having to declare bankruptcy. But there has been little for investors to cheer about. Back in late 2010
column5: the company pulled off its IPO at $33 a share. But now GM stock is at only $37.20.makeArticleAd();Source:William Oliver via Flickr (Modified)To put things into perspective
column6: InvestorPlace.com'sDana Blankenhorn has noted: ""Ever since the 2008 crash and government bailout
column7: General Motors stock has been treated like dirt. No matter what GM does
column8: it can't get out of first gear.""I actually think this is an understatement!Of course
column9: Wall Street can be inexplicable. Yet eventually investors will recognize the value. Hey
column10: this has happened with other stocks that languished for a long time
column11: such asMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column12: right?OK then
column13: so would GM stock be a good play right now? Or should investors hold off? Well
column14: to see
column15: let's take a look at 3 pros and cons on General Motors:3 Pros On GM StockMomentum: For the past two years
column16: General Motors has posted record earnings
column17: net revenues
column18: EBITDA and free cash flows. As forlast year
column19: revenues increased by 9.2% to $166.4 billion and free cash flows came to $6.9 billion
column20: up $4.7 billion from the previous year.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteThen again
column21: General Motors has continued to pump out popular cars
column22: with global sales at 10 million (making the company the No. 3 player). A big part of this has been the continued success in North America. But of course
column23: China remains a major factor as well. Last year GM reported3.87 million car sales in the country. Keep in mind that the company sells more in China than any country
column24: including the U.S.But GM has also been judicious with discounts and promotions. For the most part
column25: GM is focused on making sure it makes profits
column26: not just on increasing marketshare.Innovation: One of the hottest categories in technology is the auto industry
column27: as seen with the efforts with operators likeAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column28: NASDAQ:GOOG)
column29: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) andTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). The good news is that GM has been ramping up its investments. To this end
column30: the company made a $500 million investment inLyft(a top ride-sharing startup) as well as a $1 billion acquisition ofCruise Automation(a developer of autonomous car systems).Already there are signs that GM is getting traction. For example
column31: the company is testing over 40 autonomous Bolt EVs. But there are also some other innovations
column32: like Maven. This is a mobile platform that allows a person to search and reserve a car and unlock it with a smartphone. According toGM: ""With more than 25 million customers around the world projected to use some form of shared mobility by 2020
column33: Maven is a key element of our strategy to changing ownership models in the automotive industry.""It's important to note that GM has the advantage of leveraging its experience with OnStar
column34: which has been around for two decades. In fact
column35: during this time
column36: the system has logged about1.5 billion customer interactions.Yield & Valuation: GM has certainly been shareholder friendly. Last year
column37: the company returned a hefty $4.8 billion - in a combination of share buybacks and dividends. In fact
column38: GM stock has a nice yield of 4.1%.But the valuation is also attractive. Consider that the forward price-to-earnings ratio is at a lowly 6.1X. True
column39: this may be deserved for a company that is showing declining growth. But as for General Motors
column40: the company expects to increase the top line for 2017.In other words
column41: the stock does look like a great value play right now.3 Cons on GM StockCompetition: The environment is brutal. And with more dealmaking
column42: things will only get more intense. An example of this is the alliance ofRenault SAandNissan Motor Co Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NSANY) - which also involved the purchase of a large stake inMitsubishi Motors. With this
column43: the companies were able to realize significant cost savings and also hit a global sales number of nearly 10 million last year.Although
column44: accordingFiat SpA(ADR)(OTCMKTS:FIATY) CEO Sergio Marchionne
column45: an automaker may need to reach levels of15 million cars sold annually to be competitive! The reason is that R&D will inevitably increase because of the enormous costs of new technologies.As a result
column46: a company like GM may have little choice but to look for a similar alliance or a transformative acquisition
column47: which would definitely be risky and expensive.Politics: The election of Donald Trump is a wild card for the auto industry. On the one hand
column48: there are potential positives
column49: such as with lower corporate tax rates and less onerous regulations.But these may not offset the issues with Trump's anti-trade bent. If there is a border tax
column50: this could hurt GM because of its substantial production in Mexico. Actually
column51: about 20% of light production is in the country. So if there is a border tax
column52: it could mean higher prices in the U.S. - and yes
column53: lower sales. According to theWall Street Journal: ""Even a more modest border tax under consideration would wipe out a quarter of GM's regional profit.""Global Issues:While the markets in China and North America have been robust for GM
column54: there has been much softness in many other areas
column55: such as in Europe and South America. Granted
column56: there are signs of improvement - but the progress has been fairly slow. For example
column57: in South America
column58: GM has been able to cut back on the losses. But there was still $374 million in red ink last year.As for Europe
column59: the growth has been sluggish across the continent. It also does not help that England has enacted the Brexit
column60: which has caused a lot of uncertainty. As a result
column61: GM lost $300 million in Europe last year and it appears there will not be break-even until 2018. To put things into perspective
column62: the company has not seen a profit in the region since 2000!Bottom Line On GM StockPerhaps the biggest issue facing GM stock is the uncertainty regarding Trump's trade actions. Although
column63: given the importance of the auto industry to the US economy
column64: it does seem reasonable that any moves will likely be taken with care. Besides
column65: General Motors CEO Mary Barra has been savvy to meet with Trump several times already.Gas Up With Chesapeake Energy Corporation (CHK) StockIn the meantime
column66: she is doing a great job managing the core operations of the company. Note that there will be 18 new or refreshed models for five main brands in 2017
column67: up from 13 last year. And yes
column68: Barra has been aggressive with investments in new technologies.OK
column69: so is GM stock a good buy right now? I think so
column70: especially given the rock-bottom valuation.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand also has his own free iOS app to estimate your tax refund
column71: which is atPathwayTax.com.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column72: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace9 Top Pharmaceutical Stocks to Buy for the Dividends10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayThe postShould I Buy General Motors Company (GM) Stock? 3 Pros

column1: New Facebook Inc (FB) Video App Is Part of a Greater Plan;2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsVideo is becoming increasingly important toFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB). Social media users are big on watching video
column3: and video ads are an important revenue stream. But FB was missing out on the video action when members put down their smartphones to fire up the big screen in their living room. Not any longer. The company announced it's releasing a new Facebook video app for TV. The app will soon roll out to two of the most popular set-top streaming boxes.makeArticleAd();Source: FacebookYesterday
column4: FB made the announcement that it will bereleasing a new Facebook video app for TV.This will be an app that's available for some of the most popular set-top streaming boxes and Smart TVs. Specifically mentioned wereApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Apple TV
column5: theAmazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) Fire TV and Smart TVs fromSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF). Facebook also notes that more platforms will be supported in the future.Facebook Video App for TVLast year
column7: the company enabledsupport for mirroring Facebook videos on a TVfrom a mobile device. This required using Apple Airplay orAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column8: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Cast capabilities.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteThe new Facebook video app for TV cuts the Wi-Fi tether to a mobile device and lets users interact directly with the videos on their TV without picking up their device.""With the app
column9: you can watch videos shared by friends or Pages you follow
column10: top live videos from around the world
column11: and recommended videos based on your interests. You can also catch up on videos you've saved to watch later
column12: as well as revisit videos you've watched
column13: shared or uploaded.""Why Focus on Getting Facebook Video Onto TV Screens?FB CEO Mark Zuckerberg is intent on making video a priority for Facebook. He wasquoted in an investor callat the start of the month making that emphasis clear:""I see video as a mega trend on the same order as mobile. That's why we're going to keep putting video first across our family of apps and making it easier for people to capture and share video in new ways.""In 2016
column14: FB's push to video had resulted in users watching 100 million hours of video every day. Now the company is getting more aggressive about monetization. In January
column15: it began testing a feature that let video publishersinsert ads 20 seconds into watching their Facebook clips
column16: with FB taking 45% of the revenue generated.Yesterday's announcement of the Facebook video app for TV also included several new features for the company's core mobile users. Videos in the News Feed will now play with sound by default and the videos will be able to stay playing in picture-in-picture windows as users scroll through their News Feed.No
column17: Apple Inc. Is Not Releasing the iPhone 8 EarlyIn December
column18: FB was reportedlytaking to TV studios about the possibility of licensing content
column19: including traditional scripted shows
column20: live sports events and game shows. If the company ends up releasing licensed content from media companies (or even its own original content)
column21: a Facebook video app for TV means it can appeal to consumers who want to watch it as actual TV programming. And that introduces additional revenue opportunities - without having to split the cash with content uploaders.When Can We Expect the Facebook Video App for TV?FB is being a little vague about when it will actually release the app. The announcement says it will ""roll out soon to app stores for Apple TV
column22: Amazon Fire TV and Samsung Smart TV
column23: with more platforms to come."" So stay tuned. But with its lofty video ambitions
column24: it's a safe bet you'll be watching Facebook video on your TV sooner rather than later.As of this writing
