column1: Zacks Investment Ideas feature highlights: Twitter and Alphabet;2/15/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column2: IL - February 15
column3: 2017 - Today
column4: Zacks Investment Ideas feature highlights Features: Twitter (NYSE:TWTR-Free Report)and Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report).How Twitter Can Fix Itself by Learning from YouTubeWhen Donald Trump first began gaining some momentum in the presidential race
column5: it looked to be pretty fantastic news for Twitter (NYSE:TWTR-Free Report)
column6: and investors in the social networking giant too. After all
column7: Trump would frequently go onto the site to announce new plans or fight back against his detractors. It was (and continues to be) an incredible resource for political updates.Now that Trump is President
column8: his tweets move markets. His attacks on companies can send share prices lower in a heartbeat and are an important thing to consider for investors these days. Some haveset up apps to track his tweetsand how they relate to the market. Others do a tweet analysis in order to get better insight into the mind of the President
column9: includingThe Atlantic'sTrump Tweet Tracker.But beyond Trump
column10: Twitter also managed to become the single greatest collection of primary sources of all-time. When breaking news happens
column11: it is almost always reported first hand on Twitter
column12: and then it is disseminated out from there.You'd think that these factors alone would make Twitter an unstoppable media juggernaut. A must for journalists and those seeking to stay up-to-date on the news alike. So how has Twitter capitalized on this incredible timing and presidential stroke of luck? Well
column13: in short
column14: it hasn't.Bad Earnings Report AgainThe company posted yet another disappointing quarter for Q4
column15: missing expectations on the revenue front and posting shockingly poor active user figures. It remains stuck around the 320 million active monthly user mark
column16: and can't even seem to grow revenues either. Add in disappointing adjusted earnings guidance
column17: and it isn't a great situation by any stretch forTWTRinvestors these days
column18: especially given that the company has a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell).And let's remember
column19: these figures are with the leader of the free world literally using the service to clarify policy and goals on a regular basis. The environment cannot possibly get any better for Twitter. Its product is in the news on a near hourly basis at this point and it still can't find a way to get the job done.Clearly
column20: Twitter needs a shakeup and it needs a bit of a Hail-Mary in order to get back into investors' good graces. So
column21: what can the company do?Twitter Needs to Copy YouTube. Now.Fortunately for Twitter
column22: the path to relevancy and growth is already laid out before them. The good folks at Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) have already done all the hard work in their YouTube division and Twitter needs only to copy their best practices.First and foremost is capitalizing on the incredible missed opportunity of getting an ad right on to tweets. As you can see in the picture below
column23: there is always a big white box at the bottom right hand corner of each tweet.Why not fill that with a small advertisement? Sure
column24: some people are not going to like that
column25: but people will adjust accordingly. We saw something similar with YouTube where at first only certain videos had ads
column26: and now nearly everything has an advertisement before the video. People have adapted and it has become the norm to see this before a video. People will do the same with Twitter (and embedded tweets) and this will help with casual users (much the same way embedding helped with casual YouTubers).After all
column27: these casual users who mostly see tweets embedded somewhere else make up a huge base of people and are arguably the key to Twitter's success. Finding a way to make money off these people-much like how YouTube doesn't need you to be signed in or making videos to make revenue off of you-should be paramount in Twitter's near term plans.According to Twitter
column28: embedded tweets reach more than a billion peopleeach month across the web
column29: a truly massive figure. And that number is actually from before Donald Trump burst onto the scene and tweets were on the nightly news on a regular basis.But what if people hate this idea and recoil from the service? Well
column30: an easy way to placate people will be to pay the content generators for the work they are doing. Giving tweeters a slice of the ad revenue that they generate would go a long way to getting people and small businesses to tweet more
column31: and it is pretty much akin to what YouTube does with their stars. AndTwitter has even looked to do this on the video side
column32: so why not extend it over to their bread and butter anyway?Bottom LineAre some of these ideas going to be popular? Definitely not. But Twitter needs to try something in order to jumpstart its floundering share price and lackluster growth. Everything needs to be on the table
column33: and now is the time to do it.The company finds itself in a truly historic position and it is an opportunity that isn't going to come around every four years. The confluence of Trump and the increased desire for real-time (and unfiltered) news from around the globe should be a godsend for Twitter
column34: but the company has completely failed to capitalize on the trend.Taking some of YouTube's best practices might be a good place to start in order to return to relevancy though. It certainly has a better shot of reviving the stock than anything Twitter has come up with recently
column35: and it could push TWTR back towards growth too.And a position of growth would make Twitter a much better candidate for a takeover
column36: perhaps from a company like Alphabet. Such a partnership makes a lot of sense and it would allow better integration between Google search results and tweets
column37: while the melding of tweets and YouTube comments would be a great match as well.So
column38: if Twitter wants to get to this end-which seems like the best possible outcome for TWTR investors at this point-take a page out of YouTube's book and start thinking about ways to get more ads out there
column39: and how to benefit creators in the process. Because if Twitter can't take some risks and find a way to make things work when their service is at the forefront of news and popular culture like it is now
column40: they never will.Want key ETF info delivered straight to your   inbox?Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will brief you on top news and analysis
column41: as well as top-performing ETFs

column14: there is no need for that. Users can choose to ""disable"" the feature by switching off ""Videos in News Feed Start With Sound"" in Settings. Also
column15: Facebook has improved vertical video experiencing on mobile phones by incorporating a ""larger format."" The company also introduced a picture-in-picture view that will help users to watch videos and scroll at the same time.As video ads generate more revenues than its photo and text-based substitutes
column16: Facebook and a host of several others social media sites like TwitterTWTR) and Snapchat are trying to incorporate more and more video oriented content to bring in more ad dollars. Ad revenues contribute over 90% to Facebook's total revenue. Per media reports
column17: Facebook is looking to grab a share of the reportedly $70 billon brand advertising that is allocated to linear TV by increasing video content on its platform.  At its last earnings call
column18: Facebook said that video emerged as a ""megatrend"" on the same lines like mobile.However
column19: Facebook is yet to work out an ad model for live video. Given CEO Mark Zuckerberg's aversion to pre roll ads
column20: Facebook is reportedly testing a new ad platform - mid roll format - whereby publishers will be able to put in ads in a video (which has a minimum duration of 90 seconds) after a user has played it for 20 seconds or more. Reports add that Facebook will share revenues with publishers in a 45:55 ratio
column21: similar to that of Alphabet'sGOOGLYouTube.At present
column22: Facebook has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Moreover
column23: we note that Facebook has outperformed the Zacks categorizedInternet Servicesindustry in the last one year. The company's shares increased 31.21% compared with the industry's gain of 18.26%.Key PickA better-ranked stock in the wider technology space is MeetMe IncMEET

column1: How Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Turns Lemons Into Profits;2/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOver the past few months
column3: Facebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) has had to revise its advertising metrics several times to account for errors. For the most part
column4: the errors seem relatively minor and have had little impact on FB stock.makeArticleAd();Source:Via Stock SnapIn September
column5: management disclosed that the reported figure of average time spent viewing a video was inflated. A company post in November cited a summary figure of ""reach"" (the number of Facebook users who viewed an impression in their timeline) as being overstated.In two more posts the following month
column6: further problems were announced and more changes were made. The company changed its methodology for measuring reach (not just reporting the figure). ""Reactions"" to live video were mis-allocated
column7: and counts for ""likes"" and ""shares"" had been miscalculated.Again
column8: Facebook stock investors seem relatively unconcerned. In fact
column9: the FB stock price sits at an all-time high. But
column10: combined with general concerns about ""click fraud"" and other problems in the online advertising space
column11: the metric changes highlight a key issue for Facebook - and online advertising as a whole.How Facebook responds as a company will be key for Facebook stock.Click Fraud
column12: Bots and Facebook's ResponseIn a widely cited figure
column13: the Association of National Advertisers estimated that online ad fraud would cost $7.2 billion in 2016. (Bear in mind that Facebook alone generated $27 billion in revenue last year.) Estimates of how many ads are fraudulent range from 30%-60%. Indeed
column14: many analysts have forecast a collapse in the online advertising space as a whole.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018Much of the questionable activity comes from bots
column15: which mimic actual online users. There are also ""click farms
column16: malware and display tactics such as ""pop-under"" ads
column17: which are rarely
column18: if ever
column19: seen. Most of the complaints are directed at traffic generators and other middlemen. But
column20: some argue that programmatic marketplace operators such asRocket Fuel Inc(NASDAQ:FUEL) andCriteo SA (ADR)(NASDAQ:CRTO) are turning a blind eye to these issues.Facebook is not implicated in these tactics. In fact
column21: the company's efforts outside the platform have shown a notable willingness to fight low-quality tactics. In 2016
column22: Facebook shut down its Atlas ad-buying platform. Its head of ad tech wrote in a blog post
column23: ""We were amazed by the volume of valueless inventory"" coming into that exchange. That poor traffic was a key reason for management's decision to move on.Another unit
column24: LiveRail
column25: was shut down last year as well. Facebook paid a reported $400 million-$500 million for that company
column26: with the goal of building a video ad exchange. But
column27: similar to Atlas
column28: fraud and traffic concerns led FB to shut down the ad exchange. (In both cases
column29: Facebook has salvaged measurement capabilities from the business.)The irony of the questions surrounding Facebook's metric changes is that
column30: so far
column31: when confronted with the worst of the worst in online advertising
column32: the company has acted in a seemingly ethical manner.But the question for FB stock is what the apparently worsening state of ad tech means going forward.Are Growing Ad Tech Concerns a Plus or Minus for Facebook Stock?The core concern regarding not just fraud
column33: but poor measurement of online advertising impressions and click-throughs
column34: is that advertisers can't accurately gauge ROI. Facebook's recent measurement errors - including inflated video duration figures for more than two years - seem of a piece with that concern.There are other issues with the Facebook platform
column35: too
column36: including fake accounts
column37: for instance. In the filings ahead of the Facebook IPO
column38: the company estimated that 8.7% of accounts were fake. That figure was later updated to a range of 5%-11%. Click farms lead to paid promotions for users that aren't real potential customers. The same issues that plague online advertising more generally seem to pop up for advertisers on Facebook as well.But
column39: there's an argument that the problems in online advertising could represent another growth driver for Facebook stock. The company's closed ecosystem eliminates many of the middlemen that are alleged to cause the disruption in programmatic marketplaces. While there are fraud problems
column40: management continues to aggressively work to resolve those problems.Facebook's long-term growth potential - which
column41: in the end
column42: will drive FB stock - is based on happy customers. But keeping happy customers means Facebook must fix any potential fraud problems as quickly and aggressively as possible.Facebook is doing just that. Management announced last week that it would submit to third-party auditing by the non-profit Media Rating Council. Twenty-four third-party companies now have access to the platform to improve measurement. FB is providing more data
column43: and more options for buying as well.Why Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Holders Shouldn't Sweat SnapchatIf the concerns about online advertising are accurate - and there's an awful lot of evidence at this point - Facebook seems better-positioned than its rivals
column44: should advertisers pull back. Rather
column45: Criteo
column46: Rocket Fuel and evenAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) seem far more at risk.In that scenario
column47: actually
column48: Facebook's attractiveness to advertisers would onlyincrease. A closed platform
column49: improved measurement capabilities and third-party verification would offer confidence to those advertisers not available elsewhere on the Web.And that would be a boon for FB stock.As of this writing
column50: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 3 Best Bear Trades on Wall Street Right Now7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveApple Inc. Hits New All-Time Highs. What's Next?The postHow Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Turns Lemons Into Profitsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: How Twitter Can Fix Itself by Learning from YouTube;2/14/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();When Donald Trump first began gaining some momentum in the presidential race
column2: it looked to be pretty fantastic news for Twitter (TWTR)
column3: and investors in the social networking giant too. After all
column4: Trump would frequently go onto the site to announce new plans or fight back against his detractors. It was (and continues to be) an incredible resource for political updates.Now that Trump is President
column5: his tweets move markets. His attacks on companies can send share prices lower in a heartbeat and are an important thing to consider for investors these days. Some haveset up apps to track his tweetsand how they relate to the market. Others do a tweet analysis in order to get better insight into the mind of the President
column6: includingThe Atlantic'sTrump Tweet Tracker.But beyond Trump
column7: Twitter also managed to become the single greatest collection of primary sources of all-time. When breaking news happens
column8: it is almost always reported first hand on Twitter
column9: and then it is disseminated out from there.You'd think that these factors alone would make Twitter an unstoppable media juggernaut. A must for journalists and those seeking to stay up-to-date on the news alike. So how has Twitter capitalized on this incredible timing and presidential stroke of luck? Well
column10: in short
column11: it hasn't.Bad Earnings Report AgainThe company posted yet another disappointing quarter for Q4
column12: missing expectations on the revenue front and posting shockingly poor active user figures. It remains stuck around the 320 million active monthly user mark
column13: and can't even seem to grow revenues either. Add in disappointing adjusted earnings guidance
column14: and it isn't a great situation by any stretch for TWTR investors these days
column15: especially given that the company has a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell).And let's remember
column16: these figures are with the leader of the free world literally using the service to clarify policy and goals on a regular basis. The environment cannot possibly get any better for Twitter. Its product is in the news on a near hourly basis at this point and it still can't find a way to get the job done.Clearly
column17: Twitter needs a shakeup and it needs a bit of a Hail-Mary in order to get back into investors' good graces. So
column18: what can the company do?Twitter Needs to Copy YouTube. Now.Fortunately for Twitter
column19: the path to relevancy and growth is already laid out before them. The good folks at Alphabet ( GOOGL) ( GOOG) have already done all the hard work in their YouTube division and Twitter needs only to copy their best practices.First and foremost is capitalizing on the incredible missed opportunity of getting an ad right on to tweets. As you can see in the picture below
column20: there is always a big white box at the bottom right hand corner of each tweet.Why not fill that with a small advertisement? Sure
column21: some people are not going to like that
column22: but people will adjust accordingly. We saw something similar with YouTube where at first only certain videos had ads
column23: and now nearly everything has an advertisement before the video. People have adapted and it has become the norm to see this before a video. People will do the same with Twitter (and embedded tweets) and this will help with casual users (much the same way embedding helped with casual YouTubers).After all
column24: these casual users who mostly see tweets embedded somewhere else make up a huge base of people and are arguably the key to Twitter's success. Finding a way to make money off these people-much like how YouTube doesn't need you to be signed in or making videos to make revenue off of you-should be paramount in Twitter's near term plans.According to Twitter
column25: embedded tweets reach more than a billion peopleeach month across the web
column26: a truly massive figure. And that number is actually from before Donald Trump burst onto the scene and tweets were on the nightly news on a regular basis.But what if people hate this idea and recoil from the service? Well
column27: an easy way to placate people will be to pay the content generators for the work they are doing. Giving tweeters a slice of the ad revenue that they generate would go a long way to getting people and small businesses to tweet more
column28: and it is pretty much akin to what YouTube does with their stars. AndTwitter has even looked to do this on the video side
column29: so why not extend it over to their bread and butter anyway?Bottom LineAre some of these ideas going to be popular? Definitely not. But Twitter needs to try something in order to jumpstart its floundering share price and lackluster growth. Everything needs to be on the table
column30: and now is the time to do it.The company finds itself in a truly historic position and it is an opportunity that isn't going to come around every four years. The confluence of Trump and the increased desire for real-time (and unfiltered) news from around the globe should be a godsend for Twitter
column31: but the company has completely failed to capitalize on the trend.Taking some of YouTube's best practices might be a good place to start in order to return to relevancy though. It certainly has a better shot of reviving the stock than anything Twitter has come up with recently
column32: and it could push TWTR back towards growth too.And a position of growth would make Twitter a much better candidate for a takeover
column33: perhaps from a company like Alphabet. Such a partnership makes a lot of sense and it would allow better integration between Google search results and tweets
column34: while the melding of tweets and YouTube comments would be a great match as well.So
column35: if Twitter wants to get to this end-which seems like the best possible outcome for TWTR investors at this point-take a page out of YouTube's book and start thinking about ways to get more ads out there
column36: and how to benefit creators in the process. Because if Twitter can't take some risks and find a way to make things work when their service is at the forefront of news and popular culture like it is now
column37: they never will.Want key ETF info delivered straight to your inbox?Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will brief you on top news and analysis
column38: as well as top-performing ETFs
column39: each week.Get it free >>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today
column40: you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free reportTwitter

column1: Exploiting The Amateur Investor's Edge: Investing In What You Know To Discover Bargains And Earn Conservative
column2: Outsized Returns;2/14/2017;"ByMichael Seeley:""Buying what you know about is a very sophisticated strategy that many professionals have neglected to put into practice.""[i]- Peter LynchThe author isn't sure just how descriptive the above statement is when applied to institutional money managers and investment analysts today. The ones we have spoken to seem to have a very detailed understanding of all the companies and industries they cover. The author does believe it accurately describes the average individual stockpicker.makeArticleAd();IntroductionInvesting
column3: as practiced by the average investor
column4: is a game rigged so the housealmostalways wins. Wall Street will take the average investor's life savings
column5: and will do so dispassionately and unapologetically. This fundamental understanding is essential to engaging in buying and selling activity in the market.""Investing is a zero-sum game. To buy a stock
column6: someone else has to be selling.You are betting you know the company better than the person that is selling it to you.""[ii]- Peter LynchMake no mistake about it
column7: buying and selling stocks is a competition. It is serious
column8: it is real
column9: and if one is not constantly aware of this fact and doesn't take it seriously
column10: one is apt to be a sucker. Someone is always trying to either sell someone else an overpriced security
column11: or they are trying to buy another person's underpriced security for pennies on the dollar. That is what the market often is
column12: [iii]an exchange to take advantage of the person on the other end of a transaction. This reality is not always appreciated
column13: as one's competitor is rarely seen
column14: but it is a competition all the same
column15: and one with real financial stakes. Every single time you buy or sell a stock
column16: there is somebody on the other side of that transaction betting you are wrong
column17: and they are betting real money on it. They are also betting they know more than you
column18: and they are trying to exploit your ignorance in the business underlying the security.""There are rich teams
column19: and there are poor teams
column20: and then there's fifty feet of crap
column21: and then there is us."" - Brad Pitt's character Billy Beane in Michael Lewis'Moneyball
column22: speaking of the Oakland AthleticsWhat's more
column23: the game most institutional money managers and Wall Street institutions play is stacked heavily intheirfavor. They have more resources than the amateur investor
column24: better industry coverage
column25: better contacts
column26: better access to management teams
column27: better technology
column28: brilliant (and let's face it
column29: moreintelligent) analysts with more prestigious post graduate and doctoral degrees from the finest institutions in the country. Playing a game even remotely in this machine's wheelhouse is almost certain to be a disaster. The chances are that those institutions are generally on the other side of every transaction the amateur investor enters into.If the reader is not yet discouraged
column30: he or sheshouldbe. Forgetting the above facts and becoming complacent
column31: or even arrogant
column32: will not lend the sense of humility and caution that are necessary for successful stock picking. A measure ofarroganceis necessary in picking stocks
column33: but it must always be balanced with humility and awareness
column34: and it is good only when logically supported by research and analysis. All of this brings us to a harsh truth that the reader will be wise to remember.""Choosing individual stocks without any idea of what you're looking for is like running through a dynamite factory with a burning match. You may live
column35: but you're still an idiot.""[iv]- Joel GreenblattIf we accept Mr. Greenblatt's statement as true
column36: and the author is a firm believer it is true
column37: then why even try to buy and sell individual securities?Well
column38: the real truth is that buying and selling individual stocks is generally only stupid if one engages in the practice in the way almost everybody always does. Put another way
column39: there is a right way
column40: and then there is the way nearly everyone does it.The right way is the exception.Despite all the above
column41: the amateur may still achieve results in excess of the majority of the professionalsifthe amateur insists on playing his or her own game on his or her own field. To make money consistently over the long term
column42: the investor needs toonlybet when the odds are in his or her favor; in other words
column43: only when he or she has anedgeover the competition.How do we do that? The author will answer the question by posing a few questions of his own:Wouldn't it be nice if undervalued companies that are profitable
column44: with durable competitive advantages and reliable earnings streams
column45: companies that may even be likely to compound over time had like a flashing light and loud noise going off to attract our attention
column46: but only our attention (meaning most of the competition would miss the signs)?Wouldn't it be nice if we could take the thing we are best at
column47: that we know the most about
column48: and we could place bets on that
column49: and even then could choose to only bet when we were certain
column50: or nearly certain that we will win?What we will do in this particular article is to identify a specific ""edge"" that provides most investors a leg up over the large financial institutions and over the army of financial analysts on Wall Street. An edge is a place where the odds are stacked in your favor
column51: through practice
column52: knowledge
column53: skill
column54: time frame
column55: or location. We will also provide real world examples on how to exploit these edges
column56: but first
column57: please permit us an analogy
column58: to really drive the concepts home into the reader's grey matter.Selecting Your Opponent…I cannot help but remember my friend from London
column59: in what is known as theEast End. Mr. McDonald-Smith is a fairly large man of Jamaican descent
column60: speaks fluent Spanish due to a couple of years living in the Dominican Republic
column61: and is
column62: as they say in England
column63: quite fit. You know the type
column64: someone with arms the size of their head where even an extra-large shirt is in constant danger of popping its buttons? Mr. McDonald-Smith can honestly boast that he has never been beaten in arm-wrestling. This feat is not overly surprising when looking at him
column65: but how is it possible that one can have a100%success rate in anything? Surely
column66: there is always someone stronger
column67: or more skilled

column71: the fact is that Mr. McDonald-Smith is undefeated due to a very simple strategy that is designed to help him be successful.What is his secret? It is quite simple.He never engages in a match with anybody that he isn't absolutely certain he can beat.In such a manner

column76: undefeated and triumphant. Why is this important? Well
column77: Mr. McDonald-Smith has an edge in arm-wrestling. He is large of stature. He is strong. He is fit. He is smart. And he manages his ego. Taken as a percentage
column78: the probabilities of encountering a formidable opponent are quite small. On the rare occasion that he meets such an opponent
column79: Mr. McDonald-Smith graciously declines the match.Now

column1: Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN): Is It Time to Start Worrying?;2/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) seems unstoppable. This is also one of the biggest problems for AMZN stock. When everyone is in
column4: there is no upside left. Of the 43 analysts now covering Amazon
column5: 33 have it rated as a buyand none have it lower than a hold.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBut the expectations attached to these recommendations are what should give Amazon bulls pause. Most analysts expect sharp acceleration of earnings this year
column6: far beyond what the company has delivered so far
column7: with estimates as high as $17.43 per share in 2018.AMZN is a company which
column8: until recently
column9: never made any money
column10: instead being obsessed with plowing every dollar it could find into growth opportunities.Even after closing the books on 2016 - net income of $2.371 billion
column11: or $4.90 per share on revenue of $135.987 billion - Amazon's profitability still trails that ofWal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT)
column12: which earned $3.034 billion
column13: or 98 cents per share
column14: on revenue of $118.790 billion in the October quarter alone.4 Dow Jones Titans That Are Shooting HigherThe super-bullish stance on Amazon stock is based on the idea that
column15: despite its growth
column16: it still has a long way to grow
column17: and that it will soon extract margins the retail industry has never seen.Forget stopping Amazon
column18: though. But
column19: can anyone hope to contain it?Eye-Popping NumbersAt its Feb. 13 opening price just below $832 per share
column20: Amazon stock is selling at 168 times 2016 earnings. Its market cap of $402 billion represents approximately three times its sales
column21: which is an absurd number for a company that is still
column22: at heart
column23: a retailer. Most retail market caps are a fraction of revenue.But of course
column24: the bulls respond
column25: Amazon isn't really a retailer. Indeed
column26: AMZN is the leading cloud provider
column27: a front-runner in artificial intelligence with Alexa
column28: and is the first ""over the top"" video provider to gain Oscar buzz.All elements of its logistics are for sale
column29: includingpayments
column30: deliveries andeverything in between.Wherever you look with Amazon
column31: you seeeye-popping numbers. It's not just an American growth story anymore
column32: it's a global one.What Can Slow AmazonAmazon doesn't have to be stopped for AMZN stock to suffer. Any sign of a slowdown could cut its value by half
column33: or perhaps even more.Source:FlickrJeff Bezos has been honest about what could happen. He is worried about""trade and protectionist measures""from the new Administration
column34: and he isfiercely opposedto the Administration's recent orders on immigration.Political risks may have moved Bezos to buya $23 million housein Washington D.C. - and politics costs money. However
column35: thosepolitical risks are not just Americanand they are not just physical. A Balkanization of the Internet - the requirement that local data only be used locally
column36: and that citizens of each country read or see only what leaders want - could prove costly to implement. But
column37: it's already happeningin the world of books.Despite efforts to control costs by owning its own logistics
column38: delivery costs remain a concern.Is it Really Good to Be the King?Amazon may be King
column39: but the crown hangs heavy. AMZN managers know thatcompetitors are catching up in the cloud space
column40: Alphabet Inc.(NASDAQ:GOOGL) is challenging Alexa and has the capital to beat it in the cloud
column41: and Amazon's success with tabletshas the potential to threatenApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All WorldsNo tree grows to the sky
column42: and likewise
column43: no business can conquer the whole world of technology
column44: media and retail. Amazon has a host of challengers wherever its managers look
column45: and its ambitions are also facing political resistance.Does this mean I'm selling out of Amazon stock and predicting a crash? No. But
column46: when everyone's telling you to buy something
column47: that's actually when you should start to worry
column48: and I've started to worry about Amazon.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column49: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in AMZN
column50: AAPL and GOOGL.More From InvestorPlace7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You Deserve5 Income Tax Deductions You Can't Afford to Miss10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayThe postAmazon.com Inc. (AMZN): Is It Time to Start Worrying?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Internet of Things Stocks You Don't Have to Babysit;2/13/2017;"The technology sector isn't always the best place for   investment stability
column2: nor are new technology trends ever much of   a safe investment. But it doesn't have to be this way. The   Internet of Things (IoT) is ushering in a massive wave of   technological changes -- nearly 50 billion things will be   connected to the IoT by 2020 -- and there are three companies at   the forefront of this $7 trillion market that should remain   steady
column3: long-term investments:Verizon Communications(NYSE: VZ)
column4: Cisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column5: andAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Verizon CommunicationsVerizon is stalwart dividend stock that has plenty of   long-term potential in the IoT. The company already   dominates the wireless network space despite cutthroat   competition fromAT&TandT-Mobile
column6: and it's only getting stronger.Verizon is making early investments in 5G networks that should   give the company an edge over its competitors in the IoT network   space
column7: much like the company's early push into 4G kept it ahead   of the competition. Verizon calls 5G the ""foundation for creating   more internet-connected devices"" and says that it will use the   network to bring traffic lights
column8: stop signs
column9: parking meters
column10: and   other city systems online.Over the next few months
column11: the company plans on rolling out   commercial 5G field tests in a few locations. Verizon CEO Lowell   McAdam said at an investor conference in December that he   believes the company is two to three years ahead of the   competition for 5G because of its early tests and the company's   recent purchase of the fiber-optic network company XO   Communications.5G will allow new types of faster-than-ever device   connections
column12: and Verizon's early mover advantage could pay off   down the road.Cisco SystemsCisco is a perfect example of a company that will plug away in   its respective field without offering investors much drama -- and   at the same time provide a nice 3.3% dividend yield to boot.Cisco has been talking about the IoT for quite some time
column13: but   one of biggest moves came early last year when the company   announced it was buying Jasper Technologies for $1.4 billion.Jasper is a cloud-based IoT service platform that allows   enterprise and service customers to ""launch
column14: manage and monetize   IoT services on a global scale."" In short
column15: Jasper allows   companies to bring nearly any device online (think cars or jet   engines) and then manage those connections through its   proprietary software.Jasper brings with it 3
column16: 500 enterprise customers from around   the world that have devices running on 27 service providers.   And Cisco said that it will be able to add to Jasper's   services with its own enterprise Wi-Fi
column17: IoT security solutions
column18: and advanced analytics.With Jasper
column19: Cisco transitions further into the the   software-as-a-service (SaaS) market that brings recurring   revenue
column20: and allows the company to rely a little less on the   traditionally cyclical hardware market.AlphabetAlphabet and its subsidiaries have been extremely aggressive   in the IoT space
column21: and given the company's massive market size and   its quarterly revenues north of  $26 billion
column22: this is   certainly a company investors don't need to babysit.Most of Alphabet's IoT opportunities stem from Google
column23: which   is already a leader in the connected home space with Google Home   and Nest Labs. By having a slew of IoT devices for the home
column24: along with an embedded smart assistant in Google Home
column25: the   company is helping to lead the way in IoT home connections.But one of Alphabet's biggest IoT pushes right now comes from   a company called Waymo
column26: which wasrecently spun out of Google. Waymo is the product of years of research and real-world   testing of self-driving cars and Google is looking to the company   to now stand on its own and start generating revenue.Waymo has partnered withFiat Chryslerto bring 100 self-driving minivans to to the roadways to begin   testing an autonomous driving service. The company is likely   still years away from bringing in any significant revenue for   Google
column27: but it's clear that under Alphabet's umbrella   self-driving tech is a big part of the company's IoT plans.On top of that
column28: other companies under Alphabet are exploring   IoT possibilities
column29: like usingnanoparticles to find diseasesin the bloodstream
column30: by pairing them to wearable tech devices.Whatever you do
column31: just don't miss this opportunityInvestors looking for steady companies shouldn't overlook themassive opportunities that the IoT has to   offer. Nearly 50 billion things will be connecting the internet in   just a few years and the IoT market has the potential to   transform many aspects of our lives. The three stocks above are   all big tech names that are tapping into the IoT's potential in   their own way
column32: offering investors growth opportunities on top of   stable existing businesses.10 stocks we like better than Verizon     CommunicationsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column33: it can pay to listen. After all
column34: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column35: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column36: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Verizon Communications     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column38: an executive at Alphabet
column39: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Chris Neigerhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Alphabet (A shares) and Alphabet (C     shares). The Motley Fool recommends Cisco Systems
column40: T-Mobile US
column41: and Verizon Communications. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Alphabet Inc – Is Google Assistant Going Everywhere? (GOOGL);2/13/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Pixel Phone holds a significant advantage over third-party Android smartphones. Since its release
column4: Google Assistant - the new AI powered personal assistant - has been a Pixel Phone exclusive. Third-party smartphones remain stuck with the previous generation Google Now. However
column5: Google released an Android ""alpha"" build late last week and the new Android release enables Google Assistant on third-party smartphones.makeArticleAd();Source: GoogleGOOGL's third-party Android smartphone partners have been feeling a little betrayed since the release of the Pixel Phone last fall.Up until then
column6: Google had not been directly competing against them. It developed Android and allowed them to use the operating system on their phones for free - a fair trade off for the hundreds of millions of mobile devices defaulting to revenue-generating Google search. Google did release the Nexus line of smartphones
column7: but they were more of a showcase for Android than an attempt to compete against its partners.The Pixel Phone's Google Assistant AdvantageThe Pixel Phone changed the equation. It was stamped with the Google name for the first time and it was designed to compete head-to-head with the best of the Android smartphones. In another first
column8: a key new Android feature - Google Assistant - was a Pixel Phone exclusive. Google Assistant leverages Alphabet's latest AI technology in a personal digital assistant that goes beyond Google Now
column9: even gaining the ability to participate in two-way conversations.The situation was serious enough to help convince Android smartphone leaderSamsung Electronic Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) that it needed its own personal assistant. Samsung'sBixby is expected to debut on the Galaxy S8.7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendNew Android Release Spills the Beans: Google Assistant for All?Android Policeexamined a developer ""alpha"" release of Android over the weekend and discovered thatGOOGL may be having a change of heartabout keeping Google Assistant to itself.Its team was able to activate and use Google Assistant on several non-Pixel smartphones
column10: including a Samsung Galaxy Note 5 running Android Marshmallow and a Nexus 6P running Android Nougat.This means that GOOGL is at least experimenting with making Google Assistant available to third-party smartphones in an upcoming new Android release.Where Would This Leave the Pixel Phone?While Google's Pixel Phone has premium design and a very nice camera
column11: its primary advantage over third-party smartphones is the exclusive availability of Google Assistant. Take that away and it's more or less competing on a level footing with the big guns from the likes of Samsung. True
column12: the Pixel Phone is guaranteed Android updates
column13: but that's no different than the Nexus phones.No
column14: Apple Inc. Is Not Releasing the iPhone 8 EarlyWith AI and digital assistants in the spotlight
column15: Google may have decided that having Google Assistant become a standard Android feature is important to maintain its lead overApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhones and Siri.I wrote a few days ago about Google's struggle againstAmazon.com
column16: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)in the smart home. The Amazon Echo and Alexa have taken a huge lead there and Google Assistant on the Google Home speaker and Pixel Phones may not be enough to catch it. If it were to give up its exclusivity and enable Google Assistant on third-party smartphones
column17: GOOGL would suddenly have hundreds of millions of additional devices in play. This would give it far more leverage against Amazon
column18: at the cost of the Pixel Phone competing on a more level playing field.And the company has always marketed the Pixel Phone as being the ""first phone"" with Google Assistant - not the ""only phone"" - leaving the door open for an eventual general roll-out.Of course
column19: at this point we aren't certain that GOOGL will pull the trigger. The new Android release in question is alpha software - that'sbeforebeta. The company may simply be having some developers test Google Assistant compatibility with third-party hardware with no intention of actually opening up the feature. However
column20: hints like the message ""New! You just got the Google Assistant"" suggest that GOOGL is leaning toward ending Pixel Phone exclusivity and rolling out the AI-powered feature as part of a general Android release.As of this writing
column21: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceIs Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?Report: Apple Inc. iPhone 8 Could Cost More Than $1
column22: 000 (AAPL)The postAlphabet Inc - Is Google Assistant Going Everywhere? (GOOGL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Facebook Agrees to MRC Audit Following Ad Data Discrepancy;2/13/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Facebook Inc.FBrecently agreed to evaluation of its advertising metrics by measurement watchdog Media Rating Council (MRC). This is quite unsurprising in the light of the confessions by the tech giant regarding its miscalculations of ad measurements last year.Last September
column2: Facebook first indentified a ""mistake"" in it ads metrics. The company realized that it had been overstating the average time spent by users on watching videos. The company only took into account the video with views greater than three seconds
column3: excluding the ones with the views of lesser time
column4: thereby leading to greater than actual average view metrics. Following this
column5: in Nov 2016
column6: Facebook revealed that it had found 'discrepancies"" in calculation in four more metrics followed by two more in December.Facebook
column7: Inc. PriceFacebook
column8: Inc. Price|Facebook
column9: Inc. QuoteFacebook had been facing pressure from advertisers and publishers to gain approval from MRC. Further
column10: per media reports
column11: Carolyn Everson
column12: the global marketing solutions' vice president for Facebook has conveyed to the Association of National Advertisers that Facebook will be providing ""granular data"" to third parties like Integral Ad Science and Moat for making it easier for advertisers and publishers to verify data through the third party. Notably

column1: Why Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Would Win Big With a Twitter Buyout;2/13/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsData it's what makes the tech world go 'round. And in the case ofAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column4: it's what drives its profits
column5: cash flows and ultimately the value of its stock. Google has made a name for itself delving into people's lives
column6: running it through an algorithm and selling the output to advertisers. Pretty much everything GOOGL stock does -even controlling your thermostat- has to do with creating this huge base of data for the company to play with.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAnd its latest
column7: and somewhat secret moves are all about getting its hands another massive pile of people's lives. Google is buying floundering social media networkTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR).Well
column8: not entirely. But GOOGL has started picking off pieces of the Twitter corpse. And by snagging some of TWTR's items now
column9: Alphabet could be setting itself up for to buy the whole enchilada later on. In the end
column10: that actually might be a great deal for GOOGL stock investors as its all about the data.GOOGL Snags Developer ToolsTwitter has been a potential buyout candidate basically the second it IPO'd a few years ago. Perhaps even more so now that the social network has struggled to see user growth and profitability. TWTR stock has plunged about 60% since its public offering. But like Google
column11: Twitter is much more than just its namesake service. In this case
column12: it's about app development.For an undisclosed sum
column13: Alphabet hasagreed to buyout Twitter'smain developer project - Fabric.7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All WorldsFabric provides a software toolkit for development and design of mobile apps. And even though it's part of Twitter
column14: it's not small potatoes. The software is used by more than 580
column15: 000 mobile developers includingAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NASDAQ:BABA) andWal-Mart Stores Inc's(NYSE:WMT) Jet.com.Fabric will be folded into Google's own Firebase mobile developer platform
column16: and its employees will be now part of Alphabet.So why would the company want this stuff and the talent pool? As I said
column17: it's all about data.With the addition of Fabric
column18: GOOGL will own two of the most popular tools for developing mobile apps. Fabric is a favorite stomping ground for app development forApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) iOS software for iPhones/iPads. By having the two under one umbrella
column19: it gives Alphabet an easy inroad to help developers make formerly exclusive iPhone apps available for the mobile web and Google's Android software. You know
column20: where GOOGL stock makes a bulk of its advertising dollars.The second big data kicker comes from the fact that while much of Google's tools are available for free; many developers will buy computing power and storage from the company's cloud service. It's expected that once Fabric is integrated fully
column21: the deal would be the same. Not only does that boost GOOGL's cloud revenues
column22: but it gives it a chance to comb through all the data being produced and potentially mine it for what it is worth.Backend as a service (BaaS) platforms like Fabric and Firebase fit perfectly into Google's ""Here
column23: have it for free
column24: we'll just keep the data"" business model.In the end
column25: the purchase will allow Google to further cement itself as one of the world's biggest mobile app developers and give it a new source of additional revenue.Alphabet Still Wants BluebirdBut what about Twitter's real function - those juicy 140 character tweets and the social network? Even though Google didn't make an offer to buy the firm
column26: the truth is
column27: Twitter proper still makes for an excellent fit for GOOGL stock. Twitter has a hard time data mining and getting advertisers to embrace all those tweets. But for someone like Google
column28: the social media network - and its 300 million users - is pure gold. Advertisers are starting to prefer social media networks and their ability to drill down to specific users.How Twitter Inc (TWTR) Stock Fooled the Suckers AgainThe idea behind Twitter selling off this hobby business was so that it could focus on boosting the main product's user base
column29: remove spam/bots and make it a better product. Buy waiting to buy it later
column30: all the hard clean-up work will be done. And if it is still floundering
column31: it gives Alphabet a chance to buy it on the cheap. And considering that there will be now plenty of former Twitter employees at GOOGL
column32: integrating it later on will be a snap.Bottom Line on GOOGL StockWhile it continues to be a perpetual rumor
column33: Google's latest actions suggest that Twitter will very much be an Alphabet business in the future. The moves to strengthen its one developer base in mobile apps and snag key personal from the social media company is just the first step. It gives plenty of time for Twitter to refocus and reorganize. In the meantime
column34: the additional revenue from Fabric and cloud sales will be certainly welcome.And when Google finally does buy TWTR
column35: it'll be great news for GOOGL stock. That's 300 million more users it can mine for data and potential extract useful info for advertisers. Google is just one step closer to putting the rumors to rest and snagging the social media company.As of this writing
column36: Aaron Levitt did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy Today7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendThe postWhy Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Would Win Big With a Twitter Buyoutappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Google's Biggest Cloud Customer Just Signed a $1 Billion Deal With Amazon;2/12/2017;"It didn't take long for Google's biggest cloud customer to   split its allegiances. Just a week afterSnap(NYSE: SNAP) announced it signed a $2 billion five-year contract   with theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) company
column2: it signed a $1 billion   contract with Google's biggest cloud competitor --Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) .Snap will continue to use Google Cloud for the core Snapchat   functionality. The Amazon Web Services contract is for ""redundant   infrastructure support of our business operations
column3: according to   Snap'samended S-1filing.The new filing also revealed Snap has been using Amazon for   nearly a year
column4: so not much will change in the near term. But the   way Snap's contract is structured with Amazon
column5: it could be   spending nearly as much on AWS five years from now as it is on   Google Cloud.makeArticleAd();It's worth taking a closer look at Snap's cloud contracts.     Image Source: Snap.A quick look at Snap's cloud contractsYearAmazon spendingGoogle spending2017$50 million$400 million*2018$125 million$400 million*2019$200 million$400 million*2020$275 million$400 million*2021$350 million$400 millionSource: Snap S-1. *Snap has the option to defer up to 15% of   the amount to the subsequent year.Snap uses Google for most of its heavy lifting today. That   might change in five years. While Amazon just provides redundancy   for Snapchat to ensure the app doesn't suffer significant   downtime right now
column6: it could grow into a much bigger partner for   Snap. That's evident by the ramp in minimum obligations.Google still has a big advantage over Amazon. Snap built   Snapchat on Google's Cloud Platform. Transition to another cloud   provider ""would be difficult to implement
column7: and may cause us to   incur significant time and expense
column8: it said in its S-1. What's   more
column9: Snap built Snapchat using the tools available on Google
column10: some of which do not have an alternative in the market
column11: according to its prospectus.But if Snap wants to expand to China
column12: where Google doesn't   operate
column13: it'll have to rework things on another cloud provider
column14: anyway. Considering the growing size of Snap's cloud spending
column15: Amazon may be able to offer tools comparable to what it uses on   Google to help facilitate a transition.Google's cloud business is minuscule in comparison to   Amazon's. Snap's $400 million per year contract very likely made   it Google's biggest cloud customer
column16: and now Amazon's going to   steal away a good chunk of its business. That doesn't mean much   for Amazon -- its cloud business brought in $12 billion last year   -- but it means a whole lot to Google.What this means for SnapSnap is now committing $3 billion to cloud services over the   next five years. That's a lot for a company with only $405   million in annual revenue
column17: even one growing as quickly as   Snap.At some point
column18: it would make more sense for Snap to build out   its own infrastructure like other popular internet services.   Building infrastructure is capital intensive
column19: but once it's   built
column20: the company would no longer be as reliant on third parties   to support its flagship app. With Snap locked into contracts for   the next five years
column21: it's unlikely we'll see it go that way   anytime soon
column22: which means continued pressure on its gross   margin.Last year
column23: Snap's cost of revenue exceeded sales. The bulk of   its cost of revenue was attributed to its cloud infrastructure   expenses
column24: which climbed $192 million last year. As such
column25: Snap   posted a negative gross margin
column26: which is crazy for a company that   primarily produces software.By 2021
column27: Snap will be paying at least $750 million for cloud   services. That will make it one of the largest cloud-computing   customers in the world. With that much committed to Google and   Amazon
column28: Snap better get to work on growing its revenue.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 5 Things We Learned From The Wall Street Journal's Exclusive Report on SpaceX;2/12/2017;"By now you've almost certainly heardthe big news about SpaceX: Last month
column2: The Wall Street Journaluncovered a treasure trove of internal   documentsfrom the company. These documents clearly demonstrate that   SpaceX is neither profitable nor cash flow positive any   longer.It's what you maynothave heard
column3: though
column4: that will really shock you: SpaceX never   planned to earn much profit from launching rockets in the first   place. Instead
column5: SpaceX is placing its faith in a megaproject
column6: partially backed byAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column7: to create a satellite broadband   internet constellation
column8: which will encircle the globe
column9: and (as   theJournalputs it) ""eventually dwarf [SpaceX's] rocket division.""Now
column10: here are five more things you need to know about SpaceX's   secret plan for satellite dominance.makeArticleAd();Look! Up in the sky! It's not a bird or a plane -- it's how     SpaceX hopes to turn profitable. Image source: Getty     Images.1. Tiny satellites
column11: huge profitsWhile most famous today for its rocket launches (and soon to   become famous for launching reused rockets
column12: perhaps as soon as   this month)
column13: SpaceX sees rockets as only a small part of its   plans for future profits.According to internal documents dated from 2015
column14: SpaceX hopes   to begin putting aconstellation of 4
column15: 425 broadband internet   satellitesinto orbit in 2018
column16: and begin collecting revenue from it as an   internet service provider as early as 2019.2. Moving the needleThat year
column17: revenue from satellites will be minuscule -- a few   hundred million dollars at most
column18: and probably contributing   nothing to profits. Just one year later
column19: however
column21: SpaceX   expects to get roughly equal amounts of revenue from rocket   launches and from satellite internet
column22: about $3 billion each.   Profits are expected to leap to $2 billion -- 33% of revenue.3. Blasting offAnd this is just the beginning. SpaceX expects its revenue   from satellite internet to grow by leaps and bounds from 2020 on
column23: eclipsing revenue from rocket launches in 2021. SpaceX expects   that by 2022
column24: satellite revenue will account for roughly 75% ofallrevenue the company collects
column25: then grow to more than 80% in 2023
column26: and to 85% or more in 2024 and 2025 -- by which time SpaceX   expects to be regularlylanding astronauts on Mars.4. Planned obsolescence for rocket launches?You might expect that once SpaceX has begun its Mars   colonization project
column27: the company would lose interest in the   workaday business of merely lofting satellites into Earth orbit   -- and you'd be right.SpaceX's rocket launch plans got knocked off track by its twin   SpaceXplosions in 2015 and 2016. But before those plans went   askew
column28: the company had mapped out a surprising future for its   rocket launch program. Starting off from a base of zero launches   in 2011
column29: SpaceX planned to steadily increase the pace of launches   through 2019. SpaceX had 27 launches slated for this year
column30: for   example. That number would grow to 44 launches in 2018
column31: and then   52 in 2019. But in 2020
column32: satellite launch activity would suddenly   reverse course
column33: and fall to just 41 launches.At the same time
column34: SpaceX projects modest increases in launchrevenueeven after 2020. The logical conclusion is that by 2020
column35: what few   rockets SpaceX is still launching will be bigger
column36: and more   expensive
column37: and will carry bigger
column38: more expensive satellites
column39: too   -- just not as many of them.5. A margin explosionSo what does all of this mean for SpaceX stock
column40: and for the   investors who hope to invest ina possible eventual SpaceX IPO?As we explained last week
column41: SpaceX's internal documents show   that even in the best of years
column42: it has been only marginally   profitable
column43: and is not profitable at all at present. Introducing   reusable rocket launches
column44: as the company plans to do this month
column45: holds the potential to put SpaceX back in the black. But   significant profits -- the kind that can finance the colonization   of Mars -- will depend on the company's successful deployment and   operation of a constellation of broadband internet   satellites.Based on the numbers laid out above
column46: SpaceX appears to be   targeting operating profit margins of 33% once its satellites   begin operating in 2020. Operating profits could total $4 billion   by 2021 (a profit margin of more than 40% on projected revenue of   about $9.5 billion). Margins will top 50% by 2022 -- then soar   into the mid-50s range in 2023
column47: and finally top out at better   than 60% by 2025. At that point
column48: SpaceX expects to be collecting   $36 billion in annual revenue -- almost all of it from satellites   -- and earning roughly $22 billion in operating profit. To put   that final goal in context
column49: $22 billion inprofitis 11 times more than the $1 billion inrevenuethat SpaceX collected in 2014
column50: its best revenue year ever.Logical conclusion:IfSpaceX can bring its broadband satellite internet project to   fruition
column51: SpaceX stock could turn out to be a very profitable   investment. But if you're planning to invest in SpaceX
column52: you need   to do it for the satellite business (which doesn't exist yet)
column53: and not for the rocket launch business that does exist.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 3 Stocks Begging for a Buyout;2/11/2017;"Sometimes mergers are necessary for survival
column2: and at other   times
column3: they simply just make good old-fashioned sense. In either   case
column4: investors lucky enough to own stocks that do get bought out   can turn a nice profit.We reached out to our contributors
column5: and asked them to tell us   what stocks they think could get bought. They settled onTwitter(NYSE:TWTR)
column6: GoPro(NASDAQ: GPRO)
column7: andMerrimack Pharmaceuticals(NASDAQ: MACK) . Read on to learn if these companies are worth   owning in your portfolio.A stock good enough for a presidentRich Smith(Twitter):Remember how last year
column8: the internets were all a-twitter with   rumors thatWalt Disney-- or maybeGoogle
column9: or perhapssalesforce.com-- was going to buy Twitter? It never actually happened
column10: of   course
column11: but I think it might have happened -- and I think it   stillshouldhappen.makeArticleAd();IMAGE SOURCE: TWITTER.Second only toFacebookin internet mindshare
column12: Twitter is the stock success story that   never quite made it. Twitter went public more than three years   ago at $26 per share
column13: and almost immediately doubled in price   before investors began to notice a ""giant sucking sound
column14: which   ultimately pulled down Twitter to its current price of   $18.50.You can blame Twitter's failure on any number of things: a   lack of profits
column15: single-digit revenue growth
column16: or zero growth in   its user base (as of last quarter). At the same time
column17: with 320   million monthly visitors to the site
column18: Twitter remains a force to   be reckoned with on the internet
column19: and will only grow more   important as President Trump uses it as his social-media   trumpet.Other fans of Twitter may tout its usefulness for keeping   abreast of celebrity news
column20: its deals with sports organizations
column21: or its efforts in live-streaming. But for me
column22: the key is this:   Today
column23: anyone who wants to know what's going on in the White   House
column24: and even anyone who wants toopposewhat's going on in the White House
column25: needs to be on Twitter to   stay informed. This single fact makes Twitter one of the most   important pieces of internet real estate out there today; if the   company's current owners can't figure out how to make a profit   off that
column26: I'm certain there are other internet tycoons who have   the egos to believe that they can do better.Sooner or later
column27: one of those guys is going to buy Twitter.   I'm betting on sooner.Will a buyout send this stock flying?Tim Brugger(GoPro):Now that the Karma drone is back
column28: at least in limited quantities   in the U.S. (for now)
column29: some pundits have suggested that GoPro's   future relies on consumers getting back on board now that its   battery-latch issue has been resolved.Unfortunately
column30: it's not quite as simple as that. As founder   and CEO Nicholas Woodman noted in GoPro's recently announced   fourth-quarter and 2016 annual results
column31: its HERO5 Black camera   was the best-selling digital ""imaging device"" in the country
column32: along with select international markets
column33: last quarter. And   GoPro's mobile efforts
column34: which include its Quik app
column35: are picking   up steam. But the primary concern remains: GoPro simply doesn't   have the product diversification it needs to weather an   unexpected storm.Woodman warned investors to not expect much in GoPro's fourth   quarter
column36: and the reason behind his trying to mute expectations is   why GoPro is begging for a buyout. The problems started with the   aforementioned Karma being recalled ahead of the all-important   holiday shopping season
column37: along with some manufacturing hiccups.   When one product miscue causes the poor results GoPro announced   on Feb. 2
column38: on the heels of an equally disappointing third quarter   -- in which its revenue of $540.6 million was woefully short of   the $574.5 million expected -- it's a scary proposition.However
column39: a buyout by a company that could add GoPro's camera   and drone to an already diversified product lineup: Nowthatwould make sense. And the timing couldn't be better for a suitor
column40: given GoPro's woeful 18% stock-price decline over the past   year.It's unlikely
column41: but it could still happenTodd Campbell(Merrimack Pharmaceuticals):Instead of buying Merrimack Pharmaceuticals lock
column42: stock
column43: and   barrel

column45: especially now that it's sold its only commercial drug. But an   acquisition is still possible.Weighed down by a heavy debt load and commercialization   expenses associated with its pancreatic cancer drug Onivyde
column46: Merrimack announced a massive layoff last fall. The layoff gave   the company some wiggle room
column47: but it wasn't enough
column48: so the board   cut a deal to sell Onivyde to Ipsen for $575 million up front
column49: plus promises of up to $450 million in milestone payments.The company plans to return $200 million of the up-front money   to investors as a special dividend
column50: and plans to retire $175   million in long-term debt. Management will also invest $125   million of the windfall back into its clinical-stage drug   pipeline.This deal gives Merrimack Pharmaceuticals a cash runway that   stretches into 2019; hopefully
column51: that will be enough time for   management to prove that the remaining drugs in its pipeline are   worthwhile. Those drugs include MM-121
column52: which is being evaluated   in non-small cell lung cancer
column54: which is being studied in   metastatic pancreatic cancer
column55: and MM-310
column56: a preclinical drug   that's expected to enter phase 1 trials this year.Undeniably
column57: the company will be in better financial shape than   it's been in years
column58: once this deal closes. But trial uncertainty   and ongoing expenses could make Merrimack Pharmaceuticals open to   entertaining offers from a suitor. If not
column59: it might at least be   willing to cozy up with a deep-pocketed biopharma on one or more   of its remaining drugs.10 stocks we like better than Merrimack     PharmaceuticalsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Ford is Spending $1 Billion on a Tiny Self-Driving Start-Up;2/10/2017;"Ford Motor Company(NYSE: F) announced on Friday that it is acquiring a majority   stake in artificial-intelligence start-up Argo AI for $1 billion
column2: to be paid over five years.What is Argo AI?Argo AI is a new company
column3: founded late last year by CEO Bryan   Salesky and COO Peter Rander. Both are big names in self-driving   circles: Salesky was the head of hardware atAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Waymo unit (formerly known as   the Google Self-Driving Car Project); Rander was a top engineer   in Uber Technologies' autonomous-vehicle division. Both were   previously at the robotics institute at Carnegie Mellon   University
column4: where they worked on artificial-intelligence (AI)   technology.The plan for Argo AI is to use the founders' expertise in AI   to develop autonomous-vehicle software. The company is   headquartered in Pittsburgh. It's small now
column5: but it expects to   have more than 200 employees by the end of 2017.makeArticleAd();Argo COO Peter Rander (left)
column6: Ford CEO Mark Fields
column7: Argo CEO     Brian Salesky
column8: and Ford CTO Raj Nair. Image source: Ford Motor     Company.What Ford said about the dealFord said that Argo AI ""is bringing together some of the most   experienced roboticists and engineers working in autonomy from   inside and outside of Ford."" An existing Ford team that has been   working on what Ford calls its ""virtual driver system
column9: the brain   of an autonomous vehicle
column10: will become part of Argo AI.While Ford will continue to develop its self-driving hardware   in-house
column11: it appears that Argo AI will be responsible for much of   the software development. That software could be licensed to   other companies
column12: CEO Mark Fields said
column13: and it's possible that   Argo AI will go public at some point.""The next decade will be defined by the automation of the   automobile
column14: and autonomous vehicles will have as significant an   impact on society as Ford's moving assembly line did 100 years   ago
column15: Fields said. ""As Ford expands to be an auto and a mobility   company
column16: we believe that investing in Argo AI will create   significant value for our shareholders by strengthening Ford's   leadership in bringing self-driving vehicles to market in the   near term and by creating technology that could be licensed to   others in the future.""Ford will hold a majority stake in the new company. Fields   wouldn't say exactly what Ford's ownership percentage will be
column17: but he did say that it was gauged to leave plenty of room to   provide equity compensation to new employees.Ford's global product chief and CTO
column18: Raj Nair
column19: and group vice   president of global strategy
column20: John Casesa
column21: will hold two of the   five seats on Argo AI's board. Salesky and Rander will hold two   more
column22: and the fifth will go to an independent director to be   named later.Investors
column23: take note: Fields said that Argo AI's spending and   results will be consolidated into Ford's automotive financial   results
column24: primarily in the North America region.What this deal is really aboutHere's how I'm thinking about this deal: Ford just hired two   rock stars in AI and autonomous vehicles
column25: put them in charge of   its self-driving software team
column26: and structured the whole thing to   give the team members -- and very importantly
column27: future hires
column28: in a   field in which the competition for talent is fierce -- the upside   of a start-up with lower risk
column29: because Ford's investment has   essentially capitalized the company and Ford will be its first   customer. It's an intriguing idea; it could turn out to be a   brilliant one.During a conference call for analysts and media
column30: Salesky   emphasized that the structure of what he called the   ""collaboration"" between Argo AI and Ford would help recruiting:   New hires (and Ford's existing virtual-driver team) will go to   work for a start-up with significant potential upside
column31: not   (directly
column32: at least) for giant Ford.And while it's a start-up
column33: Ford's involvement means that new   hires can be assured that Argo AI has both solid funding and a   major customer. The combination of relatively low risk with high   potential upside should make for a potent recruiting tool in a   field where the competition for talent has been extremely   fierce.The upshot: An intriguing move to boost Ford's technology   pushFor Ford
column34: this is a way to bring some deep AI expertise into   its self-driving development project
column35: structured in a way that   will help boost its recruiting efforts going forward. Nair said   that he doesn't expect the deal to ""accelerate"" Ford's effort --   he stuck by thepreviously announced 2021 deadlinefor Ford's first mass-produced self-driving vehicle.But there's a clear advantage to putting the team under the   leadership of Salesky and Rander

column1: Alphabet Inc. Takes Another Shot at Amazon With Home Control;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc.'s(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Home connected speaker takes onAmazon.com
column3: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa on its home turf. But what about Google's big advantage over Amazon in the smart home war - all those smartphones?makeArticleAd();Source: GoogleThe company has just begun rolling out Home Control
column4: a new feature that lets Google Assistant control smart home devices by voice.However
column5: at this point
column6: Home Control - like Google Assistant - remains a feature that's exclusive to Google's own Pixel Phones.The Battle for the Smart HomeGoogle Home is a connected speaker with Google Assistant baked in. Owners can use Google Assistant on the speaker to answer questions
column7: find music and control a growing number of smart home devices using their voice only.The device is GOOGL's answer to the Amazon Echo. Amazon's Alexa-enabled speaker has been a surprise hit and allowed Amazon to take a big lead in the race to become the smart home hub - despite the distinct disadvantage of lacking a smartphone platform to host its digital assistant.Google has Google Now and the new Google Assistant
column8: whileApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has Siri. Between them
column9: the two companies have billions of mobile devices in consumers' hands
column10: yet Amazon still managed to leapfrog them with its personal assistant hosted in a speaker
column11: to build an impressive smart home lead.Apple's Siri can control HomeKit-compatible smart home devices using voice commands
column12: and now GOOGL is rolling out asimilar feature for its Google Assistant
column13: Home Control.Home ControlGoogle's new feature for voice control of smart devices isn't actually new. Anyone who owns both a Pixel Phone and a Google Home speaker already had a Home Control setting on their smartphone.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayHowever
column14: as of yesterday
column15: GOOGL has begun to roll out Home Control to all Google Assistant users. This amounts to all Pixel Phone owners
column16: since Google Assistant remains an exclusive that third-party Android smartphones don't get.With Home Control
column17: someone with a Pixel Phone gets the same voice control ability for smart devices they would have if they owned a Google Home speaker. They can use voice commands on their phone to change the temperature on their Nest Learning Thermostat or turn off the smart lighting in the room they just left.The Battle for the Smart Home Enters a New Phase (Sort of)At the start of this fight to be the company that becomes the hub of the smart home - the one who controls all those smart devices - the smartphone was it.Smartphones ran all the apps that controlled each of the devices and everyone owned one. With smartphones
column18: the battle came down to iOS and Android
column19: Apple and Google.Then Amazon disrupted everything with the Echo and Alexa. With thousands of compatible products and services
column20: consumers have been snapping them up. Amazon sold out of the Echo at Christmas
column21: afterselling nine times moreof the smart speaker than the previous year.Voice control is in. Having to poke buttons on a smartphone is out.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Finally Fires Back at Apple With Android Wear 2.0However
column22: Apple and Google are not about to cede the smart home to Amazon. GOOGL began its assault on Amazon with the Google Home smart speaker to directly take on the Echo and Alexa. With Home Control
column23: it's bringing voice control of smart devices to the smartphone
column24: leveraging its massive lead over Amazon when it comes to numbers. There may be millions of Alexa-powered homes
column25: but there are billions of people already carrying an Android smartphone.Except
column26: most of those people still won't be able to use Home Control. GOOGL has baked Home Control into Google Assistant
column27: a feature that's been exclusive to its Pixel Phones since they were released last fall. With Google Home and now Home Control
column28: Alphabet clearly has Amazon's number. The question will be whether Amazon gets Alexa into more third-party devices before Google decides to let third-party Android smartphone makers have access to Google Assistant.For GOOGL
column29: the decision comes down to which is more valuable: maintaining a key competitive advantage for its own Pixel Phones
column30: or giving up that Google Assistant and Home Control exclusivity to take a real shot at unseating Amazon in the smart home.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceNo

column1: Nvidia (NVDA) Earnings: Why This Q4 Beat Was Really Important;2/10/2017;"Nvidia earnings (Shutterstock photo)It appears the only thing now strong enough to stop Nvidia (NVDA) stock from climbing higher are investors’ expectations.
