column1: 3 Stocks We're Never Selling;2/6/2017;"We Fools are constantly on the hunt for winning stock ideas   that we believe will generate strong returns for years on end.   When we think we have identified a winning business
column2: we like to   buy it and hang on to it through thick and thin.With that in mind
column3: we asked a team of Fools to highlight a   stock in their portfolio that they plan to hang on to for the   ultra-long term. Read on to see why they pickedAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column4: Under Armour(NYSE: UA) (NYSE: UAA)
column5: andStarbucks(NASDAQ: SBUX) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Alphabet will continue to benefit from digital browsingJamal Carnette
column6: CFA(Alphabet): The market wasn't kind to Alphabet's recently   reported fourth-quarter and full-year results. Overall
column7: the   company continues to post enviable growth rates for a company of   its scale. Alphabet increased revenue 20.4% over the previous   year's results; on a quarterly basis
column8: it grew revenue 22.2% over   last year's corresponding period. However
column9: the company's   fourth-quarter bottom line increased by only 8.3%
column10: to $5.3   billion
column11: as Alphabet's provision for income taxes increased by a   massive 450% over last year's corresponding quarter
column12: on account   of a one-time tax adjustment. Still
column13: the fickle market sold off   shares to the tune of 2% because the company missed analyst   expectations.On a positive note
column14: Alphabet confirmed that mobile search is   one of its highest-growth areas. The biggest shift in internet   browsing over the past five years has been from desktop to   mobile
column15: and that move benefits Alphabet
column16: considering Google   controls approximately 95% of the mobile-search market.The company also continues to grow its advertising business.   Earlier this year
column17: a shocking report fromMorgan Stanleyanalyst Brian Nowak found that 85% of every new dollar in online   advertising was going to just two companies: Alphabet andFacebook. As the shift to online advertising continues
column18: look for Alphabet   to continue to post strong revenue growth rates.Simply put
column19: Alphabet's long-term thesis remains intact. The   company is the largest digital advertiser and search engine in   the world
column20: and Alphabet will only continue to grow search and   advertising revenue as internet usage increases from a   combination of penetration and accessibility
column21: while a push for   digital advertising will boost the company's bottom line.Still a believer in Under ArmourBrian Feroldi(Under Armour): The past six months haven't been kind to Under Armour's   shareholders. The stock took a big hit inlate October
column22: after management ratcheted back its long-term growth   targets. More recently
column23: shares gotcrushedafter the company reported sales growth of just 12% in the   all-important fourth quarter. Not only was that figure far shy of   management's guidance
column24: but the company's CFO also resigned   suddenly. That's a lot of bad news for investors to take in all   at one time
column25: so it was no surprise to see that shares took a big   hit.However
column26: a closer look at the quarter hints that investors   shouldn't throw in the towel on this growth story just yet. While   total sales growth was disappointing
column27: the biggest culprit was   slowing sales in North America. That's understandable
column28: as the   retail environment stateside was quite challenging for many   retailers over the holidays. The recent bankruptcies of The   Sports Authority
column29: Eastern Mountain Sports
column30: Sports Chalet
column31: Golfsmith
column32: City Sports
column33: and Bob's Stores didn't help the matter
column34: either.However
column35: Under Armour's report did contain a handful of bright   spots. Direct-to-consumer sales -- which bypass retailers   altogether -- jumped by 23% and now account for nearly 40% of   total sales. And footwear sales grew by a solid 36% year over   year. Best of all
column36: international revenue grew by 55% and now   comprises 16% of total sales. These figures suggest that Under   Armour's brand still remains strong.While the company has some near-term challenges to overcome
column37: I   have a hard time believing that this growth story is dead. As   long as founder and CEO Kevin Plank is at the helm
column38: this is one   stock I can't ever see myself parting ways with.Middle-class people love their coffee
column39: and there's about to   be a lot more of themJasonHall(Starbucks): The global coffee giant's stock is down around 8% since   first-quarter earnings came out in late January
column40: and not without   some justification. After all
column41: Starbucks reported that traffic in   its North American stores was pretty much flat in the quarter
column42: a   trend that started in 2016 and could continue through 2017.   Furthermore
column43: management indicated that it may feel the same way   and is now projecting revenue growth between 8% and 10%
column44: a   reduction from original full-year guidance of 10% or greater at   the end of the prior quarter.But Starbucks isn't the kind of company that will scare me   away with a minor flattening of growth in its most mature market   -- especially not right now. Starbucks' best days could be   ahead of it
column45: even as Howard Schultz steps down as CEO for the   second time.To start with
column46: Starbucks' growth opportunity in Asia is simply   enormous. Within a decade

column1: Xiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock — What Happened?;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOnly a few years ago
column3: Xiaomiwas worryingApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) investors. Xiaomi had become the world's third-largest smartphone manufacturer and was expanding into other products like fitness trackers
column4: TVs and video streamers. It was valued at $45 billion
column5: hired a prominent executive away fromAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column6: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google and planned an expansion into America.makeArticleAd();Source: XiaomiToday? It has dropped out of the top five smartphone vendors list
column7: marketshare in China has plummeted
column8: the Google exec has jumped ship and some analysts are valuing the company as low as $3.6 billion.What happened to Xiaomi and is its threat to Apple truly neutralized? Or are the troubled Chinese tech giant's plans merely on hold?Xiaomi's Rapid RisePrivately held Xiaomi was founded in 2010
column9: released its first smartphone in 2011 and rapidly gained popularity in China. The company offered high-quality in its smartphones
column10: with low pricing -a combination that led to it being the top-selling smartphone brand in China by 2014.It came seemingly out of nowhere to capture thethird place spot for worldwide smartphone salesthat year as well. The feat was especially impressive given that Xiaomi was not selling its phones in the U.S. market.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99Like Apple
column11: Google andSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column12: the company wanted to expand into consumer electronics in general. That effort included the inexpensive Mi Band fitness tracker that vaulted Xiaomi intosecond place worldwide for wearable salesby 2015
column13: behind onlyFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT).The company pursued a strategy of investing in hardware startups
column14: buying into dozens of companies making everything from smart lighting to headphones and TVs. While these products are not always Xiaomi-branded
column15: they are designed to all work well together.It also added software and services to the mix.Chinese CompetitionThe success of Xiaomi spurred homegrown competition. Other Chinese manufacturers stepped up to the plate and followed Xiaomi's formula. However
column16: they did a better job of marketing to increasingly demanding Chinese consumers by charging a little more but offering more striking designs. One of these companies -Huawei- was good enough that Googlepartnered with it to build the Nexus 6P smartphone in 2015. Xiaomi's phones seem lower quality than these competitors and rather than innovative
column17: its designs are often seen as being too similar to Apple's.At this point
column18: Xiaomi has been leapfrogged by its Chinese smartphone rivals. While Xiaomi has dropped off the global top five smartphone manufacturer list
column19: China's Huawei
column20: OppoandVivocurrently hold the third
column21: fourth and fifth places.American ObstaclesKey to Xiaomi's ambitions were an expansion into the U.S. market. To lead that effort
column22: thecompany hired Hugo Barra- the VP who oversaw Android product management - from Google.However
column23: Xiaomi's U.S. push has failed to materialize. There are dozens of products Xiaomi offers online through itsMi Store(which carries only a fraction of Xiaomi's and its partner companies' gear)
column24: including eight different smartphone models
column25: multiple smart TVs
column26: VR headsets and even a self-balancing electric scooter. U.S. customers are limited to being able to buy a few sets of earbuds
column27: a pair of headphones
column28: a battery pack and a Bluetooth speaker.A big part of the problem in moving into the U.S. market is that Xiaomi has taken advantage of China's relatively lax approach to patents. In late 2014
column29: it wasbanned from selling smartphones in Indiaas a result of a patent infringement ruling (it has since resumed Indian operations). If Xiaomi tried to push into the U.S. with its smartphones at this point
column30: there's a good chance Apple and other tech companies would sue it into oblivion.In an attempt to defend against this scenario
column31: Xiaomi has begun buying up patents. Last year
column32: it purchased 1
column33: 500 patentsfromMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) relating to areas like wireless communication
column34: multimedia and video
column35: and the cloud.No Longer a Threat to Apple?At this point
column36: Xiaomi is a paper tiger that isvalued at as little as $3.6 billion. In 2015
column37: it sold 70 million-plus smartphones
column38: missing its initial goal of 100 million and then the revised goal of 80 million. It's refusing to say how many it sold in 2016
column39: but that silence speaks volumes.Hugo Barra bailed on the companya few weeks ago
column40: joiningFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB). A few months before leaving
column41: he toldReutersthat lower smartphone sales wouldn't impact the companybecause it made no money on them:""Basically we're giving [handsets] to you without making any money… we care about the recurring revenue streams over many years. We could sell 10 billion smartphones and we wouldn't make a single dime in profits.""The problem with that approach is that as of 2015
column42: smartphones still accounted for 95% of the company's revenue. All those other products and services just don't seem to be sticking.Barra also told reporters not to expect Xiaomi to release a smartphone in the U.S. in 2017.3 Reasons Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Is Much More Than Its Main PlatformXiaomi CEO Lei Junposted a letter to employeeson Facebook in January. In it
column43: he admitted the company had pushed ahead too fast
column44: cutting into its long-term growth
column45: but says the worst is over.The company's revenue target is RMB 100 billion (roughly $14.5 billion) -the same as its 2015 target. In trying to be so much
column46: so fast
column47: Xiaomi has set itself up for some very challenging times. If treading water is the goal it has set for itself
column48: Apple doesn't have much to worry about.As of this writing
column49: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryThe postXiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock - What Happened?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Tech Companies Take a Stand Against Trump's Immigration Ban;2/6/2017;"Immigration has been a driving force behind many of the   leading technology companies in the United States.Some
column2: includingMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column3: are led by CEOs who were not born in this   country while over 200 companies on the Fortune 500 were started   by immigrants or their children. In addition most top tech brands   are global
column4: with offices all over the world
column5: and talent working   domestically that was not born in the U.S.At least partly because of that nearly 100 technology   companies including Microsoft
column6: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column7: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column8: Facebook
column9: Twitter
column10: and many others have filed a legal brief in the U.S. Court of   Appeals for the 9th Circuit opposing President Donald Trump's   temporary immigration ban keeping people from seven predominantly   Muslim countries from entering the U.S. In the brief the   companies argue that the ban ""inflicts significant harm on   American business.""makeArticleAd();Trump signed an executive order banning immigration from     seven predominantly Muslim countries. Image source: Getty     Images.What are they opposing?In one of his first acts as president
column11: Trump signed an   executive order banning refugees and visa-holders from seven   predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States.   That order has been stayed by aU.S. District judgeand an appeals courtdeclined to immediately reinstatethe presidential order. The technology companies
column12: many of which   operate and employ workers in and from the impacted countries   filed their brief to show their opposition to the president's   actions.""Immigrants make many of the Nation's greatest discoveries
column13: and create some of the country's most innovative and iconic   companies
column14: the brief states. ""America has long recognized the   importance of protecting ourselves against those who would do us   harm. But it has done so while maintaining our fundamental   commitment to welcoming immigrants -- through increased   background checks and other controls on people seeking to enter   our country.""The companies that signed the brief acknowledged what Trump   was
column15: at least on the surface
column16: trying to accomplish with the   executive order.""We share your goal of ensuring that our immigration system   meets today's security needs and keeps our country safe
column17: said a   draft of that letter obtained byBloomberg News. ""We are concerned
column18: however
column19: that your recent Executive Order   will affect many visa holders who work hard here in the United   States and contribute to our country's success.""Tech requires global talentPutting aside any political questions
column20: the tech industry   opposes Trump's immigration ban in part because it takes global   talent to compete. The U.S. simply does not produce enough   workers -- specifically coders who write the software that powers   the products made by these companies -- to meet demand.To fill those needs companies across the U.S. use H1B visas to   receive special dispensation to hire workers who otherwise would   not be able to legally work in the country. A H1B visa
column21: according   toMyVisaJobs.com
column22: allows U.S. employers to temporarily employ foreign   professionals in specialty occupations for three years
column23: extendable to six years. ""To qualify for H1B Visa
column24: the foreign   professional must hold a bachelor's or higher degree from an   accredited college or university in the specialty occupation
column25: according to the site. In some cases specialized training can be   substituted for a degree.Technology companies dominate the list of employers using   workers on H1B visas. Data compiled by MyVisaJobs.com shows that   in 2016 Infosys held the top spot
column26: having sponsored 25
column27: 405 visas.   while Microsoft
column28: Apple
column29: and Alphabet were all in the top 25.It's about more than self interestIt's easy to see the business reasons behind why these   technology companies oppose Trump's immigration restrictions.   Most
column30: if not all of the companies that filed the brief would be   impacted by having employees unable to travel and in some cases   the executive order would impact hiring.For at least some of these companies
column31: however
column32: the opposition   goes beyond pure business logic. Many of these brands were either   founded by immigrants or by the children of immigrants and   immediate business concerns aside
column33: they simply want a world where   new immigrants to the U.S. can be free to move here and found the   next Microsoft
column34: Apple
column35: or Alphabet.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Alphabet (GOOGL) to Sell Terra Bella Business to Planet Labs;2/6/2017;"Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle announced on Friday that will sell its Terra Bella Imaging satellite business to Planet Labs.In exchange
column2: Google receives a stake in planet and will also enter in to a multi-year contract to buy its Earth-imaging data.Google did not disclose the financial terms of the deal. Bloomberg had reported in January that talks were in progress between the two companies.For the last six months
column3: Alphabet has outperformed the ZacksInternet-Servicesindustry. It has returned 1.87% compared with the industry's return of 1.17%.Formerly known as Skybox
column4: the Earth imaging company was founded in 2009 and the search giant bought it for $500 million in 2014
column5: the same year when Skybox was named no. 1 on Inc. magazine's 25 Most Audacious Companies. Google rebranded it to Terra Bella last year.In Quest of Financial DisciplineThe move underscores Alphabet's efforts to trim relatively less-revenue generating businesses and attain financial discipline. The company could save more by purchasing satellite imagery from a third party instead of operating its own imaging satellite business.Alphabet's sales
column6: marketing and R&D expenses have gone up considerably in the last five years. There are also some other margin pressures. The most significant at the moment is related to currency
column7: which continued to impact Alphabet's results despite the fact that it has a hedging program in place.Alphabet Inc. Total Expenses (TTM)Alphabet Inc. Total Expenses (TTM)|Alphabet Inc. QuoteOther expense pressures include fast-paced international growth
column8: a growing volume of lower-priced YouTube clicks and strength of the mobile platform. So we believe that Alphabet has foreseen an escalation of costs in the years to come and is gearing up well in advance with decisions like these.The company has recently been getting rid of its audacious ventures. In Aug 2015
column9: it reportedly curbed the expansion of its high-speed fiber optic Internet network
column10: cutting 9% of its staff. In November
column11: the company scaled back Project Wing
column12: its experimental drone delivery program.Benefits for Planet LabsPrivately-held Planet Labs operates with dozens of small satellites that take pictures of the Earth surface frequently. However
column13: the resolution of the images is low. Terra Bella has larger satellites with high image resolution but its fleet contains only seven satellites
column14: which limits the frequency of capturing images.Thus
column15: we believe that through this acquisition
column16: Planet Labs will add high resolution satellites to its fleet. Both companies share the satellite imaging space with giants like Airbus Group'sEADSYAirbus Defence & Space and DigitalGlobeDGI.Zacks Rank and Stocks to ConsiderCurrently

column1: Will Facebook Challenge Netflix and Amazon Via Set Top Boxes?;2/5/2017;"Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) is reportedly developing a dedicated video app for   set top boxes to  expand its social networking ecosystem   into living rooms
column2: according to theWall Street Journal. The app will be different from its existing app for set top   boxes
column3: which is basically just a widescreen version of its mobile   app.Image source: Facebook.makeArticleAd();Instead
column4: the new app will mainly deliver videos from Facebook
column5: potentially turning it into a streaming rival toNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) andAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) . This supports previous reports that Facebook was   looking to license original content
column6: and suggests that its users   could deliver live broadcasts to TVs via Facebook Live.Will this move pay off? Or are Netflix
column7: Amazon
column8: andAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) YouTube already too far ahead in   the video streaming wars?Understanding Facebook's video effortsYouTube is the biggest video streaming site in the world
column9: but   Facebook's video ecosystem has been growing quickly. Last   January
column10: Facebook revealed that  its users watched 100   million hours of videos per day. At the time
column11: Business Insiderestimated that YouTube users were watching about 650 million   hours of video every day.During last quarter's conference call
column12: Facebook CEO  Mark   Zuckerberg called video ""a megatrend on the same order as   mobile""
column13: and highlighted the ways that video ecosystem was   expanding. It recently added a new tab in the Facebook app for   top videos and recommendations in the U.S.
column14: tested a version of   Live 360 videos for slower connections
column15: and added live face masks   and camera effects. It also plans to invest more in original   video content to ""seed that ecosystem"" throughout 2017.Facebook's interest in videos makes sense
column16: since video ads   cost much more than traditional display ads. As Facebook's active   user growth slows down
column17: video ads can bolster its top line by   milking more ad revenue from existing users. Since nearly 94% of   Facebook's 1.86 billion monthly active users already access the    site from mobile devices
column18: it also needs to look toward   other platforms -- like set top boxes -- to continue growing its   ad ecosystem.Carving out a niche between Netflix and AmazonAt first glance
column19: it seems like Facebook could collide with   Netflix and Amazon's streaming video ecosystems. But Facebook   doesn't plan to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on big   budget shows likeHouse of CardsandMan in the High Castle.Instead
column20: Zuckerberg plans to focus on ""shorter-form content to   start
column21: noting that the videos will generally be split into   content people produce socially for friends
column22: promotional content   from businesses and celebrities
column23: and a class of Facebook-financed   ""premium"" content to differentiate it from other platforms. CFO   David Wehner was vague about what that premium content would   actually be
column24: merely stating that the company was ""looking at a   wide range of content"" and ""working toward a revenue share model   with creators.""Those statements indicate that Facebook wants to carve out a   niche on set top boxes
column25: instead of trading costly blows with   Netflix and Amazon. Since Facebook's video platform is all about   delivering ads
column26: the platform should also be free -- so it won't   be competing for Netflix or Amazon's subscription-based   revenues.Is Facebook actually making a play for smart     homes?Facebook's new set top box app could also help it gain a   foothold in smart home ecosystems. Amazon has already established   a major presence in homes with its Kindle tablets
column27: Fire TV set   top boxes
column28: and Echo speakers. Google is trying to catch up with   Home
column29: andAppletethers devices to its HomeKit platform for iOS.Facebook doesn't have an official horse in that race yet
column30: but   Zuckerberg recently showcased Jarvis
column31: a smart  home AI   platform he developed for his own home. The platform
column32: which uses   voice commands to control devices
column33: is controlled via a Messenger   bot.Image source: Facebook.By expanding Facebook's ecosystem to set top boxes like Apple   TV
column34: Fire TV
column35: and Roku
column36: the social network couldpotentiallypiggyback off that hardware to sync with smart home devices. If   Facebook links Messenger to those ""hubs""
column37: it could take control   of users' homes
column38: gather even more data from those users
column39: and   widen its moat against Amazon
column40: Google
column41: Apple
column42: and other   challengers.The key takeawayFacebook's plans to expand its video ecosystem aren't   surprising
column43: and a dedicated video app for set top boxes would be   the logical next step. It won't challenge heavyweights like   Netflix and Amazon
column44: but it could capture a niche market of users   who want to view Facebook video content on a streaming platform   optimized for TVs. If the effort is successful
column45: it could make its   video ads more valuable and give it a firm foundation for   eventually challenging other smart home players.Find out why Facebookis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. column2: Google's Brand Is Not More Valuable Than Apple's;2/5/2017;"Last week
column3: Brand Finance came out with itsannual listing of brand valuations. In a somewhat shocking finding
column4: the consulting group declared   thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) had lost its supremacy toAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary Google.Alphabet is a phenomenal company with a long track record of   innovation
column5: and the Google brand is extremely powerful.   Nevertheless
column6: it still isn't in the same league as Apple's brand   in terms of total value.Is Apple turning sour?While Brand Finance still rates Apple as the second most   valuable brand in the world
column7: it appears to have a fairly negative   view of the iPhone maker. According to the recent report:makeArticleAd();However
column8: Apple's evangelists are beginning to lose their     faith. The snaking queues of early adopters have shrunk almost     to the point of invisibility. Apple has failed to maintain its     technological advantage and has repeatedly disillusioned its     advocates with tweaks when material changes were expected.Put simply
column9: Apple has over-exploited the goodwill of its     customers
column10: it has failed to generate significant revenues from     newer products such as the Apple Watch and cannot demonstrate     that genuinely innovative technologies desired by consumers are     in the pipeline. Its brand has lost its luster and must now     compete on an increasingly level playing field not just with     traditional rivalSamsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF)
column11: but a slew of Chinese brands such as     Huawei and OnePlus in the smartphone market
column12: Apple's key source     of profitability.As a result of this assessment
column13: Brand Finance reduced its   estimate of the Apple brand's value by 27% year over year
column14: to   $107.1 billion. Meanwhile
column15: it estimated Google's brand value at   $109.5 billion
column16: up 24% from $88.2 billion a year ago. Brand   Finance cited Google's dominance in search
column17: among other things
column18: to justify the big increase in its brand value.Consumers are paying more and more for iPhonesBrand Finance's declining opinion of the Apple brand is   contradicted by consumers' willingness to pay more and more for   iPhones. Last quarter
column19: Apple reported record quarterly iPhone   sales of 78.3 million units. Even more impressively
column20: the average   selling price (ASP) reached a new record of $695.The iPhone's ASP hit a new record last quarter. Image     source: Apple.In the same quarter two years ago
column21: right after Apple released   the hugely popular iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus
column22: the iPhone's ASP   had surged 8% year over year
column23: to $687. Apple's ability to   continue growing that ASP over the past two years
column24: despite facing   stiff foreign exchange headwinds in both years
column25: is a testament to   the massive value of its brand.Indeed
column26: the cost of high-quality smartphones is coming down.   Leaving aside Samsung
column27: several Chinese manufacturers have become   known for designing high-quality smartphones and selling them at   near-breakeven prices in recent years. Apple's ability to command   a huge price premium over competitors -- which extends beyond   smartphones to PCs and (to a lesser extent) tablets -- indicates   that its brand is as strong as ever.Apple is a profit machineAccording to Brand Finance
column28: Apple has failed to maintain a   technological lead over Samsung and other rivals. In fact
column29: many   tech pundits have argued in recent years that Samsung has   overtaken Apple in terms of innovation.Assuming that the two companies are on a relatively even   technological footing
column30: they should be able to produce roughly   similar earnings. However
column31: that's not even close to being   true.Last quarter
column32: Apple barely retook the lead in terms of   smartphone shipments with 78.3 million
column33: compared to 77.5 million   shipments for Samsung
column34: according to Strategy Analytics. Yet Samsung's mobile-division operating profit totaled just   $2.1 billion for the quarter. By contrast
column35: Apple's operating   profit was more than 10 times higher at $23.4 billion.On a full-year basis -- or looking just at the smartphone   business -- Apple's advantage is somewhat smaller. But any way   you slice it
column36: Apple generates many times more profit than   Samsung. (In its most recent fiscal year
column37: Apple's operating   profit was $60 billion
column38: compared to about $10 billion for   Samsung's mobile division.)If Apple doesn't have superior technology relative to Samsung
column39: its brand must be doing most of the heavy lifting to generate $50   billion of additional operating profit on an annual basis. That's   more than double Alphabet'stotalannual operating profit of $23.7 billion.Google may be a powerful brand. However
column40: it doesn't come close   to the value of the Apple brand
column41: which has turned the   traditionally low-margin technology hardware business into a   long-term cash cow that churns out tens of billions of dollars of   profit every year.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How Profitable Is SpaceX
column2: Really?;2/5/2017;"Last year
column3: prior to the big SpaceXplosion -- which kind of     knockedSpaceX off the rails-- we spent a lot of time digging into SpaceX's finances.     We asked:How does SpaceX make money? And we answered the question: ""How profitable is SpaceX"" when it makes all that money?Much of this was based on educated guesswork
column4: however
column5: as we     extrapolated what we knew about the finances at SpaceX rivalsBoeing(NYSE: BA)
column6: Lockheed Martin(NYSE: LMT)
column7: Orbital ATK(NYSE: OA)
column8: andAirbus(NASDAQOTH: EADSY)
column9: and applied it to what wethoughtthat might mean for SpaceX's own finances. It would have been a     whole lot easier to just take a good hard look at SpaceX's own     financial documents
column10: and get the answers straight from the     source.Lucky for us -- and for you --The Wall Street Journaljust did that.makeArticleAd();Here's your first look at SpaceX's CRS-8-mission rocket --     before it becomes the first ""reused"" orbital rocket in history.     Now let's take a look at SpaceX's finances. Image source:     SpaceX.In a detailed
column11: multi-page expose
column12: theJournalrevealed last monththat it has come into possession of a treasure trove of internal   financial documents from SpaceX. Combined with interviews of   ex-SpaceX staff
column13: theJournalwas able to put together a pretty good picture of SpaceX's   finances.It isn't a pretty picture. Here's what we know.Wall Street Journalspills the beans on SpaceXSpaceX likes to portray itself as a growing rival to space   incumbents such as Boeing and Lockheed
column14: Airbus and Orbital ATK.   But in fact
column15: SpaceX's revenue growth halted --temporarily
column16: we hope-- in 2014. Two failed space launches in the past two   years curtailed launch activity at the space start-up
column17: with the   result that revenue actually peaked in 2014
column18: at roughly $1   billion.SpaceX's sales then declined to just $945 million in 2015
column19: when the company conducted only six launches. (Revenue may have   grown again in 2016
column20: or it may not have. The documents theJournalobtained apparently didn't extend into 2016.)What the documentsdoshow
column21: though -- and show quite clearly -- is that no matter how   much revenue SpaceX records
column22: it's not earning much profit from   that revenue.Dissecting SpaceX's financesAs revealed in theJournal's report
column23: SpaceX turned just a small fraction of its $1 billion   in 2014 launch revenue into operating profit -- much lessnetprofit. The numbers aren't entirely clear from theJournal's chart
column24: but appear to show SpaceX earning an operating profit   of perhaps 0.2% on $1 billion in revenue -- profitability far   below the 10%-ish profit margin that Boeing earns on its space   operations
column25: or the 12.6% operating profit margin at Lockheed   Martin.That bleak situation got even worse in 2015 when a small   reduction in launch revenue sufficed to push SpaceX deeply into   the red
column26: and forced the company to record a $260 million loss on   $945 million in revenue.What SpaceX hopes to earnSpaceX'ssuccessful return to spacelast month holds forth the promise that things will improve in   2017. Prior to the September SpaceXplosion
column27: documents show that   SpaceX was targeting $1.8 billion in launch revenue in 2016
column28: and   aiming to earn $55 million in profit thereon. While it probably   didn't get there in 2016
column29: there's still a chance that it could   succeed in 2017 -- and achieve a 3% operating profit margin.And that's your answer right there: Currently
column30: all indications   suggest that SpaceX isnotprofitable
column31: but losing money. Only if things go well
column32: and SpaceX   regains its footing in 2017
column33: can we hope that the company will   achieve positive operating profit margins of 3%.Even if SpaceX succeeds at this
column34: though
column35: it would still be   earning only roughly half the 5.7% operating margin that Airbus   earns at its ""Defence and Space"" business (as reported byS&P Global Market Intelligence). SpaceX's targeted $55 million profit would also be a small   fraction of the $400 million in annual profit that the Boeing and   Lockheed joint venture ULAearns. On the other hand
column36: SpaceX would eclipse thebreak-even profitsat Airbus' dedicated space launch subsidiary
column37: Arianespace -- and   SpaceX could grow its profit margins in the future if its plans   to begin reusing relanded rockets
column38: at lower cost than using   ""expendable"" rockets
column39: pan out.SpaceX 2.0: A New HopeSo what's the upshot for SpaceX for investors who hope to one   day invest in its IPO
column40: and for investors who already
column41: today
column42: own a piece of SpaceX through their investment inAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) stock? Simply put
column43: the documents   theJournalunearthed show that SpaceX is not nearly as profitable an   operation as we once believed it to be..There's also a corollary conclusion
column44: though
column45: that affects   investors in the space industry in general. Lacking substantial   profits from its launch business
column46: SpaceX is going to have a very   hard time financing atrip to Mars-- a voyage it hopes to makeas early as next year-- and a voyage that could inspire a whole host of   other companies to accelerate their own races to space.HowdoesSpaceX plan to fund its first trip to Mars in 2018 and the dozens   of follow-up trips it hopes to make in the years and decades to   follow? Tune back in next week for the answer.(But here's a hint:It will involve satellites.)10 stocks we like better than BoeingWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column48: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column50: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Boeing wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: These 2 Tech Companies Have Made the Most AI Acquisitions;2/4/2017;"Market-intelligence firm CB Insights has compiled alistof the major acquirers of private artificial-intelligence (AI)   companies over the last five years. This list reveals well-known   tech giants making large investments to increase their   capabilities in AI. It also provides insight into the evolution   of the technology
column2: and its direct uses.Google and Intel are in the race for artificial     intelligence. Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();Google's been on a buying spreeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google is well known for itsaspirations in artificial intelligence; it heads the list with 11 acquisitions. A number of these   companies specialized in areas that led directly to recent   improvements in the Google Assistant. They also tie to the launch   of Google Home and its plans to take onAmazon's(NASDAQ: AMZN)Alexa virtual assistantand the Echo smart-speaker home system.The acquisition of Emu provided an assistant that used voice   commands to schedule appointments
column3: set reminders
column4: and make   reservations. Api.ai added tools for building conversational   bots
column5: while Dark Blue Labs contributed natural-language   improvements. Two companies helped personalize recommendations:   Clever Sense learned about nearby coffee shops
column6: restaurants and   bars; Jetpac searched for visual cues in photos to improve   recommendations. Timeful used priorities to add items to a   calendar using smart scheduling.Three companies specialized in image recognition: DNNResearch   focused on image search and facial recognition; Moodstocks   technology improved image recognition for smartphones; Vision   Factory worked to enhance accuracy and speed in object   recognition. Each of the aforementioned technologies serves to   improve specific functions in Google Home's ecosystem
column7: and   specifically within Assistant. This will compete directly in the   virtual personal assistant market currently led by Amazon's   Alexa.London-based DeepMind was one of the largest acquisitions
column8: with a price tag estimated at $660 million. Google already   boasted a significant investment in the area with its development   of the Google Brain
column9: a neural network developed in-house. Gains   in AI research have been used to improve many areas of its   current business. DeepMind is focused on improvements in general   AI research
column10: without any specific business objectives. That said
column11: Google will use every opportunity to apply research gains to   business uses.Is Intel's acquisition of Nervana a threat to NVIDIA? Image     source: Intel.Intel will take the fight to NVIDIAIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) has made a number of acquisitions as well. Saffron   specialized in cognitive computing
column12: combining data analytics with   deep learning; this relates directly to Intel's efforts in the   same area. Indisys provided natural-language recognition
column13: gesture   recognition
column14: and virtual-assistant technologies
column15: but also created   user interfaces for unmanned drones. Itseez focused on software   for the Internet of Things (IoT)
column16: cameras
column17: drones
column18: and autonomous   driving. Movidius brought computer-vision hardware for drones and   cameras; it also provided system-on-a-chip (SoC) technology for   accelerating computer vision
column19: as well as deep-learning   capability. These companies integrate directly into Intel's   RealSense brand for drones and virtual reality
column20: and bolster its   IoT business.The most significant of Intel's acquisitions
column21: however
column22: may be   that of deep-learning start-up Nervana Systems. With a reported   price of $408 million
column23: this company is attempting to reduce   machine learning to the size of a computer chip. Intel competitorNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) has seen its stock price triple in 2016
column24: as its   graphics processing units (GPUs) become the chip of choice for   companiestraining AI systems. If Intel can succeed at reducing machine learning to a level   that could reside on a processor
column25: that would be a significant   boost to its business and a potentially troubling development for   NVIDIA.As the battle for AI supremacy continues
column26: we will likely see   more consolidation in the industry
column27: as tech giants try to gain an   edge in this nascent technology. Success in the field will likely   depend on successful integration of these acquisitions into   existing business lines. Alphabet and Intel are on the right   track.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 1 Thing NVIDIA Investors Should Worry About;2/3/2017;"WhenIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) acquired artificial intelligence (AI) start-up   Nervana Systems late last year
column2: at first glance it appeared to be   another big tech company jumping on the AI bandwagon. A closer   look
column3: however
column4: reveals a very specific motivation. And it could   spell trouble for NVIDIA.NVIDIA GPU is the go-to chip to train AI systems -- for now.     Image source: NVIDIA.makeArticleAd();Intel has seen the market for its CPU chips shrink along with   the worldwide shipment of personal computers
column5: which fell an   estimated 6% in 2016
column6: the fifth consecutive year of declines.   CompetitorNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA)
column7: meanwhile
column8: has seen the market explode for its   graphic processing units (GPU)
column9: along with its stock price
column10: which   tripled in 2016.Though once used solely to render graphics in video games
column11: NVIDIA's GPUs have become the go-to chip fortraining neural networksdue to the massive parallel processing capability. According to aFinancial Timesarticle in December
column12: NVIDIA ""is widely credited with having   developed the best chips for training the artificial neural   networks"". The use of NVIDIA GPUs by data centers -- many   training AI systems -- helped revenue nearly triple in the most   recent quarter
column13: to $240 million from just $82 million in the   prior year. Intel dominates the non-AI data center market
column14: selling nearly 99% of server chips used
column15: and it now has its   sights on the nascent AI market as well.What is Intel doing?Late last year
column16: Intel announced that it would release a server   chip specifically designed for AI applications -- the Xeon Phi
column17: aka Knights Mill. It indicated this processor would run 2.3 times   faster than NVIDIA's GPUs when used for deep learning. NVIDIA   countered
column18: saying Intel deliberately used outdated benchmarks and   older versions of its products in the comparison. It claims that   had Intel used the updated benchmark
column19: NVIDIA's offering is 30%   faster
column20: and that its latest processor is 90% faster.Intel wants to ""unleash the next wave"" in artificial     intelligence. Image source: Intel.Intel's recent acquisition pushes it deeper into this market.   Nervana Systems took a different approach in its AI research. It   has created an application specific integrated circuit (ASIC) for   its AI research called the Nervana Engine. Certain elements in a   GPU needed for graphics processing are not necessary in an AI   application. By stripping out unnecessary elements and   reengineering the memory
column21: Nervana claims it can achieve 10   times increases in the computing power currently available on   GPUs. In an article from October 2015
column22: Barron's[subscription required] explained:Their chip has thousands of little logic engines sitting     next to pools of memory
column23: with a plethora of connections between     them. They claim the chip can perform in a fraction of the time     an image-recognition task that would take an Intel server chip     2
column24: 000 hours
column25: or an Nvidia GPU
column26: 33 hours. The key is that they     are designing for specific algorithms
column27: so the chip's design is     more efficient than a general-purpose chip like Intel's or     NVIDIA's.Nervana Engine ASIC chips are designed to accelerate AI     system training. Image source: Nervana Systems.Intel will be integrating the new technology into its existing   chips in early 2017
column28: so expect new offerings that will directly   challenge NVIDIA's GPUs in the AI space. Intel also claims that   by 2020
column29: it will be able to train AI systems 100 times faster   than with today's technology
column30: thoughsomehave deemed those goals very aggressive.It's not the only oneAnd Intel isn't the only one claiming improvements beyond what   GPUs currently accomplish.Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google has been conducting   research in the field ofAI for over five years. It announced it has a Tensor Processing Unit -- which is also   an ASIC -- capable of delivering performance that is 10 times   faster than any GPU running today
column31: and that it has been running   TPUs in its data centers for more than a year.  They were   also used in the AI system Alpha Go
column32: which recently made   headlines bydefeating many top rankedGoplayers. This provides a degree of confirmation of Nervana's claims   regarding the potential of such custom circuits.NVIDIA sees AI as a billion-dollar opportunity
column33: though   data center revenue amounted to only $240 million in its most   recent quarter.  Intel's revenue from data centers
column34: meanwhile
column35: amounted to $4.7 billion in its most recent   quarter. This illustrates that while gains in the market   would barely move the needle for Intel
column36: they could be a big mover   for NVIDIA. While GPUs currently hold a commanding lead in the   training of AI systems
column37: that could change quickly if the   technological advances claimed by Intel came to fruition.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Amazon (AMZN) Q4 Earnings Beat
column2: Revenues Miss Estimates;2/3/2017;"Amazon.com'sAMZNfourth-quarter 2016 earnings per share (EPS) of $1.54 cents surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.40.However
column3: revenues of $43.74 billion lagged the consensus mark of $44.87 billion. The stock was down 4.15% in Thursday's after-hours trading in response to the lower-than-expected revenues
column4: higher operating expenses and weak guidance.Over the last one year
column5: the stock has however outperformed the Zacks  Electronic Commerce industry. It has gained 56.63% compared with the industry's gain of 47.98%.Last quarter
column6: despite an increase in operating expenses
column7: the company showed much better financial discipline. The spike in operating expenses was due to buildout of fulfillment centers
column8: and increased spending on original TV shows and movies. Amazon Web Services (AWS) and India expansion-related expenses also resulted in higher spending.The North America and AWS segments contributed to profits while investments in international continued. Improvements in AWS were the result of operating efficiencies and increased utilization of assets.The numbers in detail-RevenuesAmazon reported revenues of $43.7 billion
column9: up 33.7% sequentially and 22.4% from the year-ago quarter. Quarterly revenues were at the mid-point of the guidance range of $42-$45.5 billion.For the full year
column10: revenues were $136 billion
column11: up 27% from $107 billion in 2015.Both product and service sales were up sequentially and year over year. Service sales grew much stronger than product sales from the year-ago quarter (up 43.7% compared with product sales growth of 15.1%). Revenue distribution between the two was 70%/30%.The company generated record sales during this year's holiday season
column12: primarily led by its devices strategy. Echo Dot
column13: Fire TV Stick
column14: Fire tablet and Amazon Echo topped the best-sellers list.Segment DetailsThe North America segment accounted for around 60% of sales
column15: representing a sequential and year-over-year increase of 39% and 22%
column16: respectively. The International segment accounted for 32%
column17: up 31.6% sequentially and 17.9% year over year. The AWS segment was up 9.4% sequentially and a massive 47% year over year with revenue share at nearly 8%.North America: Media was up 30% sequentially and 7.1% year over year. EGM was up 40.9% sequentially and 24.8% year over year. Other was up 42.6% sequentially and 80.4% year over year.International: Media was up 35.6% sequentially and 2.6% from last year. Sales from EGM were up 30.5% sequentially and 23.8% from last year. Other revenue was up 19.35% sequentially and 17.9% year over year.AWS: The business contributed $3.5 billion in the fourth quarter. AWS is gaining momentum with customers including McDonald's

column33: International Business Machines CorporationIBMand AlphabetGOOGL.Gross MarginGross margin was down 122 basis points (bps) sequentially but up 189 bps year over year to 33.8%. Sequential variations in gross margin were largely mix-related

column36: which was also a positive.Gross profit dollars were up 29.8% from last year. The consistently rising gross profit dollars from the year-ago period reflects the success of Amazon's strategy.Net income was up 197.2% sequentially and 55.4% year over year.Operating MetricsAmazon's operating expenses of $13.5 billion were up 24.3% sequentially and 31.4% from the year-ago quarter. Amazon's heavy investing activities (headcount

Cost of goods sold increased 121 bps sequentially as a percentage of sales with marketing expense increasing 45 bps and technology and content increasing just 5 bps. All other expenses declined as a percentage of sales.The net result was an operating margin of 2.9%

The International segment's operating margin of 4.07% shrank 315 bps sequentially but was up 100 bps from the year-ago quarter. Operating margin of AWS was 26.2%

column1: Zillow In Position To Dominate Online Real Estate Ad Market;2/3/2017;"Zillow Group(Z)
column2: operator of the online house-hunting network that dwarfs all   competitors
column3: has the inside track for winning a dominant share of   real estate agents' digital ad spending.""Their competitive position is quite strong
column4: said Macquarie   Capital analyst Tom White.While the homes-for-sale data that underpins sites like   Zillow and Realtor aren't proprietary
column5: White notes that   Zillow ""is out-innovating its competitors in augmenting that   basic listings data"" with other data
column6: including listings of homes   not for sale
column7: and by investing heavily in mobile.makeArticleAd();Citing comScore data
column8: Zillow says its five brands account   for nearly two-thirds of the total online real estate   category and nearly three-quarters of the mobile segment.Yet White notes that there's ""a big disconnect"" between   Zillow's majority share of traffic and its slice of the real   estate advertising pie.Turning clicks into commission for agents and more ad dollars   for Zillow turns out to be easier said than done.Fast CompanyA partial explanation is that a big slice of real estate   advertising dollars is going to companies that aren't direct   competitors
column9: likeFacebook(FB) andAlphabet's(GOOGL) Google.But the good news for Zillow is that it has been getting   better and better monetizing that traffic
column10: growing sales by   upwards of 30% over the past year even as real estate agents have   lowered their overall spending on digital advertising.The bulk of Zillow's revenue - 70% in the last quarter - comes   from its Premier Agent program
column11: where sales rose 32.5% from a   year ago. Real estate agents pay to have their picture
column12: credentials and ratings linked to Zillow's listings of homes for   sale
column13: with up to four agents attached to each listing.Home shoppers who don't have an agent are likely to click on   those with high ratings and a history of similar   transactions
column14: and that's exactly what Zillow wants to   see.Zillow has a strategy to help accelerate the real estate   industry's evolution to the survival of the fittest. Zillow is   looking to help the best real estate agents - the ones who   can best capitalize on the leads that Zillow generates and will   therefore pay the highest ad prices - to extend their   domination.[ibdchart symbol=""Z"" type=""daily"" size=""threequarter""   position=""rightchart"" ]""We are accelerating the broader trend   across the real estate agent population of higher-producing   agents gaining market share from those who are less productive
column15: Chief Executive Spencer Rascoff said on a November   conference call with analysts.Agent OverhaulRascoff also noted that Zillow overhauled the ways it sells   ads to its Premier Agents last quarter. Under its old model
column16: Zillow came up with a price for a fixed number of ad impressions   based on a ZIP code's characteristics.But Rascoff noted that the fixed-price model sometimes sold   out impressions in desirable ZIP codes
column17: requiring the company to   call up agents to increase ad prices. So now prices will be set   dynamically
column18: based on the total dollars agents budget to   advertise on Zillow in a given ZIP code.The goal is ""to have the marketplace"" determine ad costs
column19: Rascoff told analysts.Zillow
column20: which reports fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday
column21: advised analysts on its November call that its guidance   carried an extra margin of error because of the nationwide   rollout of the new pricing strategy.Analysts expect the company to earn 11 cents a share vs. a   one-cent loss a year ago
column22: as revenue rises 31% to $222 million.   In 2017 revenue is expected to grow 23% to $1.038 billion.Smaller Number
column23: But Bigger SpendingThe number of agents advertising on Zillow declined modestly   in the third quarter to 89
column25: but that was part of a planned   shakeout. At the same time
column26: the number of advertisers spending at   least $5
column27: 000 per month rose 79% from a year ago
column28: while average   spending per agent rose 46%.IBD'S TAKE:Zillow shares showed promise in early December
column29: after     forming acup-with-handleand starting to break out. But shares retreated into a flat     base and remain there. Check out IBD Stock Checkup to see     the top companies in theInternet-Content group.Tuesday's results also will provide a checkup on two other new   initiatives: a partnership with Facebook and Zillow's first   effort to monetize the sell-side of the housing market.Zillow is partnering with Facebook to offer a precision-ad   targeting program that enables real estate agents to connect on   Facebook with home shoppers who are using its site or   Trulia
column30: its sister property acquired in early 2015.Zillow also announced its Seller Boost program in October
column31: involving the placement of Premier Agent ads on listings of its   huge inventory of homes not for sale to provide potential   leads for agents if the homeowner decides to sell.Leveraging The NetworkAt the same time
column32: Zillow is trying to leverage its large   network of users - 164.5 million in the seasonally slower   third quarter - to get a broader slice of advertising   dollars.Zillow's marketplace for mortgages
column33: which connects homebuyers   to area mortgage lenders much likeLendingTree(TREE)
column34: generated $19.8 million in revenue in the third quarter
column35: up 57% from a year ago.The traffic at Zillow properties is roughly triple that of its   closest direct competitor
column36: Realtor.com
column37: which was acquired byNews Corp.(NWSA) in November 2014.Thanks to the merger with Trulia
column38: Zillow removed a major   competitor. Meanwhile fears that News Corp. might jump-start the   growth and promotion of Realtor.com have been mostly   unfounded
column39: Macquarie analyst White said.Bigger Slice Of PieBy some measures
column40: though
column41: Zillow has a growing slice of a pie   that has been shrinking in recent years. Borrell Associates   estimates that real estate agents spent $7.7 billion on digital   ads in 2016
column42: down from $9 billion in 2014. Some 78% of real   estate ad spending was done online in 2016
column43: Kip Cassino
column44: Borrell's executive vice president of research
column45: told IBD.The decline in spending partly reflects a relatively modest   pace of home sales
column46: especially among millennials
column47: Cassino says.   The other reason is that agents ""have become more discerning   about how they spend
column48: using Google keywords
column49: social media or   unpaid search engine optimization strategies.Still
column50: digital spending
column51: including spending on related   technologies
column52: has been growing as a percentage of agents'   marketing budgets
column53: Zillow says.Rascoff's focus is making sure Zillow is ""well-positioned for   the billions of dollars of real estate agent ad spend which will   surely migrate on to the internet over the next couple of   years
column54: and making sure that we've the right ad model to   capture the lion's share of that.""After several days of losses
column55: shares of Zillow reversed course   late last week. The stock ended trading Friday up 1.6% to 35.93   and climbed another 1.9% Monday to finish the day at 36.62
column56: right   on its 50-day moving averageRELATED:Analyst Sees 'Modest' Earnings Upside For     ZillowZillow Group Challenged By Rising Interest     Rates

column1: How Social Media Changed Super Bowl Commercials Forever;2/2/2017;"In these times of deep political division
column2: America's great unifier is visible on the horizon. Regardless of your partisan identity
column3: race
column4: ethnicity
column5: or religion
column6: if you live in the United States
column7: you are probably going to watch the 51stannual Super Bowl this Sunday. Heck
column8: even if you hate football
column9: it is a great excuse to have some friends over and gorge yourself with French onion dip and potato chips.But what is more American than apathetic binge eating? Well
column10: commercials of course! As if viewers were not satisfied with an hour-long
column11: ultra-violent faceoff between the world's top athletes
column12: the Super Bowl is traditionally paired with interesting and unique commercials to ensure that we do not take our eyes off the television for one second.It makes sense that a company would want to put their best advertisement out during the Super Bowl; the big game is always the most-watched television event of the year in the U.S.
column13: and based on last year's 112 million viewers
column14: we can expect more than a third of the entire country to be tuned in on Sunday.(Also Read:51 Essential Houston Facts to Get You Ready for   Super Bowl LI)With that said
column15: the advertising industry as a whole is not what it once was. Over the past decade or so
column16: advertisers have been forced to adapt to new consumer behaviors
column17: and that has meant the rise of viral marketing and digital ad campaigns.Super Bowl commercials have not been immune from these changes. Viewers simply do not want to miss any of the big commercials
column18: and with plenty of trips to the fridge and bathroom on the average Super Bowl watcher's schedule
column19: companies have started using the internet as a means of distributing their Super Bowl ads.While it is nothing new for Super Bowl spots to begin widespread circulation after the game itself
column20: the latest phenomena has been the pre-releasing of commercials before the actual event. Many companies are now debuting their Super Bowl ads more than a week out from the game and pairing their release with a massive social media marketing campaign.Indeed
column21: the rise of social media has coincided with an adapted Super Bowl commercial tradition. These days
column22: companies want people to buzzing about their commercials well before they are set to debut. In fact
column23: a recentNew York Timesarticlehighlights the fact that companies are spending even more money for online marketing on top of the cost of airing the commercial during the game.Mary Scott
column24: a president at sports and entertainment marketing agency UEG
column25: toldThe Timesthat she recommends clients spend at least 25% of the cost of the Super Bowl spot on their digital marketing rollout of the commercial.The cost of a 30-second advertisement during this year's Super Bowl rose to an astounding $5 million
column26: and that means companies will want to get the most value for their investment. ""There's become more of a game around the game in terms of ensuring that really pays off in a big way
column27: said Scott.""The game around the game"" that Scott is referring to includes massive social media exposure to the commercials in advance of the Super Bowl. For instance
column28: a company may upload the spot to YouTube before spreading it around FacebookFBand TwitterTWTR.Social media also gives consumers new ways to react to the advertisements. Discussion about the spots plays out online
column29: and it does not take much for these massive companies to become trending topics. Furthermore
column30: Alphabet Inc.GOOGLis celebrating 10 years of YouTube's AdBlitz competition
column31: a voting system that allows users to support their favorite spots.Some may argue that the pre-game debuts ruin some of the fun related to watching the Super Bowl
column32: but if I point you to our piece that highlights some of the commercials that are already out
column33: are you seriously not going to watch them? You are
column34: and you can check them out here:Preview The Super Bowl Commercials That Are   Already Out.Personally speaking
column35: I am happy about this trend. I plan on having some people over for the game this year
column36: and it is always difficult to get people to stay quiet during the commercials
column37: especially when the drinks start getting finished. I will be checking out as many as I can beforehand.Long-Term Buys You Won't See in the NewsThe stocks you see in today's headlines may not be in the news tomorrow or next week. If you're looking for profitable long-term investments
column38: you may be interested to see what Zacks Research is recommending to our private members. These moves have double and triple-digit profit potential. Starting now
column39: you can look inside our stocks under $10
column40: home run and value stock portfolios
column41: plus more. Want a peek at this exclusive information?Click here>>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today
column42: you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free reportmakeArticleAd();Facebook

column1: Google Earnings: The Market Has Made The Same Mistake Twice;2/2/2017;"Google Earnings (Shutterstock photo)As a general rule
column2: the market is pretty good about learning from its mistakes. After all
column3: there is nothing like a hefty loss to teach traders what not to do.That is a simple fact that must be borne in mind when looking for patterns in pricing; if the pattern involves a reaction to news that was ultimately proven wrong
column4: it is unlikely to repeat very often
column5: and the few opportunities when it does should be grabbed with both hands.makeArticleAd();That is what makes Google parent company Alphabet (GOOG:GOOGL) look like such a good buy after its reaction to Q4 earnings.As you can see from the chart below
column6: prior to last week’s earnings report Google (I’m sorry but I just can’t bring myself to call the company “Alphabet”) had dropped sharply on earnings misses contained in two of the previous three releases
column7: in April and October.On both of those occasions
column8: though
column9: the big drop in price was
column10: with the benefit of 20/20 hindsight
column11: an opportunity to buy the stock at a discount. There are different circumstances this time around
column12: of course
column13: but the dynamic that has made negative reactions to earnings in the past opportunities is still in place
column14: so the end result is likely to be the same.The biggest problems with the Q4 results as far as traders were concerned
column15: it seems
column16: were that cost per click was down
column17: and operating costs had risen to the point where earnings per Class A share (EPS) of $9.36 fell short of the Street’s estimates of around $9.64. Still
column18: revenues of $26.06 billion beat the estimated $25.26 billion.There was also a concern lurking in the background regarding Google taking on both Amazon (AMZN)’s Echo and Apple (AAPL)’s iPhone with recent hardware launches. Google said that they were pleased with the reaction to both Google Home and the Pixel phone without going into specifics
column19: but doubts about the wisdom of the strategy persist.I actually believe that Google has a chance of limited success in each case. The Pixel will be the most uphill struggle as the iPhone’s dominance of the mobile phone market is well established. Most estimates of sales of the phone so far are around 1 million
column20: which hardly puts a dent in the iPhone
column21: but may prove to be enough of a base to make the Pixel profitable as a niche product.Home has an easier
column22: more logical path to success as Google is the natural choice of those looking for what is
column23: essentially
column24: a free-standing search engine.Ultimately
column25: though
column26: neither Home nor Pixel is going to be the driver of the recovery in the stock price that history suggests will come soon.First
column27: the increase in operating costs that Google reported seems
column28: on a breakdown of the numbers
column29: to be the result of investment in the core business. Losses in what the company calls “Other Bets
column30: ” things like “Nest” and self driving cars
column31: were actually reduced somewhat in the fourth quarter
column32: but there was significant progress on the autonomous vehicle front.The possibilities of that field are endless and Google
column33: along with Tesla (TSLA) and Apple
column34: are generally seen as the leaders in driverless car research and technology.The other issue
column35: of falling cost per click (CPC)
column36: is also not what it seems on the surface. It reflects a continuing move to mobile that results in that metric falling
column37: but the volume of clicks increasing. The same issue was
column38: in part
column39: responsible for the April and October drops in GOOG after earnings
column40: and the chart tells the story of how long it was until investors realized that volume more than offset falling CPC.Looking at Google’s results and the market reaction to them
column41: I get a sense of déjà vu. We have actually been here before
column42: twice
column43: and each time the drop in GOOG gave investors a chance to buy cheaply. It seems that in this case the market is still learning from its mistake and over time the outcome here is most likely to be the same."

column1: Domino's (DPZ) Expands Ordering Facilities on Messenger;2/2/2017;"One of the world leaders in pizza delivery and digital ordering platforms
column2: Domino's Pizza
column3: Inc.DPZ
column4: is further expanding its digital ordering capabilities on Facebook Inc.'sFBMessenger.makeArticleAd();Until now
column5: customers with a Pizza Profile were restricted to placing their most recent order or Easy Order via Facebook Messenger. Domino's went one step ahead by becoming the first national pizza chain to have full ordering capabilities on Messenger. Customers can now place any order for any menu item on the Messenger. Now
column6: they won't need any Pizza Profile and can place orders through the company's enhanced ordering assistant bot - Dom.The enhancement comes just in time for one of the company's busiest day of the year - Football's final Sunday. Domino's expects sales to be five times more than on a typical Sunday. Thus
column7: making ordering more convenient for customers could further add to the sales.The digital wave has hit the U.S. fast casual restaurant sector. Hence
column8: an increasing number of restaurants are implementing technology to enhance guest experience. Similarly
column9: Domino's is also investing heavily in technology-driven initiatives like digital ordering to boost sales. The company keeps on adding various ordering apps and platforms to its digital capabilities.In fact
column10: Domino's lineup of AnyWare ordering capabilities currently has a total of 10 platforms that include Alphabet
column11: Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle Home
column12: Amazon.com
column13: Inc.'sAMZNEcho
column14: and ordering via a Pizza emoji on text.Notably
column15: digital leadership is helping the company expand its brand in the domestic market as well as overseas. This is one of the reasons Domino's shares have widely outperformed the broader Zacks categorizedRetail-Restaurantsindustry over the past year. While the stock gained 50.3%
column16: the broader industry declined 3.6% in the same time period.Although the company's initiatives such as implementation of technology and re-imaging of restaurants offer long-term advantages
column17: the costs related to them are expected to continue dampening margins in the near term. Further
column18: the company's wide international presence makes it highly vulnerable to foreign exchange headwinds
column19: while a soft industry backdrop is putting pressure on the top line.Nevertheless
column20: going forward
column21: the extended ways to order a pizza are poised to keep Domino's in the forefront of digital ordering and customer convenience. Also
column22: this should help in improving the Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) company's sales trends and enhance its competitive positioning.You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank   (Strong Buy) stocks here.Zacks' Best Private Investment IdeasIn addition to the recommendations that are available to the public on our website

column1: Facebook (FB) Tops on Q4 Earnings Driven by Mobile & Video;2/2/2017;"Facebook
column2: Inc.'sFBearnings streak continues with yet another better-than-expected quarterly performance. Facebook's fourth-quarter 2016 adjusted earnings of $1.24 per share and revenues of $8.8 billion easily topped the respective Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.11 and $8.5 billion. This is Facebook's sixth successive quarter of earnings and revenue beat.Mobile and live video efforts are paying off big time for the social media giant. Instagram is also emerging as a major cash cow with over 500
column3: 000 advertisers. CEO Mark Zuckerberg continued to emphasize on bringing more and more video content on to the platform. It has been investing on original content and said that it will keep doing the same this year as well.As expected
column4: Facebook continues to maintain a cautious stance on revenue and ad growth. Facebook again stated that ad revenues will continue to grow but will face tougher year-over-year comparisons in the current year. Moreover
column5: as Facebook continues to ramp up investments
column6: costs will increase. The company plans to go on a hiring spree this year and especially recruit engineers
column7: which will further add to its costs. Well it's a no brainer that Facebook(or even any other company for that matter) will keep up with those dizzying initial growth rates as it gets bigger.Quarterly Numbers in DetailsFacebook reported non-GAAP earnings of $1.21 in the quarter
column8: up 124% year over year. Revenues
column9: excluding the impact of year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates basis
column10: increased 51% year over year.Facebook's consistently expanding user growth remains one of its biggest growth catalysts.  Facebook's monthly active users (MAUs) were up 17% year over year to a staggering 1.86 billion. In addition
column11: at the end of the quarter
column12: mobile MAUs were 1.74 billion
column13: representing 21% year-over-year growth. Daily Active Users (DAUs) were 1.23 billion
column14: reflecting 18% growth year over year while mobile DAUs were 1.15 billion
column15: up 23% year over year.Breaking down revenue components
column16: advertising revenues were $8.629 billion
column17: surging 53% year over year. Excluding the impact of changes in foreign exchange rates
column18: revenues from advertising also increased 54% year over year. Advertising revenues were driven by increasing mobile engagement
column19: higher number of marketers
column20: and continuing investment in new products.Mobile ad revenues in the quarter were $7.2 billion (up 61% year over year)
column21: contributing 84% to total ad revenues. Ad impressions grew 49%
column22: driven by surging mobile ad impressions. Average price per ad increased 3% from the year-ago quarter. Average revenue per user was $4.83Payments and other fees decreased 12% year over year to $180 million in the reported quarter owing to a reduction in payment revenues related to PC games. Management expects revenues from this segment to face further decline as PCs lose market share.On the cost front
column23: cost & expenses increased 29.3% to $4.2 billion
column24: driven by increases in workforce and marketing expenses. However
column25: robust revenue growth provided enough cushion to operating margins.Non-GAAP operating income of $5.6 billion grew 58.9% year over year.Facebook
column26: Inc. Price
column27: Consensus and EPS     SurpriseFacebook
column28: Inc. Price
column29: Consensus and EPS   Surprise|Facebook
column30: Inc. QuoteBalance Sheet & Cash FlowFacebook exited the quarter with cash & cash equivalents and marketable securities of $29.4 billion
column31: up 59.7% year over year.The company generated nearly $16.1 billion of cash flow from operating activities in 2016 compared with $10.3 billion in 2015. Free cash flow was $11.6 billion compared with $7.8 billion last year. The company incurred capital expenditure of $4.5 billion in the year.OutlookNon-GAAP expenses are projected to increase in a band of 47% to 57% while capex is expected to be $7 billion to $7.5 billion. The company expects 2017 to be a year of aggressive investments. The company plans to build more data centers as well as recruitmore engineers to fuel its AI & AR/VR technology ambitions.Stock-based compensation is estimated in a range of $3.9 billion-$4.1 billion. The company expects amortization expenses in 2016 to be within $700 million-$800 million.Final WordWe remain positive on Facebook as it works on becoming a tech powerhouse. Its chief Mark Zuckerberg aspires to make Facebook much more than just a social media platform.  Last year

ZeniMax has slapped a $2 billion lawsuit against Oculus accusing it of stealing its intellectual property to boost its own VR research.The company is also aggressively working on monetizing its subsidiaries
column41: Messenger
